Title: It’s a blessing in disguise: Vishal on turning director
Content: So, how has it been handling dual roles on the set — that of an actor and a producer? “I am used to it. In fact, I’m taking on a triple role in the next film,” he said, referring to him taking over as the director of Thupparivalan 2 . A clash with Mysskin over the budget led to the latter leaving the project.“I think it’s a blessing in disguise. I didn’t expect this to happen, but I am excited. A director is the captain of the ship. You have responsibilities… it’s nice to dwell in departments like editing, composing, rerecording… you need to don so many avatars. So, I’m looking forward to that aspect. I was planning to direct next year… a film on animals that I had already planned. But I believe in fate and so, I’m going along with it,” he said.

Title: BBMP moots license fee waiver to promote adoption of indie dogs
Content: In what is seen as a major boost for the cause of indie dogs, the Bruhat Bengaluru Mahanagare Palike (BBMP) is set to introduce a new clause in the Pet Dog Licensing Bylaws 2020 (Draft), which exempts adoption of indie dogs, and that of rescued, injured or abandoned dogs of other breeds, from licensing fee. “This time, the focus is on incentivising adoption of indies and rescue dogs by waiving off license fee. The idea is to change the perspective around these dogs, which are normally considered a menace. Indie breeds are far more suited for Indian conditions than foreign breeds,” says Randeep D, Special Commissioner for Solid Waste Management and Animal Husbandry, BBMP.According to BBMP’s 2019 survey, the total estimate for stray dogs in Bengaluru was 3.1 lakh, representing 3.67 dogs per 100 people. Considering these numbers, this rule inclusion might herald in a better future for strays. Randeep adds, “We are trying to bring in social awareness among pet owners to look at this option, so that strays find a home and are not out on the street. There will be no restriction on the number of indie or rescued dogs a person can adopt.” The Pet Dog Licensing Bylaws 2020 (Draft), is pushing for the one dog for one flat and three dogs for an independent house rule, which has been contested by pet owners earlier.Sanjana Madappa from the rescue and rehabilitation wing of Compassion Unlimited Plus Action (CUPA) says, “BBMP is not limiting the number of Indies and rescued dogs someone can adopt. But they have to be adopted, which, in a way, will discourage buying from backdoor breeders. And, it is time that people stop giving second-class treatment to strays and rescued dogs.”

Title: Music Review: Kannum Kannum Kollaiyadithaal
Content: The songs of Kannum Kannum Kollaiyadithaal, the romantic thriller by Desingh Periyasamy, do sound peppy and upbeat in the beginning, but by the time you’re done with the album, composed by Masala Coffee, the overload of percussion, same type of beats, tunes and lyrical treatment begin to seem overbearing.The songs were obviously written and set to music to show carefree youth life, but do they have to be so noisy? Let’s start with Sirikkalam Parakkalam sung by Benny Dayal and Madurai Souljour, who’s also written part of the lyrics along with Desingh. This song is the sole high point of the album, mainly because as the first one, it sounds peppy and upbeat and quite dance-y. Ennai Vittu, sung by Ranjith, and written by Vignesh Shivan is a first romance song, interspersed with cutesy dialogues. Among the plethora of ‘pogathey’ songs we’ve had lately in Tamil films, this one is a better version. The next song is Yelo Pullelo, sung by Anirudh Ravichander, written by Mani Amudhavan. More percussion, noisy background babble that cuts off the main song at many places. Kanave Nee Naan is the love-lost song. Sad and maudlin, sung by Sooraj Santhosh and written by Hafeez Rumi and Desingh, who’s also written Ennil Nee, sung by Janani SV. It’s the lone female song, which she sings mostly in soprano.Then come the two versions of Assai Illa – the Kannum Kannum Kollaiadithaal theme songs, so to say. One is by sung by Hashavardhan Rameshwar, the other remixed by Gouthami Ashok EFI. Short numbers both, must be background scores – but both sound good. The last song of the album is Maagaa Maagaa sung by Hashavardhan Rameshwar, Kavya Ajit and Janani SV, and written by V Lakshmi Priya. I feel like flying in the sky... go the lyrics of this one, by which time, you also feel you could fly far away from some of the songs in this album!

Title: This city really does feel like home to us: SVDP
Content: Canadian Tamil rapper Shan Vincent De Paul (SVDP) is at the last leg of his maiden five-city Indian tour and he has saved the best for his last. Along with frequent collaborator and mridangam player Yanchan, SVDP will be finishing his India tour with a concert in Chennai today.“We purposely booked Chennai as the last stop because it has been the most supportive. Chennai really does feel like home to us. The city has been treating us so well, so naturally I have high expectations for the show,” the Jaffna-born musician said. The duo, who started the tour with their debut at a music festival, are known for seamlessly blending Carnatic tunes into rap. They rose to fame for Mridangam Series, their hit episodic album, where they fuse rap hip-hop with mridangam.“I know our biggest fanbase is in Chennai with a lot of Carnatic fans. I'm excited to tear the stage up,” Yanchan said, adding that fusion music has endless possibilities today. “I think a lot more people have become open to the idea that it is okay to crossbreed Carnatic music with other genres of music. From watching legends like L Subramaniam and Karaikudi Mani do fusion concerts as a kid, they helped give me the confidence to explore Carnatic music with hip-hop,” he noted. The first episode of the Mridangam Series was more of an experiment, SVDP recalled, adding, “At this point, we fully have a grasp of what we’re trying to do. We want to make sure we challenge ourselves and make sure each episode evolves musically and visually.”Among the pieces that SVDP will be performing will include material from IYAAA, his collaborative album with Yanchan. “The goal was to make a fusion album that the south audience will really connect to. It is a lot more different than our solo projects, we’re really pushing each other to leave our comfort zone,” the musician added.

Title: Shoot at Site: Vishal is in search of the Chakra
Content: It was a regular Friday for shoppers, who flocked to a city mall. Even as they milled about at the mall, browsing through shops and indulging in retail therapy, they remained largely unaware of a different kind of excitement that had gripped a bunch of people who were busy in their own world at the basement car park. There were hefty-looking men, wielding weapons, waiting for their prey.And that’s when Vishal and Shraddha Srinath entered the car park, probably after a fruitful day of shopping. Just as the duo got set to leave, they were attacked. And what followed was heavy-duty action, with bone-breaking moves. Yep, we were at the shooting spot of Chakra, directed by debutant MS Anandan.“We are shooting the opening sequence of Vishal sir,” began the filmmaker, “It will be stylish and engaging. Chakra will be an edge-of-the-seat thriller, and every character that appears in a frame will have some purpose. Script is the base for a film, but it’s characters that bring the story together. We have a crisp flashback, and I’m sure the action sequences in the film will be appreciated.”Talking about how he pitched the story to Vishal, Anandan said, “I was so nervous the night before meeting him. It was a big opportunity for me, and I didn’t want to waste it. But the way Vishal treated me boosted my confidence. He quietly listened to the whole story, and didn’t even take a coffee break in between. He said, ‘The story is good and the characterisations are strong. Don’t change anything for me.’ He believes in script and doesn’t believe in promoting the hero and downgrading the villain. I think both of them have to be equally strong if the face-off sequences have to come out well.”We were joined by Vishal then, who had just finished giving a shot. “The reason why the film is called Chakra is because it revolves around Ashoka Chakra, India’s highest peacetime military decoration. The hero is in search of the medal that belonged to his dad,” he revealed and added, “Many think the film is a sequel to Irumbu Thirai, but it’s not. However, thematically, while that film spoke about hacking phones, this one will raise an important question — what if your entire life is hacked? This is the first time that I’m working with both Shraddha Srinath and Regina Cassandra, and I love how both of them have super powerful characters.”“We will wrap up shoot by March 13. Yuvan Shankar Raja has given us lovely songs; one of those will be shot from March 11,” Vishal informed us before going for his next shot.This is the first time ever that I’m wearing khakhi for a film. In fact, I’m doing things I haven’t done before for this movie. My character is hot-headed, impulsive, and Vishal is the cool cat among the two of us. When I shot my opening sequence, I was so nervous. I thought it would look unnatural for me to do stunts. I was wondering if I was even physically fit to do it. But Anbariv masters were so good. I’ve seen the edited scene, and I’m so excited to see the film for my own action sequence!— Shraddha Srinath, actressThis is a stylish action sequence that we are shooting. Shraddha also has a powerful action-based opening scene. Every character in the film will be very strong. We have planned a crisp flashback portion as well.— Anandan, directorAll the characters have been sketched well by our director. So, I’ve ample scope to make the action sequences stylish. This one, in particular, will be a mass-meets-class one. We’ve used Krav Maga techniques, where you use the opponent’s power to defeat him. The moves are slick and almost unexpected. I’m also excited about the climax action sequence.— Anl Arasu, stunt choreographerThe whole film is based on contrast. This fight is being shot in a basement car park, but we haven’t used extra lights. Anl Arasu master wanted to use high speed shots, which require a lot of light. But we have kept it raw. We recently shot at a dirty, unclean place in Chennai, and that also was quite challenging.— Balasubramaniem, cinematographer

Title: Govind Padmasoorya: The success of Ala Vaikunthapurramuloo has opened doors for me
Content: Since Pretham 2 in 2018, Govind Padmasoorya has been missing from Mollywood, but the Malayali audience’s support has been endless, he says. In 2019, he made his debut in Tamil with Kee and earlier this year, he was part of Allu Arjun’s blockbuster, Ala Vaikunthapurramuloo. The actor talks to us about how these movies have helped him get better offers, working with Allu Arjun and more.There are two reasons for that. The movies that I have been doing outside of Malayalam are star-studded films – be the Jiiva-starrer Kee or Allu Arjun’s Ala Vaikunthapurramuloo. The only reason I could be part of such big films is because I played the antagonists. I did get other roles in Telugu and Tamil but they didn’t excite me. Those projects in which I was offered the lead role were either helmed by debutants or had a new production company backing the film. When I start in an industry, I wanted it to be with a good project. I think it was the right decision as I was offered Ala Vaikunthapurramuloo after its director Trivikram Srinivas saw my performance in the Tamil film Kee.I have always only done projects when they excite me. Irrespective of movies being big or small, I look at whether there’s a takeaway for me and whether the audience would love it. If a project satisfies these two conditions, then I am in. For Ala Vaikunthapurramuloo, my takeaway was that I got to be part of a huge film with Allu Arjun and for the audience, it was a great entertainer that I could recommend without thinking twice.However, the funny thing is that I didn’t immediately say yes when they approached me. For Kee, the character was a huge challenge and that is what attracted me to take it up. But when the team of Ala.. narrated the story, I was hesitant at first because I was not sure how much the scope of performance was. Even though I was the main villain, I didn’t have a lot of acting to do and I wanted a bit more. However, at the end of the day it was a Trivikram Srinivas-Allu Arjun film, and finally I decided to be part of the film. I didn’t know it would be such a huge hit.Earlier the number of offers I got from other industries were very limited and I could select only the best from what was being offered. Right now, the success of these two films have opened a lot of doors. But I still haven’t committed any film because I want to do a movie that meets all the criteria I had mentioned.He’s a sweetheart and charmer, both onscreen and offscreen. He is very considerate, not just to me but to everyone he meets, be it to a light boy or a fan or a director. After he had introduced me by name in that event, a major chunk of Allu fans now message me on social media asking what my next project is. It’s one of the sweetest things he did.During the shoot, he had complimented me, saying I had sharp expressions and that I was using my eyes well. It didn’t stop there. He also spoke highly about my performance in his interviews and highlighted these points, and I found that very genuine. Many directors took a snapshot of that interview and sent me, and it felt good.I think after Pretham, this was the role that was appreciated the most. Many people called to say that it was a powerful role and I had performed well. I wish it would have done better in Kerala theatres, but I also think a lot of people had watched it in theatres. I remember when I went to a theatre in Edappally, Kochi, to watch 1917 and the theatre owners took me to their office to say it was running to packed houses for two weeks. When you are part of a hit film, the world lets you know.

Title: Qatar Open: Petra Kvitova beats Ashleigh Barty to set up Qatar Open final with Aryna Sabalenka
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

File image of Petra Kvitova (Reuters Photo)

DOHA: Petra Kvitova battled past world number one Ashleigh Barty 6-4, 2-6, 6-4 on Friday to set up a Qatar Open final against Belarusian Aryna Sabalenka .

The two-time Wimbledon winner overcame a second-set blip to reach the 37th WTA final of her career and her second in Doha , where she won the 2018 title.

Kvitova ended a run of four straight defeats to Barty, including in the Australian Open quarter-finals earlier this year.

Australia's Barty has now lost in back-to-back semi-finals after her last-four loss to eventual champion Sofia Kenin in Melbourne.

It will be Kvitova's first final since April last year in Stuttgart.

The 29-year-old Czech, ranked 11th in the world, is chasing a 28th tour title.

Earlier on Friday, Sabalenka dispatched Russian veteran Svetlana Kuznetsova 6-4, 6-3.

Ninth seed Sabalenka, 21, broke twice former Grand Slam champion Kuznetsova four times as she reached a 10th career WTA final -- her first of the 2020 season.

Title: Battered oil augurs well for consumer inflation, interest rate cut
Content:
(Representative image)

NEW DELHI: Oil prices tested a three-year low on Friday due to heightened fear of deeper impact of the corona virus outbreak crushing global economic growth and energy demand.Global benchmark Brent slipped below the $50 per barrel-mark briefly, marking a decline of over 4% and a level last seen in July 2017, before recouping to close 2.4% down from the previous close.Global oil prices have been declining since the outbreak due to falling demand, largely from China as it went into a lockdown mode to contain the outbreak. Since India meets 83% of its oil needs through imports, lower prices augur well for the government and consumers.A low oil price regime reduces fuel costs for the aam admi and industry, which helps the latter in times of economic slowdown. It also improves macro-economic parameters – lower inflation and subsidy bill, keeps the rupee healthy as there is lesser need to buy dollars to pay for crude. This in turn improves the balance of payments position.There are other benefits. Lower inflation creates ground for interest rate cut, which eases burden on households by reducing home or consumer loan installments. Reduced subsidy burden and improved current account deficit means more legroom for the government to spend on social schemes or announce incentives to revive growth.India’s crude purchase has so far averaged $64 per barrel in 2019-20 and is likely to close the fiscal around this level. This is comforting since the government math is based on a $65-per-barrel oil price. The road ahead also looks comfortable as the International Energy Agency has projected the coronavirus outbreak leading to the first quarterly contraction in global oil demand in more than 10 years.The IEA slashed its 2020 oil demand growth forecast by 365,000 bpd (barrels per day) to just 825,000 bpd, the lowest oil demand growth since 2011.A prolonged period of subdued prices, thus, will keep pump prices low and allow the government to raise levy on fuel to make up for shortfall in tax revenue. It will also make it easier for refiners to recoup investments made for producing BS-VI fuel . The government had raised excise duty nine times between November 2014 and January 2016 to shore up finances as global oil prices fell.The flip side, however, is that if global economic activity continues in the slow lane, it will hurt India’s exports. Continuous fall in oil prices will also lead to inventory losses for refiners, lowering their profitability. This will result in lower payouts to the government. Low prices will render investments made in new fields unremunerative for explorers, forcing them to pull back on fresh investments. This in turn will lead to inadequate capacity - and volatility - when demand picks up in the second half of the fiscal.

Title: Novak Djokovic: Novak Djokovic hails 'amazing escape' after beating Gael Monfils for 17th time
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Novak Djokovic hugs Gael Monfils after the match (AFP Photo)

DUBAI: Novak Djokovic saved three match points before defeating Gael Monfils 2-6, 7-6 (10/8), 6-1 to reach the Dubai Championships final on Friday, describing his victory as "an amazing escape".

It was the 17th win of the season for the world number one and a 17th career win over Frenchman Monfils without a loss.

Djokovic will play on Saturday for a fifth Dubai trophy against Stefanos Tsitsipas after the second seed and 2019 finalist beat Dan Evans 6-2, 6-3.

The Serbian fought off three Monfils match points in the second-set tiebreaker, as the Frenchman committed forehand and backhand errors on his first two winning chances.

An increasingly weary Monfils blew the third with a double-fault.

Djokovic finally squared the semi-final at one set a-piece on his eighth set point before rolling on to victory in the third set after more than two and a half hours.

"It was an amazing escape," said Djokovic who now has a 20-match win streak stretching from the end of last year.

"Gael was playing as well as he ever has. It was difficult to go through him. I have good defence, but what he did today was unbelievable.

"On the match points, I just hoped that he would miss on first serves, which he did. That gave me an opportunity to get into the points.

"I know Gael was injured and he could not play his best, but once he's healthy, watch out."

Tsitsipas, who lost the final a year ago to Roger Federer, won his eighth match in a row by seeing off Evans.

The Greek lifted the trophy last Sunday in Marseille.

Tsitsipas could not fault his victory in 83 minutes over the 37th-ranked Evans in a first-time meeting.

"I managed to stay solid throughout the whole match, I didn't have too much stress, I stayed quite calm and played well," he said.

"I was dominating a lot from my forehand side, playing with a clear head and not thinking of too much, staying in the moment, trying to process of what potentially he's going to use on the court.

"It was just a matter of time for me to take the lead and get up in the score."

Tsitsipas, winner of 16 of his last 17 sets, won his 10th career match at the Aviation Club against two defeats.

British number one Evans was competing in his fourth semi-final at the ATP level.

He saved three match points against Pierre-Hugues Herbert in the second round and two set points in the quarter-finals against Andrey Rublev.

Tsitsipas never faced a break point on Friday while breaking Evans' serve four times.

Title: Shah Rukh Khan should make 'Dilwale Dulhaniya Le Jaayenge 2': Wife Gauri Khan on Donald Trump mentioning film in his speech
Content: Superstar Shah Rukh Khan should make a sequel of his 1995 blockbuster 'Dilwale Dulhaniya Le Jaayenge', his wife Gauri Khan feels.Gauri's contention came in the wake of US President Donald Trump mentioning DDLJ in his speech while addressing the packed crowd at Motera Stadium in Ahmedabad on his recent India visit. He spoke of DDLJ as one of the 'classic films' that the Indian film industry has given to the world, leaving SRK fans in a frenzy.Asked how it feels when one of the most influential leaders in the world acknowledges her husband's film, Gauri said with a grin: "May be he (Shah Rukh Khan) should make part two of DDLJ. That's the next plan and I think he will do that. I am going to tell DDLJ director-producer to make part two, so every president and prime minister who enters India should discuss that."Meanwhile, Gauri and SRK recently attended an event together in the city. And like always, the looked fabulous as the arrived at the venue.On the work front, Shah Rukh was last seen in Aanand L Rai 's 'Zero'. He is yet to announce his next project!

Title: Kagiso Rabada: Injured Kagiso Rabada out of Australia and India series
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Kagiso Rabada (AFP Photo)

JOHANNESBURG: South Africa 's premier pacer Kagiso Rabada has been ruled out of the three-match ODI series against India after sustaining a groin strain which has abruptly ended his ongoing Australia tour.

The 24-year-old will be out of action for four weeks after suffering the injury during the final T20 international against Australia on Wednesday.

South Africa after losing the T20 series 1-2, are now locked in a three-match ODI series with Australia.

"Kagiso sustained a groin muscle strain in the T20 series against Australia, he was assessed by the medical staff, assisted by an MRI scan," Cricket South Africa (CSA), Chief Medical Officer, Shuaib Manjra said in a media statement.

"The significant injury means that he will take approximately four weeks to heal, which effectively rules him out of both the Australia and India ODI series," he added.

The Proteas are scheduled to travel to India for a three-match ODI series, starting on March 12 in Dharamsala.

CSA also announced right-hand batsman Temba Bavuma has recovered from his hamstring injury and will be available for the ODI leg of the Australia tour.

Title: New Zealand strongly encourages India to become participant of RCEP in future: Foreign minister
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

India can come back to RCEP in the future, said New Zealand foreign minister and deputy prime minister, Winston Peters, but at present the Indian government’s position does not hold out much confidence that RCEP would go ahead with India.

In India to pick up the threads of a bilateral relationship, Peters who has been accompanied by a large and diverse business delegation, is keen to get India to open up its agriculture market for New Zealand. India and New Zealand last held talks on a trade agreement back in 2010. Peters said he was here to restart that dialogue. “We have been aspiring for that bilateral deal for 10 years. But we respect India’s decision.”

Describing New Zealand as the country with the greatest ease of doing business, Peters said, “there is need for wider understanding of the Indian agricultural market. Due to rising demand in India and need for added value, our discussion was about having a chance to prove to the domestic agriculture market in India that we are no threat to them. The size of their milk industry is so much larger. If you look at the future demand that’s building here, it’s very difficult to envisage how we could possibly be a threat. We just want a chance to demonstrate that. We don’t want to compete with any Indian farmer. Rather, to work in concert with them and to grow the capacity of supply keeping in sight the future demands. “

This was, Peters said, his third meeting with foreign minister S. Jaishankar . The focus of the discussions, he said, were “Democracy, rule of law, multilateralism, discussions for the need to continue down that path in the interests of our two economies and the world. That includes the wto, and institutions that promote free and fair trade, in what is currently a difficult environment.”

Could New Zealand be the next entrant into the Indo-Pacific universe? “It’s an emerging concept and putting flesh and shape around this concept is what we’re keen to have a discussion on. If you look at it, we’re at one end of the Indo-Pacific, down in the South Pacific . India’s at the other end. But there are a lot of areas where the promotion of values and institutions, peace and security is fundamental to the health and stability of the region. We don’t have to go too far to point out the areas of trans-national competition that we have as two countries.” New Zealand, like India, he said, regards Asean as central to the Indo-Pacific strategy.

With close relations with China, how does New Zealand regard the Asian hegemon? “We have our eyes wide open about what we’re dealing with. We cooperate with China as much as we can. There are Lots of reasons for us to press on. Where we disagree we have to be frank and disagree, bearing in mind that with respect, the differences can become a pathway to compromise and understanding.” Despite such close ties, though, New Zealand has blocked its 5G market to China and Huawei . “Bear in mind that our law passed by the previous government dates back to 2013. In short, no PM or cabinet minister can change it – it’s a decision made by the oversight body, in this case the GCSP, when applications come in. Which is to say they have to commit to the laws of the government. But they have to satisfy the criteria set out in the legislation seven years ago before they can proceed further.”

How has New Zealand dealt with terrorism in the post Christchurch attack era? “The reality is that the appalling attack on humanity in our country happened by the intersection of an outsider. We have a commission of inquiry into the event. In the meantime, we have communicated and discussed with other countries on the importance of sharing information. Because the particularity of this sort of terrorism is that its under the radar, often undetected, festering away in undiscovered environments. That needs more surveillance to look for those trigger points that IT and other modern tools can investigate, provided we can put resources into that. We need to work with other countries, and help other countries. But I think our political systems are way behind technological advances.”

Title: FIFA chief accepts matches are at risk due to coronavirus
Content:
FIFA president Gianni Infantino (AFP Photo)

EURO TRAVEL

BELFAST: FIFA president Gianni Infantino has said March's international soccer matches could be threatened by the coronavirus but was hopeful that this year's European Championship tournament and the Olympic Games will go ahead unaffected.On Friday, six countries reported their first cases of the virus and the World Health Organization (WHO) raised its global spread and impact risk alert to "very high".The spread of the virus has already hit sporting events and on Thursday Italian club Inter Milan were forced to play their Europa League home match against Bulgarian side Ludogorets at San Siro behind closed doors.A number of international fixtures, including the Euro 2020 playoffs as well as friendlies, are scheduled for the final week of March. Asked whether he would consider halting those games, Infantino said nothing was out of the question."I wouldn’t exclude anything at this moment. I hope we will never have to get into this direction. I think it will be difficult in any case to make a global ban because the situation (in each counry) is really different," he told reporters."The health of people is much more important than any football game. The health is beyond anything and that’s why we have to look at the situation and hope that it (the coronavirus outbreak) will decrease rather than increase."At the moment it looks like it is still increasing. If games have to be postponed or played without spectators until it is over then we have to go through that," added the head of soccer's world governing body.Euro 2020 is scheduled to begin on June 12 and will see an unprecedented amount of international travel with the tournament being held in 12 cities in 12 different European countries."I think the Euros will take place in June. Before that we have many matches at international level with lots of travelling involved as well so I think we have to monitor the situation and those in charge, the government, the institutions they also take decisions on what is allowed and what isn’t," said Infantino."We don’t have to panic. I am not personally worried as well. But we have to look at it seriously. We can't underestimate and say it’s nothing but we don’t have to overreact and panic. We have to follow the instructions given by the authorities," he added.The other big soccer tournament on the horizon is at the Olympic Games which is due to be held in Tokyo in July. Infantino said he had not recently discussed the matter with the International Olympic Committee."We all hope the Olympic Games will take place as planned and that we can travel safely to Japan in the summer," he said.The FIFA chief added that he did not believe closed-door matches without fans were a solution to the problem."I don’t think it is sustainable but that is my personal view. Every competition organiser has to decide what is best for him. In the short term it can be a solution in order to move on but you cannot imagine a few months of a competition with several matches played behind closed doors."

Title: FIFA president says open to changes in offside law
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

FIFA president Gianni Infantino (AFP Photo)

BELFAST: FIFA president Gianni Infantino says he is open to changes to the offside law to help address problems that have arisen since the introduction of VAR video reviews.

Football's law-making body the International FA Board (IFAB) will meet on Saturday and discuss VAR and the offside law, although no proposal has been tabled for a concrete law change.

Frustration in England's Premier League with VAR ruling out goals for tiny margins of offside, in some cases involving heels and armpits, has led to calls for a different approach.

Some commentators have suggested there should be clear 'daylight' between the attacking player and the defending one for offside to be called while FIFA’s head of global development Arsene Wenger has floated another alternative.

The former Arsenal manager suggested earlier this month that a player should be deemed onside if any part of their body which can legitimately score a goal is level or behind the last defender.

"The offside discussion is an item we need to look at and personally I’m certainly in favour of discussing a new way of looking at the offside rule, to see if it can help, because I think the issue is more an issue of understanding," Infantino told reporters on Friday.

"Some of (the decisions) are very, very close and it’s difficult for the people who are watching to see whether it’s offside, so we have to look at whether we can make the offside rule clearer by having light in between," he added.

"But it’s for discussion of course – there will be no decision on this one because there is no proposal on the table. But it is to be discussed and to see whether it has to be tested or not," added the head of soccer's world governing body.

However Infantino rejected the idea of introducing some element of leeway over offsides.

"It doesn’t solve the issue. Even if you put a margin of 10 centimetres and then if it’s 11, it’s still one more, if it’s 10-1/2... it doesn’t solve it," he said.

Infantino suggested the Premier League problem may be due to excessive examination of video reviews.

“In Italy, in Spain, in Portugal, in Germany this offside discussion is not existing on the VAR. But it’s not a problem, it’s something to look into.

"And maybe it shows that actually it’s more a question of the rule and the application of the rule, and application of the VAR itself. If you need 10 minutes to find out whether it was offside, maybe it’s not," he said.

One option Infantino rejected outright, however, was getting rid of VAR completely.

“VAR is here to stay as far as FIFA is concerned," he said.

Title: Tanishk Bagchi: Why should someone else take credit for my music?
Content: Composer Tanishk Bagchi , known mostly for his recreated songs, is singing a different tune these days.For the first time, 2020 will see him take over the music of a film. This will include not just the songs, but also the background score.Talking about how other music directors have used his work, Tanishk says, “They (background score composers) take my tracks and paste it throughout the film. Case in point is the recent film starring Ayushmann Khurrana ('Shubh Mangal Zyada Saavdhan'). The entire background score actually has many parts of my original songs. That’s why I decided to take this up seriously. Since the background musicians are using my tracks, I thought why not do it myself? Why should someone else take the credit for my music?”Tanishk, who has earlier worked on background scores for other music directors, adds, “Creating a film’s background score will help me be completely involved in the project because I will be composing more than just the songs in it.” When asked about his numerous recreated numbers, he states, “The response to my remixes has always been good, but this year onwards, I am going to concentrate on my original music and score music for the entire albums. Right now, I am doing at least four to five songs for each film that I am composing for.”2020 will see Tanishk getting into live stage performances too and he will be debuting that with an upcoming award show in Bhopal.“I will be singing, playing instruments on stage for the first time. I am preparing myself for being a performer as it will be a very different experience. I have not done something like this before. I’ll also be doing more independent singles, will be into many international collaborations, and will also work with a lot of new artistes. I’ve always been someone who is into a lot of indoor work, and I’d be stuck in my studio for hours. This year I have decided that I will change all that and will travel a lot,” he signs off.

Title: Bhavini Purohit: I plan to get married this year
Content: Actress Bhavini Purohit , better known as Radha from ' Saath Nibhaana Saathiya ', has found her Mr Right in Mumbai-based businessman, Dhaval Dave . They had a roka ceremony on December 12, 2019, and are likely to tie the knot this year. Talking about how they met, Bhavini says, “My family had been looking for a prospective groom for me, while I was busy with my professional commitments. My father introduced me to Dhaval around seven months ago and told us that we should get to know each other first. Fortunately, we hit it off instantly and told our parents that we were ready to take our relationship to the next level. So, technically, it is an arranged marriage. Though we haven’t decided on a date yet, I plan to get married this year. We will start planning for the big day after March.”It’s Dhaval’s ability to understand her that attracted Bhavini. She shares, “I don’t open up to people easily, but he understands me well despite the fact that I am an introvert. He knows everything about me and we are very honest and transparent with each other.”The two also bonded over their love for travelling and blogging. Bhavini says, “I have always wanted to become an influencer and I am glad that I have been able to realise my dream. I like to talk about fashion, food and travel and these are Dhaval’s interests as well. In fact, he also shoots some travel videos with me and is really good at it.”While she is busy with her new-found interest, Bhavini plans to return to TV soon. Last seen in ' Jaana Na Dil Se Door ' almost three years ago, the actress says, “Though I am caught up with all the work that I am getting, I would love to get back to acting as well. I am waiting for something exciting to come my way.”

Title: How will you ring in the Leap Day?
Content: A birthday comes around once a year, so does an anniversary, but there’s another special date that's popped up on your calendar this year. Yes, we are referring to February 29, which makes its appearance once every four years, as it does today, making 2020 a Leap Year. People around the world mark it by doing something special, including taking up a new class, going on a break or just having a Leap Year gathering with pals.In Mumbai, a few restaurants have jumped onto the Leap Year bandwagon. At a restaurant at Bandra-Kurla Complex, you have to pay only 29% of your total bill, if your birthday falls on Leap Day. Another eatery on Linking Road is inviting folks to ‘leap’ into the fun with a ‘best of four years’ menu. At another café at Airoli, you celebrate the extra day with any item on the menu at `29.In a leap year, February 29 is considered the day when women propose marriage to men. In the West, ladies who are planning to pop the question are offered gifts, free hotel stays and meals. As per a report, in many countries, the tradition goes that any man who refuses a woman’s proposal on a Leap Day must pay a penalty.Those born on Leap Day are called ‘leaplings’ or ‘leapers’.

Title: Priyanka and Vikaas Kalantri: Our son Vihaan has changed our lives completely
Content: It’s been six months since they welcomed their bundle of joy, and life has taken a 180-degree turn for actor couple Priyanka and Vikaas Kalantri.Vikaas says, “I could never imagine myself as a father and more so as a caring one, who would happily change diapers. But that’s what Vihaan has done to me. I always want to rush home from work and I don’t feel like leaving home until he wakes up and gives me that million-dollar smile. I’m even enjoying my sleepless nights.”For Priyanka, too, each day is a new experience. She shares, “My world revolves around Vihaan now, his routine has become my routine. These days, I’m trying out new recipes for him because he has just started having semi solids. Also, most of my online shopping is for him. He is my life and everything that affects him, affects me. I keep harrowing my pediatrician with my constant worries. But having said that, being a mother is indeed a great feeling.”

Title: Music review: Baaghi 3
Content: Ahmed Khan’s action thriller, 'Baaghi 3', which is an official remake of 2012 Tamil movie 'Vettai', stars Tiger Shroff, Riteish Deshmukh and Shraddha Kapoor. After 'Baaghi' (2016) and 'Baaghi 2' (2018), this is the third film of the action franchise. The film’s three-song album (at the time of going to press) has only recreated and remixed versions atthe moment.The first, '' is a remake of the Bappi Lahiri cult classic, 'Ek Aankh Maaru' ('Tohfa', 1984). The Kishore Kumar-Asha Bhosle duet has been recreated by Tanishk Bagchi. While talented singers Dev Negi and Jonita Gandhi transform the track into a tapori wedding dance number, the original composer, Baapi Lahiri, rocks the antara.The next,' is a remake of a Lebanese track by the same name and the filmmakers have given original music credit to René Bendali. The song also has similarities with electronic music artiste TroyBoi song’s 'Do You'. Singer Nikhita Gandhi earlier heard in 'Qaafirana', 'Aao Kabhi Haveli Pe', 'Raabta' and other popular songs, does complete justice to this heavy-on-EDM track. The video of the slow lounge-y number has Disha Patani grooving to it wearing an embellished bikini.The next track, '', sure proves that an original will always hold a special place in hearts of music lovers. The original 'Dus Bahane Karke Le Gaye Dil' ('Dus', 2011) sung by KK and Shaan had impeccable swag and inimitable music.In the recreated version, the original composers, Vishal-Shekhar (this is the first time that the composer duo have remixed their own song), have tried to create in a fresh feel without altering the core essence of the song.The new version has Vishal and Shekar’s vocals along with an added antara, which has been crooned by Tulsi Kumar . Tiger and Shraddha, however, struggle to match up to the visuals of the original.

Title: Supreme Court: Protests can’t infringe rights of others
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

NEW DELHI: After a few judges spoke on the cardinality of the right to dissent and protest peacefully, the Supreme Court on Friday ruled that one’s right to protest could not infringe upon the rights of others as it upheld the Uttarakhand high court verdict initiating stringent action against lawyers boycotting district court work for years.

Uttarakhand lawyers had moved the SC claiming that the HC verdict violated their fundamental right to free speech to go on strike court work to protest against issues concerning them. They said it was a mode of peaceful representation to express grievances of the lawyer community.

Rejecting the arguments, a bench of Justices Arun Mishra and M R Shah said, “Such a right to freedom of speech cannot be exercised at the cost of litigants and/or at the cost of the justice delivery system as a whole.”

“To go on strike or boycott courts cannot be justified under the guise of right to freedom of speech and expression under Article 19(1)(a) of the Constitution,” the SC bench said.

Advocates in the districts of Dehradun, Haridwar and Udham Singh Nagar have been boycotting court work on Saturdays for the past more than 35 years. The Law Commission had found that between 2012 and 2016, advocates were on strike for 455 days (average 91 days per year) in Dehradun district and 515 days (average 103 days per year) in Haridwar district .

A PIL against the strikes was entertained by the HC, which passed a series of directions on the line of law settled by the apex court banning strikes by lawyers. It also warned of contempt of court proceedings against errant advocates.

The bench also took suo motu cognisance of lawyers resorting to strikes in several parts of the country despite a series of judgments by the SC banning strikes by advocates. “We take suo moto cognisance and issue notices to Bar Council of India and all state bar councils to suggest further course of action and to give concrete suggestions to deal with the problem of strikes/abstaining from work by lawyers,” the bench said and sought responses from BCI and state councils within six weeks.

The court criticised the inaction of BCI and state councils against lawyers indulging in strikes. “The day has now come for the Bar Council of India and bar councils of states to step in and take concrete steps. It is the duty of bar councils to ensure that there is no unprofessional and unbecoming conduct by any lawyer,” it said.

Writing the judgment endorsing the steps taken by the HC against lawyers of three districts of Uttarakhand, Justice Shah said, “We direct all concerned and district bar associations to comply with the directions issued by the high court in its true spirit. It is directed that if it is found that there is any breach of any of the directions issued by the high court in the impugned judgment and order, a serious view shall be taken and the consequences shall follow, including punishment under the Contempt of Courts Act.”

Title: Three Italian third division football players among coronavirus cases
Content:
File photo of football fans wearing masks to protect themselves from coronavirus (Getty Images)

MILAN: Three players from third-division Italian football club US Pianese have tested positive for coronavirus , the Tuscany side confirmed on Friday."At the moment those infected are four, three players and a team official," the Siena-based club said in a statement. "The first is a young player who had started to experience a slight rise in temperature and headache last Saturday, when the team was away to Alessandria to play a championship game."The second player is in self-isolation at his home, while not showing any symptoms, as well as the third player who is slightly feverish."The fourth person tested positive for the swab is a club official who this morning, after spending the night in a feverish state, was transported by ambulance to the hospital in Siena."The Serie C side added: "Currently all the players, the technical staff and the managers present during the trip last weekend are in a 15-day quarantine." Italy has the largest coronavirus outbreak in Europe with more than 650 people infected and 17 deaths.Matches in the north of the country, the hardest hit by the virus, will be played behind closed doors this weekend, including five Serie A games, among them league leaders Juventus and title-rivals Inter Milan in Turin.The other four are Udinese against Fiorentina, AC Milan at home to Genoa, Parma against SPAL and Sassuolo versus Brescia.Juve called off their scheduled pre-match press conference on Saturday "in compliance with the restrictions currently in force" as did AC Milan before their game against Genoa in the San Siro on Sunday."It will be strange to play such an important match like Juve-Inter without the fans," Portugual star Cristiano Ronaldo told Sky Sport Italia."It's not nice, but health remains the most important thing."Inter Milan's Europa League game against Bulgarian club Ludogorets also took place behind closed doors in the San Siro on Thursday.Four second-tier Serie B matches will also be played behind closed doors -- Cittadella versus Cremonese; Chievo against Livorno; Venezia hosting Cosenza and Virtus Entella welcoming Crotone.

Title: Cycling: Italy's Filippo Ganna sets new men's individual pursuit world record
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Filippo Ganna (Getty Imges)

BERLIN: Italian Filippo Ganna beat his own men's individual pursuit world record with a time of 4 minutes and 1.934 seconds at the World Track Cycling Championships in Berlin on Friday.

The 23-year-old, who rides on the road for Team Ineos, was close to breaking the symbolic four-minute mark in his qualifying run.

Ganna had previously set the record with 4 minutes and 2.647 seconds in November. He is bidding for a fourth pursuit world title, having taken gold in 2016, 2018 and 2019.

Ganna, who also claimed world silver in 2017, will face Ashton Lambie in the final later on Friday, after the American qualified in 4min 3.64sec.

Frenchman Corentin Ermenault will face Italian teenager Jonathan Milan for bronze.

Elsewhere, 19-year-old New Zealander Corbin Strong claimed gold in the men's points race in an event which has been scrapped from the programme for this year's Tokyo Olympics.

Spain's Sebastian Mora Vedri finished second with the Netherlands' Roy Eefting in third, as title holder Jan-Willem van Schip decided against competing to focus on the omnium and the madison later in the championships.

Title: FIA make private settlement with Ferrari over F1 engine
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Getty Images

LONDON: Formula One 's governing body said on Friday it had reached a settlement with Ferrari after technical investigations into the team's 2019 power unit.

Details of the agreement were kept private but the governing FIA said both parties had agreed to "a number of technical commitments".

It said these would improve monitoring of all Formula One power units in future and "assist the FIA in other regulatory duties in Formula One and in its research activities on carbon emissions and sustainable fuels."

Ferrari's engine was the subject of much speculation last year, with rivals suspecting the team were circumventing fuel flow sensors to gain performance.

They had started the season as early favourites after impressive times in testing and a clear straight line speed advantage.

The performance appeared to tail off, however, after the FIA issued several technical directives concerning fuel flow sensors later in the year.

The team denied anything untoward, with principal Mattia Binotto saying in December they had been one of the most checked teams on the grid.

"We have never changed our way of operating the engine for the last part of the season," he said.

Ferrari finished runners-up to Mercedes last year, with three race wins.

Title: Sensex suffers its 2nd-biggest 1-day loss ever
Content:
The sensex suffered its second-worst single-day loss ever in terms of points on Friday (File Photo)

The sensex suffered its second-worst single-day loss ever in terms of points on Friday, falling in tandem with global markets that followed Thursday's crash in US stocks . On Thursday, the Dow had closed 1,191 points lower, its largest-ever one-day drop in points, on fears of a coronavirus pandemic.A key trigger for the fall in US markets was California authorities announcing that they were monitoring 8,400 people for coronavirus. Traders described the fall in the Dow Jones as a correction as US stocks had hit a record high in mid-February.Asian markets had lost 2-3% by the time the Indian market opened. The sensex fell nearly 1,000 points in early trade and slipped further to close down 1,448 points, or 2.6%, as coronavirus fears spead to Europe as well. The cumulative fall in the sensex in six sessions adds up to 2,872 points. Friday’s decline alone wiped out Rs 5.5 lakh crore of investor wealth.Among the sectors that were affected, auto and pharmaceuticals, which have been hit by supply chain disruptions, continued to weaken. New losers were tech and bank stocks which also fell sharply on Friday. All sensex scrips, barring ITC, closed in the red. The only positive for the Indian economy was the fall in international crude oil prices, which slipped to a 12-month low of $50.“As coronavirus spreads rapidly around the world, hopes that it would be contained has vanished and the market fears that it could turn into a pandemic. Investors are fearful that it might lead to global recession as the outbreak is spreading to the world's largest economy - the US as well as Europe, which will adversely impact global supply chains and derail economic growth,” said Siddhartha Khemka, head - retail research, Motilal Oswal Financial Services.“The world markets are in panic mode over the virus. All the money is moving into US treasuries, which are as a safe haven,” said Abhishek Goenka, CEO, IFA Global. While the markets are expected to be under pressure, Goenka does not see a one-to-one correlation between stocks and the rupee. “RBI has built a huge war-chest of $476 billion and it can easily spend $30 billion to defend the rupee,” said Goenka.While the rupee has been holding up so long, concerns of large-scale exit by foreign institutional investors led to the rupee closing 60 paise lower at 72.21. “This week’s fall can be attributed to FIIs who have been aggressively moving flows out of the country. Surprisingly, domestic institutional investors were net buyers this week till Thursday,” said Jimeet Modi, founder & CEO, SAMCO Securities .

Title: Poor putting dooms world No. 3 Brooks Koepka at Honda Classic
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

File image of Brooks Koepka (Reuters Photo)

MIAMI: World number three Brooks Koepka said poor putting was the problem as he missed the cut Friday at the Honda Classic , another speed bump in his return from a left knee injury that hindered him last season.

"I'm fine," said Koepka, who had stem cell therapy in August to treat a partially torn patella tendon. "No complaints. It's nothing to do with my knee. It's just me."

Specifically it was Koepka's struggles on the greens at PGA National that cost him. He missed half a dozen putts from within 10 feet on Friday as he posted his second straight 74.

His eight-over total put him well outside the projected cut line.

"Struck it really well," said Koepka, who had a triple bogey and a double bogey on his card on Thursday and two double bogeys on Friday. "Really pleased with how I'm hitting it. Putter, I just haven't putted well."

Koepka teed off on 10 and his hopes of gaining ground to make the cut dimmed at 13, where he was right of the fairway off the tee. His third shot was a chip to nine feet, but he missed the putt to save par as well as the short putt for bogey.

He chipped in for his only birdie of the day at the second, but had a bogey and another double-bogey -- when he was in the water at the par-three fifth -- the rest of the way.

"Maybe need a little bit more touch around the greens, a little more feel," said Koepka, noting that he's played only about 18 rounds since August.

As he tries to return to peak form in time for the Masters in April, Koepka is scheduled to play the Arnold Palmer Invitational at Bay Hill next week with the Players, the Valspar Championship and the WGC Match Play Championship to come after that.

"Just need to pick it up a little bit," Koepka said.

Title: Europa League: Andre Silva nets twice as Frankfurt storm through to Europa League last 16
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Andre Silva (AFP Photo)

Andre Silva scored twice as Eintracht Frankfurt reached the last 16 of the Europa League on Friday with a 2-2 draw, and 6-3 aggregate win, over FC Salzburg in a storm-delayed match in Austria.

Frankfurt, 4-1 winners at home, will now play Swiss side Basel in the next round.

Salzburg took the lead at the Red Bull Arena through captain Andreas Ulmer in the 10th minute but Silva headed in the equaliser in the 30th.

The home side again went back in front with a header from defender Jerome Onguene in the 71st but Portuguese striker Silva again equalised by smashing the ball into the top corner from the edge of the area with seven minutes remaining.

The match had been postponed from Thursday after a severe storm warning in the area.
