Title: Justice Mishra: On a lighter note, SC judge who praised PM takes a dig at critics
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

The Supreme Court Bar Association (SCBA) had on Wednesday condemned Justice Arun Mishra’s praise for the PM. (... Read More

NEW DELHI: Supreme Court judge Arun Mishra on Friday took a dig at those criticising him for praising Prime Minister Narendra Modi at a recent conference, saying he had good things to say about many others but would refrain from doing so lest he is criticised again.

Justice Mishra’s observation came during hearing of a plea challenging SC-appointed monitoring committee’s decision to seal ‘Learning Tree’ play school near Khan Market in Delhi. Senior advocate A M Singhvi, appearing for the school, contended that it was the only play school in Lutyens’ Delhi which has been running for 25 years and its closure would affect many children. He said no construction was done by the school which was run from tents.

The bench, also comprising Justice Deepak Gupta, however, rejected the plea. At the end of the proceedings, Justice Mishra asked Singhvi, “Do you want to hear something good about you? I have some good words for you.”

When Singhvi replied that it would be an honour for him, a smiling Justice Mishra said, “But if I use good words for you then other people will blame me.”

The Supreme Court Bar Association (SCBA) had on Wednesday condemned Justice Mishra’s praise for the PM and urged judges to maintain judicial independence by refraining from making such statements or show close proximity to the political executive. Mishra, who retires on September 2, had described Modi as an “internationally acclaimed visionary” and a “versatile genius who thinks globally and acts locally”.

Saying that it “expresses its strong reservations of the statement and condemns it strongly,” the SCBA resolution added, “the SCBA believes any such statement reflects poorly on independence of judiciary and so calls upon the judges not to make statements in future nor show any proximity or closeness to the executive, including higher functionaries”.

Justice Mishra and Singhvi also engaged in a humorous exchange on ‘Khan Market elite’ — a common refrain in the capital’s social circles. When the lawyer told the bench that the school was just across the road, the judge asked Singhvi whether he is also part of ‘Khan Market elite’. Singhvi said he never lived in Lutyens’ Delhi but won’t mind being called so. He said even judges visited the famed market for shopping, prompting Justice Mishra to add, “Do not bring judges into controversy.”’

Title: GDP growth in October-December quarter slows to near 7-year low of 4.7%
Content:
(Representative image: Reuters)

Coronavirus impact an unfolding story: Government

NEW DELHI: The country’s quarterly economic growth slowed to a near seven-year-low in the October-December period of 2019-20, dragged down by contraction in manufacturing and electricity, reinforcing the view that more measures are needed to help the economy navigate choppy waters, especially with the coronavirus threat looming.Data released by the National Statistical Office (NSO) on Friday showed GDP (gross domestic product) grew by 4.7% in the December quarter, slower than the upwardly revised growth of 5.1% in the previous quarter and below the downwardly revised 5.6% in the December quarter of 2018-19. The October-December GDP growth of 4.7% is the slowest in 27 quarters according to official data and slowest since the 4.3% expansion in the January-March quarter of 2012-13.Since the NSO has revised quarterly data for 2018-19 and 2019-20 it may be difficult to do a comparison given the fact that revisions for other quarters are yet to be unveiled.The NSO also retained the GDP growth estimate of 5% for 2019-20 in the second advance estimate but did not spell out anything about any impact of the coronavirus impact, which is expected to be a major drag on global economic growth.The farm sector was the mainstay of growth, growing by a steady 3.5% during the December quarter compared with 2% growth. The manufacturing sector contracted 0.2%, compared with a 5.2% expansion in the year-earlier quarter but a decline of 0.4% in the previous quarter.The services sector, which accounts for nearly 60% of the economy, grew 7.4% in the December quarter, slightly higher than the 7.3% in the previous quarter and at the same level of the previous year-ago quarter.The government, which has unveiled a string of measures since last year and in the February Budget, said growth may have bottomed out. “We have noted the estimates of growth for third quarter of 2019-20. Sustained improvement in agricultural and services continue to drive the growth. The turnaround in composite eight core industries index in December 19 and January indicates well for the manufacturing sector,” economic affairs secretary Atanu Chakraborty said. Asked about the impact of the coronavirus outbreak, he said it was an unfolding story.Experts have cautioned that the outbreak could have a significant impact on growth given the country’s strong links to Chinese imports across sectors and the impact on the global supply chain.Finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman has said the government is closely monitoring the impact of the coronavirus outbreak on the economy and has said there is no need to press the panic button.“Based on the expenditure method, robust and double digit growth in consumption along with higher government expenditure has driven the overall GDP growth in Q3-FY20. However, contraction in gross fixed capital formation (GCFC) has limited the upside,” said Madan Sabnavis, chief economist at Care Ratings.“The investment activity, as measured by GFCF (as a % of GDP) has declined to 26.1% in Q3-FY20 compared with 29.1% shared in corresponding quarter a year ago. The decline in growth in GFCF has been significant at 3.3% in Q3-FY20 as against a robust growth of 16.3% seen in Q3-FY19,” said Sabnavis. GCFC is a proxy for investment.The Indian economy, Asia’s third largest, has been in the throes of a slowdown as investment and consumption have remained tepid. The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has also aggressively cut rates to support growth and has indicated its willingness to do more if needed.“At present, it is difficult to conclude whether the risks arising from the rapid spread of the coronavirus for domestic tourism, trade and manufacturing, would outweigh the improved outlook for the agricultural sector and rural spending, engendered by the encouraging outlook for the rabi crop,” said Aditi Nayar, principal economist at ratings agency ICRA.“The continued slowdown in economic growth in Q3 FY2020 suggests that the MPC (monetary policy committee) may well undertake another rate cut, but only when the CPI inflation retraces considerably towards the 4% mark. Therefore, we continue to expect a pause, at least in the April 2020 and June 2020 policy reviews,” said Nayar.

Title: Tiger Woods: Tiger Woods' back still stiff, will skip Palmer Invitational: Agent
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Tiger Woods (AFP Photo)

Tiger Woods' back remains stiff and he will not play in next week's Arnold Palmer Invitational in Florida where he has won eight times, his agent said on Friday.

"Back still stiff and just not quite ready," Mark Steinberg said in a text to ESPN when asked if the former world number one would play at Bay Hill.

Woods, who is chasing a record 83rd career win on the PGA Tour , has not played since finishing last at 11-over par 295 among players who made the cut at the Genesis Invitational at Riviera in California two weeks ago.

"I was just off, it happens," Woods, who has been bothered by a stiff back, said after the tournament.

"I’m off and I got a chance to have the week off (passing on last week's WGC-Mexico Championship) and do a little prep, a little practising, some training, be at home and all positive things."

The 44-year-old also decided not to play in this week's Honda Classic near his South Florida home.

Woods said on Tuesday he would prepare for the April 9-12 Masters in much the same way as in 2019 when he ended an 11-year wait for a major title at Augusta National.

“It worked last year, so yeah, I’ve got a blueprint for what I need to do and hopefully I can have the same feelings,” Woods said on a conference call.

Title: fc goa: ISL: Ability to stay calm behind Corominas's goal-scoring feats
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

File image of Ferran Corominas (TOI Photo)

CHENNAI: Ferran Corominas might be 37, but there is hardly any let-up in his intensity. Having been prolific in the past two seasons, FC Goa ’s Spanish striker has continued his rich vein of form and netted 14 times this season to be the joint second-highest scorer in the Indian Super League (ISL) behind Kerala Blasters’ Bartholomew Ogbeche (15 goals). He has also managed to take his total ISL tally to 55 goals – the most by any striker – and will be gunning to add one more Golden Boot to the two he has already won over the last two seasons.

What sets Corominas apart is his consistency and finding the net in crunch situations since joining Goa back in the 2017 season. So even though forward Hugo Boumous has proved to be the most influential player for FC Goa this season, Corominas still remains the biggest threat for Chennaiyin when the two sides face off in the first semifinal on Saturday.

Corominas said that his ability to stay calm under pressure is the reason behind him scoring on the big stage.

“Throughout my career, I have loved to score on big occasions. This is because I can stay calm and composed. I am not intimidated by pressure. My dream is to score in the ISL final and help the team win,” Corominas told TOI on Sunday.

The reason behind the Spaniard’s success in the league is his vision for goals. Neither a poacher nor having the physique to bully defenders, he finds spaces behind the defence to run into and has the uncanny ability to be at the right spot at the right time.

“It’s about keeping the focus, having the mentality to score when it matters and striking a bond with teammates. It’s not about adapting to each other. It’s about the application on the pitch. Having stayed together for so many years, we know each other’s strengths and weaknesses. We have been practising the same style over the years and now it has become much easier to understand where the ball will come from. So it helps me to take my position,” Corominas said.

He, though, is aware that things might not be easy for the team on Saturday despite the fact that Goa have got the better of Chennaiyin twice this season.

“They are coming on the back of very good momentum. It will be foolish to take Chennaiyin lightly. All their foreign players are well rested and they will be aiming to prove a point against us,” he said.

The former Elche player admits that he is at the twilight of his career and is already taking coaching lessons. But he wants to realise his one last dream before saying goodbye to the sport.

“My dream is to score in the ISL final and help Goa triumph. The hard work that we have put in over the last three years should translate into the ISL title. I don’t know what the future will bring but if I can stay fit and find enough motivation and excitement, I would love to continue playing.

"At the moment, I am getting my coaching license. I am one level away from turning into a professional coach,” he signed off.

Title: Gokulam Kerala, Punjab FC not giving up on I-League title race
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Gokulam Kerala and Punjab FC are unwilling to give up on the title race even as Mohun Bagan are 12 points clear at the top of the I-League table with at least seven more rounds remaining.

Punjab, visitors to Gokulam’s home turf in Kozhikode on Saturday, sit second in the 11-team table with 21 points. The 2017-18 champions have been solid since a first-round thrashing from Churchill and their only other defeat since then came early February against Mohun Bagan.

“We are not losing hope,” said Punjab coach Yan Law on the eve of their clash with Gokulam at the EMS Corporation Stadium. “They (Mohun Bagan) also have seven more matches to play and mathematically it is still possible, so we will keep doing our part,” he added.

Gokulam head coach Santiago Varela, whose side are sixth with 17 points, reciprocated: “It is very difficult (to close the gap) but always possible if you are willing to fight. Mohun Bagan are now more stronger than when they started the I-League. But anything is possible.”

Even as the two sides have their eyes set on the big prize, they are determined to not lose any more ground as the difference between the second- and tenth-placed Aizawl is only six points.

“This match is vital for us to keep our position and stay second for now,” said Yan Law.

Punjab had a 1-0 win over Real Kashmir in their previous outing two weeks ago and will be hoping for an encore on their 3-1 thumping of Gokulam when the two met in Ludhiana in January. Dipanda Dicka had a brace in the win and the Punjab front-man, with nine goals, should be eager to go top of the goalscorers’ table replacing Bagan hitman Javier Gonzalez.

“It is going to be a tough game because they are well organised. Their coach always comes up with something new every time. The conditions are humid than where we come from, so it could be a bit difficult,” said the Punjab coach.

Gokulam, meanwhile, are happy to return to home comfort after throwing a lead and losing 2-3 to Neroca last week. Varela has blamed the quality of grounds elsewhere that he believes deters the execution of his passing game.

“If we don’t have a good pitch, it is difficult to play our style of football . But here we are happy,” said Varela, who is expected to reinstate Henry Kisekka alongside captain and top scorer Marcus Joseph after dropping the Ugandan in Imphal.

The match will kick-off at 7 pm and the home side has planned a half-time introduction of their women’s team that lifted the Indian Women’s League on Valentine’s Day.

Title: Coronavirus spreads in three continents; $5 trillion wiped off
Content:
A worker wearing a protective suit is seen inside the Shanghai Stock Exchange building (Reuters photo)

Panic in the stock market over the spreading coronavirus continued into a seventh day on Friday, with world share markets crashing again, compounding their worst week since the 2008 global financial crisis and bringing the global wipeout to $5 trillion.The S&P 500 index dropped more than 3 percent in early trading Friday. Before trading began, the index was already down more than 12 percent from a record high reached just last week, and the drop has put the index on track for its worst week since the 2008 financial crisis.The sell-off is fueled mostly by worry that measures to contain the virus would hamper corporate profits and economic growth, and fears that the outbreak could get worse. The selling has dragged stock benchmarks around the world into a correction — a drop of 10 percent or more that’s taken as a measure of extreme pessimism — in a matter of days.A potential outbreak in the United States represents a significant test for President Trump, whose presidential success has been deeply tied to the economy and a rising stock market.On Friday, the slide in Asia and Europe followed a 4.4 percent nose-dive in the S&P 500 index on Thursday, the worst day for American shares since 2011.Hopes that the epidemic that started in China late last year would be over in months, and that economic activity would quickly return to normal, have been shattered as the number of international cases have spiraled. “Investors are trying to price in the worst-case scenario and the biggest risk is what happens now in the United States and other major countries outside of Asia,” said SEI Investments Head of Asian Equities John Lau.“These are highly uncertain times, no one really knows the answer and the markets are really panicking.”Fear over the economic fallout from the spreading coronavirus tightened its grip on global markets, sending US equities to a seventh straight loss and sparking demand for safe assets from Treasuries to the yen.The S&P 500 plunged more than 3.5% Friday and is now down 15% from its record. The index is mired in its longest slump in over three years and careening toward its worst week since the financial crisis. The Dow Jones Industrial Average has shed more than 4,000 points this week. Treasury yields sank to all-time lows, with the two-year tumbling through 1% and 30-year rates under 1.7%. Crude slid toward $45 a barrel, while gold lost 2%. European shares headed for August lows and Asian equities fell more than 3%.The sell-off picked up steam after a White House official suggested the virus could force some schools to close and more companies warned that disruptions could upend sales and profit forecasts. Germany quarantined about 1,000 people and Switzerland banned large events, leading to the Geneva car show being canceled. Iran and South Korea revealed more infections while the first cases appeared in Mexico and Nigeria, Africa’s most populous country.That’s all put shares worldwide on course for the worst week since the 2008 crisis, down around 10%. With the likes of Citigroup Inc. saying they want to see markets “closer to panic” before going all-in on global equities, the dip buyers who have helped make this bull market the longest on record are nowhere to be seen.“Investors are selling stocks first and asking questions later,” Keith Lerner, SunTrust’s chief market strategist, wrote in a note. “We are seeing signs of pure liquidation. ‘Get me out at any cost’ seems to be the prevailing mood. There is little doubt the coronavirus will continue to weigh on the global economy, and the US will not be immune. There is much we do not know. However, it is also premature to suggest the base case for the US economy is recession.”Downgrades to the global outlook keep rolling in and money markets now see three Federal Reserve interest-rate cuts this year. Bank of America predicted that the global economy will see its weakest year since the financial crisis as the virus damages demand in China and beyond.“Asset prices diverged significantly from growth in the past year, in part because of central bank policy, but also because passive investment’s main signal is price action,” reckons James McCormick, global head of desk strategy at NatWest Markets. “The COVID-19 escalation runs a real risk of virtuous cycle turning to a vicious one. Either way, given where growth estimates are heading for the next few months, I’d expect more downside.”Amid the hunt for havens, the yen is on course for its biggest weekly gain since mid-2016, though gold was set for a decline after a multi-month rally.Elsewhere, New Zealand’s dollar fell 1% Friday as the country reported its first case of the virus and investors bet on policy easing from the central bank. Turkish stocks plunged as tensions between Ankara and Moscow soared.

Title: Ayushmann Khurrana's 'Shubh Mangal Zyada Saavdhan' VS Vicky Kaushal's 'Bhoot: The Haunted Ship': Which film scored better on its second Friday at the box office?
Content: Ayushmann Khurrana's 'Shubh Mangal Zyada Saavdhan' has been the talk of the town since the announcement for its unique content. The film deals with the subject of same-sex marriage where Ayushmann is playing a gay character along with Jeetendra Kumar.The trailer of the film received a lot of appreciation from the masses as well as critics. The film was released on February 21 and had a fair run at the box office. It earned Rs 42.35 crore in its first week. Now, according to BoxOfficeIndia report, the film collected Rs 1.75 crore nett on its second Friday. It scored decently in Delhi NCR region.Talking about the subject which is quite sensitive in an exclusive interaction with ETimes, Ayushmann opened up about the challenges he faced while filming. He said, "No challenges as such. Of course, the biggest challenge was to play a homosexual guy being a heterosexual guy."Meanwhile, the film is helmed by Hitesh Kewalya and also stars Neena Gupta , Gajraj Rao, Manvi Gagroo, Manu Rishi and more.Now, on the other hand, Vicky Kaushal 's 'Bhoot: The Haunted Ship' which also released on the same day as Ayushmann's flick collected Rs 23 crore nett in one week. The BOI report stated that Vicky's film scored Rs 1 crore on its second Friday. Reportedly, the reason behind such low turn out is that the weekend was dull and weekday trend was not as strong as it should have been which could mean a dull second week.Well, during an exclusive interaction with Etimes, Vicky opened up about his horror film. He said, ''My experience of shooting for Bhoot was amazing and it was a great learning experience for me because it was a completely new genre. It was a genre I was not prepared for, a grammar I was not prepared for.The film is helmed by Bhanu Pratap Singh and also stars Bhumi Pednekar and Ashutosh Rana in pivotal roles. The trailer received a postive response from the audience but the film failed to impress.

Title: Violence in Delhi: Toll rises to 42 as 4 more die in hospital; Friday prayers pass off peacefully
Content:
Muslim devotees offer Friday prayers at a mosque in Mustafabad area in New Delhi (AFP Photo)

NEW DELHI: The official death toll in northeast Delhi’s riots rose to 42 on Friday with four more people dying at Guru Tegh Bahadur Hospital. The Jumma prayers, meanwhile, passed off peacefully. Policemen and paramilitary forces kept a close watch, with drones deployed above, during the 10 hours of section 144 being relaxed.The police are, however, still looking for AAP councillor Tahir Hussain, booked in the murder case of IB official Ankit Sharma. His mobile phone has been switched off and a man who was coordinating with the media on his behalf claimed he has not been in touch with him as well. On Friday, a forensic team, along with members of SIT, inspected the drain from where Sharma’s body had been recovered. The police suspect that Sharma was first killed and then his body dumped in the drain.GTB’s medical director Dr Sunil Kumar told TOI they had recorded 38 deaths since Monday. Of these, 16 people have been identified and 12 are unknown. Seven had gunshot injuries, eight had blunt assault wounds, three had been stabbed, five had suffered burns, one had been stabbed and shot while the cause in four cases was unknown. He added that about 50 injured people were still in the hospital.Lok Nayak Hospital has recorded three deaths and another death has been reported from Jag Pravesh Chandra Hospital in east Delhi ’s Shahdara. Dr Kishore Singh, medical director of Lok Nayak Hospital, said 56 injured people had been brought there in the past four days. One of them was brought dead while two died during treatment. Eleven people are still in hospital, he said.“On Monday, when the riots began and patients started pouring in with serious injuries, there was some chaos. But within a day, a system was put in place for smooth triaging – deciding the order of treatment – depending on seriousness of the injuries and to manage the manpower needs. Some of the staffers who were on leave were asked to join immediately,” said a senior nursing staff at GTB Hospital.This hospital, with 2,500 beds, is the largest in east Delhi. Due to its proximity to the areas where maximum violence took place, most of the injured were rushed to the hospital beginning Monday.A senior official in the state health department said Wednesday onwards, when GTB Hospital’s emergency wing was running to near-full capacity, some of the patients with minor injuries were referred to Jag Pravesh Chandra and other hospitals. “Now, the government has also clarified that it will bear the cost of treatment for those injured in the riots even if they are being treated at private facilities,” he pointed out.

Title: Differences in Maha alliance, this time over Muslim quota
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

File photo of Eknath Shinde (L) and Nawab Malik (R)

MUMBAI: The Maha Vikas Aghadi government will provide 5% reservation for Muslims in government educational institutions, minorities minister Nawab Malik announced in the legislative council on Friday, drawing sharp reactions from the opposition as well as the Shiv Sena, which said no decision has been taken yet. If implemented, the total reservation in the state will rise to 69%.

The move takes forward a 2014 ordinance brought in by the then Congress-NCP government to provide quota for Muslims in education and government jobs. The Bombay high court had stayed the job reservation and quota in private educational institutions, but had cleared it for state-run educational institutions. Malik said the government will soon bring a bill as per HC orders. This means, private educational institutions and government jobs will not be included.

The NCP minister’s announcement in reply to a Congress member’s query comes barely a week after the allies clashed on the issue of CAA and NPR. CM and Sena boss Uddhav Thackeray had initially backed the Centre on CAA and NPR, only to concede ground later and signal conditional support following criticism from allies NCP and Congress.

When BJP’s Bhai Girkar sought to know if the Sena supported the quota, Malik said, “The Sena is committed to resolve the issues of various communities, including Muslims. Also when it was part of the previous regime and NCP-Congress MLAs raised the issue of Muslim reservation, several Sena MLAs had supported it.”

Several states such as Kerala, Bihar, Karnataka, Tamil Nadu and West Bengal already have reservation for Muslims.

Congress MLC Husnabanu Khalife demanded that the issue of reservation for Muslims be decided before admissions begin in May. Minorities minister Nawab Malik replied that a decision would be taken at the earliest.

On the issue of reservation for Muslims in government jobs and private educational institutions, Malik told the legislative council these issues would be resolved.

The quota issue was raised by Congress’ Sharad Ranpise who expressed unhappiness over the written reply given by the government and said, “The answer is the same as that given by the previous government.” Ranpise then asked if the 5% reservation which was not stayed by the Bombay HC in its interim order would be implemented.

However, Sena minister Eknath Shinde said no decision has been taken so far on the issue. "The CM will take a decision after speaking to all the allies at the right time," said Shinde.

Opposition leader in the assembly Devendra Fadnavis later told TOI that BJP was opposed to all reservations based on religion. “We want to what deals the Sena has agreed to, to form the government. When the Sena was with us it had opposed the reservation. We will oppose the reservation based on religion. Also, there is no final order (of the Bombay High Court ) on the 5% reservation,” he said.

Fadnavis said Dr B R Ambedkar’s Constitution does not allow for reservation based on religion. A similar view was taken by the Andhra Pradesh High Court, he added.

“The Modi government has already provided 10% reservation for the economically poor which includes Muslims. This enabled a Muslim boy to obtain admission in the IIT,” he said.

The Muslim reservation will impact that for the Other Backward Caste and Maratha community reservation, he said.

Title: ‘After Balakot, Pak will think 100 times before a misadventure’
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Defence minister Rajnath Singh (File Photo)

NEW DELHI: India’s “out-of-the-box” response against cross-border terrorism through air strikes on the JeM facility at Balakot a year ago has forced rewriting of doctrines and military manuals in Pakistan, which will now “think 100 times” before trying “any future misadventures”, defence minister Rajnath Singh said on Friday.

“Today, the world stands shoulder-to-shoulder with India in forcing countries like Pakistan to bring terrorists to justice. We have recently seen the impact of collective diplomatic and financial pressure on Pakistan. Terrorists like Hafiz Saeed , who were treated like VIPs and heroes, have been put behind bars,” said Singh.

But much more needs to be done, said the minister, adding that unless Pakistan was made fully accountable for sponsoring cross-border terrorism, it will continue with its “previous policy of duplicity and deceit”. “All attempts are being made to work in this direction … Our approach to terrorism was, and will remain, a judicious combination of clinical military action and mature and responsible diplomatic outreach,” he said, speaking at a seminar on “No War, No Peace” organised by the Centre for Air Power Studies to mark the first anniversary of the Balakot air strikes.

The 2016 “surgical strikes” and the Balakot air strikes were not just resolute military strikes against terrorism but also sent a strong and unequivocal message to Pakistan that it can no longer use terror infrastructure on its soil as “safe havens” to wage a low-cost war against India. “Balakot must teach us to think strategic rather than tactical,” said Singh, adding that while an operational victory may be achieved on the ground, the real war must be won in the enemy’s mind.

IAF chief Air Chief Marshal R K S Bhadauria, in turn, said the government’s “bold decision” to strike at the “heart of terrorist training camps” inside Pakistan represented a paradigm shift in use of air power in a sub-conventional scenario. Pakistan’s “Operation Swift Retort”, the attempted counter-strike with a large package of aircraft 30 hours after the Balakot air strikes, was an effort to satisfy its domestic audience and was successfully thwarted by the IAF, he said.

“We had an edge over Pakistan Air Force in terms of beyond visual range missiles at the time of the Kargil conflict in 1999. But we allowed that to slip and thereafter it took a decade and a half in our struggle to acquire better capabilities,” said ACM Bhadauria, adding that the induction of the 36 Rafales from France from this year onwards will help the IAF in retaining the combat edge.

Chief of Defence Staff General Bipin Rawat, on his part, said India must maintain credible deterrence in land, air and at sea at all times, stressing that the three Services must closely work together to deal with any potential threats. “Credible deterrence comes from the will of the military leadership and intent of the political class while taking tough decisions. This was amply shown after Kargil, Uri and Pulwama attacks,” he added.

Title: coronavirus: Cycling stars in lockdown as two Gulf hotels isolated over coronavirus scare
Content:
A mask-clad man at the entrance of the Crowne Plaza hotel in Yas Island Abu Dhabi, where two Italian cyclists ... Read More

DUBAI: Two luxury hotels in Abu Dhabi were in lockdown on Friday to isolate guests including scores of professional cyclists after two Italian members of the tour the riders were participating in were suspected of contracting the coronavirus The final two stages of the UAE Tour , featuring 140 riders including some of the sport's biggest stars, was cancelled after the tests.The W Abu Dhabi and the Crowne Plaza Abu Dhabi, both on Yas Island in the United Arab Emirates' capital, said they had been placed under lockdown as authorities screened all guests over concerns they might have interacted with the Italians."This means that no one can leave or enter the property until it is deemed safe to do so," said a spokesman for the W.Other people who also interacted with the two Italians on Yas Island have been isolated at home, UAE state news agency WAM said, citing the health department of Abu Dhabi.The health department said that 167 people isolated on the island had tested negative for the virus and that remaining test results would emerge in the next few hours, according to WAM. It did not give the total number of people being screened.On Thursday evening, riders including four-time Tour de France winner Chris Froome took to Twitter to say they were confined to their hotel rooms."We are all awaiting testing and will remain at the hotel until further notice," Froome posted.UAE authorities reported the positive diagnosis of the Italians on Thursday.But cycling 's governing body UCI said the two cases of the illness among two staff members of one of the participating teams were only suspected ones.It was not immediately clear which of the two hotels the Italians were staying at.One of the hotels was accommodating participants in the race and the other the media following it, wrote a journalist with the magazine VeloNews who is staying in one of them.

Title: Mukhiya held for accepting Rs 63,000 bribe in Bihar
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

ARA/ PATNA : A team of vigilance investigation bureau arrested Sarna panchayat mukhiya Sanjay Kumar Singh (45) while he was allegedly accepting a bribe of Rs 63,000 at his residence at Sarna village in Bhojpur district from a ward councillor Phulsundari Devi on Friday. The arrested mukhiya is also Shahpur block president of Lok Janshakti Party (LJP).

Phulsundari is the councillor of ward number eight which falls under Sarna panchayat. The raiding team was led by DSP Sarvesh Kumar Singh.

Vigilance sources said the woman councillor had constructed drainage and had got water-supply pipelines laid in her ward under the Chief Minister Nitish Kumar’s ambitious seven-resolves scheme and the mukhiya was demanding a bribe to clear her bank cheque against the expenses made. They said that it is the mukhiya who used to make payments against such construction work under the scheme.

“The mukhiya had demanded 40% as commission from the entire amount spent on construction work. A total bribe money, as calculated by mukhiya was Rs 1,26,600,” a senior official of the bureau said preferring anonymity.

He said the final deal was struck at Rs 1.25 lakh and Rs 63,000 was the first instalment to be paid to the mukhiya. “The bribe was to be paid on Thursday. However, he was busy due to some meeting of his party at the panchayat- level. We delayed the raid by a day after which action was taken on Friday,” said the official.

Vigilance bureau sources said the ward councillor had written to the block development officer and others for clearing her payment against the construction work but no action was taken. “She finally wrote to the bureau on February 17. The very next day, the bureau verified her complaint and found it to be true that the mukhiya was demanding money to clear her payment. Following this, a trap team was formed to nab him,” he said.

Title: Delhi violence sends alarm bells ringing in Bihar, cops put on alert
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: The state police headquarters has sounded an alert in the state in view of forthcoming festivals, especially Holi. The recent violence in Delhi and pro or anti-CAA protests in the state has kept senior police officers on their toes. Upcoming assembly elections are also in the mind of law enforcement agencies.

The SPs of the districts, which had witnessed group clashes in the past, have been asked to maintain extra vigil on movement of outsiders or unfamiliar faces. The members of cyber senani groups have been directed to closely monitor fake news or rumours spread through social media.

ADG (law & order) Amit Kumar said on Friday, “An alert is in place. We have made foolproof security arrangements to ensure peace and harmony. Additional forces are being deployed in the districts identified as sensitive from security point of view.”

Though Kumar refused to share details of force deployment, sources said four companies of Rapid Action Force would be deployed in hyper sensitive districts in the state.

A senior IPS officer said special arrangements were made in the districts which have witnessed anti or pro-CAA protest marches recently. “In fact, the entire state has been put on alert,” he added.

Besides RAF, the state anti-riot force’s 15 companies would also be deployed in the districts. Each company comprises 96 effective personnel, who have been imparted special training to deal with mobs.

Those cops who were earlier earmarked for training have been sent to the parent districts of their posting. The police chiefs of the districts which had earlier witnessed group clashes during festivals have been asked to arrest anti-socials.

The DGP, during his recent visit to several districts, had told the SPs to conduct beat meeting with people in neighbourhood localities.

In addition, intelligence agencies have been asked to give inputs on anti or pro-CAA protest sites. They have been assigned to keep a close watch on the developments.

“We will not allow any miscreant to create trouble,” said an IG rank officer, who is on field assignment.

Title: Two from Bihar die in Delhi violence
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

ARA/BEGUSARAI: A mill-worker from Bhojpur district and a 15-year-old boy from Begusarai have lost their lives in Delhi violence .

The deceased hailing from Bhojpur has been identified as Deepak Kumar, a native of of Salempur village under the Chandi police station area. He was the sole bread earner of his family and is survived by his wife and three children.

Deepak worked at Jhilmil Rolling Mill under the Shahdara police station in Delhi. His uncle, Nand Kumar Yadav told media persons that Deepak went to Chandni Chowk at around 10am on February 25 to buy clothes with his friend Vikki. “On getting information that the market was closed, Deepak and Vikki decided to return. When they reached Gokulpuri locality, Deepak was surrounded by a frenzied mob, who were pelting stones and firing indiscriminately. Though Vikki managed to escape, Deepak became a victim of the mindless violence,” Yadav said.

Deepak’s wife Sarita broke down saying that he had promised to come back home in Holi. “He was supposed to call me around around 11 am on February 25, but on February 24 about 1 pm, we got the sad news."

Deepak’s six-year-old son, Ritik said, "Papa had promised to bring clothes for us in Holi. The government should give strict punishment to those who have killed my papa."

The 15- year- old deceased boy from Begusari has been identified as Bipin Kumar, a native of Sonma village under Garhpura block. Family members of the deceased claimed said the incident occurred in Bhajanpura area of north-east Delhi on Wednesday.

Bipin was the youngest son of Sogarath Paswan, who migrated to Delhi five years ago to eke a living. Family members of Paswan in the village told reporters on Friday that Bipin had gone to the local market to buy goods for daily use of the house. However, he got trapped in clashes between the police and the locals. He got seriously injured and police later admitted him to a local hospital, where he succumbed to his injuries. It was not clear whether he got injured in the firing by the locals or retaliatory police action.

Title: State govt staff to get free treatment under Atal Ayushman
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Dehradun: The state cabinet on Friday gave its approval on extending free health treatment benefits to the state government employees under Atal Ayushman Yojana.

The move comes in the backdrop of the ongoing agitation by state government employees on the issue of reservation in promotion. The extension of the health insuarnace sop is also being seen as a means to placate the agitated employees.

Sources said that the state government is going to charge a nominal premium from the employees, according to their pay grade. The premium will be in the range of Rs 250 to Rs 1,000. Moreover, the cabinet has also done away with the mandatory procedure of referral by government hospital for taking treatment in a private hospital, according to government sources.

Further, the government is going to open 10 call centres to provide better services in this regard.

The cabinet also gave its approval to Uttarakhand Witness Protection Bill 2020, aimed at providing protection to the witnesses in cases involving death penalty.

Besides, GS Rautela has been appointed as an advisor in science city. Rautela was associated with National Council of Science Museums. He will have a tenure of three years. The maximum tenure of deputation of police personnel in State Disaster Response Force (SDRF) has also been increased to seven years from present five years. Cabinet also approved amendments in the Mega Industry Investment Policy 2015. As a result, products in the negative list will no longer enjoy any duty exemptions. A change in the Mega Textile Park Policy was also approved by the cabinet, which extended the tenure of the policy to 2023 from 2021. The cabinet also made changes in the Start-up policy.

Title: No plan to introduce domicile policy in Bihar, says minister
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Bihar minister Bijendra Prasad Yadav

PATNA: Energy minister Bijendra Prasad Yadav was non-committal on Friday regarding introduction of domicile policy in Bihar even as leader of opposition in state assembly Tejashwi Prasad Yadav maintained that non-pursuance of domicile policy for the natives of Bihar had led to candidates from other states getting most government jobs here.

Tejashwi said the government in neighbouring Jharkhand and some other states have introduced domicile policy for 100% government jobs to the locals. “However, due to non-pursuance of the domicile policy in Bihar, youths going to other states in search of government and private jobs are being harassed and assaulted,” Tejashwi told reporters outside the assembly.

While giving the government’s reply to the call attention motion from an RJD member who had sought to know if the government had any intention to introduce domicile policy for the natives of the state, Bijendra said, “Give it in writing which states have been implementing what kind of domicile policy and also mention in which states youths from Bihar are assaulted or prevented from getting government jobs. After you give it in writing, our government will look into it.”

Bijendra said be it the government jobs or admissions to educational institutions, scheduled caste, scheduled tribe, backward castes and extremely backward castes have got 50% reservation in the state. “If 10% additional quota enjoyed by the economically weaker sections in the state is considered, the total reservation goes up to 60%. The remaining 40% is open for the natives of Bihar and from other states,” he said.

“Youths from Bihar going to other states for jobs is not a problem, because they are free to find job anywhere in the country,” he added.

While addressing a public meeting in Gaya district as part of his ‘Berojgari Hatao Yatra’ on Thursday, Tejashwi had maintained that if elected to power, the RJD government would implement the domicile policy for the natives of Bihar and give 80% of jobs to the locals.

Earlier in the day, Tejashwi tweeted, “Nitishji lacks willpower. People are going to moon, but he is unable to give jobs to seven crore youths from Bihar. Good schools, colleges, universities and world-class institutions needed to be opened in the state.”

In another tweet, he wrote, “In the last 15 years, not even a factory for needles has been established. What is the reason that no one is willing to set up IT park, manufacturing, food processing and other industrial units in the state (sic)?”

‘4,012 medical officers to be appointed’: Health minister Mangal Pandey said in the state assembly on Friday that decks have been cleared for the appointment of 4,012 medical officers and 2,425 specialist doctors on the recommendations of the Bihar State Technical Commission (BSTC). Counselling for the same will be completed by the end of March, the minister said.

Similarly, the counselling of nursing staff and auxiliary nursing maids (ANMs) have also been completed for their posting in various government hospitals, the minister said while giving the government’s reply to the short-notice question of RJD member Shiv Chandra Ram.

The shopping complex in Deesa where the woman was allegedly raped on Friday

Title: Diamond workers threaten strike over professional tax
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Last year, more than 13,000 diamond workers were laid off

SURAT: Diamond workers in the world’s largest diamond cutting and polishing centre in Surat are on the warpath against state government on the issue of professional tax . The industry is set to witness closure and dharnas by workers from March 15.

Surat Ratnakalakar Sangh (SRS) has given a call for bandh in the diamond industry on March 16 to demand abolition of professional tax charged by the state government from diamond workers. A three-day long dharna programme will be organized at Mini Bazaar diamond market in Varachha from March 15.

SRS president Jaysukh Gajera told reporters, “About 5.5 lakh workers will stay away from work on March 16 to demand abolition of professional tax. We are appealing unit owners to support workers by keeping their units shut for a day.”

Gajera added, “Workers and the industry have for long been demanding abolition of professional tax, but the state government is yet to accept this. The government is collecting over Rs150 crore worth of tax from workers and that they are not being given any benefits.”

He said diamond workers are not getting enough work in the industry due to weak market conditions and that the diamond unit owners have slashed production of polished diamonds in the last few months. Last year, more than 13,000 diamond workers were laid off from small and medium diamond units.

Meanwhile, Surat Diamond Association (SDA) has stated that an industry delegation will be meeting chief minister Vijay Rupani in Gandhinagar to make a representation against professional tax on March 2.

SDA president Babu Kathiriya told TOI, “We have requested diamond workers to stay away from bandh in the diamond industry. The association will be meeting chief minister Vijay Rupani along with health minister Kumar Kanani to demand abolition of professional tax.”

Title: FOSTTA demands MSME status for textile traders
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

SURAT: Federation of Surat Textile Traders’ Association ( FOSTTA ) has urged Union ministry of micro, small and medium enterprises (MSME) to provide status of MSME to textile traders in the city.

FOSTTA office-bearers held a meeting with special secretary and development commissioner of MSME, Ram Mohan Mishra, who was on a day’s visit to the Diamond City on Friday. The traders’ body raised several issues including that of their long-pending demand of providing MSME status to textile traders.

Purshottam Agarwal, joint secretary of FOSTTA, said, “Textile trading business involves 60% job work on cloth, which passes from more than 12 different types of processes. However, traders are also manufacturers and that they should be given the status of MSME.”

Traders said a representation has been made to MSME development commissioner for setting up a ready-made garment centre in Surat.

FOSTTA president Manoj Agarwal said, “We raised an important issue with MSME development commissioner for setting up a skill development centre for women doing hand-embroidery on saris and dress material. After GST implementation, hundreds of women have been rendered jobless.”

Title: Tamil Nadu net-makers caught in DRI net for Rs 30 crore ‘export’ scam
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

SURAT: The Directorate of Revenue Intelligence ( DRI ) has detected Rs 30 crore scam under the export incentive scheme by Tamil Nadu-based exporters of mosquito nets.

Official sources said that the DRI’s Surat unit had raided two firms based in Karur in Tamil Nadu exporting bed nets and mosquito nets. The DRI sleuths had received intelligence that the firms were indulging in fake classification of their export products and wrongfully claiming the Merchandise Exports from India Scheme (MEIS) benefit despite their non-eligibility.

Sources said that the MEIS scheme is an export incentive scheme of the Union government under which exporters get 1-7% of the free on board (FOB) value of their export product as incentive depending upon their product and customs tariff heading under which they are classified.

During the search operation on the two Tamil Nadu based firms, the officials found incriminating documents related to the misuse of the MIES for getting benefits. The owners of the firm admitted in their statements that they had wrongly availed the MEIS benefit.

The total value on the ineligible MEIS scrips issued and utilised by the exporters was worth Rs 30 crore. The exporters voluntarily paid Rs 5.4 crore towards wrongful availment of benefit under the MEIS scheme.

Official sources said that the exporters have been asked to pay up the rest of the amount wrongly claimed under the MEIS. Further investigations are going on.

Title: Yarn spinners, weavers engaged in face off over anti-dumping duty
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Yarn spinners from the city had filed a petition with DGTR for imposing anti-dumping duty on nylon filament ya... Read More

SURAT: Nylon yarn spinners and powerloom weavers are engaged in a face off over anti-dumping duty on import of nylon filament yarn proposed by Directorate General of Trade Remedies (DGTR), Government of India.

Yarn spinners from the city had filed a petition with DGTR for imposing anti-dumping duty on nylon filament yarn last year. On February 4, DGTR had issued a disclosure report in favour of yarn spinners, considering the injury to domestic industry due to dumping of cheap nylon yarn by China.

Powerloom weavers started a campaign against spinners stating that anti-dumping duty on nylon yarn will ruin the industry by allowing spinners to form price cartels to loot weavers. Weavers feared that the anti-dumping duty on nylon yarn would increase domestic yarn prices by Rs 100 per kilogram.

According to yarn spinners, out of the total 18 nylon yarn spinners in India, about 11 are based in Surat. The industry is suffering from cheap import of low-grade yarn from China since 2016. About 23 metric tonnes of nylon yarn were imported from China in 2016, which rose to 1,250 metric tonnes in 2019.

Nylon Spinners’ Association (NSA) president Narayan Agarwal said, “Weavers are making false allegations about yarn price hike in domestic market to influence proceedings in DGTR. Majority of weavers are using yarn manufactured by local spinners and only 0.4% utilize imported yarn.”

NSA vice-president Rakesh Choudhary said, “After disclosure report by DGTR, importers’ lobby is backing weavers to spread false propaganda to influence the ongoing proceedings. We can’t even think of increasing prices by Rs100 per kilogram thereby losing business in domestic market. Weavers are trying to malign the image of spinning sector.”

Pandesara Weavers’ Association Ashish Gujarati said, “There is no anti-dumping duty on nylon yarn, but the moment it is imposed spinners will definitely rig prices. We fear that about 1.5 lakh powerlooms will be affected and more than 6,000 workers will lose their job.”

Title: Man gets 2-year jail for rash driving in Puducherry
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

PUDUCHERRY: A 36-year-old man has been sentenced to a two-year jail term for rash and negligent driving, without a valid licence, which caused the death of a woman and injured three others in Puducherry 11 years ago. Judicial magistrate II M Dhanalakshmi also slapped a fine of Rs 7,000 M Mohanraj.

Police said Mohanraj drove a tipper truck in a rash and negligent manner. The vehicle hit a motorcycle and fatally ran over rider Subasri. Pillion rider Rajalakshmi suffered injuries. The heavy vehicle also hit another motorcycle and caused grievous injuries to rider Malarvizhi and injuries to pillion rider Bharani. The accident happened on March 30, 2009.

Police booked the driverrash driving causing hurt by act endangering life or personal safety of others.

Title: Mortal remains of CRPF jawan who died in Odisha consigned to flames
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

GORAKHPUR: The mortal remains of Dharamdev, CRPF jawan , whose skeletal remains were reportedly found in Rayagada mgada district of Odisha on February 22, were brought to his home in Gorakhpur on Friday.

His mortal remains were consigned to flames at Rajghat in Gorakhpur in presence of MP Kamlesh Paswan, SDM Arpit Gupta, officials and a huge number of people. Dharamdev was missing from December 29, 2019. His skeletal remains were later found from behind a bush. It is suspected that he was killed by Nxalites.

Dharamdev Paswan (50), a native of Deoria district, started living Chauri Chaura area of Gorakhpur after marriage. He joined CRPF in 1991 and was posted as halawadar, 4th batalian at Rayagada district of Odisha. He went missing on December 20 and his skeletal remains were found behind a bush around 15 km away from Rayagada headquarter on February 22.

MP Kamlesh Paswan said that he would try fmartyr status to the deceased, “I will try for martyr status for Dharamdev ji and also to get government assistance for job and finacial help for his family. A building in Dharmadev’s name will be constructed from my MP fund.”

Dharamdev’s wife Anari told reporters that on she last communictaed with her husband on phone on December 20, 2019 at around 12.30pm. He had told her that he was going from CRPF Cantt to Rayagada headquarter for duty. Later when she called him at around 1.30pm his phone was switched off and after that there was no information about him.

His 23-year-old son Rakesh went to Odisha to search for him and returned after 10 days. On February 22, he got a call from CRPF headquarter that his father’s body has been retrieved from behind a bush. Dharadev is survived by three daughters Rinki (24), Suman (19), Soni (17) and a son Rakesh.

Title: Science Park inaugurated in Ankleshwar
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Suyog Science Park aims to teach the students various innovations of science, theoretically and practically

BHARUCH: A first of its kind science park was inaugurated by union agriculture minister Purshottam Rupala at a school at GIDC Ankleshwar on Friday.

Suyog Science Park aims to teach the students various innovations of science, theoretically and practically.

N K Navadia, trustee of Sansakrdeep Trust, said: “The science park has been developed with the cost of Rs 41 lakhs where various classroom experiments of solar, wind and other conventional energy and their basic principals will be explained effectively.”

“With the support of IIT, Gandhinagar , Centre for Creative Learning Stem (Science Technology Engineering Mathematics) lab will be developed with the cost of Rs 30 lakhs,” added Navadia.

Title: HIV+ women fight stigma in search of new life
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

A file photo of a similar event that was organized last year

SURAT: They have rejected fear to accept life, a new living free from prejudices and social stigma. As many as 75 women have come out open on their HIV positive status and will search for suitable marriage partner at a marriage fair which is being organised in Hazira on Saturday.

In what appears to be a positive step towards positive thinking, the numbers this year have almost doubled compared to the past years in among participants of 'Jivan Sathi Chayan Mela'. The fair is organized by the Gujarat State Network of Positive People (GSNP+) — an organisation run by HIV positive people from across Gujarat.

The 12th such fair supported by Reliance Foundation and being held at Reliance AIDS and TB Centre in Hazira will see more than 900 male and female candidates participating on Saturday. In the annual fair, majority of the volunteers are couples who found their partners in similar fairs organised in the past.

Along with awareness drive, organisers are encouraging the women to attend the fair offering benefits like transportation charges. Along with participants from Gujarat, many from other neighbouring states including Maharashtra, Madhya Pradesh and Rajasthan are also participating.

"It is a good sign that women are shedding their inhibitions. In past only 20 to 25 women attended such fairs but the growing numbers reflect their rejection of fear from being identified," said Daksha Patel , founder of GSNP+.

Patel further said that by marrying a suitable match these HIV positive people will find a reason to enjoy their lives like any other normal person.

To make it easy for participants to register, we started online registration, said Rasik Bhuva, president of GSNP+, adding that to make it even more user friendly, the registration form has been kept in Gujarati.

One of the volunteers at the fair said that after finding his life partner in last year's fair, he understands the importance of such fairs in changing lives. I got married two months ago and now help the organisers as a volunteer, he said.

Title: AAP councillor Tahir Hussain booked in murder case absconding
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Tahir Hussain (ANI photo)

NEW DELHI: AAP councillor Tahir Hussain , who has been booked in the murder case of IB official Ankit Sharma , is absconding. His mobile phone is switched off.

As per the FIR registered on the complaint of Ankit’s father, Ravinder, “Tahir had gathered goons at his residence who were engaged in violence and firing, throwing petrol bombs and pelting stones.”

“My son stepped out on February 25 evening to buy some items for the house, but never returned home. He was found just in his underwear, and had wounds on his head, face, chest, waist and back by a sharp weapon. He even had burnt marks on his body,” Ravinder added.

On Friday, a team of the forensic department, along with the SIT team members, reached the drain from where the body was recovered. As blood was found there, police suspect Sharma was first killed and then his body dumped in the drain.

The SIT also inspected the riot-hit areas. Initial examination of Hussain’s video indicates that his speech may have been superimposed in the background of riots. Not only is the background changing slightly but his ears are also missing in some frames, said a source.

Meanwhile, inquiry into the attack on DCP Shahdara, Amit Sharma, and other officials has revealed that after Sharma was attacked, the protesters went on a rampage. TNN

Title: JDA action fails to rein in spurt of illegal colonies
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Jaipur: With spurt in population and increase in demand for land, the illegal construction and development of colonies in the city is on rise.

As per the data available, in 2009 attempts to develop 66 illegal colonies were checked by the Jaipur Development Authority (JDA). Similarly, the civic body took action against the 4,000 illegal constructions in its periphery. Though the numbers look impressive, the illegal colonies and construction continued to crop up.

Chief minister Ashok Gehlot last week also pulled up the officials about the alleged corruption within the department because of which illegal construction is rampant. Sources in the department said, “After the CM pointed out corruption in the enforcement wing, three officials were relieved on Friday. A list of officials are also been prepared who are allegedly involve in shielding or promoting illegal construction,” sources said.

Source said, the move to relieve officials were taken after receiving repeated complaints from zone 9 and 10 and Privthi Raj Nagar, south region. The civic body's ground officials are allegedly turning a blind eye to these illegal constructions. “Settling illegal colonies on vacant government land is not the only type of corruption in PRN; high-rises going beyond permissible heights in connivance with JDA officials are the latest abuse of law taking place in this locality. Private developers are blatantly violating the building bylaws,” said sources.

Title: Life insurers may offer bundled life & health packages, likely at lesser price
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Chennai: As discussion begins to assess the feasibility of life insurers to design and offer health insurance products, existing and potential policyholders may be offered bundled packages of life and health products, with a possibility of cheaper insurance premiums. “Unlike non-life insurers we can offer unique bundled products like — life and health products, health and savings. In this case, the morbidity risk still stays with us, but the savings part goes back to the customer. We may also offer five-year guaranteed premium products as we have the expertise to offer long-time products. Given our history of having a significant distribution channel, we plan to leverage on them to cover the significantly bigger under-insured population,” said Bikash Choudhary, appointed actuary and chief risk officer, Future Generali India Life Insurance Company Limited.

Last Tuesday, IRDA announced the setting up of a committee to study the feasibility of allowing life insurers to offer indemnity based health policies, Life insurers have expressed interest and their ability to create newer markets to cover the under insured population.

NS Kannan, MD and CEO, ICICI Pru Life Insurance said the focus has shifted to living well from living long. Going forward, the problem of the country is not mortality as longevity is increasing, but are people living well and healthy. Speaking on the advantage which life insurance companies will have in offering health products, Kannan said, “The deep expertise to assess morbidity and mortality is the biggest advantage, in managing the risks associated around health products.”

On pricing of health insurance policies by life insurers, Aalok Bhan, Director and CMO, Max Life Insurance said if a customer is buying both life and health cover from the same insurance provider at a given point of time, there will be no need for separate medical and financial underwriting for each product, thus, cost of policy issuance and administration might also be lower. There will be a possibility to pass on such cost benefit to policyholders. The distribution strength of life insurance companies is unparalleled at 2.3 million, especially with LIC alone having over 1.2 million agents. “Besides agent-driven distribution model, we have recorded vast customer base via bancassurance model, where 40-50% of premium comes from these bank partners.” Policybazaar.com spokesperson said through the drafted regulations, life insurers may be able to implement the actuarial models and review the price periodically say in every few years or so instead of doing it every year. IRDA banned life insurers from offering indemnity-based health products since 2014 .

Title: Rupee weakens below 72
Content: Mumbai: The rupee, which had been range-bound despite the market rout this week, broke the 72 level on Friday on fears of foreign funds exiting. Even after Friday’s decline, the rupee continues to be among the better-performing Asian currencies.On Friday, the rupee fell by 62 paise to settle at a nearly six-month low of 72.18 against the US dollar as global markets cracked due to panic over the coronavirus pandemic. The rupee opened weak at 71.9 in the interbank foreign exchange market and soon hit a low of 72.29 in intraday trade. Friday’s close of 72.18 is the lowest since September 2019.“Considering risk-off trades seen in recent weeks, further weakness in the currency cannot be ruled out,” said a report by ICICI Securities . However, dealers are confident that the RBI will not let the rupee slip as this could hurt sentiment in the bond markets and the RBI has $476 billion of reserves.The current level of reserves is enough to cover nearly a year of imports and 80% of the total debt. “Globally, funds are going back to US government bonds. As a result, the yield on the 10-year bond has hit a new low of 1.16%,” said a dealer.“I expect the rupee to remain range-bound with the caveat that the Chinese yuan does not slip which could lead to pressure on the rupee,” said Abhishek Goenka , CEO, IFA Global. India and China have been the best performing BRICS currency in 2020.While the Chinese currency is down only 0.4%, the Indian rupee has slipped 1.1%. The worst performers are the South African rand, which slipped 10.7%, and the Brazilian real which declined by 10.6%. The only Asian currency to gain against the US dollar in 2020 was the Japanese yen, which appreciated marginally to 0.26%.“The panic selling of foreign investors in Indian equities has led to the rupee depreciation. Now that the big hurdle of 72 is crossed, it can take 72.50 as the next level on upside,” said Jateen Trivedi, senior research analyst (commodity & currency) at LKP Securities.

Title: CM Nitish Kumar demands special status for Bihar at EZC meeting
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Bihar CM Nitish Kumar

PATNA: Amid reports of growing bonhomie between leader of opposition in state assembly Tejashwi Prasad Yadav and CM Nitish Kumar , the latter on Friday reiterated his demand for special category status to the state at the 24th Eastern Zonal Council (EZC) meeting chaired by Union home minister Amit Shah in Bhubaneswar.

Nitish said his government had been consistently demanding grant of special category status to Bihar. “Today, I once again strongly put up my demand before the Union home minister so that we can get our genuine share and Bihar too can progress and make its contribution to the development of the country,” Nitish said.

The meeting was also attended by Naveen Patnaik and Mamata Banerjee, CMs of Odisha and West Bengal, respectively. Jharkhand’s finance minister Rameshwar Oraon represented Hemant Soren at the meeting. Bihar, Jharkhand, Odisha and West Bengal are members of the EZC.

“Despite achieving double-digit growth rate during the last so many years, we are still behind the national average in major development parameters like poverty line, per capita income, industrialization and social and physical infrastructure. Some other states also are like Bihar in terms of backwardness. The states, which are given special status, have progressed on development scale. Therefore, a new policy framework is needed to bring all the backward states to the national mainstream in terms of development,” Nitish said.

He also sought cooperation from Jharkhand and West Bengal governments to check smuggling of illegal liquor in Bihar. “Bihar had enforced total prohibition April 2016. Several vehicles laden with illegal liquor were seized in the recent past by Bihar police after they crossed borders of Jharkhand and West Bengal. We urge the governments of the two states to take effective action against the smugglers who are sending illicit liquor to dry Bihar,” Nitish said.

He urged Shah to prevail upon the Jharkhand government and ask it to clear the pending payment of Rs 310 crore to Bihar under the pension liability, as agreed before a meeting of Union home secretary on June 18, 2018.

The CM also drew the attention of Shah towards Bihar’s pending dues of Rs 911.82 crore with the erstwhile Planning Commission under the special plan (Backward Region Grant Fund) and urged him to ask the NITI Aayog (which was formed in place of Planning Commission) to send the amount to Bihar at the earliest.

Nitish pointed out that altogether 10 companies of the Central Reserve Police Force (CRPF) stationed in Bihar were sent to other states in the recent past. “Of the 10, only two companies have so far returned to Bihar. I request the Union home minister to ensure early return of the rest eight companies to Bihar,” he said.

Nitish also demanded allotment of Rs 1,000 crore per year to Bihar under the Centre’s project ‘Bringing Green Revolution to Eastern India’ project to enhance agriculture output in the state. He called for formulation of National Silt Management Policy to maintain uninterrupted flow of the Ganga water and check floods in the region.

Title: ‘World-class’ East-West Metro still wows Kolkata but crowd thins in 14 days
Content:
Students take the East-West Metro home from school on Friday

KOLKATA: Scientist Amit Pal’s affair with the East-West Metro started on Valentine’s Day and has continued unabated for a fortnight. But some, like Shakila Khatun, stepped on to the state-of-the-art trains for the first time on Friday. But it was still “love at first ride”.“I have been watching everyone taking rides on the new Metro. Since I live right opposite, I decided to wait for the crowds to thin. And it was worth the wait,” said Khatun, a resident of DL 13/1.However, even though the ridership has dipped, East-West is still the best for people like Pal, who takes a train from Sector V to stadium and walks to Beliaghata ID Hospital. “Green transport and walking through Subhas Sarovar have made me feel younger and happier,” the 56-year-old said.Bookshop owner Anuradha Chowdhury, the daughter-in-law of former Left Front land and land reforms minister Benoy Chowdhury, has ditched her petrol-driven car to take the train to work at her bookshop at EC Market. “Why is the enthusiasm ebbing? I guess it’s the 20-minute interval and early end to services. My shop closes at 9pm, so I can’t take the Metro home,” she said.Dipping ridership notwithstanding, East-West seems to be elevating itself from its “joyride” status. TOI caught up with a group of St Francis Xavier’s School students who have ditched the “uncomfortable bus ride” home for the “world-class Metro”. “We would pay Rs 8 on a bus. Now we pay just Rs 5 and travel in luxury,” said Rishiraj Roy, a Class-XI student from Bengal Chemical.

Title: Rajkot: Prisoner caught with cellphone in boxers
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

RAJKOT: A prisoner in Rajkot Central Jail was booked for allegedly hiding a cellphone in his boxers. Though the crime was reported on Wednesday, the complaint in this connection was lodged on Friday.

Police said accused Yaqubkhan Pathan, was found to be possessing the cellphone. “Jail authorities also recovered a pouch containing tobacco from Pathan’s possession,” said an official from Pradyumannagar police station.

The jail authorities had received a tip-off that Pathan was carrying a cellphone, following which jail official Manoj Lakhtaria frisked him and found the banned items.

“The phone had a battery, but did not have SIM card. We have sent the phone to forensic department for examination. We are investigating as to who had provided Pathan with the cellphone,” added the official.

It may be recalled that recently a person was caught for allegedly throwing cellphone, charger and pouches of tobacco inside the premises of Rajkot Central Jail.

Title: Rajkot: Police raid houses of gang rape accused BJP leader
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

Title: Three arrested for Amreli bootlegger’s murder
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

RAJKOT: The special operation group (SOG) of Amreli police arrested three persons on Thursday night for their alleged involvement in murder of a 27-year-old man killed on Wednesday in Amreli town.

The police said the accused, Murtuja Rawda (24), Samirsha Pathan (23) and Anadu Vala (23), had first tonsured the head of Mayur Sakaria (27) and then dumped his body in front of Jumma mosque in Amreli after beating him up with bats, iron pipes and bottles.

Sakaria was first taken to Amreli Civil Hospital and from there he was shifted to Rajkot Civil Hospital where he succumbed to his injuries.

The accused trio was arrested on the basis of a tip-off while they were going towards Rajkot from Shelkhambhalia village on their two-wheeler.

“During their interrogation, the accused said that Sakaria’s murder was the result of the internal rivalry they had with him in the bootlegging business. The accused alleged that Sakaria used to give tip-offs about their liquor supply to the police. Nursing a grudge against him, they had decided to kill him,” said K D Jadeja, inspector with Amreli SOG .

The accused had taken Sakaria on the bank of Dharangani village river, telling him they had organized a liquor party. Then they attacked Sakaria as part of their conspiracy.

Title: Instagram mentors to teach Kolkata influencers how to blend old-world charm with modernity
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Facebook India’s Manish Chopra with actor Ritabhari Chakraborty and an instagrammer at the event on Friday.

KOLKATA: The city’s passion for food and travel is reflected on the photo-sharing app Instagram , said officials who were in Kolkata to meet local instagrammers on Friday. Kolkata’s old-world charm of Raj-era buildings and monuments, particularly in the central business district and by the Hooghly, along with its high-rises, flyovers, urban spaces and swanky cafes makes for attractive visual landscapes. The photo-sharing app has now launched ‘Born on Instagram’, through which several users from the city will be mentored and taught how to shoot and share visual landscapes where the traditional and the modern come together.

On Friday, over 200 instagrammers gathered for an interaction on rediscovering Kolkata through Instagram lens. “Kolkata has been known for its cultural vibrancy and this is exemplified in the city’s content creators,” said Manish Chopra of Facebook India .

Instagram influencers in the city have been using their ‘followers’ to boost the appeal of several eateries, cafes and tourist spots in Kolkata, promoting them under the term “instagrammable”. “Food, travel and lifestyle have been the main characteristics of the content instagrammers in the city have been posting so far. Kolkata is a very interesting mix of old-world charm and modernity, which is reflected in the pictures that the youth of the city post on the photo-sharing app,” Chopra said.

Several handles, like Calcutta Instagrammers and Streets of Kolkata, capture the daily life in the city — from its streets to local festivals to various modes of transport. Several images of Kumartuli, Howrah bridge, St Paul’s Cathedral and trams have become synonymous with Kolkata on social media. But the app is not just for the youngsters. Chief minister Mamata Banerjee, who joined Instagram a few months ago, already has 50,000 followers. She has shared 175 posts, which are normally behind-the-scenes pictures taken during her visits to the various districts. Kolkata Police , too, regularly interacts with the citizens via Instagram.

Title: Ahmedabad: ‘Leapers’ celebrate Fab February 29
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Hemang Gandhi (L), Sanaya Shah (C), Hitesh Agarwal (R)

AHMEDABAD: Sanaya Roopesh Shah, a BBA student at Ahmedabad University , will celebrate her fifth birthday on Saturday. Surprised?

“I am 20 years old now but this is just my fifth birthday, as I am one of the few whose birthday falls on February 29 , Leap Day,” says Sanaya. “It not only makes the day very special but incidentally all my February 29s have been very special due to grand celebrations they come with. Even on Saturday, I will be in Rajasthan with my family to mark the occasion.”

Known as ‘ leapers ,’ they are an exclusive club who celebrate their birthdays every four years. Hitesh Agarwal, a city-based businessman, said his friends have planned a party for him on Saturday. “In other years, I celebrate my birthday on midnight of February 28, but it never has the same charm. Instead, my friends and I save our resources for grand parties on February 29,” he said.

Hemang Gandhi, a state government employee, believes his birthday has made him unique. “I have been a topper throughout my academic career and bagged five government jobs so far. It certainly is a talking point when people learn that I my birthday is February 29. I feel lucky to have such a memorable birthday which ensures that people never forget it,” said Gandhi.

Title: Bihar’s per capita income rises to Rs 43,000: Deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Sushil Kumar Modi

PATNA: Deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi , who also holds the finance portfolio, said in the state assembly on Friday that the development process in the state was on the track under the leadership of CM Nitish Kumar.

“The state witnessed development activities only during the rule of Shri Krishna Singh. After his death, there started political instability, when the state saw 23 CMs between 1961 and 1990,” Modi said, adding the development exercise was a ‘total washout’ during the 15-year-rule of Lalu Prasad and Rabri Devi.

Modi was giving the government’s reply after the conclusion of the two-day discussion on the Rs 2.11 lakh crore state budget that he had presented in the House on Tuesday. He stressed that the state’s average growth rate at 2011-12 constant prices had remained steady at 10%, while the per capita income had also increased from Rs 30,000 at the 2011-12 constant prices to Rs 43,000 at current prices in 2019-20.

Modi also assured the people of Patna that all the pumping stations and drainage systems would be qualitatively improved before the onset of monsoon, so that there is no repeat of the unprecedented waterlogging that the city faced last year. “Tenders have been invited for the allotment of work to restore pumping stations and drainage system,” he said.

Modi added that of the Rs 1.25 lakh crore package for Bihar announced by PM Narendra Modi in 2015, Rs 53,000 crore was spent on constructing quality roads in the state.

The deputy CM presented a comparative picture of the state’s economy under the 15-year-rule of Lalu and Rabri versus that of the NDA government led by Nitish. Noting that the state’s budget had increased eight-fold since 2004-05, he said the growth rate of the state’s gross state domestic product then was meagre 9% at current prices, and the per capita income at Rs 3,037 in 1990-91 and Rs 8,000 in 2004-05.

“The state’s own tax revenue increased from Rs 3,340 crore in 2004-05 to Rs 30,000 crore in 2019-20 and capital expenditure from Rs 1,140 crore in 1990-91 to Rs 21,058 crore in 2018-19. Further, if the market borrowing of the government was as high as 64% of GSDP in 1990-91, it had come down to 32% in 2019-20, and the fiscal deficit from 6.2% in 2004-05 to 2.7% now,” he added.

Title: Bihar: MLCs seek service rule for contractual teachers
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Legislators, cutting across party lines, erupted in anger in the legislative council on Friday after education minister Krishna Nandan Prasad Verma blamed delay in framing of service rule for contractual teachers and librarians to failure of the committee formed in this regard to hold its meeting.

“Service rule is very important, but it is unfortunate that the committee formed to frame the service rule has not met yet. I will find out the reason behind it,” Verma told the House after a call attention in this regard was brought by CPI MLCs Kedar Nath Pandey, Sanjay Kumar Singh, JD(U) MLCs Sanjeev Shyam Singh, Sanjeev Kumar Singh and Congress MLC Madan Mohan Jha.
