The MLCs had asked the government to explain delay in notification of service rule for contractual teachers and librarians with policy for continuation in their service, monetary increment, promotion to the post of principal and choice transfer.

After Verma’s reply that a committee had been formed to frame service rule for contractual teachers, CPI MLC Pandey said, “You are giving the same reply from past three sessions. Please notify the service rule so that teachers start concentrating on teaching, rather than wasting their energy on protests.”

BJP MLC Nawal Kishore Yadav sought to know whether the committee was superior or the House.

Verma had earlier said that the department had formed a committee on August 11, 2015 with principal secretary or secretary level representatives from finance department, education department, general administration department, urban development and housing department and panchayati raj department.

“The committee had recommended revised salary for contractual teachers and librarians on May 15, 2017. Subsequently, as per department’s resolution, their salary was increased 2.57 times of their basic pay. Accordingly, they were given revised financial benefit from April 1, 2017. As per the resolution taken on October 11, 2017, they were also given dearness allowance, medical allowance and house rent on the revised rates,” the minister said.

Title: No rule framed to curb practice of ‘jaywalking’
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Pedestrians crossing busy road in Patna (File photo)

PATNA: Most pedestrian accidents occur because of jaywalking or crossing a busy road unlawfully, claim experts.

The Motor Vehicles (Amendment) Act, 2019 empowers states to regulate the activities of both motorists as well as pedestrians. However, no rules have been made for pedestrians in Bihar under this clause.

According to Sanjeev Sinha, traffic expert from NIT-Patna, behavioural issues and lack of awareness among people are the main reasons behind jaywalking, which is a common sight in the city.

“There are several facilities given to pedestrians that they hardly use. Traffic signals are not just for motorists, but pedestrians as well. However, more that 90% of the people walking on roads do not even know about them,” Sinha told this newspaper.

Talking about the lack of proper footpaths and zebra crossings, Sinha said, “Most footpaths in the city have been encroached upon. A number of them are so high that it becomes difficult for children, elderly people and women to climb them. Besides, some of the busiest areas like the Rajendra Nagar Terminal and Govind Mitra Road do not have zebra crossings.”

Sinha also laid emphasis on the proper construction and designing of roads. He pointed out, “Roads should be designed and built in such a manner that they accommodate the needs of all users.”

If the figures of the transport department are anything to go by, almost 20% of the accidents occur because of pedestrians, who cross roads while vehicles are on the move.

Asked why jaywalking had not been made a punishable offence, transport secretary Sanjay Kumar Agarwal said, “Since it is considered a minor offence, pedestrians are not penalized for it. There are also no rules regarding pedestrian penalties in the MV Act. Hence, we feel educating people and creating awareness among them is more important and effective at the moment.”

He claimed that several initiatives, including crosswalk buttons, were launched for pedestrians in the city few months back.

“These buttons were installed on Hartali Mor, Punaichak Mor and Bailey Road near the Patna zoo. Even then a large number of people can be seen flouting the rules openly,” Agarwal said, adding, “Unauthorized cuts on roads will soon be shut to ensure public safety and avoid mishaps. Also, dividers on airport road, Dak Bungalow road and Saguna Mor are being fenced.”

On his part, traffic superintendent D Amarkesh has deployed more traffic cops at several places in the city. He said, “Bailey Road witnesses heavy traffic throughout the day. Traffic cops in that area have told me that their pleas fall on deaf ears as most people do not use crosswalk buttons.”

Some pedestrians, on the other hand, are of the view that the city lacks proper infrastructure to ensure their safety. “Many areas do not have footpaths or zebra crossings, as a result of which many people violate the rules and regulations,” rued Rakesh Sharma, a pedestrian near Exhibition Road.

Title: Textile traders stare at Rs 200 crore loss due to violence in Delhi
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

SURAT: Communal riots in New Delhi have cast a dark shadow over the business prospects of the country’s largest man-made fabric (MMF) wholesale market in the city. Supply of saris, dress material and other textile products has been affected because of the riots and local traders are staring at losses to the tune of over Rs 200 crore.

Textile traders stated that New Delhi is their largest market and that they daily supply textile products worth Rs50 crore. However, the trade now remains suspended ever since the violence broke out and transporters refuse to accept goods to New Delhi.

Industry sources said New Delhi is gateway for supply of textile products to Uttar Pradesh, Jammu & Kashmir, Haryana and Punjab.

Federation of Surat Textile Traders Association (FOSTTA) president Manoj Agarwal said, “New Delhi is largest market for Surat fabrics. The communal violence in New Delhi has paralysed textile trade, affecting supply of fabrics to the tune of Rs200 crore in the last few days.”

Textile traders stated that apart from saris and dress material, New Delhi is the largest market for home-furnishing clothes, duppatas, lehngas, salwar suits, gowns and kurtis manufactured in Surat.

Krishna Banka, a textile trader at JJ A/C market, said, “All our buyers in New Delhi have stopped giving us orders. The trade between Surat and Delhi has got suspended. We pray that communal tension in New Delhi calms down. We supply about Rs10 lakh worth of saris and dress material to New Delhi in a month.”

Surat Textile Goods Transporters’ Association (STGTA) president Yuvraj Deshle said, “Daily 45 transport trucks leave from Surat to New Delhi. The transporters have halted supply fearing losses to trucks and fabrics. We will resume the services once New Delhi returns to normalcy.”

Title: 300-foot wide road to connect Rajkot with AIIMS
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

File photo of the land finalized for the AIIMS near Parapipariya village

Title: Gujarat: Two more arrested for Bhavnagar jeweller’s kidnapping
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

RAJKOT: In the alleged kidnapping case of the owner of a jewellery showroom in Bhavnagar on January 29, police arrested two more accused on Friday.

“We had received a tip-off that the accused, Naresh Kotar and Hasmukh Chad, were hiding in Himmatnagar, following which we sent teams of Bhavnagar special operation group and local crime branch to Himmatnagar and nabbed them,” said Ashok Kumar, Bhavnagar range DIG.

The teams also recovered gold jewellery worth Rs 20 lakh and the car used in the crime from the accused duo.

Earlier, the police had arrested Rohit Kotar (30), Yashpalsinh Chudasma (28) and his brother Shaktisinh Chudasma (27) on Wednesday.

It was during their investigation that the trio had revealed the names of Naresh and Hasmukh as the co-accused.

Rohit, Yashpalsinh and Shaktisinh had allegedly kidnapped Mukesh Jodhvani (43) from his residence in Prarabhda Residency at Bhangli Gate in Hill Drive locality of Bhavnagar.

The accused had demanded the ransom of Rs 50 lakh cash and jewellery worth Rs 50 lakh, and only after receiving the ransom did they free Jodhvani. The accused had kidnapped Jodhvani in their car after stopping his two-wheeler near his residence. The accused had threatened Jodhvani with firearms and knives.

Police had recovered Rs 12.10 lakh cash, two cars and two cellphones from the trio arrested on Wednesday.

Title: Bicycle sharing project starts at Ankleshwar GIDC
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

The idea on the bicycle sharing project was mooted by ABC during the recently held cyclo-walkathon organized i... Read More

SURAT: Taking a cue from diamond city , notified area authority of Ankleshwar GIDC and Ankleshwar Bicycle Club (ABC) have jointly started a bicycle sharing project on a pilot basis at the GIDC Joggers’ Park. The idea behind the pilot project is to promote cycling for healthy living among residents in the industrial town.

The idea on the bicycle sharing project was mooted by ABC during the recently held cyclo-walkathon organized in the Ankleshwar town in this month in which more than 1,200 cyclists from across the district had participated to promote healthy living and green environment.

At present, the ABC has started the pilot project with 11 bicycles—five bicycles donated by Ankleshwar notified area authority, five by the ABC and one bicycle donated by the Surat bicycle club.

Naresh Pujara, convenor of ABC, told TOI, “Around 4,000 people use the huge joggers’ park in Ankleshwar GIDC during morning and evening hours daily. However, we thought of starting the bicycle sharing project on the lines of the one started by the Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC).”

Pujara added, “We are charging a token amount of Rs 10 for half an hour ride and Rs 20 for one hour ride from the people wanting to use the bicycle at the joggers’ park. The amount collected from the bicycle usage will be utilized for purchasing new bicycles.”

The ABC has plan to start bicycle sharing project in the entire Ankleshwar town in the coming months following the success of this pilot project.

Kiran Modi, owner of a pharma company in Ankleshwar and member of ABC said, “The response from the citizens is overwhelming and we are inspired to roll out the project in other areas of the town as well.”

Ashok Chovatiya, chairman of Ankleshwar GIDC notified area authority, said, “Ankleshwar is an industrial town and we have taken an initiative to promote bicycling among the residents. We have donated five bicycles for the pilot project and are ready to donate even more in the coming days.”

Title: ‘Law not always competent to meet new tech challenges’
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Surat: “Law has never been ahead of technology. We are forced to frame new laws to meet the challenges arising from new technologies,” Dr. Subramanian Swamy, BJP Rajya Sabha MP , said here on Friday.

Dr Subramanian Swamy, who inaugurated the ‘Sixth Auro National Moot Court Competition’ at AURO University’s campus, described ‘regulation of autonomous vehicles’, the theme of the competition, as an interesting subject of debate. There is a need to discuss technological innovations and how good the law is to deal with their consequences, he added.

The competition aims at providing a platform to students to do research and debate on the challenges arising as a result of advancement in technologies such as driverless cars etc, said Dr. Rohit Singh, dean (academics), AURO University.

Twenty-two teams from across the country, including from national law universities, are taking part in the national-level competition being organized by AURO University’s School of Law. It will conclude on Sunday.

Title: Dressed to rob, beware of ‘dulhans’ on UP's highways
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

PRAYAGRAJ: Imagine driving down a deserted highway at night, when you spot a woman seeking a lift. What would you do? Most of us would stop and offer the damsel in distress a lift.

Well, your efforts as a Good Samaritan might not always be good for you. For this certainly was the case with the dozens of truck drivers who ended up being looted by thugs dressed up as village women, when they stopped to help the said damsel.

Touted as a revamped version of the infamous ‘ looteri dulhan ’ gang — where women married innocent youths only to flee after robbing the groom and is family a day after the wedding — the new brand of crooks refer to themselves as the ‘dulhan gang’ and have targeted more than 20 drivers in Prayagraj , Bhadohi and Varanasi in the past few months.

The gang’s activities came to light after the arrest of one its members Gyan Chandra on Wednesday. A resident of Upardaha village in trans-Ganga area of the city, the 25-year-old youth has been involved in robbing over a dozen truck drivers in the past. Police said that Chandra has been sent behind the bars more than thrice.

According to police, the gang’s members are aged between 18 and 25 years. Clad in ‘chunari’ and ‘ghaghara’, they stand on deserted roadsides of the Prayagraj–Varanasi highway, seeking lifts and then target innocent commuters.

SSP (Prayagraj) Satyarth Anirudh Pankaj said, “The members of the gang wear ghagharas and dupattas and usually stand on the roadside of the Prayagraj-Varanasi highway at night. When they see a truck coming their way, they flash a torch in the drivers’ direction to indicate that they need a lift.”

“Most truck drivers mistake them for prostitutes and often stop to allow them into their cabins. However, once the gang members enter the cabin, they are surprised to see a man instead of a woman. By then it’s too late to do anything and they end up being robbed at gunpoint or knife-point,” the SSP added.

“The gang members usually cover their faces under a chunari, so that the truck drivers are not able to see their faces. Once they enter the truck’s cabin, they rob truck drivers after tying their hands and legs.”

Pankaj said that most of the gang’s members are from Upardaha and nearby villages. The gang has been active since the past one-year-and-a half.

Police records show that Chandra got a bail about two months back in connection with a road hold-up case in Bhadohi.

Chandra also told the police that he had tried to rob a truck driver two days on Prayagraj – Mirzapur route two days back.

Police also seized four crude bombs from his possession.

Meanwhile, Handia police have identified five more members of the gang and are raiding possible hideouts to nab them.

Title: KMRC strengthens Bowbazar buildings on Urvi route
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Iron props set up in one of the buildings in Bowbazar to strengthen it.

KOLKATA: The Kolkata Metro Rail Corporation ( KMRC ) on Friday carried out strengthening of buildings in Bowbazar where occupants alleged that cracks have appeared during the second stint of Metro tunnelling.

TBM Urvi is currently at work below Chaitan Sen Lane . On Thursday, locals had alleged that ever since Urvi started digging on February 18, fresh cracks have appeared on the walls of buildings, which fall within 30m radius of the TBM’s route.

On Friday, the KMRC team started strengthening the structures with iron props and carried out other safety procedures. The team, led by chief engineer Biswanath Deewanjee, spent the entire morning assuring residents that all steps are being taken to ensure there is no repeat of the accident on August 31.

Sukalyan Dutta, a businessman living at 11, Chaitan Sen Lane, said, “The chief engineer said all kinds of measures are being taken during and after the tunnelling. Some repairs have been carried out, but we have told him that we don’t need superficial repairs. Concrete measures must be in place so that the building can withstand the upheaval 15m below the ground. We just hope KMRC keeps its promise.” Ward 51 councillor Sanchita Mondal was present at the spot when Deewanjee told the residents that the hairline cracks that had surfaced were superficial. They were mostly fissures and would not affect the structural foundation of the buildings.

Apart from strengthening the buildings with iron props, the team also carried out grouting and installed crack-and-tilt meters to identify ground settlement and assess if the cracks were widening. “Our strengthening activities involve improving structural performance to enable the buildings to fulfil new functional requirements, which includes curbing ground settlement that the movement of the TBM may or may not have caused,” an engineer said. He added that the agency would keep monitoring and submit a status report to experts who would, in turn, submit them to the Calcutta High Court .

Title: LJP chief Chirag Paswan asks BJP to take action against Kapil Mishra, Giriraj Singh
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Chirag Paswan

BIHARSHARIF/PATNA: LJP chief and Jamui MP Chirag Paswan on Friday said the BJP should take action against all its leaders who make inflammatory speeches.

In Nalanda as part of his ‘ Bihar First, Bihari First’ yatra, Chirag said the NDA recently paid for the communal overtures of BJP leaders in Delhi election. He said BJP should immediately take action against Kapil Mishra and Giriraj Singh.

Chirag lauded CM Nitish Kumar for improving basic infrastructure in the state and improving health and education sectors. He, however, expressed concern over “poor” law and order in the state.

The LJP chief maintained that NDA was intact and all its allies would fight the upcoming assembly election in Bihar together.

“I will release vision document of the party at a rally at Patna ’s Gandhi Maidan on April 14. Every ticket aspirant of the party will be required to 25,000 new members. They will also have to work for the appointment of booth workers,” Chirag said.

On recent meetings between Nitish and leader of opposition Tejashwi Prasad Yadav , Chirag said, “Nitishji is CM and Tejashwiji is the leader of opposition. It is a healthy sign for the democracy that the two leaders have cordial relations.

LJP chief’s plea to PM: LJP chief Chirag Paswan has written to PM Narendra Modi, requesting him to declare December 3, the birth anniversary of first president of India Dr Rajendra Prasad, as ‘National Skills Day’.

Title: Three-day ‘Craft Bazaar’ begins at NIFT-Patna
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

PATNA: A three-day ‘Craft Bazaar’, an exhibition-cum-sale kicked off at the National Institute of Fashion Technology (NIFT), Patna, with zeal and fervour. Altogether 21 stalls were put up by the artisans of Bihar and Jharkhand as well as budding fashion aspirants of the institute.

The event was inaugurated by Padma Bhusan awardee and former principal of College of Arts and Crafts, Patna, Shyam Sharma. The main objective behind the three-day initiative is to promote and facilitate the handicrafts and handlooms created by weavers and artisans.

Around 50 artisans and weavers from Bihar and Jharkhand are participating in the event. The artisans showcased various crafts like Sikki, applique, khatwa, Madhubani painting, paper mache, terracotta, Manjusha art, Sujini, cane and bamboo, Chikankari and attractive motiffs in different patterns of Bhagalpur and Nalanda like Bawan Butietc.

Along with the stalls, awareness workshops were held for the artisans and weavers on current designs and market demand, colour trends, tie and dye, digital marketing, online transactions, organized retailing among others to expose them to the demands of the urban market and means to meet those demands effectively. A special session was conducted for the artisans and weavers in the ongoing open house to introduce them to the admission process of NIFT.

Title: Myanmar President U Win Myint offers prayers at Mahabodhi Temple
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Myanmar President U Win Myint offers prayers at Mahabodhi Temple (PTI photo)

GAYA: Myanmar President U Win Myint arrived in Bodh Gaya on a two day visit. Accompanied by a 28-member delegation comprising first lady Daw Cho Cho , information minister U Kyaw Tin, religious affairs minister Thura U Aung Ko, transport minister Thant Sin Maung and others, the Myanmar president landed at the Gaya International Airport by a special aircraft on Friday morning.

At the airport, the visiting dignitary was received by state building construction minister Ashok Chaudhary, Gaya MP Vijay Manjhi, Magadh divisional commissioner Asangba Chuba, zonal IG Rakesh Rathi, Gaya DM Abhishek Singh and SSP Rajiv Mishra.

Myint, soon after his arrival went to the Mahabodhi Mahavihara, the seat of Lord Buddha’s enlightenment and offered prayers at the shrine.

At the shrine, he gifted a 3-feet tall Buddha image and also went around the shrine premises including the Meditation Park and the Muclind Sarovar. It is believed that Buddha, then Prince Siddhartha, had spent the sixth week of his seven-week-long meditation in the Muclind Sarovar under a snake’s protection.

The visiting dignitary was offered a memento by BCD minister Ashok Chaudhary. Gaya DM Abhishek Singh presented a copy of the Bodh Gaya coffee table book.

Penning down his impressions, the Myanmar president wrote in the visitor’s book, “As a devout Theravada Buddhist I deem it a remarkable and invaluable experience for us to pay homage to the sacred Bodhi tree and to perform meritorious deeds at the temple in Bodh Gaya. On behalf of the Myanmar delegation and my own behalf, I would like to place on record our sincere appreciation to the Government of India for arranging this memorable visit.”

The visiting dignitary also went to the Myanmar monastery and nearby Shaivite Math located to the north east of the Buddha shrine. He also visited the 80 feet high Great Buddha statue built by the Japanese.

Title: Government stake in some PSBs can be brought down: Uday Kotak
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Kotak Mahindra Bank chairman and managing director Uday Kotak (File photo)

PUNE: Kotak Mahindra Bank chairman and managing director Uday Kotak on Friday proposed diluting government stake to below 50% in three of the 12 state-owned banks and running the other three through public-private pa-rtnership. Kotak said he did not advocate moving away from state-owned banks, but state ownership, in some of them, could be reduced.

“After the merger of various state-owned banks, we are now down to 12 public sector lenders. I still believe we need to have a six-three-three formula. Six banks should remain in the public sector. In three others, state ownership should go below 50%. And for the rest, we should think out-of-the-box and find a transparent way for public-private partnership, with domestic and non-domestic players,” Kotak said, while speaking at the Asia Economic Dialogue here.

Kotak said India was at the cusp of making some serious choices in the financial sector and people needed to ask some tough questions. “India nationalised its banking system in 1969. I want some analysis on the amount of taxpayers’ money that has been put into these banks from 1969 to 2020…Then we need to ask that over a period of 70 years, what is the return to the taxpayers on the crores of rupees that have been put into the state-owned banks?” Kotak asked.

He added he saw a potential battle for the global financial technology order in the future, between Western and Chinese systems, currently exemplified by the debate over 5G wireless technologies that were being aggressively marketed by Chinese companies.

Title: Rs 252cr for roads in 10 dists
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

PATNA: Road construction department (RCD) on Friday sanctioned a sum of Rs 252crore for redevelopment of 16 roads in 10 districts across the state.

According to a statement issued by the department, the bidding committee sanctioned funds for strengthening and redevelopment of total 138km stretch of roads in the districts. The statement quoting road construction minister Nand Kishor Yadav said that all the 16 projects will be completed within six to 18 months.

“The roads which have been approved for redevelopment are in Buxar, Vaishali, Siwan, Darbhanga, Aurangabad, Patna, Rohtas, Katihar, Purnia and Samastipur among other districts,” Nand Kishor said.

Regarding Patna, the bidding committee of RCD has sanctioned funds to the tune of Rs3.25crore for redevelopment of road number 2 to 5 in Kankerbagh Colony. Three projects have been approved in Vaishali district, which will be executed utilising an estimated outlay of Rs39.69crore. Similarly, funds to the tune of Rs 98.88 crore will be spent on strengthening and widening of five roads in Samastipur district.

Also, Rs 22.13crore will be spent for redevelopment of Dhansoi- Dinara road in Buxar district and R13.05crore for redevelopment of Hardia Mor to Siswan Dhala road in Siwan district.

Similarly, Rs10.07crore will be spent for Kochas-Shivsagar-Senari road in Rohtas district and Rs29.03crore will be spent on redevelopment of Kalikapur-Dumar via Barari road in Katihar district. A sum of Rs 20.71 will be spent on redevelopment of Darbhanga-Samastipur road. Funds to the tune of Rs 3.31crore have also been sanctioned for a bridge on Ramrekha river under Amba-Navinagar road in Aurangabad district.

“All officials and engineers concerned have been instructed to ensure highest quality in construction and redevelopment of roads. Instructions have also been given to ensure that projects are completed by the given deadline without fail,” Nand Kishor said adding that all eight decisions of the bidding committee have been uploaded on the official website of RCD (rcd.bih.nic.in) for complete transparency.

Title: Poor quality of steel being used in Gandhi setu reconstruction: Opposition
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

PATNA: Opposition MLCs from RJD and Congress protested outside the Bihar legislative council on Friday against alleged use of inferior quality of steel in Mahatma Gandhi Setu reconstruction work.

Talking to reporters at the entrance of the legislative council, Congress MLC Prem Chandra Mishra said low quality of steel worth over Rs 1,000 crore was purchased for reconstruction of the bridge. The MLC also expressed concern over delay in completion of the project.

The 38-year-old Setu is being rehabilitated with the use of triangular steel truss and the work for the same had started in February 2017. “As per the contract, rust-free steel structure of high quality was to be used in the bridge rehabilitation work. However, the same is not being used. The consultant hired for the project was blacklisted by Gujarat and Bihar governments earlier,” Mishra said.

He added that Gandhi Setu division executive engineer Sunil Kumar Singh and resident project engineer I N Mishra were removed from the project after they gave a written complaint about use of sub-standard material for the construction work. “The then team leader for this project, Prashant Bhattacharya, was also removed from the project after he submitted a written complaint,” Mishra said.

State road construction minister Nand Kishore Yadav, however, said the rehabilitation work was being done by central government and the state had no role to play in it.

“He (Mishra) had raised same question in the House earlier as well and I had answered his query. Those who are surrounded by corruption only see corruption everywhere,” Yadav said.

Title: EEPC looks to bring more SMEs into exports net
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Chennai : Engineering exporters will meet in Coimbatore to draw up a blueprint to bring in more small scale businesses under the export umbrella, in its pursuit to push up Indian exports beyond $81 bn recorded last year. Engineering Exports Promotional Council (EEPC) India will organise its ninth edition of its flagship event International Engineering Sourcing Show (IESS) in Coimbatore from March 4-6, 2020. While EEPC has already held IESS editions - five in Mumbai and three in Chennai, the Coimbatore event has turned out to be the largest such event.

While Malaysia is the partner country, Tamil Nadu will be the partner state for the event, which will have 400 exhibitors displaying their wares. Over 400 foreign delegates are participating in the event, which will also have 10 thematic sessions including Vendor Development Meets with MNCs from several countries.

“India’s engineering exports, which was $81 billion last financial year, stood at $64 billion till January, 2020. While the last quarter of the fiscal is the best phase for registering higher growth, we hope to push exports this year,” Ravi Sehgal, chairman, EEPC India said.

But, Sehgal outlined global challenges that need to be overcome by the Indian industry. The protectionist approach of the US and Europe has been an issue. From being a net exporter of copper, India has now become a net importer of copper. There are a few challenges to overcome, he said.

“The corona virus epidemic has already affected the global logistics industry. It may take about three months for us to assess the impact on India,” he said.The US – China trade war had made several businesses to look at India. “But our lack of capacity was a problem. We have to increase the capacities of our MSMEs. We are discussing this with Union minister Nitin Gadkari to look at way to improve the capacities, since we need to urgently scale it up to meet any eventual increase in demand,” Sehgal said.

Title: Rumbling sounds in Hingoli, but no tremors
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Aurangabad/Pune: The residents of two villages in Kalamnuri taluka of Hingoli district ran out of their homes around 2am on Thursday after hearing a rumbling sound in the ground. The sound lasted for around 10 minutes, sparking fears of an earthquake, villagers said.

However, the Hingoli district administration on Friday said the sound was not linked to either an earthquake or a tremor. “The residents of Bothi and Maldhaunda villages heard the mysterious sound, discussed the development and went back to sleep after some time. Some of them alerted the administration,” Kalamnuri tehsildar Kalashchandra Waghmare told TOI.

Waghmare visited the villages with police officials on Friday. “Everything is normal. None of the houses have developed any crack or losses,” he said.

Sources in the India Meteorological Department’s seismic department told TOI that while there was no earthquake recorded in and around Hingoli on February 27 early morning, tremors of 2.5 on the Richter scale were recorded 133km south of Akola around 3:47 am on February 27. They said more analysis will have to be done to find out these tremors had any connection with the rumbling sound in the Hingoli villages.

The siesmograph centre at Latur too has not recorded any tremors in Hingoli.

Title: School bus mows down owner’s son
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Jaipur: A 5-year-old boy was crushed to death by a schoolbus when he came on the road while playing, in Jhunjhunu on Saturday morning. He died on the spot.

Incidentally the bus, which mowed Mohit Saini down, belonged to the school owned by his father.

Bhagwan Sahay, SHO, Udaipurwati police station, said, “The child was visiting his aunt’s house and the bus had come to pick a few children when Mohit came in front of the vehicle and was crushed under it as the driver did not see him.”

The bus belonged to the school owned by the child’s father, the official said, and added, “We have registered a case against the driver. We will initiate an investigation soon.” Officials are also unsure if Mohit’s father will in fact lodge a case at all. The child’s body was handed over to the family after post-mortem.

Title: Delhi high court seeks governments’ response on plea for NIA probe
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Delhi high court

NEW DELHI: Delhi high court on Friday sought response from the Centre and AAP government on a PIL seeking a probe by the National Investigation Agency (NIA) into the violence and its funding in northeast Delhi over the Citizenship (Amendment) Act. The plea also wanted cases to be lodged against Congress member Salman Khurshid and AIMIM members Waris Pathan and Asaduddin Owaisi for allegedly provoking citizens against CAA.

A bench of Chief Justice D N Patel and Justice C Hari Shankar issued notices to the ministry of home affairs, Delhi government and police seeking their stand on the plea by Ajay Gautam, urging the court to direct the Centre to order NIA to find out the “anti-national forces” behind the agitations and to probe the role of People’s Front of India (PFI), which is allegedly “funding, motivating and supporting the protests”.

It said protests have been on the lines of Palestine, where children and women were used as a shield for carrying out anti-national activities. It also sought an investigation into the role of PFI and who was funding, motivating and supporting these alleged anti-national protests.

It also sought an investigation against “anti-India forces, who are allegedly openly threatening to kill the Prime Minister and home minister, which is evident from the videos gone viral in social media and direct the state authorities to normalise the situation for the sake of convenience of the general public.”

It wanted directions to identify the roads blocked by protesters over CAA and immediate clearance of these roads. The plea also sought action against several Opposition members and social activists for allegedly provoking protesters at Shaheen Bagh.

Title: HC notice to state EC, civic body over ward formation manipulation
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Aurangabad: The Aurangabad bench of Bombay high court on Thursday issued notices to the state election commission (SEC), Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC), state government and other authorities following a petition challenging the legality, propriety and correctness of illegal delimitation and ward formation for the upcoming civic elections.

The petitioner, Sameer Rajurkar, a former corporator, has moved court challenging the ward formation process and accusing the authorities concerned of manipulating population ratio in at least 28 wards and reserving wards for SC/STs to help some political leaders.

He also pointed out that false records were prepared and the wards were abruptly changed.

The petition said: “Population of municipal area is required to be divided into 115 wards and thus the ratio of population per ward comes to 10,769. A difference of 10% is permissible in this ratio. Thus, maximum population limit per ward is 11,747 whereas the minimum is 9,611. As population per ward has nexus with reservation of seats of SC/ST, the EC has directed that only in exceptional case, the ratio of population can cross the minimum or maximum limit. However, during the current ward formation, due to interference of political persons, this ratio of population per ward has been violated in 21 places. The entire ward formation and consequent reservation is thus tampered with in 80 wards.’’

It added: “The reservation of scheduled caste and scheduled tribe is required to be carried out in a descending order. For that purpose, the ratio of total population of ward with the ST and SC population is taken into consideration. The data is then submitted to the SEC in schedule 6 and 7 by the AMC. All the wards are arranged in a descending order on the basis of the percentage of SC and ST population. The wards which were reserved earlier are excluded and then other wards are reserved in the descending order. However, while tampering with the SC/ST reservation a mischief is played.”

Following the petition, the high court bench — comprising justices SV Gangapurwala and Shrikant Kulkarni — ordered issuance of notices to the respondents while posting the next hearing on March 5.

Title: Implement Street Vendors Act 2014: Hawkers
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Aurangabad: The hawkers in the market areas of Gulmandi and Paithan Gate staged a demonstration on Friday demanding the implementation of the Street Vendors Act, 2014. in front of the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation office.

The Street Vendors Act, 2014 regulates street vendors in public areas and protects their rights. This comes after the AMC removed the hawkers from the market areas of Gulmandi and Paithan Gate.

Under the Shaheed Bhagat Singh Hawkers’ Union, around 100 hawkers raised slogans against the civic body. Abhay Taksal, the union organiser, said, “AMC has failed to implement the act and instead is trying to develop a conflict between the shopkeepers and the vendors.”

In a meeting with mayor Nandkumar Ghodele on Friday, a delegation of the hawkers’ union placed a set of demands. The Deendayal Antyodaya Yojana-National Urban Livelihoods Mission (DAY-NULM) department of the AMC had initiated a survey of hawkers through a private agency across the city in December. The hawkers union demanded the schedule of the survey to be published in the newspapers and the hawkers in the city should be part of the survey.

“The mayor has agreed to all our demands. If the action is not taken within eight days, we will initiate another agitation,” Taksal said. Three days before the protest, the shopkeepers in the market area met with the municipal commissioner and sought implementation of no hawkers’ zone.

Title: 4.58 lakh youth registered with employment exchanges in Gujarat
Content:
Representative image

GANDHINAGAR: Total 4.58 lakh unemployed youths are registered with employment exchanges in Gujarat , the state government informed the assembly on Friday.In its reply tabled in the house, the government said that in two years, 2,230 youths were able to get employment in the government sector and 7.32 lakh were provided employment in the private sector. On December 2017, 5.38 lakh unemployed youths were registered with the state employment exchanges.The government informed the state assembly that of the 4.58 lakh unemployed in the state, the number of educated youths was 4.34 lakh. Ahmedabad had the highest 38,611 educated unemployed youths where the the government could give government jobs to only 119 youths.The government stated that the 2,230 youths who got government jobs, also include the youths who were employed through various camps organised by the defence forces.Unemployment was main issue of the Patidar agitation of 2015 in the state. The agitation had triggered a backlash from reserved categories, which were not willing to share the reservation pie with the Patidars. The recent protests over Lok Rakshak Dal recruitment policy also saw organisations of reserved and non-reserved categories engaging in a stand-off.The socio-economic review for 2019-20 tabled on Wednesday stated that as on October 31, 2019, a total 4.53 lakh job seekers were registered with employment exchanges, of which 4.30 lakh are educated.According to the report, of the 4.30 lakh educated unemployed, 1.26 lakh had studies up to SSC and 1.31 lakh had cleared their class XII examination. In all, 1.11 lakh were graduates, 25,000 were diploma holders, 16,000 engineering graduates and 21,000 postgraduate degree holders.In 2018, 4.68 lakh fresh candidates were registered with the employment exchanges, and 3.79 lakh candidates were provided employment. In 2019 (up to October), 3.94 lakh fresh candidates are registered with the employment exchanges and 2.81 lakh candidates are given employment.The socio-economic review stated that of the 1.11 lakh graduates who were unemployed, the maximum 45,801 were from arts stream and 29,453 from commerce.

Title: 322 applicants given extra funds under PM housing plan: Report
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

AGRA: A probe into disbursement of funds for the Pradhan Mantri Awas Yojna (Urban) in Agra district has found that some beneficiaries were provided extra funds totaling Rs 2.57 crore than they were entitled to. As a result, while needy applicants are doing the rounds of offices for funds for building their houses, some applicants allegedly having link with officials have been provided the installments twice.

Under the PM housing scheme, central and state governments together provide a monetary assistance of Rs 2.5 lakh to the people of low income group living in urban areas. The sum is provided in three installments for construction of a house on a piece of land owned by the applicant.

The first installment provided to the applicant is Rs 50,000, the second is Rs 1.50 lakh and third Rs 50,000.

In Agra, 226 applicants were provided the first installment and 96 applicants, the second installment twice.

Last year, a probe was ordered into the matter by the state government following numerous complaints. Investigations revealed that a total of 322 applicants were provided the first and second installments two times. It was found that the then project director of District Urban Development Authority (DUDA) and two managers were responsible for the malpractice. They are likely to face action.

SVS Rajput, DUDA, Agra project officer, said, “For now, the state government has ordered that former project officer Anupam Rai and two managers should be given 15 days’ time to recover the funds wrongly transferred to over 300 applicants. State authorities will be taking suitable action if they fail to recover the money. Besides, we will be issuing notice to the beneficiaries to return the excess funds received or else legal action will be taken against them.”

Title: BHU healthcare MoU with Silicon Valley venture
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

University spokesman said BHU has joined hands with Tenacity for establishing and running a world class health... Read More

VARANASI: Banaras Hindu University ( BHU ) on Friday entered into a partnership as ‘sister’ institution with Tenacity, a Silicon Valley venture , to develop affordable and accessible healthcare ecosystem focused on clinical care, education and research.

A memorandum of understanding ( MoU ) in this regard has been signed between BHU and Tenacity.

University spokesman Rajesh Singh said with Tenacity’s key partnerships established in the US, and BHU’s talent in India, the ability to leverage the best of US and India talent would enable a unique value proposition to advance healthcare in India.

“Through its expert medical faculty members and scientists who are dedicated to teaching, research and innovation besides providing quality health care consultation, and infrastructural facilities, BHU has joined hands with Tenacity for establishing and running a world class health care service in India,” he said.

He said since BHU is at the forefront of creating and running best health care services in the region at affordable cost, collaboration of Tenacity with BHU, world class health care services would be possible in India.

Title: Draft rules for land pooling scheme up rights of owners
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Chennai: The draft rules for the state government’s land pooling scheme released on Friday enhance landlords’ rights over their property acquired for infrastructure projects. The government launched the scheme two years ago to acquire land for housing and infrastructure projects.

The rules state that the planning authority shall, where possible, promote the formation of committees to explain the scheme to owners of lands and buildings, and discuss and consult with them when the number of people likely to be affected by the scheme is more than 100. The planning authority should take into consideration all suggestions made and objections raised and hold land surveys and ownership verification meetings, as may be required.

The rules deal with multiple issues relating to land pooling, including for industries. For developing industrial parks by government agencies such as SIPCOT or SIDCO, constitution of a special purpose vehicle to govern the scheme should be considered. All or part of land can be marketed by the government, SIPCOT or SIDCO and the benefits from such sales can be shared with the land owners, instead of returning the unused portions to the land owners, the rules said.

The rules further said if the landlord is not found, the land acquisition notice can be left at his last known place of abode or business or given to some adult member or servant of his family. “At such meetings, the proposed scheme shall be generally described and explained and a minute of each meeting shall be maintained for record,” the rules added.

Title: Delhi schools in riot-hit areas to open only for staff today
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

A school was damaged by mob in northeast Delhi during communal riots (File photo)

NEW DELHI: All Delhi government and government-aided schools in riot-affected northeast and east Delhi areas will open on Saturday for the principals and the staff to assess the situation. School management committee (SMC) meetings will be held the same day.

Earlier, the schools were declared closed till Saturday. But a circular issued by the directorate of education on Friday asked the school heads and the staff to be present on Saturday to assess the condition in their respective areas. They have also been asked to convene SMC meetings. Each SMC comprises a principal, two teachers, a social activist, a MLA nominee and 12 elected parents.

The circular has suggested a comprehensive assessment to “explore the possibility of creating conducive atmosphere for conducting the board examination and the school annual examination.” The schools have been asked to submit their reports with details about the present state of preparedness and the earliest time frame to conduct the examination on Saturday itself.

There are around 130 government schools in northeast Delhi . “…All recognised private schools in these areas are also advised to open schools for the staff and the heads and assess the situation,” stated the circular. The private schools also have to submit the reports to the district education officers.

Title: T-108 makes fields near R’bore its hub, raises security concern
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Jaipur: The forest administration at Ranthambore has once again rung an alarm bell after tigers are venturing out from inhabiting area of the reserve and becoming a threat not just for humans but for themselves as well.

Ranthambore forest officials on Thursday wrote to the state chief wildlife warden (CWLW) Arindam Tomar to take action regarding tiger T-108 which has made its base in the fields close to the reserve. The tiger, which had previously killed a boy, has been out of the reserve for around four months and is creating major problem for the farmers in Sawai Madhopur, who are unable to go to their fields. T-108 has found a conducive environment as it has also found a mate in T-114 because of which it is not returning to the reserve, claimed officials.

Manoj Parashar, field director, Ranthambore Tiger Project told TOI, “T-108, sub-adult tiger named Jai (T-108), which killed the 10-year-old boy has ventured out of the reserve few months back and has made its base on the on the boundary in some fields. This has become a very serious issue for the villagers who are unable to go to the fields due to fear of the tiger. The worst part is that there is a tigress also along with T-108. So essentially, it is getting food, a mate and its own territory because of which the tiger does not want to come back to the reserve. Some action has to be taken to resolve this issue because of which I have written to the chief wildlife warden to look into the matter.”

According to sources, the tiger is also at the risk of being killed by the villagers. The officials further stressed on the fact that the department should consider relocation of few of the tigers from Ranthambore to other reserves. The Ranthambore reserve has a core area of 392 square kilometre, with a buffer zone of 1,342 square kilometre. Of the total area of little over 1,700 square kilometre in RTR, only 600 square kilometre can be used by tigers. According to the data available there are 51 adult tigers in the reserve out of which 25 are female and 26 males. Apart from this there are 13-14 young ones though the exact number is not available.

The number of tigers in Ranthambore is the highest in the state which also means that the tigers keep venturing out of the reserve to look for territory. “The letter to the Warden is essentially centered on the issue of T-108, there is also a suggestion that in it regarding possible relocation of the tigers as they are venturing out of the reserve too often,” added Parashar. The number of tigers in Ranthambore Tiger Reserve (RTR) has increased to the point that the reserve can no longer sustain the big cats that are currently inhabiting the area.

Title: 85% locals: Companies can’t find skilled employees
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

GANDHINAGAR: Labour and employment minister Dilipkumar Thakore admitted in the assembly that several units in the state have not been following the government direction to employ 85% of the local youths.

Taking part in a discussion on whether 85% employment was being provided by Maruti Suzuki and Hero Honda companies to the locals, Thakore said that the companies have not been getting skilled manpower as a result they are forced to employ people from outside the state. Thakore was replying to a question of Bechraji MLA Bharatji Thakore. He called upon the MLA to join hands with the government and ensure that the units in the state get skilled manpower.

Title: Help curb cheating cases during HSC exams: Beed collector to journalists
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Aurangabad: Beed district collector Rahul Rekhawar, in order to curb cases of cheating during the ongoing HSC examinations, has sought the help of journalists.

On Thursday, Rekhawar requested the journalists across the district to keep a close watch on all examination centres and photocopy shops, and send him photographs along with the name of the centre where cheating is being carried out.

The district administration had earlier issued a directive to photocopy centres — within 100m radius of the examination halls — to keep their shops closed from 10am to 6pm on examination days.

Rekhawar has also asked the journalists to send him name and address of the shops around exam halls with the photographs that remain open while examination is going on.

Beed ZP CEO Ajit Kumbhar, while speaking to TOI, said they are getting information about malpractices from different sources. “The appeal made to the journalists is on this backdrop. With the help of a tip-off from a journalist we were able to catch a dummy candidate from Nirgudi centre of Patoda Taluka on Friday,” he said.

Both, Rekhawar and Kumbhar, have issued a number of directives to prevent cases of copying or malpractices during the examination.

A team of Class I and Class II officials have also been appointed at each examination centre for keeping strict vigil. Teachers appointed as invigilators are sent on duty to other schools and to the school that they are teaching.

Nets have been installed on windows of the examination halls to prevent passing of chits or other material inside the hall from outside. “Candidates are also required to undergo frisking before entering the examination hall,” Kumbhar said, adding that police force has been scaled up in 24 sensitive examination centres in the district.

Title: Conference on bio-engineering and regenerative medicine begins at IIT-BHU
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Varanasi: The three-day Indo-US International conference on Bio-engineering and Regenerative medicine (ICBR -20) commenced at School of Biochemical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Banaras Hindu University on Friday.

According to convener Prof Pradeep Srivastava, more than 30 speakers and 150 research scholars are taking part in the conference. The conference aims at creating an effective platform for the exchange of innovative ideas and research in the field of bio-engineering and regenerative medicine to accomplish a healthy and sustainable economy. The thematic areas of the conference include important sessions on fields bio-pharmaceutical and medical biotechnology, bio-process and bio-separation engineering, bio-chips, bio-sensors, bio-materials, tissue engineering, and regenerative medicine.

The conference is also being attended by international convener Prof Chenzhong Li and co-convener Prof Ranu Jung and Prof Emilia Entcheva from Florida International University (FIU), Miami, USA. The conference aims to increase bilateral cooperation in academic exchange and technology development with social relevance to humankind, especially in India. It also aims to improve the research ecosystem of Indias higher education institutions by facilitating academic and research collaborations between Indian institutions and the top global Institutions.

Title: Debarred colleges made exam centres by Agra varsity
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

AGRA: Major malpractices have surfaced with regard to determination of exam centres by Dr Bhimrao Ambedkar University . Colleges where mass cheating was reported in the previous years have been made exam centres. In violation of the state government orders, some exam centres are 70 km away from parent college. Besides, no physical inspection of colleges has been conducted by the university administration to check availability of CCTV cameras and voice recorders in classrooms as mandated by the state government.

Agra University’s main examinations for 2019-20 are scheduled to start on March 2. To conduct the exam, university administration has selected 45 nodal centres and 365 exam centres. A list of all these centres has been uploaded on the university website.

General secretary of the University Teachers Association Nishant Chauhan said, “The determination of the exam centres has been done in complete violation of the standard norms and state government orders. Debarred colleges , where mass cheating took place in 2018 and 2019, have been made exam centres. As per norms, these colleges should not have been exam centres for at least two years.”

He added “According to the government orders, varsity authorities, should look for an exam centre within 5 km radius of a college. In any case, the exam centre should not be more than 10 km away from the college. But university administration has selected exam centres for several colleges which are over 50 km away.”

University registrar Rajeev Kumar said, “The colleges which have been made exam centres in previous years have been included in the list this year. So far, complaints regarding three debarred colleges being made exam centres have been received. All such exam centres will be changed. Besides, changes will be made in the exam centres located over 10 km from colleges. The updated exam centre list will be uploaded on the varsity website soon. We are committed to conducting fair examinations.”

Title: Mumbai: Govt lays foundation for vertical universities in highrises
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image.

MUMBAI: The classroom is on the 80th floor. Universities are going northward. With absolute no requirement for land, a university in Mumbai’s island city can now be housed on the 50th floor of a shiny corporate tower or find a home in a hotel wing.

The old charm of large stone public varsity headquarters, snaking academic corridors, stained glass convocation halls, all seem to be the reserve of the far-flung urbs and the countryside. With the city falling short of large land pockets, the state government has decided to allow edupreneurs to set up vertical university campuses. Mumbai will be the first city in the country to permit such an arrangement.

“Essentially, a private university is required to have 10 acres of land and 1.5 lakh of constructed area. But with just no such land parcel now available in Mumbai south and central, one needs to look at allowing universities to grow vertically. The 10-acres requirement will be hence done away with. One will only look at the constructed square foot space,” said a source.

The government has set up a committee to understand and debate what ought to be the rules governing such educational enterprises. The panel is headed by former chief secretary Jayant Banthia and has Vijay Khole and Rajan Welukar, both former Mumbai University V-Cs, as members. The panel will understand the experiences of vertical universities in other countries and study whether the UGC guidelines would permit such development and what ought to be the student strength. “Can an existing educational enterprise in Mumbai be awarded a vertical university status?” is another point that needs to be answered.

Then, there’s the fundamental question on student facilities, hostels, sporting areas. “Will these universities merely be teaching-learning laboratory spaces or will they offer what other varsities have like a sporting complex, canteens, hostels?”

A government notification said the number of students seeking higher education opportunities was growing and just because space in the city is constrained, one cannot live with a low gross enrolment ratio . “A tie-up with a nearby sports club could give students the facilities of recreation, a few floors in a residential building can be converted into a hostel,” said a source.

Former AICTE chairman S S Mantha said, “In the US, there are vertical universities in space starved cities. In India too, they can be started for certain disciplines that do not require large infrastructural requirements and machinery. Most important, there must be quality assurance and not just accreditation, that must be given, the trust must own the facility so that student interest is protected.”

Title: In UP, wedding videographer shot over ‘wrong angle’
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Victim has been identified as Rohit Kumar

AGRA: A member of a videography crew hired for a wedding shoot was shot dead by a man in heavily inebriated state following a heated argument over the camera’s angle in UP’s Firozabad district late on Thursday.

The wedding procession at Darigapur village of Khairgadh police limits took an ugly turn when Satyendra Yadav allegedly fired two shots from his double barrel shotgun. “The pellets struck two members of the crew. One succumbed due to excessive bleeding while the other recovered after first aid,” said Rajesh Kumar, superintendent of police (rural).

The 20-year-old dead videographer has been identified as Rohit Kumar while Satyendra Kumar sustained pellet injuries. Yadav and his aide Kuldeep fled after the incident. Based on a written complaint of Rohit’s relative Suresh Chandra, an FIR was lodged against the two under IPC section 304 (culpable homicide not amounting to murder).

According to the FIR, camera crew of Dinesh Kumar, Rohit Kumar and Satyendra Kumar were shooting the wedding procession from a chair. “All of a sudden, Yadav and Kuldeep started misbehaving with the videographer’s crew. They were unhappy with the angle the team was using to shoot the video. Soon, Yadav shot Rohit on his left knee and his colleague on the right leg,” the FIR read.

Yadav runs a private school, according to sources, and the wedding procession was passing through his property. “Our team is now searching for the two suspects. We have recovered the weapon used. The firearms license of the accused will be revoked,” SP Kumar added.

Meanwhile, Rohit’s relatives staged a protest against the local police on Friday. They alleged that the police “changed” their written complaint of FIR under IPC sections 302 (murder) and 307 (attempt to murder) to “culpable homicide not amounting to murder”.

Title: Realty regulator fines builder Rs 30 lakh
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: Pulling up a developer for misrepresenting facts, the Tamil Nadu Real Estate Regulatory Authority ( TNRERA ) on Thursday slapped a fine of Rs 30 lakh and cancelled the registration of the project.

The case pertains to a project named ‘Bloom’ at Thirumudivakkam in the western suburbs developed by Casagrand Builder Private Limited. V Sangeetha, who booked a unit in the housing project, alleged that the developer had provided false information to obtain registration from TNRERA for a villa township project by projecting it as a layout. The complainant also said handing over of her villa was delayed.

The developer denied the charges saying there had been no false reporting with regard to project registration.

Hearing both sides, TNRERA observed that it was clear from the brochure and various documents that it was a residential housing project and not merely a layout of residential plots as contended by the developer and levied a fine of Rs 30 lakh for misrepresentation. It also cancelled the project approval.

Title: It’s a long wait to land at Chennai airport
Content:
More than 30 planes approach the airport for landing during peak hours (File photo)

CHENNAI: Despite modern air traffic control procedures, pilots are forced to hover over the city waiting for clearance to land at the airport . Forced to circle one above the other for up to 15 minutes during peak hours, each plane burns up to 600kg of fuel in the process.Earlier, air traffic controllers asked pilots to hover or be on hold when there was smog. But it’s done on most days during peak hours now. Ground delays due to inadequate number of taxiways, parking bays and back-to-back schedules given out to flights are blamed for such delays. More than 30 planes approach the airport for landing during peak hours.Planes put on hold are told to fly over four points near Chennai — over Tirupati, over the Bay of Bengal parallel to Tirupati, over Sriperumbudur and over Puducherry — so they can come in to land when runways and taxiways are clear.“We burn around 600kg of jetfuel hovering over the city during peak hours because of air traffic congestion. Airlines tell us to carry extra fuel needed for hovering while flying to Chennai. This is in addition to the mandatory fuel that is needed for diversion to the nearest airport, Bengaluru,” a senior pilot said. The pilot said flying to Chennai is considered a risk and is expensive during peak hours because of this. He added that Bengaluru airport too faces the same issue, especially at night.“Sometimes more than five flights queue up for landing. If there are departures at that time, the wait increases and so does the need for fuel. Airports Authority of India (AAI) has told airlines that they have been revamping air traffic control procedures to prevent planes from hovering around waiting for landing permission. But that has not helped.”AAI introduced PBN (performance-based navigation system) to ensure that planes can come in a queue and land without hovering around. But this is not happening during peak hours due to limitations on the ground.The congestion has had an impact on the turnaround time of international flights operated by foreign airlines. On most days, flights to London, Frankfurt, Dubai and Hong Kong gets delayed because the airports authorities are not able to handle the planes coming in and make ground operations quicker, said an airport official.

Title: 65% Sanskrit colleges run without principals in Raj
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Jaipur: In a major boost for Sanskrit education, chief minister Ashok Gehlot had announced Rs 106 crore in the budget. However, out of 30 Sanskrit government colleges in the state, post of principal is vacant in 20 which translate into 65%.

The lack of principals in 20 colleges was informed by the government to the assembly.

For the post of lecturer, the condition is more pathetic as there are 188 sanctioned posts out of which 93 are vacant. So, 50% lecturers’ posts are vacant in the state where government claims to be working for the development of the standard of Sanskrit education. There are 12 Sanskrit PG colleges and 18 UG colleges in 17 districts in Rajasthan . As per the reply given, lecturers were last recruited in 2005 after which no vacancy has been filled.

This question was asked by state BJP president Satish Poonia in the House on February 26.

Poonia says, “Since the Congress government has come to power, it can be seen that they are not inclined towards preserving the ancient Indian educational system. Ashok Gehlot is ignoring Ayurveda, Yoga and Sanskrit education. I think they considered it to be saffronisation of education system although it is related to our heritage. They haven’t allotted a single penny to yoga in this budget. They are not serious about taking Sanskrit forward.”

The situation is even more complex in Jagadguru Ramanandacharya Rajasthan Sanskrit University (JRRSU) where the university is functioning without professor. The last professor of state’s only Sanskrit university retired in June 2019. At present, there are 52 sanctioned posts for professors, associate professors and assistant professors out of which 28 are vacant.

A university faculty said that government is claiming to improve the research facility in Sanskrit university whereas there are no faculty. “How is the condition of research will improve when there are so many posts vacant in the university? Last year, university received only 90 forms for 690 seats. This shows the degraded situation of Sanskrit education and the efforts made by the government,” said a faculty member.

Title: Five arrested with 54kg ganja, car
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

PRAYAGRAJ: Five members of an inter-district drug peddling gang were arrested near Trivenipuram Road on Friday along with 54.5kg ganja , a car , a bike, five mobile phones and Rs 4,700 in cash.

The quintet have been identified as Pradeep Kumar Sharma of Pratapgarh district and Neeraj Bharatiya, Ajeet Nishad, Akash Jaiswal and Ram Surat Sharma of Raniganj, Daraganj, Mandhata and Baharia, all in Prayagraj, respectively.

Jhunsi inspector AK Chaturvedi said the arrests were made following a specific tip-off about a ganja consignment being handed over in Trans-Ganga area. “The gang had been active in eastern districts of UP,” he added.

In another development, Ghurpur police arrested three local residents — identified as Rajkaran, Jay Singh and Ravi Bharatiya — on the charges of making and selling hooch. Nine furnaces were destroyed at their spurious liquor manufacturing unit while 180 litre of hooch, 80kg of ingredients, 55kg jaggery and 10kg urea were among the items seized.

Naini police, on the other hand, took into custody a tractor-trolley ferrying illegally mined sand near Naini Road on Friday. The driver managed to flee.

Title: TNPSC scam: Government gives nod to prosecute tainted staff
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: The Tamil Nadu Public Service Commission ( TNPSC ) on Friday informed the Madras high court that the state government has given sanction to prosecute government servants who are suspects in the Group-I services exam scam .

Counsel for TNPSC made the submission before a division bench of Justice R Subbiah and Justice R Pongiappan on a plea moved by Swapna, a transsexual candidate, alleging irregularities in the recruitment in 2015. The DMK has moved another plea seeking CBI probe into the allegations.

Recording the same, the bench directed the authorities to file their response to the plea moved by the DMK and adjourned the hearing.

Representing the DMK, senior counsel P Wilson said the scam was orchestrated by those in the highest level of the TNPSC in recruitment to 2016-17 Group-I services. The investigation officer was changed three times due to the pressure exerted by high level ministers, he added. Further, jurisdiction of state police over the TNPSC is questionable, he said, pressing for a CBI probe.

Title: Kiko Casilla: Leeds goalkeeper handed eight-game ban after racism charge
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representational image (Getty Images)

Leeds United goalkeeper Kiko Casilla was banned for eight matches and fined 60,000 pounds ($77,964.00) on Friday after being found guilty of racist abuse in a Championship match against Charlton Athletic last September.

The FA said the 33-year-old Spaniard, who joined Leeds from Real Madrid last year, must also attend face-to-face education after the breach of rule E3 (2) which covers discriminatory abuse.

Casilla had denied using racially abusive or insulting words. Media reports said the incident involved Charlton forward Jonathan Leko, who was born in the Democratic Republic of the Congo but has represented England at various age group levels.

The Spaniard said in a statement on social media that he was "sad and devastated" at being accused and believed firmly that racism should not be tolerated in any walk of life.

"I do not feel at all that the guilty verdict is a clear reflection of the incident," he said.

"I am sure that my family, friends, colleagues and the different technical teams who I have been working with for all these years in my professional career know I would never use my words with a racist meaning," he added.

"My respectful behaviour towards my opponents since I started my career has been honest and with the maximum sense of fairplay."

Leeds acknowledged the decision in a statement but observed that the FA panel "have based their decision on the balance of probability rather than proving Kiko to be guilty beyond reasonable doubt."

Title: Jaipur: Three killed as truck hits bike
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

The truck that crushed three people to death in city on Thursday

JAIPUR: Three people were killed on Thursday night when a truck lost control and hit a bike which had two women, following which the heavy vehicle swerved towards a footpath crushing a man sleeping on it to death in the city. The accident occurred at the government hostel circle in Ashok Nagar police station area.

The deceased Mamta Khichad, 21, and Neha Saini, 22, both make-up artists, were returning home on a two-wheeler when the accident took place around midnight. The truck crushed to death Suresh Bawariya, 30, who was sleeping on the footpath

“The girls were on a bike and the truck was coming from the adjacent side, but neither of them saw each other because of which the deceased came under the heavy vehicle’s tyre. The truck also crushed the person sleeping on the footpath. While Mamta and Suresh died on the spot, Neha died while undergoing treatment at a hospital,” said an official of the accident police station (south).

While Suresh was crushed, his wife and children sleeping next to him were saved as the truck hit a pole.

The women were pursuing make-up artists’ course and were returning after an event.

Truck driver Raju was arrested, and his vehicle seized. Police have also recovered the CCTV footage of the entire episode. According to sources, police are also looking at the possibility that the truck driver was drunk at the time of accident.

“At this point, we cannot rule out any possibility and must check all facts. We have the driver in our custody and will question him further to find out the cause of the accident. The bodies of the deceased were handed over to their families after autopsy,” added the official.

Title: Doctors can’t strike work, says HC, but junks transfer order
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: Doctors don’t have the right to go on strike or boycott work under any circumstance, declared the Madras high court on Friday. “Between the demands of doctors and the lives of the patients, it is life that is more important than anything else,” the court said.

By using strike to resolve issues, doctors, like lawyers, forget the moral worth and dignity of patients and leave them in the lurch, unmindful of the humanitarian consequences of their actions, Justice N Anand Venkatesh said. Patients cannot be a means to an end. They cannot be mere playthings whose lives can be put on the line to achieve other ends through the medium of strikes, he said. “The nature of duty of a doctor is such that the non-availability of the doctor even for a single minute may cost a life,” he said.

The judge, however, quashed the government charge memo to 135 doctors who spearheaded the protest for about a week in October 2019 and cancelled their transfers from Chennai to other locations, and directed the state to restore them to their original positions in the next transfer counselling.

“The action taken by the government by picking and choosing certain doctors and issuing them with the charge memos and transfer orders was not done to bring the situation under control, but it was done to warn the doctors that anyone who spearheads such agitations will be dealt with iron hands,” the judge said.

The doctors had filed the present pleas challenging the transfer and charge memo. At least 18,000 government doctors were on strike from October 25, 2019, across the state pressing various demands, including wage hike. Subsequently, in view of an announcement that no punitive actions would be initiated against them made by the state on October 30, 2019, the doctors withdrew the strike on November 1, 2019.

It is clear from the facts that the chief minister and health minister had requested the doctors to resume work with a promise that their demands will be looked into. Immediately, the agitation was called off. As a model employer, the government ought to have followed up and come out with solutions for the demands made by the doctors. Instead of resorting to such a positive step, the government decided to show its might against the office bearers, the court added.

“The charge memos and the transfer orders issued are clearly tainted with mala fides. If action had to be necessarily taken for the agitation/strike, then it should have been taken against all the doctors who participated in the same. However, the state has chosen to go only against the office bearers and hasty transfer orders have been passed and charge memos have been issued,” Justice Anand Venkatesh said.

Before parting, the judge reminded doctors that the chances of again going on a strike is virtually ruled out and said the court makes a fervent request to the government to immediately address the issues/demands made by the doctors and find a solution.

Title: 5-day week in NMC from Saturday
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Nagpur: Municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe on Thursday announced implementation of five-day working week in the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) from February 29. All Saturdays and Sundays will be holidays, stated Mundhe in a notification. Currently, second and fourth Saturdays are off days for NMC employees.

Along with implementation of the state government’s rule, Mundhe also extended working hours by 45 minutes. Now, the office hours for NMC employees will start at 9.45am and end at 6.15pm. The working hours for class IV (peon) will be from 9.30am to 6.30pm, the notification said.

As per June 4, 2019, government notification, the lunch hours for the civic body employees will be for half an hour from 1.30pm to 2pm. The five days working rule will not be applicable to departments that provide essential services like fire and health (medical).

Title: Six-year-old ‘raped’, killed in UP's Kaushambi
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

Title: Rajasthan: Opposition tears into government over custodial death in Barmer
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Gulab Chand Kataria

JAIPUR: Leader of Opposition Gulab Chand Kataria slammed government for the poor law and order situation in the state leading to the custodial death of Jeetu Khatik in Barmer.

During Question Hour in the assembly on Friday, Kataria asked for compensation for the deceased family, action against the errant police officers and legal provisions for rehabilitation of the dependents of the custodial death victims.

During the day, the Opposition went to the well, raising slogans against the government for increasing crimes in the state.

Responding to the Opposition, parliamentary affairs minister Shanti Dhariwal informed to put Barmer SP under APO and removed the Barmer circle officer.

“The inquiry into the case has been ordered and will be done by additional SP, CID-CB. A case under Section 302 of the IPC has been filed against the police,” explained Dhariwal.

He informed that the government is taking the issue seriously and has sent the ADG, Civil Rights, and the IG of Jodhpur have reached Barmer has failed to convince the opposition Kataria demanded compensation of Rs 1 crore or a package, including a job should be given to the victim’s family and asked the government if they are planning anything to prevent such incidents.

In response, Dhariwal said that victim’s post-mortem is yet to be done which will clear the cause of death is either custodial death or health reasons. “The government has always helped the victims by giving them job or compensation. In this case also the government will help, it will act according to the report,” said Dhaliwal. Till the last report came, the post-mortem of the victim has yet to be done as the family is demanding action against the police officers.

Kataria told the house that Khateek was tortured by the police for the whole night and was arrested without any FIR against him. Dhariwal admitted that police had no complaint against him and he was called in connection with the theft. “The victim was not beaten by the police," Dhariwal's statement invited ire of the speaker C P Joshi who questioned that what police did with the victim during the whole night in custody?

During the pandemonium in the assembly over the issue, Joshi advised the government to speak on the ways to handle such situations. He also asked the government if they are coming up with any legislation to protect and provide any relief to victims and their families. Both the lawmakers engaged in a heated argument over the issue on several occasions. Seeing no meaningful discussion on the subject, Joshi asked the house to defer the discussion till next week and directed the government to come up with some proposal on the subject Rights Resource Centre, an organisation working for Dalits has written to the National Human Rights Commission to ensure that action is taken against the police personnel who allegedly beat up a youth in Barmer which led to his death. The organisation has also asked that the victim's family be provided security as well as monetary compensation

Title: New centre to help Tamil Nadu in optimum clean energy use
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

The centre set up at TNEB headquarters in the city will work to forecast clean energy generation real-time

CHENNAI: In the coming summer, power consumers in Tamil Nadu will get more green power compared to the previous years as TNEB has set up a facility, Renewable Energy Management Centre (REMC), to do real-time renewable energy forecasting, scheduling and generation. The centre was opened by state power minister P Thangamani on Friday.

“REMC enables optimum utilisation of renewable power as it is connected to 154 pooling stations, which evacuate wind and solar power round-the-clock,” said a senior official in the state load despatch centre (SLDC).

Similar centres have been set up in seven states that are rich in wind and solar power generation. Such centres are also functioning at the state load despatch centres in four regions of the country.
