Title: Banned plastics make steady comeback in Trichy
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

People using plastic carry bag in Trichy

TRICHY: Banned single use plastic products are making a slow but steady comeback across the city leaving the authorities virtually clueless about tackling it effectively. Except for the penalties imposed, the authorities have been hesitant to take stern action such as cancellation of trade license of repeat offenders. Traders who once clandestinely circulated the banned plastic products are now doing the same without any remorse.

Trichy corporation had in January 2018 banned plastic carry bags with less than 50 micron thickness which are detrimental to the environment even before the state government banned 16 types of single-use plastics from January 1, 2019. But the civic body has been unsuccessful in its attempts to eliminate such plastics. According to the ban, local bodies have to penalise a shop caught storing and circulating banned plastics three consecutive times. If it is caught again, the trade license certificate, a mandatory document for a shop to carry out the business, can be nullified by the civic body. However, the shops are only being penalised and there is no account of cancellation of trade license of repeat offenders. Taking advantage of this soft approach, shops have been paying the penalties imposed, be they in thousands, but continuing to circulate the banned plastics comfortably.

“The prevalence of banned plastics including plastic carry bags is only increasing because of poor enforcement. NGOs can be roped in to supervise and alert authorities on noticing their sale,” K C Neelamegam, secretary of the eNGO Thanneer, said. Since there are no plastic production units in the city, sources said the plastic is smuggled from other states through godowns on the suburbs. Door delivery of the contraband and assurance to reimburse the penalties levied were the strategy of plastic vendors.

Trichy corporation claimed they are left alone in the battle against plastic. It blamed poor cooperation from other stakeholders including the police department. “Like the seizure of gutka transported on vehicles, police can seize plastic contraband entering the city. Food safety department can enforce the ban in hotels but only we are implementing the ban,” a corporation official said. The official added that they have planned to approach the district administration for a coordinated approach to root out the menace in the city.

Title: UP: Swine flu spreads in PAC camp, 17 personnel test positive
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

MEERUT: At least six persons died and 17 PAC jawans have tested positive for swine flu in the district in the last 48 hours.

Meerut chief medical officer Dr Raj Kumar said, “At least six persons have died of swine flu in the last 48 hours. Out of the 27 PAC jawans of the Sixth Battalion admitted to the Lala Lajpat Rai Memorial Medical College with complaints of fever, cold and other similar symptoms, 17 have tested positive for swine flu. Hence, around 370 jawans in the battalion were given Tamiflu tablets and instructed to remain on the campus to prevent further spread of the infection. With this, the total number of swine flu cases in the district has gone up to 71.” At least nine persons have died of swine flu in Meerut this season.

“We have added 40 more beds in the isolation ward of LLRMMC taking the total number to 56. Similarly, PL Sharma District Hospital and other private hospitals have also been asked to increase the number of beds in isolation wards,” he added.

In the wake of the rising number of swine flu cases, doctors have advised that only one member of the family should be involved in taking care of the infected patient to avoid spread of the disease. They added that city residents should wash hands frequently, wear a mask when in vicinity of the patient and take care of cleanliness inside the patient’s room.

Title: Work in Masi streets will not hit Chithirai festival: Corporation
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Restoration work will be started in all the four Masi streets at the earliest

MADURAI: Madurai corporation has assured the public that Smart City work taken up in the Masi streets would be planned in such a way that it will not affect the movement of the Meenakshi Amman Temple car during the upcoming Chithirai festival. Trade bodies and residents have been urging the civic body to expedite the Smart City work to ensure a smooth conduct of the festival.

Officials said that they are planning restoration work at an additional cost of around Rs 70 lakh to make sure that everything passes off smoothly with minimum inconvenience to devotees thronging from various areas. Restoration work will be started in all the four Masi streets at the earliest, they added.

Corporation took up street landscaping and pathway construction work in the four Masi streets at a cost of around Rs 48 crore which is scheduled to be completed by September. Apart from landscaping and pathway, underground drainage facility, ducting of cables underground and storm water drainage are being provided under the scheme. One side of the roads have been dug up for the construction work, causing inconvenience to traders and residents.

Corporation commissioner S Visakan said work on the dug up stretch has been completed and work to cover the channel is taking place at present. Work on the other side of the street will be taken up after the festival. Soon, restoration work will start in all the dug up stretches in the four streets, he said.

Recently, trade body members staged a protest in West Masi street for speedy completion of the work. Another trade body had urged the civic body to postpone works until Chithirai festival, which starts in April, gets over.

Commissioner said that although inconvenience faced by traders and residents cannot be completely averted, they are carrying out the work in such a way that the impact is minimal.

Title: Wadettiwar shifts MahaJyoti HQ from Pune to city
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Nagpur: Reversing state government’s earlier practice of taking away projects and departments from Vidarbha, Minister for Backward Classes Vijay Wadettiwar has shifted Mahatma Jyotiba Phule Research and Training Institute (MahaJyoti) from Pune to Nagpur.

Hundreds of students from Vidarbha are likely to benefit with this non-profit government Institute meant for research, policy advocacy, training, financial assistance for OBC, SEBC and VJNT communities’ children.

Wadettiwar told TOI, MahaJyoti will start operations from March. “It will open on temporary basis from Social Justice Bhavan near Deekshabhoomi. I will soon develop new administrative building for MahaJyoti in Nagpur,” he said.

Backward Class Welfare Department on Wednesday issued a notification announcing it’s shifting from Pune to Nagpur and named Wadettiwar as chairman. “MahaJyoti was established on August 8, 2019, for social and financial development of students from OBC, SEBC and VJNT. Considering population of OBC, SEBC and VJNT in Vidarbha, the government approved setting up of head office of MahaJyoti in Nagpur instead of Pune for speedy execution of schemes and extending benefits to these communities. Address of MahaJyoti should be changed soon with Registrar of Company,” notification said.

Wadettiwar added, “A state-of-the-art training centre will be developed in Vidarbha soon. I have planned a series of schemes for students of communities covered under MahaJyoti. Routine benefits like library, fellowship, enabling coaching for competitive examinations etc will be also taken care of,” he said.

MahaJyoti is similar to Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar Research and Training Institute (BARTI) established for SC students and Chhatrapati Shahu Maharaj Research Training and Human Development Institute (SARTHI) for students of Maratha and Kunbi communities. These two government non-profits function from Pune.

On August 8, 2019, the then minister Sanjay Kute had announced MahaJyoti with its head office at Pune. Unfortunately, MahaJyoti remained only on paper due to assembly elections followed by uncertainty of government formation.

MahaJyoti is likely to have a budget of Rs 380 crore for the first two years. Umesh Korram, president, Students Rights Association of India (SRAI), said MahaJyoti coming to Nagpur means a lot for entire Vidarbha. “Kunbi along with Maratha are covered under SARTHI. Other castes of OBC were not covered under SARTHI. There was strong demand for another set up specially for all castes of OBC, SEBC and VJNT. Fortunately for Vidarbha. Wadettiwar became minister for OBC, SEBC and VJNT Welfare and he took lead in setting up MahaJyoti. Now, government will have to exclude kunbis from SARTHI as MahaJyoti covers them,” he said.

Korram said entire expense of students for all types of competitive examinations, M Phil and PhD courses etc in country as well as foreign countries will be looked after by MahaJyoti.

Wadettiwar is likely to appoint new members on MahaJyoti. BJP government had appointed 14 government officers in MahaJyoti which will be revised as per notification.

————————

IAN

* Mahatma Jyotiba Phule Research and Training Institute (MahaJyoti) set up for for OBC, SEBC and VJNT welfare by BJP government in August last year

* Its head office was announced as Pune

* It could not start functioning due to elections followed by uncertainty on government formation

* Brahmapuri MLA Vijay Wadettiwar became minister for OBC, SEBC and VJNT Welfare

*Government recently changed its name to Backward Class Ministry

* Wadettiwar shifted MahaJyoti HQ to Nagpur. It will start functioning from March

* Kunbis will be included under MahaJyoti

Title: Era Of Revival Of The Weakest: CM
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Indore: Chief minister Kamal Nath on Friday said that excess agricultural production is the biggest challenge for the state and limited measures to deal with it in absence of equivalent purchasing and procurement capacities continue to remain a challenge.

“Ten or 20 years ago, the challenge in agriculture was shortage, but today the problem is of excess. How do we deal with this excess? Excess means prices fall and poor remuneration to farmers. Sometimes, I think, we made a mistake by getting into high irrigation and high production,” Nath said at the annual meeting of Confederation of Indian Industry (CII) Madhya Pradesh Chapter, themed ‘CII@125: Business & Beyond’.

“With fast changing time and technology, it’s the era of ‘revival of the weakest’ and not the ‘survival of the fittest’. Industry bodies should plan to address forthcoming challenges, such as the young aspirational generation that, if not placed better, will pose a big challenge,” cautioned Nath. Stressing on tapping the state’s potential in food processing and horticulture, Nath said the government is working on a new approach to expand market and ecosystem in agriculture. “Food processing is a very big sector. We are in talks with leading logistics companies to make Madhya Pradesh a logistic hub, given that it has one of the best lands to diversify,” said Nath.

Nath said the Union government “lacks planning”, pointing out that it imported “loads of onions” a few months ago and is now contemplating exporting onions, citing higher output.

The CM also stressed on the need for attitudinal changes in every level, from politics to large companies and small-scale industries. “The profile and recognition of the state must change from being known for the unfortunate Bhopal gas tragedy to one of the best places to invest,” said Nath. Responding to a question on improving air connectivity, Nath asked CII to give a proposal on domestic and international flights.

Sunil Mathur, deputy chairman of CII-Western Region Council, said, “MP, being centrally located, is set to become the manufacturing and logistic hub of the country. Time-bound clearance and skill development are encouraging initiatives for investors.”

Title: MPs urged to work for better execution of central schemes
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Madurai: The first meeting of the district development coordination and monitoring committee or ‘Disha’ this year for effective implementation of central government schemes in the district was held here on Friday. Madurai MP Su Venkatesan presided over the meeting which was attended by Virudhunagar MP Manickam Tagore, Theni MP P Ravindranath Kumar besides Madurai district collector Dr T G Vinay. Minister for Revenue, IT and disaster management R B Udayakumar was special invitee while MLAs from the AIADMK and DMK also participated.

Committee chairman Venkatesan said it was important for the members to ensure proper coordination of various central government schemes so that people benefit from them. Implementation of these schemes should be monitored stringently and Disha would meet once in three months, the MP said. Minister Udayakumar said the committee was responsible for the basic schemes which ensured proper infrastructure for development of the districts. These would ensure amenities like street lights, roads and potable water. Education and industrial development were also given thrust.

Madurai district has a population of 32 lakh in its 10 assembly constituencies put together, of which 26 lakh voters reside in the corporation limits. Many schemes including the challenging one to implement the AIIMS project had been given to Madurai. The chief minister was also implementing many development-oriented schemes. This committee should also take up the requirements of the local representatives with the central government and ensure they are met, the minister added.

Disha committee would monitor the implementation of 28 schemes of the central government including Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme (MGNREGS), Pradhan Mantri Gram Sadak Yojana (PMGSY), National Rural Drinking Water Program (NRDWP), Smart City Mission and National Health Mission (NHM) among other things.

Title: ‘Evict anti-CAA protesters from Uzhavar Santhai ground’
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Trichy: The BJP has threatened to launch a protest if the members of the Muslim community who have been on a two-week-long protest against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) at Uzhavar Santhai ground are not evicted.

Leading a protest rally of about 500 people in support of CAA from head post office to collector office on Friday, party general secretary Karuppu M Muruganandam demanded that the state government and police evict the protesters or he along with other people would sit opposite to them at the ground. “We don’t want to know how you do it, whether you carry out talks, fall at their feet or even use force, but they should be evicted. If that doesn’t happen, then a Delhi-like situation cannot be prevented in Tamil Nadu,” he told the police. Giving permission for such protests and ignoring their activities are against the interests of the country, he said.

Questioning the police action of allowing protests at Uzhavar Santhai ground for so many days, he asked if they (police) would tolerate similar protests by them too. Saying that such places have become breeding grounds for hate speech, he sought speedy eviction of the protesters failing which he would hit the road along with the people. He said that both DMK and Congress are misleading the people on CAA. TNN

Title: Sellers organise chicken food fest to overcome Covid-19 fear
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Kolhapur: To remove the fear of Corona virus infection after eating chicken, the city dealers organised a festival with over 1,000 kg of chicken dishes relished by hundreds of citizens.

The poultry business has been hit hard due to the fear of Corona infection with sellers selling chicken as low as Rs 80 per kg in the retail market.

The virus has taken a toll on many people across globe. Recently, the Kolhapur Municipal Corporation’s health department issued a public notice stating that eating chicken does not cause Corona infection. The notice cited that the notification issued by the central government’s animal husbandry department.

The chicken festival was held at Irwin Christian School ground in Shahupuri.

According to the dealers, the businesses of both the poultry farmers and the chicken sellers have to face huge losses with business coming down by 80%. The farmers are now selling poultry at Rs 25-30 per kg from Rs 60 per kg. In return, the sellers are selling chicken to consumers at Rs 80 per kg from Rs 160 per kg.

Saeed Sheikh, one of the organisers of the chicken festival said, “Over 500 citizens turned out to eat the chicken dishes. We prepared biryani with 500 kg chicken, fried chicken of 300 kg and curry of chicken with 200 kg. We gave the assurance to the citizens that no virus remains active at the temperature at which the chicken is boiled. We hope that with this festival, the fear among the consumers is done away. Thousands of families depend on the poultry and chicken business.”

Sheikh said that more such festivals will be organised in coming days at several locations in the city.

One of the sellers at the festival said, “The orders from the hoteliers have come down significantly. No case of Corona infection or even that of fever has been reported so far due to eating of chicken or any kind of meat.”

Title: Delhi riots: Seven bodies arrive in west UP, 'more in queue'
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

According to police, three of the dead were from Bulandshahr and two each from Hapur and Muzaffarnagar. Slain ... Read More

MEERUT: Of the 42 dead in northeast Delhi , at least seven are from adjoining west UP districts and the number is likely to soar as those killed in the riots are still being identified. Mostly in their 20s, those who fell prey to the mobs were daily wage labourers who had come to the national capital looking for better prospects.

According to police, three of the dead were from Bulandshahr and two each from Hapur and Muzaffarnagar. Slain IB sleuth Ankit Sharma was also from Muzaffarnagar. He was cremated on Thursday in his native Itawa village, with full state honours.

While some families are still waiting for the bodies to arrive-- with graves dug and the shrouds purchased. Till Friday afternoon, the family members of Ashfaq Hussain (22) were waiting for his body to arrive in Bulandshahr village. An electrician who got married just 10 days ago, Ashfaq was going to attend a job complaint when he was shot, five times. His wife of 10 days has not slept for the last four days, and wants a glimpse of her husband, one last time.

Parvez Ahmad, a 50-year-old social activist from Muzaffarnagar, was shot dead when he went out to pacify people of two communities rioting on northeast Delhi street.

While in Hapur Dehat, the news of Mohsin’s “presumed death” was broke to his family on Friday morning. Mohsin’s charred car was recovered during the violence. Hapur’s additional superintendent of police (ASP) Sarvesh Mishra said, “It is presumed that he (Mohsin) has succumbed to burn injuries, but his body is yet to be identified. He used to work at a generator repair shop in Noida.”

22-year-old Suleman’s body was brought to his native village in Hapur on Friday evening for burial. A resident of Babugarh area in Hapur, Suleman was a daily wage worker.

A Bulandshahr resident, Shahid Khan (25), an auto-rickshaw driver who got married three months ago, was returning home after dropping a passenger when he was killed. His family buried him on Thursday, two days after the death. Shaban Aziz (22), a labourer, was the third casuality from Bulandshahr. He lived with his family in Delhi’s Gokulpuri area.

“Efforts are being made by officials to address grievances of the victims’ families. We are taking the help of local religious leaders to check escalation of tension,” a senior police official said.

Title: ‘State poised to become pharmaceutical hub’
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Indore: Madhya Pradesh will attract encouraging investments and is poised to become a pharmaceutical hub, said chief minister Kamal Nath on Friday urging drug manufacturers to engage in extensive research and development work in state.

“Sun Pharmaceutical Industries Limited has completed almost 70 per cent of their research on cancer drug with the help of local herbs and resources available in state. The state has immense potential to set up a pharmaceutical hub,” said Nath.

Chief minister held interactive sessions with various industry associations in city on Friday.

Members of MP Small Scale Drug Manufacturers Association submitted a memorandum to chief minister urging support in development of common facility centre in pharma sector coming up in collaboration of Centre.

In conversation with industrialists, Nath said it is comparatively easy for industries to set up facilities but transportation and marketing are some serious roadblocks and state government is working on resolving industry related issues. In a meeting with members of Pithampur Audhyogik Sangathan, chief minister assured granting promissory notes against pending industrial refunds to aid industrial activities in state.

Long-pending refunds of industries, conversion of leasehold industrial land into freehold, abolition of municipal tax from industrial area in Pithampur kheda, higher industrial power tariffs among others were some issues raised by industry members in the meeting.

Gautam Kothari, president, Pithampur Audhyogik Sangathan said, “Around Rs 1,600 crore refund to be made to industries across the state is pending. The chief minister has assured us to give promissory notes that can be discounted in banks. This move will greatly benefit industries and help expansion.”

On freehold of land, CM said the move may lead to misuse of lands. Pramod Dafaria, president, Association of Industries Madhya Pradesh (AIMP) proposed chief minister to conduct MSME conclave in Indore to give a platform to small scale units of the region expand their business activities. TNN

Title: Medicinal tree park inaugurated in Palani
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

MADURAI: A medicinal tree park, with over 10,000 saplings and developed for the past two years, was inaugurated at Vaiyapurikulam Karamadai in Palani taluk by the minister for environment and forests, Dindigul C Srinivasan, on Thursday.

Speaking after inaugurating the park, Srinivasan said that the Tamil Nadu government was taking several steps to enhance the green cover in the state. Tree saplings were also being planted in huge numbers for every birth anniversary of the late chief minister J Jayalalithaa. This year, it was planned to plant 72 lakh tree saplings to mark her birth anniversary and complete the project by December this year.

Under this initiative, the exclusive park of medicinal trees was announced in the Tamil Nadu Assembly in the year 2017-2018. Kodaikanal district forest officer (DFO), S N Thejasvi said that a vacant estate in Vaiyapurikulam Karamadai, which was being misused for dumping solid waste, was taken up for establishment of the park in 2018.

“Palani is known for the siddhas and their medicines and the resource for these medicines have been obtained from local herbs and trees and hence it was decided to establish the park here,” he said.

The park has 10,000 saplings belonging to 78 different tree varieties grown with care by the workers over the past two years. Saplings of medicinal trees such as jamun - Syzygium cumini, gooseberry, neem, mahizham - Mimusops elengi , Agathi - Sesbania grandiflora, Kumizh - Gmelina arborea and bambooo among others have been planted in this park. The DFO said that creating awareness about these plants it would go a long way, which were commonly available and have high medicinal value.

Names of the trees and their medicinal properties are prominently displayed and the park also has many facilities for its visitors including walks, seating and resting spaces and drinking water and toilet facilities.

Title: Siblings given for adoption without informing family
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

BHOPAL: Three siblings, aged 8, 11 and 15, living in SOS Balgram here, were given for adoption to a US-based couple in late January — even when their father and grandmother are alive.

The kids’ grandmother went to meet them on February 22 only to find that they are already adopted. The Bal Aayog of Madhya Pradesh has taken cognizance of the matter.

The grandmother had taken the children to SOS Balgram in 2015, as CLCP (Child in need of care and protection), through Childline as their mother had died and father was of unsound mental health.

A special adoption agency of the city, linked to SOS, gave the children for adoption earlier this month, without the grandmother’s knowledge. On Friday, the grandmother filed a complaint with Madhya Pradesh Commission for Protection of Child Rights.

“I was unable to take care of the three children after my daughter-in-law passed away and son started having mental problems. A woman told me that I could go to Childline and put the children in an ashram or hostel where they will be taken care of. I took them to a shelter home with the help of Childline in 2015, and used to visit them every month till last year. The staff there told me not to come to meet the children so often, as it distracted them, so I went to meet them in January — after seven months. But they did not let me meet them. I went again in February but was sent back. I went again on February 22 when I was told that they are in a foriegn country as they have been adopted. I had not given them up for adoption. They were living there because I could not afford to take care of them,” the grandmother told MPCPCR

She had gone to the Child Welfare Committee on Wednesday but the members said they ‘knew nothing about the case’. “The previous CWC, with members — Rekha Shridhar , Seema Agarwal , Mohan Sharma, Satyendra Singh — had dealt with this case and had sent the kids to SOS as asked by the grandmother. As per records, we have the kids categorized as CLCP (child in need of care and protection) who cannot be declared legally free for adoption. We are going through other documents to verify them properly,” said Kripashankar Choubey , member of CWC.

Recalling the day the kids were brought to Childline, director Archana Sahaye said, “It had been made absolutely clear in the paperwork that the children were in need of care and protection, and had not been surrendered by the grandmother. The paperwork to make them legally free and then give them up for adoption was done without the knowledge of Childline and the grandmother.”

“We have taken cognizance of the matter and will write to the collector an commissioner WCD to investigate and see the Social Investigation Report given by the adoption agency and CWC before declaring the kids legally free for adoption and take strict agency against the guilty,” said Brijesh Chouhan, member of MPCPCR.

When TOI contacted Vipin Das — the director of SOS Balgram, about the matter, he said, “You can call CWC and SAA in question as all paperwork is done by them.”

Title: Dia Mirza pens down a heart-warming note for Taapsee Pannu and Team 'Thappad'
Content: On the release of Taapsee Pannu starrer 'Thappad' Dia Mirza on Friday penned down a heart-warming note for the actor and the team stating "YOU ARE AMAZING."The 38-year-old actor took to Instagram as she shared her glimpse from the movie along with a note that reads, "Dearest Tapsee and Team Thappad, As this story makes its way into people's hearts from today, just wanted to say, YOU ARE AMAZING. For thinking, feeling, responding to and sharing something so basic. So necessary. So needed: Love, respect and honesty for one and all For being fearless and convinced by the honesty of the truth's that have compelled this narrative. Keep telling stories. Keep being you. All my love and gratitude, Dia."Dia has reunited with Anubhav Sinha for the third time now; she has earlier worked with him for 'Dus' and 'Cash.'The Anubhav Sinha-directorial features Taapsee as the protagonist who refuses to tolerate domestic violence in the name of love and relationships.Coming from the makers of cinematic marvels like 'Article 15' and 'Mulk', the film features Ratna Pathak Shah, Manav Kaul , Dia Mirza, Tanvi Azmi , and Ram Kapoor in pivotal roles.The film hit the theatres on February 28 2020.

Title: 426-page charge sheet filed in Ankita Pisudde case
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Nagpur: Wardha police have filed a 426-page charge sheet in Ankita Pisudde case before the judicial magistrate first class court in Hinganghat on Friday. The 24-year-old college teacher had been set ablaze by an unrequited lover on February 3.

The murder had triggered a nationwide angst against atrocities on women. The state too had witnessed agitations at many places.

Pisudde was set on fire by her stalker, Vikesh Nagrale, a married man with a child, near her college at Hinganghat on February 3. She was rushed to city-based Orange City Hospital and Research Centre, where she was declared dead on February 10. The victim, a postgraduate in botany and pursuing BEd, was the elder of two siblings.

Wardha police arrested Nagrale the day of the attack, and he was shifted to Nagpur Central Jail due to security reasons. It’s learnt that Nagrale had followed Pisudde from her village at Daroda to Hinganghat, where he doused the victim with kerosene and set her afire.

SP, Wardha, Basavaraj Teli said a comprehensive probe has made the case watertight. “A foolproof investigation was done. We relied upon scientific and technical evidences to ensure there is no loophole left anywhere,” he said. Teli also said statements of eyewitnesses were part of the charge sheet. “We have included every possible detail and report, including the chemical analysis,” he said.

The state had already declared the trial to be conducted in a fast-track court with special public prosecutor Ujjwal Nikam appearing for the state.

Compensation has been paid to Pisudde’s family, including complete medical expenses for treating Pisudde. The state government has also announced a job for one family member.

Title: Cops net serial bride who trapped lonely old grooms & robbed them
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Bhopal: A 40-year-old 'looteri dulhan' has taken her 72-year-old ‘groom’ for a royal ride. A day after the wedding, the bride ran away with Rs 10,000 cash and 150 gm gold jewellery. She told the victim that her mother had fallen ill and she had to leave, after few days she said her mother had died. The victim, who married her as he was lonely after the death of his first wife, has gone into depression and is having suicidal tendencies, say police.

Police arrested the two accused, including the woman and her 71-year-old real husband, who met the victim posing as her father. Police have also recovered the jewellery the accused had robbed. The accused were identified as Ramfal Shukla, 71, and Rani alias Sunita, 40, residents of Satna. The accused has confessed to duping elderly men in Kota, Rajasthan, and Jabalpur in a similar manner. She would target elderly men, who were either divorced or widowed. Once married, she would take money from them on pretext of conducting her mother’s last rites. A case on charges of fraud has been registered against the woman and her husband.

ASP (Crime Branch) Nishchal Jharia said that the 72-year-old victim had retired as engineer in a government department. He lives alone as his wife died a year ago.

The victim told police that after his wife’s death, he started feeling lonely and his friends told him to marry again. He gave an advertisement in a newspaper for marriage. After this, one Shankar Dubey, a resident of Panna, called him and said he has a relative, Rani Mishra, 40, who could not get married as she cannot conceive. He said, Rani is very poor and will serve him well. The victim agreed. ASP Jharia said that on February 20, Shankar and Rani came to Bhopal, and the victim married Rani in his house. He also gave his late wife’s jewellery to Rani. The next day, Shankar told the victim that Rani’s mother was seriously ill and they would leave for Satna.

The victim gave Rs 10,000 to Rani for this. A few days later, Shankar informed the victim that Rani's mother died and asked for Rs 40,000 to conduct rituals. Before he could transfer the money, he received a call from Rajasthan. The caller, Rajkumar Sharma, 53, said that ten days back, Rani and Shankar met him in Satna and he married Rani, but they fled with cash and jewellery. The victim then understood that he was duped.

Title: Indurikar’s event at SUK called off
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Kolhapur: The organisers of Shiv Mahotsav have called off the programme of controversial preacher Nivrutti Indurikar which was slated to take on Friday.

The activists of Maharashtra Andhshraddha Nirmoolan Samiti (MANS) and progressive outfits of the city had objected to Indurikar’s programme and had even threatened to disrupt it. The activists said that Indurikar propagates irrational concepts and blind faith in society.

Indurikar had recently made a controversial statement that intercourse by a couple on an even date would create a male child while intercourse on an odd date would result in the birth of a girl. Indurikar is famous among the rural areas and performs at several places. The MANS had demanded that a case against Indurikar should be filed for alleged violation of the provisions of the Pre-Conception and Pre-Natal Diagnostic Techniques (PCPNDT) Act. However, the government has refuted the demand.

Shivmohotsav is organised every year at Shivaji University, Kolhapur (SUK). The students perform and participate in different cultural activities during the annual event. Indurikar was invited to deliver a kirtan (recitation) at the SUK. However, the activists of progressive outfits, Yuva Sena workers and the student wing of Shiv Sena met vice-chancellor Devanand Shinde in the morning demanding cancellation of Indurikar’s recitation.

Anuradha Bhosale, progressive activist and president of Ekati organisation said, “The university bears the name of Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj. He always honoured womenand respected them in the same manner in which he would respect his mother. Organising the event of some preacher who considers women secondary to men would be against the Maratha warrior king’s principles.”

Seema Patil, an activist associated with MANS, said, “Our movement is based on rational thoughts. Indurikar made irrational statements which had no scientific basis. Also, he has not understood our Constitution which upholds scientific temperament. His programme should not be held in the premises of Shivaji University, Kolhapur.”

Manjit Mane of Yuva Sena said, “Shiv Mahotsav is organised every year. Each year, various personalities are invited to the varsity to guide youth. Some people oppose it to gain publicity.”

Title: State seeks update in ’97 scam when Fadnavis was city mayor
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Nagpur: The Maha Vikas Aghadi (MVA) government, an alliance of Shiv Sena-NCP-Congress led by chief minister Uddhav Thackeray, on Thursday sought details of action taken in the multi-crore sports equipment purchase scam that rocked Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) from 1997-98 to 1999-2000. Former CM and leader of opposition Devendra Fadnavis was Nagpur mayor at that time.

The move comes days after the government ordered a probe into NMC’s garbage-to-compost project at Bhandewadi dumping yard.

The information on the sports scam was sought after Congress MLA from Rajura Subhash Dhote submitted a calling attention over the scam in the ongoing budget session of state legislature.

Municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe, deputy municipal commissioner Nirbhay Jain and a group of senior NMC officials worked till late night on Thursday to prepare the report for the state government. Subsequently, Mundhe flew to Mumbai on Friday morning.

The Congress had ruled the state from 2001 till 2014, and did nothing during these years. “Now, after almost two decades it is seeking action taken report. This is nothing but vindictive politics,” said mayor Sandip Joshi.

Speaking to TOI, Congress MLA Dhote said he came to know that the BJP-led NMC had dumped the recommendations of the Nandlal Committee and not initiated any action against 50 NMC engineers nor recover the embezzled amount from them.

Dhote said, “Both elected representatives and NMC engineers had looted taxpayers’ money and committed a very big scam.” The alleged scam took place between 1997 and 2000, and following this, the Maharashtra government had in 2001 constituted Nandlal Committee to conduct an inquiry into works approved and executed between 1997 and 2000.

The then government had also dismissed the BJP-led ruling alliance in the civic body and appointed an administrator after the scam came to light. The committee had later submitted its recommendations to the government, which directed NMC to act accordingly.

As per the committee’s recommendations, the 102 corporators were booked in criminal cases and the panel had also recommended action against 50 engineers and recover of Rs8 crore from them.

“The government even reminded NMC about implementation of the committee’s recommendations in 2006. But nothing has been done so far,” said city MLA, former mayor and Congress city president Vikas Thakre, who too had demanded Nandlal Committee.

He said that he will participate in Dhote’s calling attention motion and pointed out that the BJP-led NMC had not implemented the directives of the government to protect its corrupt practices.

Dhote said, “I will demand stringent punishment to those involved in the scam.”

The Scam

Between 1997 and 2000, ruling BJP corporators allegedly produced fake bills and receipts for sport goods, which were never purchased

There was no provision for NMC to purchase and distribute sports goods

Some also accused of not delivering sports material to players despite picking it up from NMC stores

76 corporators, including 28 women, and the then acting mayor Dr Ravindra Bhoyar, were arrested by Sadar police

Two BJP MLAs — Devendra Fadnavis and Mohan Mate — were detained for interrogation

After the expose, the then Congress-led Maharashtra government dissolved NMC in September 2001

Then NMC commissioner T Chandrashekar was made administrator at that time

In 2001, former IAS officer Nandlal Gupta probed the scam

Nandlal Committee accused over 102 corporators, the then additional deputy municipal commissioner Sahebrao Raut, retired sports officer H Mohite, retired education officer late Vinayak Chaudhary and supplier of not delivering sports material worth crores in their wards

Police complaint filed against 102 corporators under Section 406, 409, 420, 467, 120 (B), 511 and 34 of IPC

Recording of evidence underway in court cases, next hearing on March 17, 2020

Title: Will give a new recognition to MP, says Nath
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Indore: Chief minister Kamal Nath on Friday said that he will not bend to any pressure and continue crackdown against mafia for earning the trust of people and providing Madhya Pradesh a new recognition.

“My effort is to provide Madhya Pradesh a new recognition that people have trust on like when you visit Tamil Nadu or Karnataka, you can proudly say that you belong to this state. We have to change MP’s image as it should not be known for its mafia. Ongoing crackdown against mafia will continue,” said Nath addressing a gathering in Rau assembly segment.

“Kamal Nath ko koi daba nahi sakta, pata nahi sakta’ (Nobody can suppress or remit Kamal Nath),” he said.

Nath added that Madhya Pradesh should not be identified with Bhopal Gas Tragedy. “Our efforts are to safeguard future of youth,” he said adding that his government is working on bringing investment while in last 15 years (of BJP’s regime), more industries left the state than the number new of plants that came up. “I don’t believe in making any announcement, I believe in working.”

Amidst ongoing protest over proposed Metro route by traders of Kothari Market and nearby commercial areas, Nath said, “Work of Metro rail will be carried out at great speed. It’s a big medium of investment that will generate employment for people. With increased commercial activities, possibilities of development will also increase.”

On the occasion, Nath inaugurated and laid foundation for different works of development worth around Rs 900 crore. “The works will help in increasing economic activities and catalyse development,” he said. From stage, Nath inaugurated a mobile-based application ‘Shubh Labh’ to provide help in farming and also released a video on Gair. TNN

Title: CBS parking will affect business, claim auto unions
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Kolhapur: The auto-rickshaw unions continue to oppose the Kolhapur Municipal Corporation’s (KMC) plan to develop multi-level car parking at the Central Bus Stand. A meeting between the KMC delegation led by Sanjay Mohite and the representatives of the auto unions was held on Friday.

The auto unions said that the car parking facility will affect their business. However, the office-bearers of the municipal corporation countered the claims saying that if the parking facility is developed, the number of visitors will increase, thereby, boosting the business of auto drivers.

The facility is likely to come up at 3,952 sq m location in front of the CBS. The parking facility was approved in 2012 and is expected to accommodate around 210 four-wheelers and 20 two-wheelers.

“The parking facility will also have covered parking accommodating around 80 rickshaws. We are going to visit the site in the next two to three days. We have asked the auto union representatives to remain present during the site visit. We are ready for discussion. We assure them that all the facilities they require in the parking facility will be given priority,” Mohite said.

Due to the lack of parking facility, the area surrounding the CBS remains congested even during the non-peak hours. The traffic department has banned the entry of private transport buses at the CBS to reduce congestion, however, the implementation of the decision is not satisfactory.

Along with the CBS, the multilevel car parking was proposed at several other locations in the city. The stone-laying ceremony of the parking facility to be developed at Saraswati Talkies will be held on Saturday. Tourists visiting the Mahalaxmi temple will be able to park their vehicles in this facility. Over Rs 8 crore will be spent on the parking facility.

The KMC is planning to develop a mobile application to facilitate booking of parking slots. The facility can accommodate 140 four-wheelers and 145 two-wheelers.

Mohite said that a similar facility will be developed at Kombadi Bazaar too. He has requested the auto-rickshaw union representatives to co-operate with the municipal corporation.

Title: Cycle rally to curb plastic pollution today
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Kolhapur: The Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) has organized a bicycle rally on February 29 to create awareness about the increasing pollution caused by plastic. The municipal corporation aims to mke the city plastic-free.

The rally will witness the participation of corporators, civic officials, students and representatives of various NGOs. The KMC has also appealed to the citizens to take active part in the rally and support their plastic-free mission.

The municipal corporation has set a target of March 31 to make the city plastic-free. The programmes initiated to implement the plastic-free city plan are going to end on March 1.

Civic chief Mallinath Kalshetti recently met state environment minister Aaditya Thackeray and submitted a copy of the plan. Thackeray said that he will support the KMC’s plan to make the city platic-free.

“The rally will take off from Janata Bazaar Chowk in Rajarampuri at 9.00 am. The bicycle rally will pass through major localities and will conclude at Shivaji Chowk. We expect to cover distance of around 25km. We are going to hold corner meetings at several locations on the way and guide participants about the environmental hazards of plastic and the ways to avoid the use of plastic,” said Kalshetti.

The rally will pass through major localities, including Rajarampuri, Shahupuri, Laxmipuri, Mirajkar Tickti, Bhausingji Road and the Mahalaxmi temple. Students, teachers and locals will have to take pledge of refraining from using plastic. “We will make all necessary arrangements to ensure smooth flow of vehicular traffic,” said Kalshetti.

Title: 10% slump in Kolkata international flyer count as trips cancelled amid corona scare
Content:
A passenger being screened in Kolkata airport (File photo)

KOLKATA: Congestion at the international terminal in Kolkata that was becoming a major issue during busy hours till recently has eased conspicuously following a 7%-10% slump in the number of flyers this month as many cancelled their travel plans following the coronavirus scare . With Saudi Arabia announcing a ban on pilgrimage to Mecca on Thursday, the possibility of Gulf carriers also hitting the nCoV air-pocket has raised further concerns on the fate of international flight operations in Kolkata.“This is a challenging time, not just for Kolkata or India but also for the global aviation industry. Passenger traffic continues to decline as the climate of uncertainty prevails. Apart from fears triggering a decline in travel, travel restrictions and advisory issued by various countries have also led to reduced loads that have forced carriers to rationalise services,” said Kolkata airport director Kaushik Bhattacharjee.At Kolkata airport, international passenger departures had gone down from 9,232 a day in mid-January to 8,574 a day now. That means a dip of 4,600 passengers a week. Along with it, retail and food and beverage sales at the terminal have also slumped, with revenue dipping 14%.Flights to China were the first to be grounded after India cancelled visas to Chinese citizens and evacuated Indians stranded in the country. But the spread of nCoV to more than 50 countries has increased the radar of uncertainty to the entire region. With flights to Hong Kong being cancelled and those to Vietnam operating intermittently, traffic in South-East Asia is also taking a tumble.Flights to Bangkok, one of the most popular international destinations for Indians, and Kolkatans in particular, aren’t immune to the scare. One airline has stopped operations and others are rationalising services.The reverberations of the nCoV are now felt far beyond the region with even Gulf-bound flights, which have a good number of passengers who travel onward to Europe or the US, also reporting cancellations. “Loads have dropped by 50%-70% on east-bound flights and 20%-25% on those headed for west. If this persists, several more airlines will ground flights to avoid losses. The alarming issue is that with the Covid-19 virus continuing to spread, no one is quite sure when the situation will improve,” said travel agent Jaydeep Mukherjee.Travel Agents Federation of India chairman (east) Anil Punjabi is praying for a quick turnaround: “I have never witnessed this widespread a disruption. Even the situation during the SARS outbreak in 2003 was this dismal. Thankfully, this is the exam season, when families don’t usually travel and India is largely unaffected,” he said.

Title: Sans permissions, tree cutters running riot in West Nagpur
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Nagpur: Tree fellers are roaming in the city, especially West Nagpur which is greener than other parts, asking for trimming and cutting jobs from gullible citizens. They are brushing off queries of rules and regulations, and convincing owners to knock off a few branches and leaves here and there.

Citizens falling in their trap may end up being severely penalized by the civic body which has contracted tree cutters who work with full permission.

Recently, a group of citizens at New Somwaripeth at Manewada Road chopped down an age-old almond tree through such fellers. The tree was planted on the road nearly 25 years back and was felled without the mandatory permission of Nagpur Municipal Corporation’s garden department.

When an environmentally conscious resident Anshu Saxena tried to stop the illegal felling, few residents and labourers started abusing and threatening her. “I tried contacting the police but in vain. This group of people residents completely chopped down the tree because they were irritated with the leaf litter. How can this be a reason to destroy our green cover,” said Saxena.

According to the standard operating procedure (SOP) released by NMC in April last year, citizens can’t seek permission to fell trees citing insignificant reasons like “troubled by leaf litter” or “improving visibility of an advertisement hoarding or shop”.

Saxena further informed that the tree fellers, who visit their residential area regularly, make the job easier. “They offer service to trim or fell trees. The residents are now planning to chop down fully-grown Neem trees,” added Saxena.

On her complaint, a team of officials from NMC’s garden department had carried out a spot panchnama. “We have issued notices to the residents who ordered felling of the tree. Appropriate action will be taken based on the reply submitted by them,” officials said.

Since last few months, TOI has received many complaints about tree fellers who visit different residential areas. Carrying axe and other tools, they offer tree felling services at affordable rates. This practice is leading to significant loss in the city’s already dwindling green cover.

NMC garden superintendent Amol Chorpagar said that such tree fellers are prominently found in areas of West Nagpur. “We have identified such groups and will soon be initiating actions like filing FIR or extern them. The issue will be raised with the municipal commissioner,” he said.

Officials have appealed to the citizens to not use services of such fellers as they are cutting trees illegally. “They do not have NMC’s permit,” said Chorpagar.

Title: Cracks on incomplete cement road from Zingabai Takli to Godhani
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

ddddd

Nagpur: Cracks are already appearing on the under-construction cement road from Zingabai Takli to Godhani village, raising questions on the quality of work being done. It has also exposed poor monitoring by the state’s public works department (division-I).

TOI has on many occasions reported about the lackadaisical approach of the state PWD and Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) towards monitoring and ensuring quality in cement concretization road works.

The Zingabai Takli to Godhani village stretch is part of the 5.6km long Bokhara-Godhani-Faras road that is being widened with grants sanctioned from Central road fund by city MP Nitin Gadkari. Some part of the road falls under Nagpur West assembly constituency while the remaining in Hingna constituency.

The Rs25 crore work order was issued in December 2016 to M/s Abhi Engineering. Work is being executed at a very slow pace and not even half of the road is complete after over three years.

TOI visited the stretch and found cracks at many spots on one side of the stretch between Mahajan Complex and Govind Lawn. If not attended to immediately, chances of these cracks opening up further cannot be ruled out.

At many places, there is gap between the road panels and interlocking blocks. The blocks too are of inferior quality.

From spot inspection it’s evident that the contractor isn’t following norms like regular sprinkling of water at the site and covering up construction material, thus leading to dust pollution on either side of the road.

Norms laid down by the traffic police too are not being followed. TOI found that the contractor has not put up barricades, signboards, blinkers, flasher boards, rotaries, directive signboards, red flags etc.

Also, traffic wardens need to be deployed round-the-clock at the site but this is ignored. Mankapur police and Sadar zone of traffic police seem to have turned a blind eye to these violations.

Former corporator Arun Dawre termed the quality of road work as poor. Citing reasons for the cracks, he said the road is not allowed to set properly. “The road is constructed at higher level from the ground and will lead to flooding of houses and shops nearby during heavy rains,” he said.

“Quality and pace of work is not being monitored. If quality is compromised, it will be like rubbing salt to people’s wounds,” Dawre said and added that compared to existing old cement roads, the new ones laid by the NMC, National Highways Authority of India and even PWD do not have a smooth surface layer.

Despite repeated attempts, state PWD’s executive engineer J Bhanuse was not available for comments. The contractor too could not be reached for comments.

Ruling party leader in the NMC and former deputy mayor Sandip Jadhav admitted that he too has found cracks on the road and said that he will raise the issue with the state PWD officials.

Title: HC notice to Centre, MP on 10% EWS quota
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Bhopal: A division bench of MP high court on Friday issued notices to the Centre and the state government in response to a public interest litigation (PIL) challenging provision of 10% reservation to economically weaker sections (EWSs) from general category.

The PIL contended that the state government issued a notification on July 2, 2019, providing for 10% reservation for candidates from EWS of general category. In the Indra Sawhney case, the Supreme Court’s constitutional bench clearly laid down that total quota for various sections of the society can’t exceed 50%. MP already has 36% reservation for SCs/STs and 14% for the OBCs.

The petitioners further said that when state government raised the quota for OBCs to 27% from 14%, it was stayed by the MP high court. There are petitions in the Supreme Court opposing 10% reservation to EWSs and the apex court has stayed 10% quota for EWSs introduced by the Central government. In the same light, 10% quota for economically weaker sections in MP should also be stayed till disposal of the petition, the petitioners contended. TNN

Title: Thieves target rail staff’s house and flee with valuables worth Rs 15 lakh
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

BAREILLY: Thieves entered railway employee Usha Sharma’s house in Izzatnagar locality and reportedly decamped with jewellery and other valuables worth Rs 15 lakh on Thursday night.

Usha wasn’t at home at the time of the incident. She went to Lakhimpur to visit her son and daughter-in-law. Her tenant informed her on Friday morning upon spotting broken locks of her rooms. The victim has registered a complaint with police .

Resident of Partapur locality under Izzatnagar police station limits, Usha in her police complaint stated that she had gone to Lakhimpur on February 10 to meet her younger son who lives there with his family. “My tenant informed me over the phone that locks of my rooms were broken and he also suspected that thieves had targeted my house. Upon getting information, I rushed back and informed the police seeing the belongings in my two rooms were ransacked,” she said.

Usha added that she had kept jewellery worth Rs 15 lakh in cupboard’s locker which was broken and all jewellery was taken away.

SHO inspector KK Verma said that they were probing the matter and further action would be taken accordingly. “Our team has reached the spot to collect evidence. After investigation, FIR will be lodged under appropriate sections,” the SHO added.

Title: Opposition instigating riots over CAA: Amit Shah
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Amit Shah

BHUBANESWAR: In his first public speech since the outbreak of violence over the CAA in New Delhi earlier this week, Union home minister Amit Shah , here on Friday accused opposition parties of misleading people and instigating riots over the new citizenship law.

Without making any direct reference to the violence in the national capital that has so far claimed more than 40 lives and left over 200 injured, Shah said, “Through this big public meeting I want to tell the people of the country that the opposition parties are spreading rumours, provoking people and instigating riots.” He was speaking at a huge rally organised by his party to highlight the merits of the CAA.

Urging people not to be misled by such misinformation campaigns, Shah, whose resignation as home minister has been sought by Congress over the Delhi violence, said, “The entire opposition — Congress, communists, SP, BSP, Mamata didi — are opposing the CAA. They are saying minorities will lose their rights. Why are you spreading lies? The Prime Minister (Narendra Modi) has already said and I have also said in Parliament. Let me tell you again, not a single Muslim or any member of any minority community will lose his citizenship because of CAA.”

Shah’s remarks on the West Bengal chief minister came hours after the two met at a meeting of the Eastern Zonal Council here, which was also attended by Odisha CM Naveen Patnaik and his Bihar counterpart, Nitish Kumar, and Jharkhand finance minister Rameshwar Oraon. Jharkhand CM Hemant Soren could not attend the meeting which coincided with the first day of the budget session in his state assembly.

Shah said, “CAA is not an act to snatch citizenship from anyone. It is an act to provide citizenship to minorities persecuted in Pakistan, Bangladesh and Afghanistan. After Partition, there were forced conversions, forced marriages and rapes were committed. Many came to India to save their self-respect. It has been 70 years, but lakhs of such people don’t have citizenship. They don’t have access to healthcare and education. What about their human rights?”

The home minister pulled out pages from history to attack Congress. “Every Congress leader in the 1950s said Hindu and Sikh refugees will be given Indian citizenship. The Congress leaders on 27 different occasions made such promises, but never honoured them,” he said, adding, “While introducing CAA, we knew attempts will be made to malign us. But we are not afraid of such slander campaigns.”

Shah also touched upon issues like the construction of a Ram temple in Ayodhya and abrogation of Article 370. Exhorting the crowd, Shah said, “Tell me whether Article 370 should have been abrogated or not. Be louder so that those Congressmen who are opposing it can hear you. Tell me whether a Ram temple should be built in Ayodhya or not. Whenever the issue of the Ram temple came up in the past, Congress tried to delay it in the Supreme Court. With your blessings, the Modi government has returned to power with a massive mandate. Now, a sky-touching Ram temple will be built at the place where Lord Ram was born.”

EoM

Title: No camps in front of school gates on KBA polling day, committee tells candidates
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

KANPUR: The elders committee of Kanpur Bar Association ( KBA ), on Thursday, made an appeal to election contesting advocates to not raise any tent or camp in front of both the gates of Huddard School on March 3.

The members of KBA will cast their votes on March 3 to elect their representatives in KBA annual election. In a meeting held this evening, the committee stated to the contestants that since the board examination of class Xth and XIIth were scheduled on March 3, the school administration had urged not to raise any slogans and to not raise camps in front of the school gates.

Moreover, no one will be allowed to campaign between MG college crossing and DC law college, the venue of voting, on that day. The committee also appealed to the advocates to come in their proper advocate dress and carry their COP identity card or certificate on the day of polling. No one would be allowed to cast vote without COP identity card or certificate, said the committee.

Abdul Gaffar, advocate member of Elder committee stated that the committee had received a complaint that in the supplementary list some advocates had no COP number, therefore, they should not be allowed to cast their votes. The committee had identified the suspicious names and they would cast their vote in a separate booth.

Title: Zoo restaurant burning a hole in visitors’ pockets?
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Mysuru: Zoo authorities have thrown up their hands even as tourists and visitors continue to complain about the high food prices at the restaurant on the campus. On an average, 8,000-10,000 people visit the zoo and are not allowed to carry eatables, barring water and baby food.

Entry on a weekday costs Rs 50 for an adult and Rs 20 for a child.

Former tourism minister SR Mahesh had assured that rates would be rationalised but nothing was done. Authorities said the rates were fixed after comparing prices at hotels in the area and the proceeds were required for maintenance of the zoo.

“The zoo is fantastic and well maintained but the rates at the restaurant are very high. We were shocked that even a cup of coffee or tea is not available for less than Rs 25,” said Radhakrishnan, a tourist from Chennai. “The government should realise that poor and middle-class people flock to zoos and can’t afford to eat here.”

“Completing one full round of the zoo is exhausting and most visitors have to grab a bite and catch their breath in order to cover all bird and animal enclosures. The high prices are a trap,” said a visitor.

Visitors pointed out that chapathi costs as much as Rs 50, a plate of idli-vada costs Rs 80. Staples such as masala dosa (Rs 65), bisi bele bath (Rs 75) and chow chow bath (Rs 100) were out of reach for most middle class families, they said.

Ajit Kulkarni, executive director of the zoo, said, “The rates were fixed after going through the prices at hotels in neighbouring areas. The zoo is maintained with the money it gets through gate collection, adoption and other contracts including the restaurant which pays Rs 10 lakh per month.” Bringing down prices would also mean more people at the restaurant which would make it difficult to manage and maintain cleanliness, he said.

Title: Don’t pay extortion to gangsters, call us, say cops
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Nagpur: City police have approached top builders’ bodies in the city, like Confederation of Real Estate Developers’ Associations of India (Credai), to take them into confidence for ensuring none of them coughs up any extortion amounts.

Opening a special ‘anti-extortion’ cell this week, cops have also made a similar appeal to the members of Vidarbha Industries Associations (VIA).

On the lines of Mumbai, Pune and Thane, city police too now have their dedicated unit of ‘anti-extortion’ cell with PI Bharat Kshirsagar and API Ishwar Jagdale at the helm, with seven personnel under them. This is the first such initiative of city police under CP BK Upadhyay to have a dedicated unit to crack down on extortionists. Around 20 top gangsters and their gangs are under scanner now.

As economic activities have increased with the city’s expansion, around 84 offences of extortions have been registered in the last two years, including the ones against top goons.

Upadhyay said attention needs to be paid to the incidents of extortions as these often lead to violent crimes. “We may not have extortion cases on a large scale as in Mumbai or Pune, but even petty criminals engaged in such type of crimes needs to be put under the lens,” he said.

“Many times, there are no complaints against the goons by the victims fearing their wrath. But, we are trying to inculcate confidence among the citizens by approaching them and creating awareness that police need to be informed,” the CP said.

Kshirsagar said even the vendors at weekly markets, roadside temporary traders and kiosk owners are being approached during the surveys. “We have already conducted detailed surveys of the markets and traders. Several names of local goons who extort from these markets have come to fore. We have told the vendors and kiosk owners not to pay any goons,” he said.

“Earlier, there were no special approach to the problem of extortion. Now, we will try to explore the possibilities of slapping stringent actions like Maharashtra Control of Organized Crime Act (MCOCA) and Maharashtra Prevention of dangerous activities (MPDA) in as many cases as possible,” said Kshirsagar.

The PI said that anyone trying to extort under whatever circumstances can be bracketed as an extortionist and acted upon.

Kshirsagar said the records of the past cases of extortion in the city and the names cropping up as accused in them are being now researched. “We are scrutinizing the details of 84 cases of extortion registered so far and the accused who are in records,” the PI added.

Title: Holika Dahan at 2,749 spots, 18 highly sensitive
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

BAREILLY: Police have identified 2,749 locations, including 18 sensitive ones, in the district where Holika Dahan have been performed traditionally for years. They have also started a flag march across the district ahead of the festival of colours.

SSP Shailesh Kumar Pandey said that police have tightened vigil in all the 18 villages where altercations have occurred during Holi in the past five years. “Sub-divisional magistrates and area circle officers have been instructed to hold meetings in villages to clear any misunderstanding between locals to ensure that the festival passes off peacefully,” he added.

According to police, the highly sensitive spots in the city include Bankhana , Matha ki Chowki, Meera ki Paith and Shahukara , and Gangapur, Shahbad, Jagatpur, Kalari, Bhagwanpur, Dhimari and Khauriya Ghat in rural areas.

Similarly, another challenge for the police and administration is to ensure that all the 49 processions are taken out peacefully during Holi.

Title: Year’s second swine flu death recorded in state
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Dehradun: A 42-year-old woman from Haridwar died of swine flu on Thursday making it the second death of H1N1 in Uttarakhand this year. The year’s first swine flu death was reported from Dehradun in January.

So far, nine swine flu-positive cases have been reported in the state.

Meanwhile, one more swine flu case was reported from Dehradun on Friday. The patient hails from Muzaffarnagar district of UP and is living in Dehradun.

Haridwar chief medical officer (CMO) Dr Saroj Naithani confirmed that the 42-year-old woman has died due to swine flu. “The patient was one among the eight positive swine flu cases that were confirmed earlier this week. She was admitted to the Himalayan Institute of Medical Sciences. One more case of swine flu was reported from Haridwar and the patient has recovered,” she added.

Talking about preventive measures, the CMO said that people must cover their nose as the H1N1 spreads by droplet infection. “Swine flu is curable but the virus can prove to be fatal in case of diabetics, children and the elderly. Hence, we advise early treatment and avoiding contact with people when symptoms are detected. One should immediately consult a doctor in case of consistent fever and breathlessness,” she said.

Title: Delhi-type violence will affect economy: Sri Sri
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Mysuru: More than 7,000 industrialists and entrepreneurs have left the country due to a deficit of trust and incidents like the violence that rocked east Delhi will only affect the economy further, Sri Sri Ravi Shankar, founder of Art of Living Foundation, said on Friday.

Ravi Shankar was speaking at a corporate wellness conference on the theme ‘Wellness and Wellbeing for a Progressive Nation’ hosted by CII, in Mysuru. He said an atmosphere of fear and mistrust pervades the country and is does not augur well for the economy.

“Bankers too are suspicious of everyone and are not extending loans to industrialists. This has posed lots of problem,” Ravi Shankar said. “This attitude among bank officials should go, as life depends on trust. When there is a deficiency of trust there is possibility of the economy slowing down.”

He said society is now faced with two important issues — aggression and depression. “Some people stage protests and pelt stones which happened recently in Delhi. This is really unfortunate,” he said. “Fear lurks in the nation’s capital, which is being used by many to create terror. This will affect economy. No country will prosper without peace.”

Wellness is the need of the hour, he said. “Corporates used to spend half their health to gain wealth and spend half their wealth to regain their health. This isn’t good economics,” he said. “We have to talk and convince people to invest in wellness. I am glad times have changed. CII has taken this big initiative and corporate wellness is buzz word around the world today.”

He went on to say, “The US has invested $27 million in the wellness industry. In universities in America, 52 have [a course on] Indology. In India, 40 years ago, yoga was not taken as profession, but today many are taking Ayurveda and yoga seriously. This is leading to wellness.”

Dr Upendra Shenoy, chief, medical services, Columbia Asia Hospital, said, “Coronary heart disease is the leading cause of death in India and it is on rise. More than 50% of people who suffer heart attack are smokers.”

He advised people not to jog or run on the steps of Chamundi Hill as the uneven steps could result in injuries. Instead, he advised the audience to walk briskly on flat surfaces for at least 30 minutes. He also urged people to sleep eight hours a day.

BOX

69% of doctors ill

Dr Upendra Shenoy said a survey conducted by AIIMS revealed that nearly 69% of doctors have health issues. Besides this, more than 50% of psychiatrists have developed problems in their course of service towards patients. “Our mind is spinning so we need to take care of our mental health,” he said.
