Title: Govt gives appointment order to slain SSI Wilson’s daughter
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Madurai: The Tamil Nadu government on Friday handed over the appointment order to Antris Rimija, the eldest daughter of slain special sub-inspector of police (SSI) Y Wilson, 57. The 27-year-old, who has a masters degree in engineering, has been appointed as junior assistant in the revenue department in Kanyakumari district.

Rimija thanked the state government for giving her the job to support the family and the district administration and the police for their support to the family at the time of crisis. The order was handed over to her by the government’s special representative in Delhi Thalavai Sundaram in the presence of Kanyakumari district collector Prashant M Wadnere and superintendent of police, N Shreenath.

The SSI was on night duty at the Kaliyakkavilai Market Road check-post on January 8 when he shot at and stabbed by two extremists Abdul Sameem and Thoufeek to avenge the arrest of their fellow accused. The two accused were arrested at Udupi in Karnataka a week later and lodged in the Palayamkottai Central Prison and the case was also transferred to the National Investigation Agency.

The state had announced Rs 1 crore compensation and a government job for a family member. The SSI was survived by his wife Angel Mary and two daughters.

Title: Extremists are preparing India for another partition: Pon Radhakrishnan
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Pon Radhakrishnan

MADURAI: Extremists are trying to divide India by misguiding people on the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), former Union minister and senior BJP functionary Pon Radhakrishnan said on Friday.

He was talking to reporters after taking part in a pro-CAA rally towards the Tuticorin district collectorate that was organised by the BJP to create awareness on CAA and urging the state government to take action against those protesting against the same.

Stating that there is no problem for anyone due to CAA, Radhakrishnan said that the situation has been thrown out of proportion by portraying it as an Act against the Muslims and the common man. “Fear is instilled in their minds by spreading false news that they will be dislocated or deported from India,” he said and accused the DMK of heading them in Tamil Nadu and the Congress of guiding them.

Playing the video of an anti-CAA protester terming the ongoing protest as a next freedom fight, Radhakrishnan said that similar speeches were taken lightly when they were made from 1905 to 1947 and that it has to be viewed seriously now. “Extremists are preparing India for another partition and it will not be permitted,” he said and added that such acts are common for everyone and they don’t distinguish Hindus, Muslims and Christians.

In Madurai, a large number of cadres from the BJP and Hindu outfits took part in the pro-CAA rally on Friday.

The rally, which started at the Raja Muthiah Mandram ended at the Gandhi Memorial Museum in the evening. A large number of members started gathering at Raja Muthiah Mandram starting from noon onwards. They raised slogans supporting CAA and NRC all along the way till they were stopped at the museum. They also condemned the DMK and its allies for spreading rumours against CAA to gain political mileage.

According to police, around 1,500 cadres, inclduing 300 women from various parts of the district took part in the rally. The rally was organised by district secretary of BJP K K Sreenivasan. Around 350 police personnel were deployed throughout the stretch to make sure no untoward incident took place.

After they were stopped by the police, a group of representatives left to petition Madurai district collector T G Vinay.

Meanwhile, the protest carried out by people from the Muslim community at Rajaji Thidal in Mahaboobpalayam entered the 15th day on Friday.

Title: Burglars strike at cop’s house, steal gold, TV
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: An unknown number of burglars broke into the house of a head constable and decamped with valuables including jewellery and television in Navalpattu in Trichy recently.

According to S Balasundari, 48, from Solamanagar in Navalpattu, the theft took place when they were away from the house. Her husband Selvaraj is a head constable at Kattuputhur police station in the district. The family was living in police quarters in Kattuputhur.

On February 10, the woman visited the house owned by Solamanagar which was locked and returned. She again went to the house on Thursday and found the front door broken. The woman the checked the house and found 14 grams of gold ornaments, a television, a home theatre, two LPG filled cylinders, a wristwatch and three silk sarees stolen.

Acting on the complaint, the Thiruverumbur police visited the house and the forensic experts also looked for the finger prints but there was no finger prints there. The police registered a case.

Title: Sexual assault victim’s kin get Rs 2 lakh aid
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

Title: Chinese consul-gen to attend prayer meet
Content: Kolkata: The Chinese consul general in Kolkata, Zha Liyou, will join a prayer meet to send out a message of love, solidarity and healing to the people of China, reeling from the outbreak of novel coronavirus . The meet, which will be attended by spiritual leaders of all religions, will be held at Press Club on March 2.He was overwhelmed with gratitude and would pray that the virus be defeated soon and the battle won, Liyou told TOI. He said he was convinced that finally, human beings would win over the virus.The prayer meet has been organized by Rakshak Foundation, which has been teaching inmates at correctional homes across the state, to create handcrafted items. “China is our neighbour, with whom we have a shared history of thousands of years. In this emergency, all we can do is pray that the crisis caused by the coronavirus outbreak is controlled soon,” said Chaitali Das, spokesperson for Rakshak.The Interfaith group that has been formed in the city with religious leaders of all faiths, will be part of the prayer. The group is headed by the archbishop of the Roman Catholic church in the city. All religious heads of the group have already come out on the citizenship issue by forming a 10-km-long human chain on January 26.“It is once again time for us to come together and pray for the people of China and for all those countries where the deadly virus is spreading,” said Satnam Ahluwalia, spokesperson for the group.

Title: Rain, hailstorm in offing in U’khand on Feb 29
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Dehradun: After witnessing dry weather in past 48 hours, a fresh spell of rainfall and thunderstorm is likely to lash isolated places in Uttarakhand on February 29, according to the regional meteorological centre.

According to the Met office, weather is likely to change in both hills and plains of the Himalayan state due to an active western disturbance. A warning has also been issued of hailstorm/lightning at isolated places, especially in the hills of the state on Saturday. “Weather under the influence of western disturbance is likely to change from February 29. Plains and foothills are going to receive rainfall while higher reaches are expected to be lashed by snowfall,” said Bikram Singh, director of regional meteorological centre.

Title: Tuticorin firing probe panel completes 19th sitting
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Madurai: The government appointed one-member retired justice Aruna Jagadeesan commission of inquiry on Friday completed its 19th sitting of the anti-Sterlite protest and police firing, which claimed the lives of 13 people. The five-day sitting in the commission’s camp office at the government circuit house in Tuticorin began on Monday.

Those who appeared before the commission include journalists who covered the incident. The commission’s counsel Arul Vadivel told reporters that so far, a total of 459 witnesses had testified before the commission till date and 634 documents have been marked. In this sitting, they summoned 31 people including actor Rajinikanth. While 15 of them appeared before the commission, 10 people had submitted affidavits and will be summoned in the next sitting to testify, he said. The next sitting has been scheduled for five days from March 17. tnn

Title: Traffic dept takes action against illegal parking
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Kolhapur: The traffic department initiated action against illegal parking of vehicles, illegal autorickshaw stops which leads to a traffic jam on the road from Chhatrapati Pramila Raje (CPR) chowk to Bhawani mandap.

This is the main road that leads to the Mahalaxmi temple which is always crowded. Traffic police along with the help of the officials of Kolhapur Municipal Corporation and the police department removed six illegal stalls.

They seized dozens of tables, chairs, fridge and other materials found in various stalls occupying the footpaths and the roads.

Vasant Babar, police inspector in-charge of the traffic department said, “We had received several complaints from people that the Bhausingji road from CPR chowk to Bhawani mandap is crowded due to illegal parking and encroachment by hawkers. On Friday, we launched the drive with the help of the KMC officials and cleared the road.”

He said, “The autorickshaw drivers are usually found parking their vehicles illegally on this road every day but once we launched the drive in the morning, they went back to their assigned autorickshaw stops.”

“The drive continued till late afternoon and we cleared obstructions from CPR chowk, Shivaji statue, Bindu chowk and from Bhawani mandap,” he said.

“At one instance, two hawkers attempted to obstruct our action. We detained them and took them to the Juna Rajwada police station,” he said.

Police have registered cases against them under section 353 of the Indian Penal Code for obstructing government officials from doing his duty. Police have not yet arrested them.

“The drive will continue for the next few days and we will ensure that no one parks their vehicles or any hawker occupies the road illegally,” he said.

Title: By June, government will launch Chennai Metro rail Phase-2 work
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Industries minister M C Sampath launching the ‘sugarbox’ entertainment app on Friday

CHENNAI: In another four months, metro rail will reach another milestone as a 9km line will link the heart of the city to north Chennai, while construction of the ambitious 118.9km phase-2 will be officially inaugurated.

“The foundation stone laying ceremony will happen in June or July this year. We will also open the 9km line between Washermenpet to Wimco Nagar by June,” said state industries minister MC Sampath, on the sidelines of the inauguration of a passenger entertainment system on Friday.

The minister said the delay in Centre’s release of their share for the project will not hinder the construction of phase-2 line.

Title: Contempt petition filed against Rampur admin, jail staff over shifting Azam, family to Sitapur jail
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Rampur: Samajwadi Party leader Muhammad Azam Khan’s counsel on Friday filed a contempt petition against Rampur jail authorities, local administration and the police over the transfer of the party leader, his wife Tazeen Fatimah and son Abdullah Azam from Rampur jail to Sitapur district jail.

Azam’s counsel Khalil Ullaha Khan informed the court, headed by additional district and sessions judge Dhirendra Kumar Kamboj, that their transfer amounts to “custodial torture” as they were forcefully shifted to Sitapur jail without informing the court.

Khan also cited the judgments of the Supreme Court and the Allahabad high court while presenting his arguments.

“Tazeen Fatimah is suffering from spinal related diseases and Azam Khan is a patient of high blood pressure. They were forced to travel for five hours and sent to Sitapur district jail without informing the court,” Khan said.

Responding to the argument, state government’s counsel Ajay Tiwari said Azam and his family were shifted due to security reasons.

The team of the prosecution counsels, headed by Tiwari, also produced the Uttar Pradesh government order 2018 which talks about the transfer of the under trial jail inmates to another jail without informing the court.

Tiwari told the court that Azam Khan and his wife Tazeen Fatimah would also get better medical facility inside Sitapur jail. “Since Lucknow is merely 90 kilometres from there, they can get better treatment if any compilation occurs,” Tiwari said.

The next date of hearing has been fixed on March 3.

Meanwhile, responding to the contempt petition, Rampur district magistrate Aunjaneya Kumar Singh said, “The administrative and the police officers have not committed any contempt. We have taken appropriate legal decision as per the government order. We will file appropriate reply of the petition before the hon'ble court into the matter."

Earlier in the day, Azam Khan’s daughter-in-law Sidra Khan visited Sitapur jail.

Title: CHARUSAT hosts ‘smart Gujarat hackathon’
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

The 36-hour non-stop event ended on Friday

Vadodara/ Anand: Charotar University of Science and Technology (CHARUSAT) along with Gujarat Knowledge Society (GKS) organised the regional round of Smart Gujarat for New India Hackathon 2019-20 at its Changa-based campus.

The 36-hour non-stop event which ended on Friday witnessed participation of 193 teams consisting of 1,034 students, 120 mentors from various academic institutions across the state.

The teams solved 74 problems like waste water management system, smart agriculture, smart dustbin, development of curcumin dispersible tablet, improving stability of clavulanic acid in finished solid oral dosage form among others.

The problems were given to them by various industries, government departments and government agencies. A total of 45 jury members from government institutes and industries judged the event.

Over 30 teams from Faculty of Technology and Engineering of CHARUSAT participated in the hackathon. A total of seven institutes are hosting regional rounds of Smart Gujarat for New India Hackathon 2019-20 in which 1,519 student teams consisting of 7,919 students, 275 jury members, 159 academic institutions participated.

“Hackathons provide an ecosystem to students where they solve big problems of industries, government departments and other agencies,” said Dr K G Maradia, convenor of the hackathon and member of the execution committee from Directorate of Technical Education and GKS.

He said that selected teams will get Rs 2 lakh support and will be connected to state ecosystem under student start-up and innovation policy of state’s education department for technical and financial support.

Title: Symposium to motivate examinees
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Madurai: Corporation commissioner S Visakan urged candidates writing competitive exams to work hard and persevere to attain success at a public symposium held at the corporation office grounds on Thursday.

The symposium on ‘How to succeed in competitive exams’ was mainly organized for candidates who prepare for competitive exams like TNPSC, UPSC, TET, bank etc. Government officials from various districts in Tamil Nadu took part in the symposium and shared their knowledge with the students.

The chief guest of the event Visakan, emphasized the importance of hard work and determination in his address. “Everyone should make their own path to success and not compare themselves,” he said.tnn

Title: HC clarifies on ‘senior lawyer’ for trial of SC/ST cases
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: Who is a ‘senior’ lawyer to be nominated by district collectors to conduct trials under SC/ST (Prevention of Atrocities) Act, 1989? Is he a designated senior counsel or a lawyer of eminence with considerable standing in the Bar?

Clarifying this tickling issue, the first bench of Madras high court Chief Justice A P Sahi and Justice Subramonium Prasad said: “Even though a long standing at the Bar beyond the period of 10 years may be a necessary benchmark, apart from this, the eminence of a lawyer should be gauged from the nature and number of cases handled by him, particularly in the field of criminal law, to place him in the panel of eminent senior advocates.”

The judges were addressing the issue, after one Mallika filed a petition in 2008 to declare the term ‘senior’ as found in Rule 4(5) of SC/ST Rules as null and void. She had said that years of practice in itself would not be sufficient to decide the eminence of a lawyer. She said guidelines may be fixed by the court or the state government keeping not only the years of practice in mind, but also the actual and effective practice of a lawyer befitting his accomplishments.

The judges observed that the petition raised a question of vital importance pertaining to legal assistance provided to SC/ST people and the level of competence of lawyers to be engaged for conducting a case on behalf of the prosecution to protect the sanctity of the procedure and also to ensure justice to the victim.

The judges also said the state government must formulate guidelines and parameters so that it could be uniformly applied by district collectors to assess the eminence of lawyers, the judges said, adding: “Care should be taken about integrity and ethical standards of the lawyer as well, which is more important in matters of such crimes to ensure that the advocate is otherwise not influenced either way while conducting the trial.

Title: ACB raid of hosps enters Day 2
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Vijayawada: The Anti-Corruption Bureau ( ACB ) continued checks at government hospitals in four districts — Visakhapatnam, Vizianagaram, Srikakulam and East Godavari — for the second day on Friday and uncovered several irregularities.

During the raids at Community Health Centre, Pathapatnam in Srikakulam district, sleuths found irregularities in the pharmacy and blood test wings. The officials exposed the nexus between the hospital staff and private medical shops as the staff purchased medicines from the private medical shops for patients. The officials also found that the staff of the hospital asked patients to undergo blood tests in the private diagnostic centers and collected commission from the centres.

Irregularities were also found at Community Health Centre, Bhogapuram in Vizianagaram district. The officials observed that the deputy civil surgeon of the centre withdrew some amount from the hospital development society funds for repair works without following due procedure and calling tenders for the works. It was found that some medicines were bought without purchase orders, violating the procedure of procurement and there was a mismatch of medicine stock in the centre.

At NTR Hospital in Anakapalle, the diet registers were poorly maintained and there was a difference between the number of inpatients as per the register and the actual number of patients in the IP wards.

There was no proper mechanism for the utilization of medicines in the dispensary, ACB officials observed.

Title: Officials take bribe through touts, farmers tell collector
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: Collector S Sivarasu has warned government officials who demand bribe for discharging their official duties of strict action. Farmers at the grievance meet alleged that government officials have invented news ways to take bribe from people through touts, even as services can be availed online bypassing touts. Responding to a complaint, the collector said that he would order the police to conduct searches at the government offices where bribery complaints are rampant.

The collector made the statement after Puratchi Thalaivar MGR social workers association president V Ganesan from Musiri raised allegation of interference by touts at all the government offices, particularly in getting certificates for income, nativity, community etc. After listening to the complaint, the collector denied it stating that people can apply for certificates and other services online where touts and bribery is not possible.

Accepting the collector’s reply, Ganesan said that the online system has failed to serve its purpose because touts persuade applicants as they are able get files quickly processed with the connivance of officers concerned and fleece them.

“Though the online system is in place, touts are taking the call in many of the offices because the officers keep the touts to indirectly take bribe from applicants. Having no other option, the applicant also shell out their hard earned money to get the work done at the earliest. Or, they will have to wait for a long time and made to run from pillar to post,” said Ganesan.

A farmers’ association leader who was also part of the grievance day meeting also echoed the same view that many of the government officials were inventing novel ways to fleece the general public to clear their files.

Ganesan also complained to the collector about missing boards at the offices of village administrative officers (VAO) which has the working hours. “None of the VAO offices has the board mentioning the working hours. It should be in place so that the people can meet them conveniently,” he said. The collector has assured to look into the matter.

Title: APNRTS recruiting teachers for US schools
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Vijayawada: Andhra Pradesh Non-Resident Telugu Society (APNRTS) continues to provide job opportunities to teachers from Andhra Pradesh in United States of America (USA). In a fresh round of recruitment, APNRTS in association with Acclaim Global Education India Private Limited, a subsidiary of Star Tech Group, USA has selected 10 teachers to work at Ector County Independent School and Kermit Independent School District.

APNRTS conducted online eligibility test for mathematics and science teachers on January 23, 2020. As many as 96 teachers have taken the eligibility test out of which 10 were selected. The remaining applications are under process of being assessed, said APNRTS in a statement on Friday. Further, APNRTS is going to recruit more teachers specialised in English and special education for district schools of Texas, USA as part of the global placement drive. Any teacher with B.Ed or M.Ed with a minimum experience of five years is eligible to undergo the required tests. Lecturers working in colleges are also eligible to apply. Certified special educators will be preferred for the special educator posts.

Selected teachers will travel to USA under J1 visa to work for five years. TOFEL exam with minimum score 22 in reading, 22 in listening, 24 in speaking and 21 in writing is a prerequisite for the visa approval. Before departure, all the teachers will be given a two-week orientation program at APNRTS office, Tadepalli to familiarise them with teaching techniques, protocols and syllabus followed in US schools.

Interested candidates can register themselves at https://dev.apnrts.ap.gov.in/home/teacherjobs. The last date for registration will be March 5, 2020.

Title: 3-day water conclave concludes in Roorkee
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Roorkee: On the last day of the three-day-long Roorkee Water Conclave , experts stressed on taking steps to combat global warming and checking misuse of water.

The event was jointly organised by IIT-Roorkee and National Institute of Hydrology, Roorkee. Speaking during the conclave on Thursday, Raghu Murtugudde, a professor of oceanic science at University of Maryland, said, “The Pacific Ocean is pumping some of the heat through the Indonesian seas into the Indian Ocean… If Bay of Bengal continues to heat up, we will be at risk of cyclones.”

Ramesh Kanwar, professor at Iowa State University, highlighted the misuse of water in agriculture sector of India and advocated for giving incentives on using micro-irrigation systems and water harvesting systems. A total of 42 technical papers were presented during the event. Director general of National Mission for Clean Ganga RR Mishra, as well as other experts like AP Dimri, PP Majumdar, Artemi Cerda, Malini Shankar, Piet Lens, and Yutaka Matsuno delivered keynote lectures during the event.

Title: Chennai: MTC reduces frequencies of AC buses during weekends
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

The frequency cut on Sundays will mostly affect buses on routes 102, 570, 21G and 91

CHENNAI: The Metropolitan Transport Corporation has reduced frequencies of new air-conditioned buses during weekends.

Nearly 29 out of the 48 new AC buses will not be operated on Sundays so that that they can serviced at depots as a part of weekly maintenance drives. The other 19 buses will not run on Saturdays.

This includes buses operated along routes 102 (Kelambakkam-Broadway), 570 (Kelambakkam-Koyambedu), 21G (Tambaram-Brodway) and 91 (Thiruvanmiyur-Tambaram).

Orders were issued to all depot managers regarding this on February 20. TOI has a copy of the order that came into effect from February 22.

A senior MTC official clarified that that there were no intentions to cut down frequencies but maintenance works were unavoidable.

“Weekends will be the best time to service the buses as crowd is less compared to regular working days,” the official said.

The 48 buses had hit city roads in January this year. Ticket cost on these buses is higher compared to regular MTC buses.

Passengers are charged Rs 15 to Rs 60 per head for travelling in AC buses. On an average, an AC bus collects Rs 14,000 per day, according to official data.

Besides cost, confusion over bus colours has deterred many from opting for AC buses, said G Venkatraman, a resident of Tambaram.

While all new buses were painted red, grey colour was chosen for AC buses.

Title: Fund woes hit rare disease patients
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Participants perform at a rare disease awareness program held at Indira Priyadarshini auditorium on Friday

HYDERABAD: The draft of the National Policy for Rare Diseases introduced by the Union government on January 13, this year, was much debated in medical circles due to the suggestion of using crowdfunding as a method of addressing funding issues. Even as the world observes World Rare Disease Day, several patient groups and experts say that the Centre’s suggestion is hardly a solution, given the huge cost of medicines and support infrastructure involved.

“It is like saying if you have a problem, beg for it and solve it yourself. Crowdfunding is a wrong premise for a policy, especially for funding. The fact is that as it is entirely dependent on people’s individual mood to donate, it is not a sustainable model,” said Syed Sanaullah, management committee member, Indian Organization of Rare Diseases (IORD) adding that the government must earmark a basic fund to start with.

While access to orphan drugs (drugs used for treatment of rare diseases) is difficult due to unavailability, as per IORD, of over 450 U.S. Food and Drug Administration approved orphan drugs, only a handful are available in India. Additionally, the prohibitive cost means less availability.

“In such a scenario, delay by even a few hours when a drug is needed can mean loss of life. It seems like the government is washing its hands off by suggesting crowdfunding,” said Karimulla Shaik, who lost a child to Spinal muscular atrophy.

Listing voluntary crowdfunding as an option, the draft policy document stated, “Keeping in view the resource constraint and competing health priorities, it will be difficult for the government to fully finance treatment of high cost rare diseases.”

The policy document elaborated that the notified hospitals will share information relating to the patients and the diseases they are suffering from, prognosis, estimated cost of treatment and details of bank accounts for donation/ contribution through online system. This will allow donors to view the details of patients and donate funds to a particular hospital.

Experts, meanwhile suggest that having a dedicated corpus fund can be the way forward. “It would be helpful if the Central and state governments could set-up a MediFund with seedfunding. Various companies and NGOs could organize fund-raising events to add to this MediFund. Every rupee raised through donation must be matched by three rupees by the government,” said Nidhi Swarup, who is launching a patients support group for Crohn’s diseases in Hyderabad and a few other cities, and runs a group in Singapore. They also suggested that tax-incentives can be provided to individual and corporate donors.

Title: Vadodara: Man dies of severe burns in house fire
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Satish Pardesi

VADODARA: A 25-year-old man died from severe burns in Wadi area of the city on Friday afternoon. Fire brigade rushed to the spot and managed to control the blaze after battling for half-an-hour.

According to the firemen, smoke began billowing from the house of Satish Pardesi , who stays on the third floor of Shreeji Dham Complex in Wadi area, at about 2 pm. The neighbours called up fire brigade that reached the spot within few minutes. “The door was locked from inside and so we had to break it open. The entire hall of the flat was damaged and Pardesi was lying on the floor,” said Om Jadeja, fire officer.

Pardesi was rushed to the hospital but he was declared dead.

Police is investigating if Pardesi set himself or the house on fire. “We are waiting for FSL reports to ascertain the cause of fire and if any inflammable liquid was used. Locals claimed that he got married over a year ago but used to have frequent fights with his wife. The incident occurred when he was alone at home.

Title: Inquisitive minds flock to Isro space expo
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Madurai: Thousands of students from schools and colleges in and around Madurai district flocked the Isro Space Expo 2020 here to learn from original models of engine, rocket and satellite parts brought straight from the Indian Space Research Organisation (Isro) during the three-day expo which kicked off on Thursday.

“We were excited when we were told we were going to see rockets. We love science, and have even made models and experimented at our school. But, this is the first time, I’m seeing actual parts of a rocket,” said Sri Devi N, a Class IX student from a government high school. Over 50 stalls were put up at the expo covering various topics about Indian space history, rockets, satellites, space and astrophysics. Models, demonstrations, posters, charts and even videos were played to make learning about space fun and exciting for students.

The expo is organized in Madurai by ISRO Propulsion Complex (IPRC) and Velammal College of Engineering and Technology, as part of ISRO’s Vikram Sarabhai Centenary Programme. The exhibition was inaugurated by Madurai district collector Dr TG Vinay in the presence of K Alaguvelu, director, IPRC on Thursday. More than 27,000 students and public visited the expo in the first two days.

Title: Three human rights ‘activists’ trying to extort money caught
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

The accused trio in police custody

VADODARA: Bapod police arrested three persons who tried to extort money from a truck driver on national highway late on Thursday. The trio introduced themselves as members of International Human Rights Organization (IHRO) and even produced identity cards.

According to the police, complainant Sakeer Sindhi said that the accused identified as Ankit Rana, Ashraf Haji and Manish Koshti , all residents of Ahmedabad, stopped his truck and started probing what goods he was ferrying. Sindhi told them that he was transporting goats to Mumbai. One of the accused suddenly slapped Sindhi, followed by the other two too. They then demanded Rs 10,000 from Sindhi and in an attempt to put pressure on him, even placed a call to the police control room.

“We questioned the trio and even checked their identity cards of IHRO. We even called the helpline of the organization and it was confirmed that the identity cards were genuine. They had joined the organization just one-and-half months ago,” said V P Chauhan, police inspector, Bapod.

“The accused were trying to extort money from Sindhi. We have arrested them and will soon write to the organization to cancel their identity cards,” Chauhan added.

The cops are also investigating if the trio had extorted money with similar modus operandi from any other person in the past.

Title: Schools peeved at misspelt Tamil names on hall tickets
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: The Tamil names of class X and XII students at many of the city schools, both government and private, who are writing their board exams next month, are getting misspelt on their hall tickets . While there is a provision to get it corrected, the issue has inconvenienced teachers and parents.

Nowadays the candidates’ names appear in both English and Tamil on hall tickets and mark sheets. The school is responsible for providing hall tickets, which are downloaded by uploading the students’ information online. “We had many cases where Tamil names were getting misspelt. Even when we type correctly, due to some technical error, the font end up changing at different spots thereby leading to a misspelt name. Sometimes, we also had the candidates’ date of birth going wrong,” said the principal of a private school. Several students and parents said they had to repeatedly ask to make corrections.

“Hall tickets for class XII students were first printed early because of practical examinations. We found that many students had misspelt names at that time and corrected them temporarily with red ink. However, later in the final nominal roll, all corrections were made and it was resolved. But, it was definitely a troublesome work,” said a teacher at a corporation school. Schools also said they were being blamed for an issue that is not in their control. “Parents think we are the ones making the mistake and many of them get easily annoyed. The students are inconvenienced when they have to repeatedly check such basic things,” added the teacher.

Meanwhile, education officials maintained that it was a matter for the heads of schools to handle and they had no part in it. “Even if it is an issue now, there is ample time to correct and processes are in place to ensure least disturbance. What matters is what appears on the final mark sheets. Till then, there is plenty of scope for making corrections,” said a senior district education official.

Title: Over 5,000 take part in Vignan fest
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Students perform at Vignan cultural fest in Guntur on Friday

Guntur: Putting students on high alert, AP State Council for Higher Education (APSCHE) vice-chairman Dr K Rammohan Rao said it wouldn’t be too long until people faced competition from robots in the job market. He called upon students to go out of the box and come up with new ideas to stay in the race. He said routine studies and scoring well in the subjects alone would not help in the future after the development of artificial intelligence. Dr Rao was addressing an annual sports and culture festival at Vignan Nirula Women’s Engineering College on Friday.

The college campus at Palakalur village on the outskirts of the city teemed with over 5,000 girl students from different engineering colleges and universities across the state. Speaking on the occasion, Dr Rao said that more than 30 million robots would be working in different industries in the next five years. “Competition might get bigger and tough with the arrival of robots in a massive scale. You will be required to work overtime to outsmart robots and grab lucrative jobs,” cautioned Dr Rao. He advised the students to learn at least a few foreign languages right at the degree level in order to get jobs in the future. He said expertise in big data, ethical hacking, networking and data science would be a must in the next few years.

Vignan Group chairman Dr Lavu Rathaiah, however, said that only team work would pave way for success in future. He asked the students to become social animals to achieve success as no one could achieve success as singles in the coming days. “Don’t always think about big victories. Try to be courageous to face defeat. It will only make you a champion,” said Dr Rathaiah.

Later in the evening, film crew of Ore Bujjiga including hero Raj Tharun, music director Anoop Rubens and singer Meghana interacted with the students on campus.

Title: Mahim Verma to contest for CAU secretary
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Dehradun: BCCI vice-president Mahim Verma filed his nomination for the election of the secretary post in Cricket Association of Uttarakhand (CAU) on Thursday. Interestingly, Verma resigned as the secretary of CAU in October 2019 as he got elected unopposed as the vice president of BCCI in the same month. Verma has served as the CAU secretary for around two months as he was elected unopposed in August 2019.

“I have filed my nomination for the post of the CAU secretary and will contest the election with my full dedication. I decided to contest the election as I can see that the development of the sport is not taking place by my standards in Uttarakhand. Therefore, I believe that it is important for me to return back as CAU secretary in order to speed up the development process here,” he said.

Verma asserted that if he wins the election, he will resign from the post of BCCI vice-president. “According to Lodha reforms, a person cannot hold two posts. So, I will resign from the post of BCCI vice-president if I win the election as CAU is my priority,” said Verma.

Notably, the final list of the candidates will be declared on February 29 but as per the tentative list, six candidates are contesting for the post —Mahim Verma, Deepak Mehra, Kumar Thapa, Sanjay Gusain, Rajeev Jindal, and Siddharth Bisht.

The nomination of Verma has sparked a speculation that CAU has got divided into factions. However, the members of the cricketing body are dismissing such speculations and stress that the unity of the association is intact.

To recall, it was after years of struggle that CAU had received recognition from BCCI in August 2019.

Title: Ousted Nyay Mandir florists up in arms against VMC
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Vadodara: Florists who were operating since decades opposite the Nyay Mandir are up in arms against the civic body after they were asked to leave the place ahead of the inauguration of the renovated Sursagar pond. The florists are not being allowed to return to the place from where they operated.

The Nyay Mandir had become a go to destination for many looking for flowers, garlands and bouquets. While the florists here did not keep exotic varieties of flowers, they were very popular for the local varieties of flowers like marigold, roses, jasmine, magnolia, lotus and others.

Florists held protests at Nyay Mandir stating that ahead of the inauguration of Sursagar they were asked to leave temporarily for security reasons and to avoid congestion in the area. They alleged that even after the inauguration, they were not being allowed to return.

It seems that the florists were caught unawares of a notification brought out by the civic body ahead of the Sursagar inauguration. The notification had barred street vending in the periphery of Sursagar as well as around Nyay Mandir.

The florists said that they had been permitted by the VMC and were also paying rent to the civic body. The florists had even gone to make representations to VMC officials on Thursday night, but did not get proper response. They have also met the mayor seeking permission to set up shops again.

Title: Synchronised bird census begins
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Tiruvarur: A two-day synchronized annual bird census began at three bird sanctuaries in Tiruvarur and Ariyalur districts on Friday to survey migratory and resident birds in this region.

Jointly conducted by the forest department and the Biodiversity Conservation Foundation (BCF) in Trichy, a 30-member team surveyed Muthupet Lagoon (mangrove forest ecosystem), Vaduvur and Uthayamarthadapuram bird sanctuaries in Tiruvarur on Friday.

The study, on the migratory pattern and nesting behaviour, is part of assessing the status of the bird sanctuaries. “There was a slight decline in arrival of birds last year following Gaja cyclone. However, the direct impact of the cyclone can be ascertained only this year based on migratory pattern of the bird species,” said S Ramasubramanian, conservator of forest, Thanjavur circle.

“Teams from Vellore Institute of Technology (VIT), Periyar EVR College and ornithologists from across state are taking part in the census,” said conservation scientist A Kumaraguru, founder director of BCF, who gave orientation to the team on the census.

Kumaraguru said that the migratory season starts from January when migratory birds start moving from Rann of Kutch in Gujarat and arrive in central regions.

“A total of 114 bird species were recorded last year. This was slightly less than the previous year when 138 species were recorded in these sanctuaries,” Tiruvarur district forest officer K Arivoli said.

“The population of spoon bill, painted stork, pelicans and greater flamingo have fallen significantly post Gaja cyclone in the sanctuary,” he said.

In the bird census at Karaivetti bird sanctuary in Ariyalur, 30 students from the zoology and biology streams of arts and science colleges in the district took part. Karaivetti is one of the biggest freshwater bird sanctuaries in the state with over 20,000 migratory and resident birds.

As a part of the annual exercise to encourage students in exploring ornithology, the study of birds, Ariyalur forest department conducts the enumeration of migratory and resident birds in the sanctuary. “The enumeration programme will go on till 7pm on Saturday. With the support of ornithologists, data gathered will be analysed to study the diversity of the sanctuary,” a forest department official said.

Title: DMC falls short of house tax target as govt offices fail to pay up
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Dehradun: With just a month left before the 2019-20 financial year ends, Dehradun Municipal Corporation ( DMC ) might not be able to meet its house tax target of Rs 50 crore. The civic body said it that it is 20% short of its target, having been able to collect Rs 40 crore tax till date. It attributed the shortage to government offices failing to pay their property taxes.

Notably, 86 government offices were newly incorporated in the list of property tax payers in the financial year 2019-20. The defaulters in this category include Mussoorie Dehradun Development Authority, Uttarakhand Housing and Urban Development Authority, Uttarahand Waqf Board, Madarsa Doon Urdu Academy, Uttarakhand State Biodiversity Board, Uttarakhand Jal Sansthan, Uttarakhand Skill Development Mission, and Uttarakhand Transport Corporation among others.

“When we served them the notice, the authorities expressed inability to submit property tax, stating that their departmental budget had no provision for payment of property tax. Some of them have promised to pursue the matter in the next financial year and make adequate arrangements to clear the liability,” DMC Commissioner Vinay Shankar Pandey told TOI.

Meanwhile, DMC officials said that they had already exceeded their last year's property tax target of Rs 25 crore. On plans to boost tax collection for the upcoming financial year, authorities said that individual owners and commercial property owners will remain the focus. “We are providing a tax rebate to encourage self-submission of house tax,” said Dharmesh Penuli, Revenue and Tax Superintendent, DMC.

Penuli added that the exact property tax expected from all the 89 government offices is being calculated. However, estimates point the figure to be around Rs 8 crore for the financial year 2019-20.

Officials stated that the house tax collected will be kept aside as “Nagar Nigam Fund” and will be dedicated for the maintenance of city infrastructure and provide for creation of new building pathways, cleaning of drains and other developmental work.

Title: Tamil Nadu: 60,000 tree saplings uprooted to build road, community hall
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

The stretch where tree saplings were removed to make way for a concrete road in Chengalpet

CHENNAI: More than 60,000 tree saplings planted at an open space reserve in Mahindra World City, Chengalpet, were uprooted to lay roads for an upcoming community hall .

A section of local residents have moved the Madras high court alleging that the location chosen for the hall, currently surrounded by industries, was too far from their houses.

Mahindra World City Limited (MWCL), an industrial park located 27 km from Tambaram, in 2012, gifted 76 acres (10% of total land extent) to Anjur village panchayat, as mandated by law.

In 2018, 1.7 lakh tree saplings were planted in the 10% reserve land by MWCL with the help of various NGOs.

In 2019, Kancheepuram district collector P Ponniah (before bifurcation of Chengalpet district) ordered construction of a community hall and access roads at the site named 'Greenery-40', which is a part of the reserve land, at a cost of Rs 72 lakh, according to official documents.

Recently, all saplings at the site were uprooted and the government began laying roads.

Local residents lodged a complaint with the collector along with photographic evidence and later moved the HC.

Petitioner V Rajendran questioned the need to choose a distant site when the local body had already passed a resolution earlier to construct a community hall at a site near their houses.

VT Leemarose, local block development officer, denied all these allegations while speaking to TOI. She, however, informed the court that the local body had no role in choosing the site for community hall.

The actual reason to lay this road was to connect a newly-opened private CBSE school to the main road, the petitioner said. This was done to ensure school vans did not have to take a detour to reach the school, Vikas Mantra Public School, run by the son of an AIADMK MP, a source said.

When TOI visited the spot, it was evident that the road was laid till the school's compound wall and didn't end at the site proposed for community hall. This site was located clearly 150m-200m before the school.

Civic activist SP Thiyagarajan said that no construction should actually happen at OSR lands but government should first clarify whether such halls were exempted from the rule.

Title: Adnan Sami: As a Muslim, I feel safe in India
Content: Singer-musician Adnan Sami on Friday said that as a Muslim he feels safe in India and the Citizenship Amendment Act is for fast-tracking people wanting citizenship and is not for Indians in India."As a Muslim, I feel safe in India," he said, answering a query at an event."Citizenship Amendment Act is for fast-tracking people wanting citizenship and is not for Indians in India," Sami said answering another query.He was asked about remarks of actor Aamir Khan made in 2015, where the actor said that his wife had stated that she does not feel safe in India. Khan's remarks had created an uproar in social media."I am not here to answer whatever Aamir Khan has to say. As far as I am concerned, I am a Muslim. I respect all religions, I celebrate all religions. I celebrate humanity in whichever form it comes. I had so many options, but if I felt that I wanted to come to India, being a Muslim doesn't that say something about how secure I would feel," said Sami, whose father served in Pakistan Air Force Answering a query on the sidelines of the even about violence in Delhi, the 46-year-old musician said it is very unfortunate."I hope peace is restored soon. Being a musician, I always talk about love and peace. I request everyone to talk and maintain peace. I request everyone to respect life and there is nothing that conversation can sort out all issues. I request people to bring peace in the country," said Sami, a Padma Shri awardee.Asked if the issue was being politicised, he said the matter is being politicised."I fold my hands and request people to foster peace and harmony," he said.

Title: Gujarat: Communal clashes only strengthen this Hindu-Muslim friendship
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Sattar Vohra and Pravin Chunara (R) both of their houses were left completely charred

VADODARA/ANAND: For three consecutive days last week, Anand’s coastal town Khambhat remained on the boil. But in Akbarpura locality, at the epicentre of communal riots in town, these septuagenarians did not let smiles on their face wane despite rioters leaving their houses completely charred.

The decades-old friendship between Sattar Vohra and Pravin Chunara, both in their mid-70s, has remained rock solid despite frequent flare-ups in this sensitive locality.

They have been neighbours since childhood and the rioters set ablaze both their houses. But every riot has only strengthened their bond. Vohra and Chunara blame social media for frequent flare-ups in this sensitive area.

The duo has their residence in Akbarpura area of Khambhat where just a petty argument between kids of Muslims and Chunaras playing on the streets have often snowballed into full-fledged riots that leave several including cops injured.

The recent flare-up which Akbarpura witnessed between members of the two communities was the first time that both Sattar and Pravin lost the only roof they had. But they are helping each other, gathering whatever is left from the charred metal sheets that once provided them shelter.

“As kids we have played ‘kancha’ (marbles) together, shared biscuits from the same packet and snacks that we used to take to school. We have been friends since we were kids and nothing has shaken our bond,” said Pravin, who stays with his nephew at a house just 300 metres away Sattar’s.

Pravin has lost all his documents including ration card, identity cards like election card, aadhar card, clothes, shawls which the rioters set on fire along with the small house where he stayed.

Like him, Sattar too has nothing much left except smoke-blackened tin sheets from the ‘kutcha’ house that the rioters set ablaze.

“It must be a loss of nearly Rs 4 lakh. I had gathered some cash which I was supposed to return for the two buffaloes that I had purchased. But even that has turned into ash,” said Sattar. The cattle was his only source of income.

Title: Chennai Corporation to pick six design consultants by March-end for mega streets project
Content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: Chennai Corporation will finalise the design consultants for the first phase of the mega streets project by March-end, after which they will be expected to create a plan for pilot project.According to civic officials, sixteen consultants from across the country have applied to be part of the project; six will be selected. Each will be allotted a neighbourhood in the first phase, which is divided into six packages.The selected consultants will study a total of 110 kms of arterial and sub arterial roads in six neighbourhoods -- Anna Nagar, Tondiarpet, Nungambakkam, Mylapore , Velachery and Adyar — and come up with a holistic plan.“Each neighbourhood has a different characteristic and that is why we are opting for a different consultant for each neighbourhood, instead of one for the whole phase,” an official with the city corporation said.The design will also have to account for utilities underground as much as those above ground to ensure that no road cut is done for the next 30 years.The project, which was announced earlier this month, was given a fillip in the Tamil Nadu budget, which provided Rs750 crore for the Integrated Urban Development Mission (IUDM) and Rs500 crore for Chennai Mega City Development.Chennai became the first city in the country to adopt a non-motorised transport policy in 2014, prioritising its pedestrians. The city’s first pedestrian plaza in Pondy Bazaar inaugurated three months ago is an example that we back up our vision, said a senior engineer with the civic body.Why does the city need a mega streets programme though? Researchers at the Institute of Transportation and Development Policy (ITDP), think-tank partners of the city corporation for the project, point out that our city roads push the vulnerable road users -- pedestrians, cyclists, differently abled — to the fringes, resulting in loss of lives.In 2017, 3,507 pedestrians were killed in Tamil Nadu, the highest in the country followed by Maharashtra (1,831) and Andhra Pradesh (1,379).“Unsafe roads also lead to inactive lifestyles. If we look at cities across the world, they are envisioning a system for greener and healthier cities,” said Aswathy Dilip, senior programme manager at The Institute for Transportation and Development Policy.Singapore has prepared a land transport master plan, envisioning safer, healthier roads with vibrant community spaces, which it aims to achieve by 2040. London has an action-plan to encourage walking and wants to become the most walkable city in the world, Ashwathy said.“If we look at Singapore, there are covered walkways and benches for pedestrians to rest. Similar practices can be adopted here,” Ashwathy said.

Title: Call to connect edu, research, innovation
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Trichy: Arabinda Mitra, scientific secretary, office of the principal scientific advisor, government of India, stressed the need to connect education, research and innovation in a seamless way to deliver science and technology products that are socially relevant.

Delivering the keynote address at the science day award ceremony at the SASTRA Deemed University on Friday, he said India is the third largest start-up destination in the world.

Mentioning new initiatives of government of India, such as technical textiles, quantum computing, genomics, deep ocean technology and biodiversity, he mentioned that deep ocean technology is gaining momentum because of wide coastline of India.

Mitra appreciated the university’s initiatives to reach out to the best scientific minds. He presented the SASTRA - G N Ramachandran award to T P Singh, AIIMS, New Delhi. SASTRA – Obaid Siddiqi award was received by Upinder Singh Bhalla, National Centre for Biological Sciences (NCBS), Bengaluru, for 2020. Alejandro Sánchez Alvarado, Stowers Institute for Medical Research, USA received it for year 2019.

He presented SASTRA – C N R Rao award for 2020 to J N Moorthy, Indian Institute of Science Education and Research (IISER) Thiruvananthapuram and S Sampath, Indian Institute of Science, Bengaluru. TNN

Title: Govt removes MGNREGA social society director
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Armed with a high court order that refused to grant immunity to government officials from cancellation of deputation service, the state government on Thursday removed MGNREGA social audit society director Abey George from the post.

A government order issued late on Thursday night also pronounced the appointment of new director, E Sreekumar, social development specialist, with effect from February 28.

The government had in December issued orders for the removal of George. But the same was challenged by the official who alleged political reasons behind the premature termination of his service as the society director. The court had then stayed the termination order. The petitioner was appointed as the society director after a rigorous selection process in December 2017 for a period of three years. The fresh order for his removal was issued after the government completed the necessary formalities, which it bunked initially in its hurry to dump the official at the earliest.

It was alleged that many in the government were not much appreciative of the fastidious nature of George in conducting the affairs of the social audit society. Inspection in various panchayats had revealed that several works under MGNREA were not in sync with the guidelines.

His refusal to go by political whims in the appointment of district and village-level resource persons, say sources, prompted the government to terminate prematurely his service in the society.

The latest HC order on February 18 gave the government freehand to decide on cancellation of the deputation service of the official.

Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Dhanya, mother of Devananda, was inconsolable as her daughter’s body was brought to their house at Elavoor in ... Read More

Title: Health worker gets 3 years jail for taking Rs 300 bribe in Trichy
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: The special court for prevention of corruption act (PCA) cases in Trichy on Friday convicted a woman multipurpose health worker of taking a bribe of Rs 300 from a pregnant woman for issuing her the government’s maternity assistance.

The judge handed out simple imprisonment for one and two years to T Kalaiselvi, 39, of Ponnagar for accepting gratification and criminal misconduct respectively. The judge also ordered her to pay Rs 1,000 each as fine for the two offences. The judge however released the woman on bail considering the quantum of punishment, which is below three years.

It was a 12-year-old case that came to an end on Friday. Kalaiselvi was a multipurpose health worker at the urban primary health centre (UPHC) in Periya Milaguparai. S Elizabeth Rani, 28, a pregnant woman from Edamalaipattipudhur, enlisted her help for getting financial assistance of Rs 6,000 under the Dr Muthulakshmi Reddy maternity assistance scheme, and got the first instalment of Rs 3000 before her delivery.

After the child was born, Kalaiselvi waited for the second instalment of Rs 3,000. However, instead of giving the cheque addressed to Elizabeth Rani, she demanded Rs 300 as bribe to hand it over. Unwilling to bribe her, the woman lodged a complaint with the directorate of vigilance and anti-corruption (DVAC) in Trichy on May 27, 2008. The team laid a trap the next day and caught Kalaiselvi red-handed at the PHC when she was accepting the money from Elizhabeth Rani.

Title: KFRI helpline becomes answer to creative kids
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

THRISSUR: A helpline started by Kerala Forest Research Institute (KFRI) at Peechi in Thrissur district around a year ago has helped children in clearing doubts on a varied number of topics.

It was on February 28, 2019 that KFRI launched ‘First Question’, a project that offers children an opportunity to ask any environment-related questions through the phone. The helpline has received more than 3,000 questions from children across the country in its first year.

The kids can call the helpline (0487-2690222) from 9.30am to 5.30 pm on Monday to Friday. The members of the project will attend to the calls from children. The questions will be answered in English, Hindi, Malayalam, Telugu and Kannada languages.

“Once a call is received, we first collect basic information such as name and location of the children and then record the question. The question is then passed over to an analysis team which prepares the answer by referring a subject expert and the kid is called back and given the answer,” said prof T V Sajeev, principal scientist, KFRI.

“There are two reasons to start the helpline. The first is that very young kids even before they start going to school ask a lot of questions which are seldom taken seriously by adults. We know that unless these questions are taken seriously and scientifically answered, that would lead to their first disconnect with the process of learning,” Sajeev said.

“The kids also raise some interesting questions like what is the actual colour of a chameleon and which came first, the chicken or the egg. At many times, teachers will not have answers to these unique questions. The helpline will give answers to all these questions and also nurture the habit of asking questions on children,” he said.

“A 15-year-old boy Abhay Singh used to regularly call the helpline and ask questions. Through regular calls we tracked the kid. He was suffering from some illness and was continuing studies from home. Last month, since we didn't receive any call from him, we contacted the number. The boy's father attended the call and said he died 17 days ago. It was a big shock for us. Abhay Singh had urged us to start the helpline in all states," Sajeev said.

Title: NGT asks CRDA for Kondaveeti report
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Vijayawada: The high court on Friday directed the Capital Region Development Authority (CRDA) to file compliance report regarding National Green Tribunal (NGT) order on restoring natural flow of Kondaveeti Vaagu and Paala Vaagu in the capital region within four weeks.

The high court said the CRDA commissioner will have to attend in person if the compliance report was not submitted. Hearing a writ petition moved by K Rambabu, G Bhanu Prakash, Nayudu Ramakrishna and Abburi Kiran Kumar over the issue, the high court bench headed by Chief Justice J K Maheswari and Justice Ninala Jayasurya gave CRDA counsel four weeks to comply with the NGT order. The petitioners moved the HC as restoration works in the rivulets in accordance with the master plan of the capital and the NGT directions were stalled. They contended that the without the completion of the works, the villages in capital region are facing threat of inundation.

The high court earlier issued notices to the CRDA to file a reply on the issue.

Arguing on behalf of the petitioners, Karumanchi Indraneel Babu told the court that though the NGT had given its orders on November 17, 2017 to complete the restoration of rivulets.

Title: Kerala: Tourists entry banned in Wayanad Wildlife Sanctuary till April 15
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Entry of tourists to the Wayanad Wildlife Sanctuary (WWS) has been temporarily banned from March 1 to April 15

KOZHIKODE: Entry of tourists to the Wayanad Wildlife Sanctuary ( WWS ) has been temporarily banned from March 1 to April 15 in view of the intensifying summer and the possibility of forest fires in the 344 sq km sanctuary.

The state wildlife warden has issued an order temporarily banning the entry of tourists in the eco-tourism centres of Muthanga and Tholpetty in the sanctuary which is the prime tiger habitat in the state under Section 33 of the Wildlife Protection Act 1972.

Forest officials said that with mercury rising, large number of wild animals from the contiguous forest areas in Tamil Nadu and Karnataka have started trooping to the WWS in search of water and fodder in the largest annual inter-state animal migration in the region. “Also there is a threat of forest fires in the sanctuary due to the summer heat. If tourists are allowed entry in ecotourism zones, it would pose disturbance to wild animals,” WWS warden P K Asif said.

He added that tourist activity inside WWS during the summer months, when wildlife population swells in the sanctuary significantly, could also pose threat to the safety of tourists.

Title: Kolkata: No more queues, blood requisition set to go online
Content:
Under the existing system, when patients require blood, their families have to stand in queues at hospital ban... Read More

KOLKATA: Waiting in serpentine queues at blood banks will soon be a thing of the past as the system is set to go online, with the state health department planning to introduce e-requisition of blood.An orientation training on e-requisition software was held for representatives of all the 73 state-run blood banks at Swasthya Bhawan on Friday.Under the existing system, when patients require blood, their families have to stand in queues at hospital banks with requisition slips and blood samples. If the required units are not available in the hospital bank, they have to run from one facility to another. But once the system goes online, the application will go straight from the hospital’s ward to the hospital blood bank. If the unit is not available there, the application will be sent to other banks, like the Central Blood Bank at Maniktala.“Once the online requisition system starts, it will not only spare patients’ families the harassment but also rationalise blood supply,” said a blood safety official at Swasthya Bhawan. For example, if a patient needs 4 units of blood, the hospital bank can directly ask with the ward whether two units were enough for the moment and the remaining two could be sent later. This would prevent wastage of blood. Once the software is in place, an alert will be sent to the registered mobile number of the patients’ families about the availability of blood units.The first phase of training on how to use the software on e-requisition and e-tendering of blood at the state’s health headquarters was attended by doctors and technicians. To be implemented in phases, the pilot project is about take off at Calcutta National Medical College (CNMC). “The ground work is prepared to run the pilot project. This is a great, patient-centric initiative,” said Sandip Ghosh, medical superintendent and vice-principal at CNMCH. Once the pilot project takes off, the health department plans to implement it in Kolkata hospitals and expand it to facilities in the district. Later, it will be taken to private nursing homes and private blood banks. “We will check for glitches at CNMC and rectify them before going all out,” said a senior health official.D Asish, an activist, said, “Online requisition will also eliminate blood racket. But more blood donation camps have to be held.”

Title: Madras HC gives lower court 2 weeks to decide on Ilaiyaraaja suit
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: Madras high court on Friday directed a city civil court here to dispose of in two weeks, a plea moved by music maestro Ilayaraja seeking to restrain owners of Prasad Studio from interfering in his peaceful access to the studio for music composition.

Justice V Bharathidasan passed the order as the music composer and the studio owners failed to reach an amicable solution through mediation as suggested by the court.

Ilayaraja has been composing music at a recording theatre on the Prasad Studio campus for more than four decades and wants to continue to do so, whereas the studio management has sought to vacate him from its premises in Saligramam .

Aggrieved, Ilayaraja moved a city civil court seeking to restrain the owners of the studio or their agents from interfering in his free access to the composing room in the studio, which he was using for the past 40 years.

Subsequently, citing unreasonable delay by the civil court in disposing of the plea, Ilayaraja moved the present plea in the high court.

On December 4, Justice Bharathidasan directed the parties to appear before the mediation centre on the high court premises and try for an amicable solution to the dispute.

When the plea came up for hearing on Friday, Maestro’s counsel A Saravanan submitted he suggested to settle the dispute amicably if he was granted free access to the studio for two to three months to complete his ongoing works.

“Since the owners of the studio refused to provide the limited access, we could not arrive at an amicable solution,” Saravanan added.

Wondering why the management of the studio was not willing to accept the reasonable deal even though composing room was used by Maestro for over 40 years, the court directed the XV Assistant Judge, Chennai to dispose of the injunction plea moved by Ilayaraja in two weeks.

Title: Three Kerala districts on high temperature alert
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

The Kerala state disaster management authority (KSDMA) issued warning to the public to protect themselves from... Read More

KOCHI: Alappuzha , Kozhikode and Kannur are on alert for high temperatures of more than 2-3 degrees above normal on Saturday. Following this, the Kerala state disaster management authority (KSDMA) issued warning to the public to protect themselves from direct exposure to sun during the peak hours of 11am to 3pm.

Meanwhile, temperatures fell in some places due to showers. The state has received some light showers during the last 24 hours. While Karipur received 2mm rain, Kochi reported 4mm rain on Friday. Kudulu (Kasaragod district) reported a rainfall of 1.2mm but the state remains 58%deficient. Skymet weather said March which is looked on as a pre-monsoon month is likely to bring some rain to the state.

At present, temperatures have already grown more than 35°C on multiple occasions throughout the state, which is a little above normal. The rising temperatures are indicative of early arrival of pre-monsoon.

It predicted light to moderate showers for the next three to four days. These rains will be widely spread throughout the state while being concentrated towards the North. Places like Kozhikode, Kannur etc., are likely to receive these rains. The reason for rain will be a feeble trough extending from the southern end of Kerala to Karnataka.

Interestingly, America’s weather company AccuWeather in its annual forecast said that central and southern India are predicted to warm up much faster than average this year. Heat waves will be more frequent across these areas due to limited soil moisture to begin with. “There is even the chance the southwest monsoon can reach Kerala toward the end of May, which would be sooner than in 2019,” AccuWeather lead international meteorologist Jason Nicholls said in a statement.

Title: Woman sarpanch held taking bribe
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Sharda Baria

VADODARA: The woman sarpanch of Khanpur village panchayat in Morva Hadaf taluka of Panchmahal district was nabbed while accepting a bribe of Rs 4,000 from a man supervising the work of laying underground cables for Bharat Sanchar Nigam Ltd (BSNL).

Curiously, the woman sarpanch Sharda Baria did not seek the bribe for the ongoing work in the village. She started allegedly harassing the man and the workers under him stating that they were wrongly staying in her village. To allow the stay in the village, Baria sought a bribe of Rs 4,000 from the supervisor. The man approached the Panchmahal Anti-Corruption Bureau (ACB) that laid a trap to nab the sarpanch. She called the complainant at her residence to take the money and was held while doing so.

Title: Rajasthan CM Ashok Gehlot announces extra relief of Rs 5 lakh each to kin of Bundi bus accident victims
Content:
CM Ashok Gehlot consoles an 11-year-old boy in Kota on Friday who lost both his parents, brother and grandfath... Read More

JAIPUR: Chief minister Ashok Gehlot announced an extra financial assistance of Rs 5 lakh each to the families of 24 people who died in the bus accident at Bundi on Friday.The government had earlier announced an assistance of Rs 2 lakh each to the dependants of the deceased.The CM, who paid homage to the victims of the accident, said that the Kota divisional commissioner would probe the accident and submit a report in seven days.“The government will take further decision based on the findings of the investigation. Steps to prevent such accidents will be taken in future,” he said at the condolence meeting held for victims who died after the bus carrying a marriage party from Kota fell into Mej river in Bundi.“In this hour of grief, the government stands with all families who lost their loved ones. We will provide education to children who lost their parents in the accident. Orders will be issued to ensure assistance to families of the victims provided under various schemes of the government,” he added.Children of the affected families will receive benefits under ‘Palanhar’ and scholarship schemes. Free education up to college and hostel facilities will also be provided to them.Families of the deceased will also get benefits under social security schemes such as old-age and widow pensions. They will receive benefits under the food security scheme and grant-in for the marriage of girls in the families.At least 24 people, including 10 women and three children, were killed when the private bus they were travelling in fell into Mej river on Kota-Dausa mega highway in Bundi district early on Wednesday. The bus had people belonging a wedding party.In Video: Several feared dead after bus falls in river in Rajasthan’s Bundi

Title: National law fest kicks off at MSU
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Vadodara: A national level law fest - ‘Lux Et Veritas 2020’ kicked off at M S University’s Faculty of Law on Friday. The three-day event is being organised by the Baroda School of Legal Studies of Faculty of Law.

The national level law fest is organised every year with the intention to help students of law imbibe pragmatic skills in an atmosphere and enquire into the intricacies of different laws.

This year’s fest includes 8th national moot court competition, 7th national client counselling competition, 7th national legal drafting competition and 3rd national judgement writing competition.

Former judge of Gujarat High Court justice Pradeep Majmudar was the chief guest at the inaugural ceremony of the national law fest on Friday.

The moot court will be judged by nearly 30 judges which includes senior lawyers from preliminary round to semi-final round. The final round will be judged by sitting judges of Gujarat high court.

The preliminary round to the final round of the client counselling competition will be judged by nearly 30 judges, most of them senior lawyers. Winners of the various competitions at this law fest will receive awards up to Rs 1.20 lakh.
