Orders will be issued to ensure assistance to families of the victims provided under various schemes of the government,” he added.Children of the affected families will receive benefits under ‘Palanhar’ and scholarship schemes. Free education up to college and hostel facilities will also be provided to them.Families of the deceased will also get benefits under social security schemes such as old-age and widow pensions. They will receive benefits under the food security scheme and grant-in for the marriage of girls in the families.At least 24 people, including 10 women and three children, were killed when the private bus they were travelling in fell into Mej river on Kota-Dausa mega highway in Bundi district early on Wednesday. The bus had people belonging a wedding party.In Video: Several feared dead after bus falls in river in Rajasthan’s Bundi

Title: ‘Trans-disciplinary facets of archaeology’ unearths treasures of a bygone era
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Exhibition titled ‘Trans-disciplinary facets of Archaelogy’ got under way at Mahatma Jyotiba Phule campus, on ... Read More

Nagpur: To celebrate the rich heritage of India, the postgraduate department of ancient Indian history, culture and archaeology organized a two-day exhibition — ‘Trans-disciplinary facets of Archaeology’.

Inaugurated by Nagpur University vice chancellor SV Kane on the Mahatma Jyotiba Phule campus on Thursday, the first day

saw students of indology preparing a Vedic thali with recipes based on the ancient diet system.

Nearly 4,000-year-old pre-historic stone tools retrieved through excavation by university students were displayed at the exhibition.

Black on red ware from the Harappan site of Bhirdana, Jorwe culture pottery and painted grey ware from Sinauli were the fascinating artefacts that caught many an eye.

The exhibition also featured replicas of sculptures of Durga from the 10th century and Vishnu’s head from the 11th century made of Plaster of Paris. On display were megalithic iron implements and semi-precious stones like jasper, carnelian and crystal.

Photos of human vandalism at heritage sites and smuggling and its antiquarian laws were pinned on the wall to make the visitors familiar with the rules and regulations surrounding archaeology and historical artefacts.

Visitors got an opportunity to get an understanding of the origin and evolution of the Stupa architecture and Indian temple architecture.

The highlight of the exhibition was the smallest sarcophagus of child burial with human skeletons excavated from Dhamna-linga, Nagpur. The only horse remains ever found from a burial in Ubali was also laid out.

Second year MA students Bipin Bansod and Pawan Harde designed simplified models to show water harvesting mechanism in the Mauryan period.

Professor and head of the department, Preety Trivedi, said, “The exhibition was organized with a view to familiarize people with the interdisciplinary facets of archaeology that comprise not just excavation and exploration. By bridging the gap between archaeology and molecular biology, we have been able to solve many historical riddles and we wish to communicate the same.”

(Reporting by Manshika Vaikkath)

Title: Capital area tense as YSRC takes out rally backing 1-cent project
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Amaravati: Tension ran high in the capital area villages of Krishnayapalem, Venkatapalem, Thullur and Velagapudi on Friday when YSRC activists, including several women, took out a rally in support of distribution of house sites to the poor. Raising slogans backing the government’s decision, they said those opposing the move were anti-poor.

They also demanded the arrest of those involved in the attack on Bapatla MP Nandigam Suresh. Suresh is a resident of the capital city area and has every right to go there whenever he wants, they said, and asked TDP to shed its upper caste and arrogant attitude and refrain from orchestrating attacks on local leaders.

“We are also from the capital city area and strongly defend the decision of the state government to grant house sites to the poor from other areas like Krishna and Guntur districts in the capital region. It will make it a more inclusive city. Landlords backed by the TDP are behind the litigations against the grant of house sites. The TDP wants only one community to have its hold on the capital city area,” alleged YSRC activist P Sambaiah. Tension prevailed for some time when the rally passed the dharna camps of pro-Amaravati farmers, with both groups shouting slogans in favour of their demands. While local farmers shouted ‘Jai Amaravati’ slogans, YSRC activists raised ‘Jai Jagan’ and ‘Jai Nandigam Suresh’ slogans. The farmers, who have been protesting for over 70 days now, said it’s unfortunate that the government is deliberately encouraging Dalits to take out counter rallies to precipitate the issue.

As a precautionary measure, additional police force were deployed in the area which ensured that the rally passed off peacefully without any untoward incidents.

Meanwhile, the Amaravati JAC has dismissed talks about gheraoing the residence of actor and former Union minister Chiranjeevi as “baseless rumours”. JAC leader Gadde Tirupati Rao said they have no plans to agitate outside Chiranjeevi’s residence as he has been away from active politics for many years now.

“Some vested interests are spreading such false information to dilute the movement as Jana Sena chief Pawan Kalyan is supporting our agitation,” Rao said.

Title: Coronavirus proves a body blow for inbound tourism in Tamil Nadu
Content:
Passenger arriving at Chennai airport wearing mask

With hundreds of international tourists who had booked a trip to Tamil Nadu in March forced to put off their plans, the Coronavirus (COVID-19 ) outbreak has thrown the tourism sector into a crisis.While some foreign travellers could not make their trips to India due to travel restrictions from coronavirus-hit countries, many are cancelling their tour programmes due to fear surrounding the virus outbreak.At least 3,000 tourists who were scheduled to visit Tamil Nadu and Kerala, kickstarting their India tour from Chennai, have called off their plans, said K Pandian, state chief of Indian Association of Tour Operators."There were six groups of Italian tourists each consisting of 25-27 individuals and two Japanese groups. Coronavirus has proved a disaster for the tourism sector… and has led to largescale cancellations not seen in the last two decades," he said. Several tour operators and hoteliers are suffering monetary losses, he added.Due to the virus spreading across the world, the Union government had announced that people travelling from Korea, Iran and Italy or having a travel history to these countries since February 10 may be quarantined for 14 days on arrival in India. "Not just travel restrictions, many do not want to venture out of their country out of fear over contracting the disease," Pandian said.Tamil Nadu has received the highest number of inbound tourists in the country consecutively for the last four years. The peak season for foreign travellers is between October and March. Approved Tour Guides Association president P Asoka said that approximately 20,000 inbound tourists would have booked their trips for March. "Most of these travellers are from European countries including France, Italy and UK, besides North America. The numbers are dipping because of Coronavirus, a havoc for the tourism sector," he said.Another tour guides association official said that 50 % of their booking have seen cancellations. Secretary of Tourist Guides’ Federation of South India, Charles M, said that the tourist groups that are handled by members of their association are associated with more than 10 tour operators specialising in inbound tourism. "In some cases, hardly a few individuals are part of group tours. There is also an impact on free independent travellers from abroad," he said.For tour operators, the virus that emerged out of the blue is proving to be a double-whammy as thousands of Indians have put off their foreign trips for the upcoming summer vacation. Southeast Asian countries are the worst hit for the tourism industry, while European countries are putting up travel restrictions, he said. City-based tour operator Sriharan Balan said several travellers from Tamil Nadu think flying out of India is a health risk. "We were pinning our hope on European countries. Those destinations have also been hit," he said.

Title: SHRC moots special cell for child safety in Kerala
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: In the wake of repeated incidents of children going missing in the state, the state human rights commission ( SHRC ) has asked the state police to explore the possibilities of setting up a special cell to keep all the suspected people involved in such cases under watch.

Commission chairperson Justice Antony Dominic asked state police chief Loknath Behera to submit a report in this regard before the commission in four weeks. The SHRC chairperson observed that in 2017, 100 children were kidnapped, while it rose to 205 in 2018. In 2019, this figure further increased to 267. As many as 578 children have been kidnapped from the state since May 2016 till the end of 2019.

He said that while the child, Devananda , went missing, everyone suspected the role of nomads and migrant workers and traders. There are complaints that thousands of such people come and leave the state every day and there are no records of such people with the police. When children go missing, such people are the usual suspects.

“If a special cell under an officer of the rank of an SP is created, the tendency of even the innocent nomads and migrant traders being suspiciously watched can be allayed to an extent. The cell should maintain the records of such nomads or migrant traders whenever they come to state and an identity card also should be issued to them by the police. In addition, all the cameras installed by the police should be functional, as the feeds from the cameras help in such cases,” Justice Dominic said.

The police had in 2017 given special instruction to all the schools to set up school safety committees that will be coordinated at the state-level by an officer of the rank of an ADGP.

The responsibility of supervising the awareness and information regarding safety measures for the children under each police station was handed over to the station house officer concerned and the circle inspector. The schools were also given specific tasks to ensure the safety of children. The class teachers were strictly asked to monitor the students and share all the information regarding the children with their parents. In case a student is missing on a day, the teachers should contact the parents of the child.

Also, the schools have been asked to create groups of three of four children so that those in the groups will be able to monitor each other regarding safety.

Content:
CM Ashok Gehlot consoles an 11-year-old boy in Kota on Friday who lost both his parents, brother and grandfath... Read More
