Title: Not the time to seek Amit Shah’s ouster: West Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Mamata Banerjee

BHUBANESWAR: West Bengal chief minister Mamata Banerjee on Friday expressed anguish at the communal violence that swept parts of New Delhi over the CAA but made it clear she did not support the Congress’ demand for Union home minister Amit Shah’s resignation for his perceived failure to prevent the riots. “The problem should be resolved first. We can discuss politics later,” she said.

Mamata was speaking to the media after attending the meeting of the Eastern Zonal Council here chaired by Shah.

The West Bengal CM urged the Union home minister to ensure that peace is restored in the violence-hit areas of Delhi. “I told him (Shah) that I am upset with what has happened in Delhi. It’s urgent to bring back peace.”

Mamata said the government give adequate compensation to the families of those who died in the violence. “A police constable and an IB official also died. If there is any problem in any part of the country, its repercussion is felt in other parts as well. I urged him (Shah) to take steps so that the situation doesn’t aggravate,” she added.

Mamata said the council meeting did not discuss the CAA. She added, “The issue of CAA or NRC was not on the agenda. The meeting was about development of the four eastern states. Nobody raised the issue.”

Title: Man who drove car, Pulwama bomber held
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Shakir Bashir Magrey, 22, a resident of Kakapora in Pulwama, is the first accused to be arrested in the case.

NEW DELHI: In a key breakthrough that will help reconstruct the conspiracy behind the Pulwama terror attack , the National Investigation Agency (NIA) has arrested a Jaish e Mohammad overground worker who not only fitted the IED in Maruti Eeco vehicle used for the attack but also drove it, with suicide bomber Adil Ahmad Dar in the front seat, till 500 metres short of the attack site on February 14, 2019.

Shakir Bashir Magrey, a resident of Kakapora in Pulwama aged just 22, is the first living accused to be arrested in the case. While Adil had died during the suicide attack, other five identified accused were killed subsequently in separate operations by the security forces between March 11, 2019 and January 25, 2020.

The Pulwama attack on February 14, 2019, which left 40 CRPF personnel martyred, was a turning point in India’s counter-terror journey as it led to the first ever cross-border airstrikes by Indian fighter jets on Jaish e Mohammad facilities deep inside Pakistan.

Magrey, owner of a furniture shop not too far from the Pulwama attack site, is an important catch as he will help piece together the events leading up to the suicide strike. His initial interrogation, an NIA officer told TOI, has revealed that he was with Adil Dar on the day of the attack. “This shows the level of trust the conspirators had in him,” said the officer.

As Adil was a shaky driver, it was Magrey who took the wheel of the explosives-laden Maruti Eeco car as they drove to the attack site. It was only 500 meters before the site that Magrey got off, given that only Adil had been chosen by Jaish for the suicide mission. Adil then drove himsef to the attack spot.

Magrey was key link in the Pulwama attack conspiracy. He had harboured Adil Dar and co-accused Pakistani terrorist Mohammad Umar Farooq in his house from late 2018 till the attack in February 2019 and helped them in preparation of the IED. As his shop is located near Lethpora bridge, he, as advised by Umar, conducted reconnaisance of the movement of CRPF convoy on Jammu-Srinagar highway in January 2019, and accordingly briefed Umar and Adil.

Magrey has revealed during his interrogation that ammonium powder, gloves and batteries for the IED used in Pulwama attack was bought from Amazon e-retail site. Ammonium powder has multiple applications, including in fertilisers.

Magrey was introduced to Adil in mid-2018 by Umar Farooq and he became a full-time OGW of JeM. He had collected and delivered arms, ammunition, cash and explosive material to JeM terrorists , including those involved in Pulwama attack, on several occasions.

Magrey was involved in modifying the Maruti Eeco car and fitting the IED in it in early February 2019.

During investigation, the make, model and number of the car used in the attack was ascertained by NIA to be a Maruti Eeco car through forensic examination of its tiny remnants. This has now been corroborated by Magrey.

The explosives used in the attack were determined to be ammonium nitrate, nitro-glycerin and RDX through forensic investigation. Investigation also confirmed the identity of suicide bomber as Adil Ahmad Dar through DNA matching with that of his father. Other key terrorists involved in the attack were found to be Muddasir Ahmad Khan, (JeM’s Divisional Commander of South Kashmir killed in an operation by security forces on 11-03-2019) Pakistani terrorists viz. Muhammad Umar Farooq and IED expert Kamran, (both killed on 29-03-2019) the owner of the car viz. Sajjad Ahmad Bhat r/o Marhama, Anantnag (killed on 16-06-2019) and Qari Yassir, JeM’s Commander for Kashmir (killed on 25-01-2020). NIA believes RDX may have been brought in by Pakistani terrorists.

Magrey was produced before the NIA Special Court at Jammu on Friday and remanded to 15 days of NIA custody.

Title: Odisha CM Naveen Patnaik seeks special package for infra development
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Naveen Patnaik

BHUBANESWAR: Chief minister Naveen Patnaik on Friday demanded a special economic package for infrastructure development in the eastern part of the country.

He was speaking at the 24th Eastern Zonal Council meeting held at the state convention centre and chaired by Union home minister Amit Shah. It was also attended by West Bengal chief minister Mamata Banerjee and her Bihar counterpart Nitish Kumar. Jharkhand was represented by its finance minister Rameshwar Oraon

“If a nationwide analysis is done for tele-density, banking density, rail and road density, the east zone would be at the bottom in all these subjects that are on the Union List. There is a need to double the allotments made to this region so that they catch up with the national benchmarks,” Naveen said. He added that as the eastern states like Odisha , Jharkhand and West Bengal contribute the most to the mineral wealth of the country because of the huge coal block reserves, which in turn helps in the energy security of the country, the fruits of this wealth should boost the economic growth of this region and its people.

He reiterated the demand for the revision of coal royalty, which was last revised in April 2012. “There is an urgent need to revise royalty on coal and to share the proceeds of clean energy cess with the state governments,” the chief minister said.

The royalty on coal is 14% at present. Though there is a provision to revise it every three years, it has not been done in the past eight years. The Odisha government has long been calling for an increase in the coal royalty to 20%.

The demand, which was also raised by other coal-bearing states like West Bengal and Jharkhand, is reportedly not being considered by the Centre as revision of coal royalty is directly linked to power tariff.

The state government has been demanding a 60% share in the national clean energy cess (collected from coal mining) for the coal-bearing states to deal with negative externalities.

Expressing gratitude to the Centre for extending help during Cyclone Fani that devastated the state in May last year, Naveen reiterated the demand to consider vulnerability to natural calamity as a criteria to declare Odisha as a special focus state. Odisha has faced at least 18 natural calamities in the past 20 years.

On the occasion, Naveen also expressed concern over the slow progress of railway projects in the state despite the state sharing the cost for some important projects.

The state provides 50% funds and land, free of cost, for important railway projects, but the progress has been very slow, he pointed out. He also emphasized on the timely completion of the 25-year old Khurda Road-Balangir line and others like the Jeypore-Malkangiri and Jeypore-Nabarangpur projects.

He also used the opportunity to talk of the delay in the release of grants to urban local bodies and non-release of the subsidy of paddy procurement to farmers and the inclusion of Ho, Bhumij and Mundari in the Eighth Schedule of Constitution that would make them the official languages of India.

Naveen, who also delivered the welcome address in the meeting being the chief minister of the host state, underlined its importance saying prime objectives of zonal councils are national integration and creation of healthy interstate and centre-state relations.

“The integration has to be financial, infrastructural, technological, so it leads and strengthens emotional integration. It is in this regard I would like to present points both concerning the region and my state Odisha in particular,” he added.

Title: Dalit youth dies in custody of Barmer cops, SP taken to task
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Jaisalmer: A Dalit youth, who was taken into custody by the Barmer rural police over theft charges on Wednesday, died under suspicious circumstances on Thursday.

The youth was taken to a hospital following lunch over deteriorating health on Thursday and was declared dead by the doctors. No case had been registered against the youth at the station. Jodhpur range IG Navjyoti Gogoi too reached Barmer and started investigating the case.

Late on Thursday, the state government put Barmer SP Sharad Chaudhry on awaiting posting order (APO) until further orders.

The issue was also raised in the assembly on Thursday and the government is expected to give a reply on Friday.

Earlier in the day, Barmer SP Choudhary suspended SHO Deep Singh and shifted the entire staff of the police station.

A judicial inquiry too has been ordered. The youth’s family held a protest outside the hospital.

According to police, junk dealer Jitendra Khatik (24) was taken into custody from Barmer city without registering a case on Wednesday after the cops allegedly recovered items stolen from a private company.

Around 9am on Thursday, his family members came to the police station and met him. In the afternoon, the youth’s health suddenly deteriorated, and the police took him to the hospital where he was declared dead.

Choudhary said that no case had been registered against Khatik at the station and admitted that he should not have been kept at the station after inquiry.

“If the SHO had called him to the station, he should have been released immediately after the inquiry. But keeping him at the station despite having no case was not right. Action will be taken against culprits as per rule. At present, we are investigating the case,” he said.

His body has been kept in the government hospital mortuary and post-mortem will done by the medical board.

Title: Cochin Smart Mission Limited wins award for best smart health project
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

KOCHI: Cochin Smart Mission Limited ( CSML ) has bagged the best smart health project for implementation of online e-health solutions at Ernakulam General Hospital by the ministry of housing and urban affairs ( MoHUA ).

The project was funded under the smart city project and the award was under the Smart City - Empowering India Awards. Binnya Joseph, manager (IT), on behalf of CSML, received the award from Union minister Hardeep Singh Puri on Saturday at New Delhi.

The core features of the e-health project are centralized health information systems, electronic health records, central demographic database and all these are facilitated through high bandwidth reliable network. In association with health department and Keltron Limited, CSML implemented the e-health project.

“E-health project will not only help in maintaining and tracking health records of a person but it will become a predictive and prescriptive tool to address health-related challenges of Kochi city. The project will also be extended to all other hospitals in Kochi region by CSML under the city investments to innovate, integrate & sustain (CITIIS) programme of the Government of India,” said Alkesh Kumar Sharma, CEO CSML.

The Smart City - Empowering India Awards 2019 has been designed to facilitate, recognize and encourage state governments and special purpose companies on the successful execution of projects under smart cities in India. The award aims to recognize pioneering projects in making cities more liveable, sustainable and economically viable by honouring best practices and models in the smart cities concept. The selection criteria for the projects were innovation, replicability/scalability, level of citizen engagement, impacts etc.

Title: States demand revision in coal royalty, special status during meeting with Shah
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Bhubaneswar: Demands for revision of coal royalty and special status to Odisha and Bihar dominated the Eastern Zonal Council meeting chaired by Union home minister Amit Shah here on Friday. Coal royalty was last revised in 2012 and the states of Odisha, West Bengal and Jharkhand, which produce the majority of coal in the country, have been demanding a greater share from the sale proceeds than the 14% they currently get.

“There is an urgent need to revise royalty on coal and to share the proceeds of clean energy cess with the state governments,” a statement issued by the office of Odisha chief minister Naveen Patnaik, stated. Odisha has been demanding 60% share in the national clean energy cess (collected from coal mining).

The states currently get 14% royalty on the sale of coal. As per norms, the royalty should be revised every three years. But it has not been done in the past eight years. The states have been demanding that the royalty be increased to at least 20%. Last month, the Centre constituted a committee to study the proposal of coal royalty revision.

Talking to reporters after the 24th meeting of the council, West Bengal chief minister Mamata Banerjee said, “Odisha, Jharkhand and our state raised the issue of coal royalty revision. The Union home minister said there needs to be a policy decision on it.”

Besides Naveen and Mamata, Bihar chief minister Nitish Kumar and Jharkhand finance minister Rameshwar Oraon attended the council meeting. Jharkhand chief minister Hemant Soren could not attend the meeting which coincided with the first day of the budget session in his state assembly.

Reiterating his demand to declare Odisha as a special focus state owing to its vulnerability from natural disasters, Naveen said, “Odisha has faced at least 18 natural calamities in the past 20 years, the last being Cyclone Fani that devastated the state in May last year.”

Bihar CM Nitish Kumar also pitched for special category status for his state for speedier development and to bring it on a par with other states. He also asked for formulation of National Silt Management Policy to take care of floods in Ganga river, a release issued by Nitish’s office said.

Mamata raised the issue of pending GST compensation with the Centre. “We have raised the issue of delay in payment of GST compensation by the Centre. Initially, there was commitment to release GST compensation every two months. But it is being released after six months, which is leading to financial crunch. This is not good. How will we pay the salary (of employees) on the first day of the month if money reaches us on the 20th of each month,” she said.

The West Bengal CM also raised the issue of pending dues. “We have not got Rs 50,000 crore in dues from the Centre. Bengal is yet to receive the required assistance for calamities like Cyclone Fani and Bulbul. Bengal has been deprived of many things,” she added.

During the meeting, Shah suggested discussion on issues relating to law and order and administrative reforms. He exhorted various central government departments to expedite pending decisions relating to the states. The home minister, who later tweeted that “the meeting was very cordial and fruitful”, suggested regular discussions and data sharing beyond the council meetings. He also laid stress on expanding banking services to ensure that the benefits are available even in the remotest areas.

The council members emphasized the need on speedy investigation of cases of sexual offences against women and children. Among others, the council discussed issues relating to Phulbari dam under the agreement of 1978 signed by Bihar and West Bengal on the Upper Mahananda Water Scheme, extension of Nuapada-Gunupur-Therubali rail link project in northern districts of Odisha, besides determination of pension liability between Bihar and Jharkhand.

EoM

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: Umrah plans of 40 people hit by flight ban
Content:
The group from Mahisagar was to take off on Thursday

VADODARA: A group of 40 devotees from Mahisagar district who wanted to go on Umrah pilgrimage to Mecca and Medina had to drop plans after Saudi Arabia halted entry of pilgrims to the country temporarily in wake of the novel coronavirus outbreak – COVID-19.The group had also made bookings in the last couple of months for the pilgrimage that was schedule to take off on Thursday.When a group had come to Ahmedabad to board a flight to Jeddah late on Thursday evening, they were told that the flight was cancelled in wake of the decision by the Saudi government. By that time, many others were either on their way to Ahmedabad or had already reached there.Iqbal Godhrawala, a resident of Lunawada, who was to go to Ahmedabad was informed about the cancellation when he was about to leave home. “There were 16 of us from Lunawada and all have had to stay back. We are keen to go again and will do so on the next possible date,” said Godhrawala. He added that there were some persons who had already reached Ahmedabad and had to return to Mahisagar district.The agents are hopeful that the flight tickets will be refunded as the airline had to cancel the flight and not the pilgrims. “We are hopeful of a refund. So far, there is no update as to when travel will resume. We have learnt that the Saudi authorities are working hard to ensure that the virus does not spread there,” said Mohammed Chanda, agent with whom the bookings had been done.Chanda added that another block booking of tickets for Umrah had been done for March 28. He added that 38 persons had already made bookings for this date too. He added that the visas of the pilgrims were valid for one month.

Title: Bhubaneswar: Father among four held for ‘selling’ infant
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

BHUBANESWAR: A day after allegation of child sale surfaced in Bhubaneswar, the Khandagiri police arrested four persons, including the 19-day baby boy’s father, on Friday. The accused were identified as Dilu Das, 32, the baby’s father, and his acquaintances Prasant Kumar Gochhayat, 34, Manas Ranjan Mohapatra, 33, and Padua Das, 65.

Police said the reason behind the alleged child sale was poverty of the parents, who are daily-wage labourers. Dilu and his wife have five children. The infant, they allegedly sold, was their fifth child. The couple had sold their baby to Manas of Mancheswar for a few thousand rupees. Prasant and Padua helped the couple in selling the kid, a police officer said. On Thursday, the Childline volunteers came to know about the child sale and rescued the baby from Manas’ custody. The child welfare committee lodged a complaint with Khandagiri police, seeking action against those responsible. Incidents of child sale had come to the light in the capital city in the past as well. In December 2017, the child welfare committee here had rescued a 3-month-old boy from a house in Salia Sahi slum following allegation that the kid’s mother sold him for money to a couple. The Kharavel Nagar police here in July 2014 had arrested a couple for allegedly selling their three children in different places in the state.

Title: Folk and devotional music mark ‘World Marathi Gaurav Din’
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Sursaptak presented musical programme ‘Utsav Marathicha’ to mark ‘World Marathi Gaurav Din’ at Scientific Hall... Read More

Nagpur: A salutation to the Marathas and the grandeur the Marathi language beholds was done musically, with divinity filled in abundance by the Sursaptak group on the occasion of ‘ World Marathi Gaurav Din ’.

The musical, which highlighted popular Marathi songs that connect one with god, was held at the Scientific Society Hall, Laxmi Nagar, on Thursday evening.

Titled ‘Utsav Marathicha’, the musical featured 28 famous Marathi folk songs which kept the audience glued to their seats.

Anchor Shubhangi Raylu was grace personified. “Marathi is not just a language. It’s an emotion,” she said.

The event provided many talented singers with the opportunity to showcase their talent and more importantly, their love for music and the Marathi language.

‘Natarang’, the title song of a famous movie, was sung as a duet by Amol Kulkarni and Vijay Deshpande.

The next song, ‘Ekach hya janmi janu’, from a Marathi music album called Padhach Paul, was presented by Rucha Yenurkar.

The applause after every performance was a clear indication of the entertainment that the event provided.

Mukul Pande, Ashish Ghate, Nisargraaj, Arun Ojharkar, Apurv Masodkar, Aditya Phadke, Padmaja Sinha, Pratiksha Pattalwar, Ashwini Lule, Sangita Bhagat, Archana Uchke, Anuja Joshi and Dipali Pank were the singers who made the Marathi Day a success.

The other songs like ‘Naveen aaj chandrama’, ‘Dahi dudh loni’, ‘Kanha vajavito baansuri’, ‘Naav sang, gaav sang’, ‘Aabhas ha’, ‘Shukratara mand vaara’, ‘Nishala tula disan naa’, ‘Dhundit gau gastit rahu’ and many more were melodies that regaled one and all.

Duets like ‘Dhundi kalyana’ by Ashish and Rucha, ‘Dipadi dipang’ by Mukul and Pratiksha and ‘Fite andhaarache jale’ by Amol and Sangita were soothing and lively. The other songs presented by the singers were also appreciated by music and language aficionados.

Shubhakar Mishra, who was among the audience, said, “Such Marathi musicals must continue. They uplift and encourage Marathi cinema which is the need of the hour.”

The programme concluded with the song ‘Mauli mauli’ sung by Amol and Ashish. It was well received and enjoyed.

The programme was conceptualized by Suchitra Katarkar and Apurv Masodkar. Well-known poet Shalini Kukde was the chief guest. The organizing team and members of the Sursaptak Group made the evening and Marathi Gaurav Din a grand success.

Title: Class XII results on April 24
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Tirupur: Results of Class XII public exams that commenced on March 2 will be declared in April 24 and of Class X on May 4, school education minister K A Sengottaiyan told reporters after inaugurating new classrooms at a government school in Muthalipalayam in Tirupur on Friday. TNN

Title: Leopard scare in Sirumugai
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: Livestock farmers in Sirumugai want the forest department to trap a leopard that killed three goats on Friday.

The animals were found dead in the cattle shed at Periyakallipatti village located 1.5 kilometres from the reserve forest. All of them had bite marks.

While the villagers said a leopard killed the animals, forest department officials said they could not find pugmarks of a big cat in the area.

The department has placed three camera traps to identify the animal, range officer E N Manoharan said. “Once we confirm the presence of a leopard, we will place cages to capture it.”

Mauled carcass of a calf, owned by N Murugan, was found near a cattle shed at Chittepalayam village in Sirumugai on February 9. Forest department officials said that a leopard could have attacked the calf. They have fixed four camera traps to identify the animal.

Title: Utkal University gets research tool on National Science Day
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

BHUBANESWAR: The Utkal University on Friday installed a Micro Raman Spectrometer worth around Rs 1.5 crore in the physics department for research purposes on the occasion of National Science Day on Friday.

The equipment was lying idle in the university since December 2017 due to lack of space for its installation. Office of the accountant general, Odisha, had last year asked vice-chancellor of Utkal University to reply on procurement of this apparatus without planning for its installation.

In March 2017, the syndicate approved the proposal to procure the equipment from the funds provided under Rashtriya Uchchatar Shiksha Abhiyan (RUSA) during 2017-18. The newly-installed instrument can be used for research in the field of physics, chemistry, medicine and biological sciences for characterisation of material, detection of explosives and to generate fingerprints of the universe.

“We use this equipment to provide a structural fingerprint through which molecules can be identified. We measure the bond length between two atoms. It is an important device for research,” said Prafulla Kumar Panda, head of the physics department, Utkal University.

He said National Science Day is celebrated on February 28 every year commemorating Indian physicist C V Raman’s 1928 discovery of the scattering of photons or light particles by matter popular as Raman Effect. Installation of this device based on his theory is a tribute to the great scientist, he added.

Vice-chairman of Odisha State Higher Education Council Asoka Kumar Das inaugurated the room with installation of the equipment in the presence of university vice-chancellor Soumendra Mohan Patnaik and teachers of the institution.

The equipment can be used by the university’s post-graduate students and researchers for education and research activities in the field of material science, physics, chemistry, biology and geological studies. Research scholars from other government universities or institutions can access this facility, said the vice-chancellor.

Title: Administrative sanction for fish landing centres
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Coimbatore: Administrative sanction for a sum of Rs 8 lakh has been granted for establishing an inland fish landing centres at Thirumoorthy and Amaravathi reservoirs. The centres will be established under a centrally-sponsored scheme titled ‘Blue Revolution: Integrated Development and Management of Fisheries’. A detailed project report was submitted by the fisheries department, which was forwarded to the national fisheries development board to get centre’s approval. The board forwarded the proposal to the joint secretary(fisheries), government of India for sanction. TNN

Title: Coim​batore: 3 ‘cops’ arrested for stealing mobile phones
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: The city police on Friday arrested three men who ‘raided’ a women’s hostel at Chinnavedampatti a week ago posing as cops to steal mobile phones of inmates.

A four-member gang had visited the private hostel on February 12 around 1.30am, a police officer said. “One of them was dressed as a police officer. They introduced themselves as Narcotics Intelligence Bureau (NIB) officers and said they were looking for ganja stashed in the building. The hostel authorities gave them permission to conduct a search,” the officer said.

The gang questioned some inmates and asked them to surrender their mobile phones on the pretext of conducting checks. “They took away three phones and told the owners to get back the phones from the Saravanampatti police station. The gang left the place in a car. The owners of the phones, who visited the police station later, realised that they were conned by fake cops.”

Police formed a special team to nab the gang. On Friday, the team arrested Sureshkumar, 29, of Karamadai, a lathe operator, Sugumaran of Chinnavedampatti and Kannan of Thudiyalur and remanded them in judicial custody. They also recovered the stolen phones. Vinodh of Thudiyalur, a former traffic warden, is absconding.

Title: Clean up act: From garbage to grandeur
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Hyderabad: A dump yard on Road No 36, Jubilee Hills, has been converted into a park with ample green cover. The garden that has been named Transit Park was thrown open to the public on Friday. Spread over an area of 362 square metres, Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation has installed a water cascade and installed benches and complementary structures based on a fruit theme.

The park has been developed at a cost of 18.5 lakh and is lined with seasonal plants and a walking track.

The park was inaugurated by Hyderabad mayor Bonthu Rammohan and Khairtabad MLA, Danam Nagender.

“The area attracts a large number of people due to the presence of the Peddama temple and many clothing stores. The park will serve as a recreation and halting point for temple goers and shoppers,” said Rammohan.

According to GHMC officials, the park has been developed as part of beautification projects taken up the civic body on minister KT Rama Rao’s instructions.

“The water cascade is taller than other fountains in the city as we want to give Metro commuters a scenic view,” said Krishna, additional commissioner, urban biodiversity wing, GHMC.

Title: Man hammers brother to death in Palakuzha
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

KOCHI: A 45-year-old man was hammered to death by his step-brother late on Thursday night. The incident happened after a drunken brawl between the brothers at their house at Palakuzha near Koothattukulam .

According to police, the deceased person is Prakashan, son of Chinnan of Palakuzha, Koothattukulam. The brothers were painters by profession.

On Thursday night, Laiju, brother of Prakashan, had brought some alcohol. “After getting inebriated, the duo indulged in a scuffle, after which their mother, who lives with them, went to a relative’s house. Police said that the deceased, the older brother, took away the alcohol bottle. Later, the accused used a hammer to strike his brother on the head when he went to sleep,” said a senior police officer.

Soon after the crime, the police said that the accused left the house without bothering to care of his injured brother. However, he called a up a friend and told him that he attacked his brother. The friend went to the house and saw the deceased bleeding. Prakashan was rushed to a hospital where he was declared brought dead.

Police said that arguments were a regular in the family. The deceased was unmarried. The accused was living separately from his wife, said police.

On Friday morning, the accused had called up his mother, however, the police had seized her phone to track him. They couldn’t answer his call as the municipal siren near the police station was ringing. Later, the accused surrendered at a police station in Palakkad .

On Friday evening, police picked up Laiju from Palakkad and brought him to Koothattukulam. He was arrested and will be presented before a magistrate in the next 24 hours.

An FIR under Section 302 (murder) of the IPC was registered. Police said that they are probing the case to find out if there was any other motive behind the crime.

Title: Play ‘Up Down’ captures woman’s life on local train
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Kruti Theatre staged play ‘Up Down’ in 59 th Maharashtra Rajya Hindi Natya Spardha at Scientific Society Hall,... Read More

Nagpur: Play ‘Up Down’ beautifully captured the nuances of interaction of daily commuters on a local train, during the 59th Maharashtra Rajya Hindi Natya Spardha at Scientific Society Hall in Laxmi Nagar on Thursday. The competition is being organized by Directorate of Cultural Affairs.

Staged by Kruti Theatre and Sports Academy Sanstha, Nagpur, ‘Up Down’ is written and directed by Sheetal Dodke.

Mukta (Nirvani Chaudhary) is a deaf and mute girl who has amassed over Rs1 lakh by working hard and selling popcorn on the train. She deposits her hard-earned money with a trusted friend whom she calls as her ‘mama’. However, a police officer (Bhismark Bhivgade) who is an acquaintance has been eyeing the money for some time. Portraying that he cares for her and is helping her, the police officer fixes her marriage with a tea vendor (Ashish Meshram) who is a notorious guy and drunkard.

When the police officer makes good with Mukta’s hard-earned money, the drunkard tea vendor physically abuses Mukta. Refusing to be bogged down by cruel fate, she speaks out against her husband, packs up her belongings and leaves him for good.

The peak of the play is the emancipation of Mukta — a girl who is not only betrayed by a trusted friend but also faced a lot of trials and tribulations in life. She refuses to accept defeat. Mukta boldly says, “I am dignified and I have a lot of strength and perseverance in me. I am not the one to cry but to fight back. I will face the problems head-on. I am not a damsel in distress, I am an empowered woman.”

Her forceful dialogue ‘Mai abla nahi sabla hu,’ gained a lot of appreciation from the audience.

The play was produced by Mayur Shende and Vijay Gaikwadi. Other members of the cast were Vijay Ramteke, Anwar Sheikh, Shravan Ghode, Naresh Yende, Deepak Bombe, Rajivraj Niketansahare, Nitesh Supatkar, Diwakar Shirke and Milind Ramteke.

Title: Kerala pollution board to monitor noise levels in real time at Cial
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

KOCHI: With concern over noise levels in airports going up over increased traffic, Kerala state pollution control board (KSPCB) is planning to undertake real time noise level monitoring at all airports in the state including Kochi .

KSPCB member secretary S Sreekala said these monitoring stations would be set up along with the proposed network of continuous real time noise level monitoring stations ( RTNLMS ) that are being planned. “We would be soon commissioning four such stations — two each in Ernakulam and Thiruvananthapuram ,” Sreekala said.

KSPCB is currently not monitoring noise levels in airports. “Sometime ago, we had received complaints from a person staying close to the Kochi airport and measured noise levels but currently, there is no continuous monitoring,” said a PCB official. The board had earlier asked the airports to initiate monitoring of noise level.

A spokesperson of the Cochin international airport limited ( Cial ) said they regularly monitor the noise output with the help of an outside agency. “The measured level so far is much lower than the prescribed outer limit. The lush green cover outside the perimeter wall also helps us,” said the official.

Philomina Eldho, president of Nedumbassery panchayat, where the airport is situated, said they have not received complaints regarding noise pollution . Union ministry of environment forests and climate change (MoEFC) had in 2018 notified limits for noise levels in airports. As per the notification, civil airports with more than 50,000 aircraft movements per year, categorized as busy airports, should not exceed noise levels beyond 75 dBA Leq (decibels) during between 6am to 10pm and 65 dBA between 10pm to 6am. Airports having more than 15,000 but less than 50,000 movements annually have noise limits of 65 dBA between 6am to 10pm and 60 dBA between 10pm to 6am.

As per a white paper by Union ministry of civil aviation published in February 2019, all aviation stakeholders shall strive to minimize the adverse effects of aircraft noise on communities by implementing effective noise management as per guidelines of International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) guidelines.

Title: Job scam: 2 government employees under lens
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: Officials of the directorate of information and public relations (DIPR) on Friday conducted an inquiry into the complaints against two former collectorate employees, who allegedly cheated several people of lakhs of rupees by promising them government jobs.

Joint director D Saravanan and additional section officer Vadivelu met accused V L Prabhu, who was an upgrade superintendent and S Sureshbabu, a driver earlier attached with the office of public relation officer (PRO) in the city.

The duo had collected up to Rs 5 lakh from job seekers by promising them posts of clerk, office assistant and driver, a source said. “Even though they had been cheating public since 2013, the issue came to light only two years ago, when the PRO received the first complaint. Subsequently, both the office of PRO and the collector received 15 complaints from people across the district, including Annur, Pollachi and Valparai,” the source said. “The district administration also received complaints from people in other districts, including Sivaganga.”

Both the accused were transferred to other districts six months ago and suspended after some time.

The officials had sent letters to the 15 complainants, requesting them to appear for the inquiry. “But as many as 20 victims turned up for the inquiry,” the source said. “The accused confessed to their crime during the inquiry.”

The entire session was videographed.

The inquiry reports will be submitted to the director of DIPR.

Title: Sixth India Idea Conclave takes off at Statue of Unity
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Statue of Unity

VADODARA: The 6th India Idea Conclave organized by India Foundation kicked off near Statue of Unity at Kevadia in Narmada district on Friday evening.

Organized on the theme of ‘Turning to Roots, Rising to Heights’, the event was inaugurated by external affairs minister, Dr S Jaishankar along with former Maldives president Mohammed Nasheed , Assam CM Sarbananda Sonowal and director of India Foundation Shaurya Doval.

Jaishankar said, “Nationalism is a tribute and love to success through the contribution of our glorious cultural heritage. Whether it’s is BRICS or the International Day for Yoga, it signifies the global position of India. This government reflects the ethos of our glorious cultural roots.” He further added that painting different types of nationalism with the same brush is not appropriate.

While addressing the gathering, Nasheed was all praises for India. “I like India rising. I love the food and music and the idea of India,” he said. Sixty five eminent speakers from different walks of life will speak during the two-and-half-day conclave. A special address on Ram Janmabhoomi will be organized on Saturday apart from rise of the Indian conservative and new roadmap for union territories.

Title: Dak Adalat to redress postal complaints on March 12
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Nagpur: The Postmaster General, Nagpur Region, has organized Dak Adalat to resolve problems related to postal services from 11am on March 12 at Shankar Nagar Post Office.

A press release informed that complaints/grievances regarding postal services pertaining to all districts of Vidarbha, which have not been settled within six weeks will be entertained in the Dak Adalat. The complaints relating to unregistered/registered mails, speed post, counter services, saving banks and non-payment of money orders etc will be considered. Complaints should contain details like names and designations of the officers to whom original complaint was addressed, particulars of articles etc, the press release stated.

People can send their complaints related to postal services in duplicate to Mahanti Santosh Kumar Narahari, assistant director, Postal Services-II and secretary, Dak Adalat, to the address — Postmaster General, Nagpur Region, 1st floor, Shankar Nagar Post Office Building, Nagpur-440010 on or before March 6.

In order to redress the grievances in an effective manner, the department periodically organizes Dak Adalat where functionaries of the department meet the aggrieved customers, gather details about their complaints and try to settle them at the earliest, the press release stated.

Title: Kochi: Grand Masjid opens doors to welcome Sikhs
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Members of the Sikh community participate in the Friday Namaz at Grand Masjid near the Kerala high court in Ko... Read More

KOCHI: Even as the national capital is recovering from the aftermath of the riots, Kochi witnessed a gesture of peace and harmony as the Grand Masjid invited members of the Sikh community to the mosque during Friday Namaz, as part of their Open Masjid Day initiative.

Men from the Sikh community of Kochi, sporting their turbans visited the mosque on Friday and stood alongside Muslims in the hall where the Friday Namaz was conducted.

After the Namaz, the Sikh community members interacted with the Muslim community. “It was wonderful to attend the Namaz. I always wanted to go to a mosque but I could never. When the imam reached out to us, I felt really happy,” said Bunty Singh, a member of the Sikh community.

He added that they were well received at the mosque. “The people were really warm and they all came and spoke to us. It was a new experience to watch their worship up close,” said Bunty.

The event was held at Grand Masjid near the Kerala high court and was attended by around five members from the Sikh community.

“It is part of a declaration that there is no place for hatred amongst us. We are basically opening up and allowing our brothers from other religions to come and see our practices and get rid of misconceptions. It is a gesture aimed at communal harmony as harmony and peace is the real answer for hatred,” said M P Faisal Azhari, the imam of Grand Masjid.

The mosque launched their Open Masjid Day initiative, around a month back as part of their communal harmony initiatives. “About a month and a half ago we did our first Open Masjid Day. Community leaders from Christian, Hindu communities and dignitaries from other religions were invited then,” said the imam. “We are planning to invite the Jain community at the next Open Masjid Day. This would be repeated every two months,” said the imam.

Title: Help farmers get crop failure certificates: Collector to officials
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

The move came after farmers said the certificate was essential for them to move the consumer court against the... Read More

COIMBATORE: District collector K Rajamani on Friday directed agriculture and horticulture officers to issue crop loss certificates to farmers, who approach them for the same, after verifying the truth in their claims.

The move came after farmers said the certificate was essential for them to move the consumer court against their seed, fertilizer, pesticide or machinery suppliers or brands.

The farmers said the agriculture and horticulture departments have, of late, been hesitant to issue the certificate, as they were under pressure from agri companies.

The order came at the monthly agriculture grievance day meeting, which was held on Friday, as the collector disposed of a petition by P Senthil Kumar, who owns four acres banana farm at Kalikanampalayam near Theenampalayam .

Rajamani ordered the agriculture officer in Thondamuthur to immediately inspect the farmland and issue a crop failure certificate, if warranted.

Senthil Kumar, a member of Tamil Nadu Vivasaigal Sangam, said he had bought a herbicide to control the growth of unwanted weeds called “Saathi” from a company named UPL in November. “They assured me that the herbicide was apt for my farm and my problem. They also inspected my farm and gave me the application instructions. As a trial, I sprayed it across one acre on November 26. Since then, the banana plants in that area look diseased and have not grown at all.”

Kumar, who later approached the company’s salesperson, found he was supplied with a pesticide that was beyond its expiry date and that was meant for paddy farms and not banana. “The company also admitted in a letter that their herbicide was expired. But they have been refusing to compensate me. I want to move the consumer court against them but can’t do that as I don’t have a crop failure certificate.”

Kumar said he was not in a position to clear the affected banana plants, which he said was the only evidence to prove his claims.

Earlier, the Tamil Nadu Vivasaigal Sangam had taken up the issue of crop loss certificate with the collector. “The crop failure certificate is essential for us to move against our suppliers in the consumer court,” said P Kandasamy, its state secretary.

Title: Auto driver gets life for killing wife
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Hyderabad: An auto driver from Pahadisharif was awarded life sentence on Friday in a dowry death case. The accused, Aakupogu Naresh, had set his wife ablaze in 2016. Police said that Naresh used to harass his wife regularly. In February 2016, during a quarrel Naresh hit her with a pestle. Then he poured kerosene and set her ablaze. tnn

Title: Bengaluru: Now, traders can get their licence renewed online
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: From now on, one needn’t make rounds of the Bruhat Bengaluru Mahanagara Palike (BBMP) office to get his/her trade licence renewed. For, the civic agency has taken the process online.

With trade licences due for renewal at the end of every financial year, February and March are the months when touts — who fleece traders by promising to help them get the crucial document — thrive.

Taking note of the tout menace and to make life easy for traders, the Palike has started the online approval system. The move is also part of its endeavour to improve the ease of doing business (EODB) in the city. With the World Bank deciding to look into Bengaluru and Kolkata apart from Mumbai and Delhi while deciding India’s EODB rankings, BBMP has initiated several measures to help entrepreneurs.

“During these two months, we receive an average of 50,000 trade licences for renewal and 4,000 fresh applications,” said Ravikumar Surpur, special commissioner, projects.

As most traders find little time to deal with the red-tapism amid their hectic schedules, they end up approaching middlemen who charge anywhere between Rs 10,000 and Rs 25,000 to get a renewed trade licence. “The bribe is directly proportional to the size of the business,” Surpur said.

Under EODB, a trader can apply for renewal online and get it done in a few minutes. If the trader wants to obtain a licence in commercial areas, he needs to upload only two documents — one that establishes occupancy of the premises like title deed or lease agreement, and the electricity bill, said another senior BBMP official.

For residential areas where the road is wider than 40ft, the owner needs to submit a document detailing occupancy of the premises, copy of the electricity bill and consent letter from neighbours. “The trader is now allowed to renew the licence either every year or for five years straight,” said senior BBMP official.

An Indiranagar pharmacist said in the locality and surrounding areas, bribes for licences range from Rs 5,000 to Rs 5 lakh.

SG Aditya, general secretary, Indiranagar Owners and Traders Association, welcomed BBMP’s online initiative. Simplifying the process and taking it online will bring transparency to the system, he added.

Sajjan Raj Mehta, trade activist, however, said trade licences should be done away with. “But if BBMP insists, then we need a little more time to get familiar with the online process,” he said.

Title: There’s no blindsiding this 25-year-old Bengaluru student on a tennis court
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Nibin Mathew

BENGALURU: Playing tennis could be hard for the blind even if the ball makes a tinkling sound when it hits a surface. But 25-year-old Nibin Mathew, a visually challenged student pursuing MSc in digital society at International Institute of Information Technology-Bangalore, has aced it.

In the recently held national blind tennis championship in Patiala, Nibin defeated 11 participants and qualified for the international blind tennis championship to be hosted by Italy in June 2020.

Nibin, who’s from Wayanad in Kerala, lost his sight due to glaucoma. He got the first taste of blind tennis at a workshop in Mumbai where he was working with the railways for three years. “I was one of the 20 participants when The Indian Blind Sports Association and Maharashtra State Lawn Tennis Association conducted a tennis camp for coaches and visually challenged players. Initially, it was the excitement of movement, where a sponge ball flying in the air makes a tinkling sound on hitting the racket or a synthetic surface. That excitement drove me to the next level and I began practising regularly,” recalled Nibin.

In blind tennis, players listen to the sound of the specially modified ball as it strikes the ground and swing the racquet according to their prediction of the ball’s location, calculating its speed and distance. “We struggled to get an inclusive court, a sound ball and support for practice as the sport is new to our country. The IBTA-approved sound ball manufactured by a Japan company is costly (around Rs 1,500 a piece) and is very fragile,” he said.

Nibin entered IIIT-B to chase his dream of pursuing pure sciences. “When I moved to Bengaluru, I felt I would lose opportunities related to the sport. But the institute ensured I didn’t stop pursuing it. The authorities had a dozen balls imported from Japan for me. Tactile court is an important factor of this tennis model, which helps a player get proper orientation. All lines except the service box should project from the court surface. IIIT-B designed a portable version of an inclusive tennis court using carpet pieces on an experimental basis,” he explained.

“Apart from this, my friends who can see, including integrated MTech student Risshi Sunkum, took out time to play with me. We used to practise at midnight or whenever we were free. He also described how blind players from other countries play by observing YouTube videos. All this helped me,” Nibin said.

The sport, he admitted, has helped improve his mobility. “Many people on campus now ask me whether I can see a little bit,” said Nibin, who plans to rigorously practise for the upcoming matches.

Title: Karnataka: Cabbie hangs himself as ex-lover fails to wish him on his birthday
Content:
Cabbie M Shivakumar

BeNGALURU: A 25-year-old man committed suicide by hanging himself from the ceiling of his residence in Chikkaballapura district after his estranged girlfriend failed to wish him on his birthday.M Shivakumar of Bandahalli village in the district celebrated his birthday on Wednesday and was upset that his former girlfriend, a Bengaluru resident, did not wish him. He took the extreme step later in the night.Shivakumar owned a cab and lived in Yelahanka between 2017 and 2019 before returning to village. During his stay in the city, he fell in love with a woman, who was his neighbour. “Shivakumar wanted to marry her. Even the families did not oppose their relationship. But differences grew when Shivakumar decided to return to his village,” police sources said.According to Shivakumar, he was worried about his mother’s health. “Shivakumar’s widowed mother, Radhamma, was suffering from multiple health issues. His younger brother, a daily wage worker, was living in Chikkaballapura and he requested Shivakumar to return home to take care of their mother. Shivakumar had told his girlfriend that he was earning well in Chikkaballapura,” sources said.However, the woman wasn’t keen on continuing the relationship, said police. “But Shivakumar was hopeful. On February 26, the day he turned 25, he was confident that she’d call him. But she did not. After dinner, he locked himself in the room and hanged himself. In his suicide note, written in Kannada, Shivakumar said no one, especially the girl, is responsible for his death,” police said.

Title: ‘Progress must be in harmony with the environment’
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Prof Anushree Malik being felicitated before delivering National Science Day lecture at Neeri Auditorium, on F... Read More

Nagpur: “We should certainly progress, but in harmony with the environment,” said professor Anushree Malik, head of the centre for rural development and technology, Indian Institute of Technology, Delhi.

‘Science: Beyond the labs’ was the theme on which Malik shed light at the NEERI auditorium, Nehru Marg, where CSIR NEERI celebrated National Science Day on Friday.

An initiative by the department of science and technology, ‘Vigyan Jyoti’ by Navyodaya Vidyaya Samiti was inaugurated by Malik, senior scientists of NEERI, Hemant Purohit, JS Pandey, Prakash Kumbhare and Zareena Qureshi, principal of Jawahar Navodaya Vidyalaya (JNV).

The initiative, inspired by the theme ‘Women in Science’, aims to encourage girls from rural areas to join the science stream and do research. “Around 50 districts have been selected and JNV, Nagpur, is lucky to be on the list with support of NEERI,” said Qureshi.

The entire talk was focused on women’s contribution in the field of science and environmental-friendly development.

Star activist Greta Thunberg’s views were discussed by the dignitaries present on dais.

Malik spoke about how their centre works to find solutions for problems that arise from society, industries and the arena of environmental biotechnology. She explained in detail the practical projects undertaken by her in collaboration with the industries and other scientific institutes, including NEERI. Some of her notable contributions include Mycotablets, a technology for the treatment of harsh textile effluents, algal mediated wastewater treatment and biogas development and algal bio-harvesting process.

Renowned Indian scientist CV Raman was remembered and revered too. Young scientists were encouraged to follow in Raman’s footsteps and pursue science with an environmental perspective and not industrially required research which will develop our country economically, but will not be in harmony with the environment.

(Reporting by Swarali Joshirao)

Title: Brown sugar worth Rs 4 crore seized in Patna
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: A drug peddler with brown sugar worth around Rs 4 crore was arrested by the police from road number three of Postal Park colony under Jakkanpur police station area in the state capital late Thursday night. He was identified as Sudama Kumar (24), a native of Bhilwara village under Gopalpur police station area in Patna district.

Jakkanpur police station SHO Mukesh Kumar Verma on Friday said two kilograms of brown sugar was seized from his possession during a raid in his rented accommodation. “He had already made 1,300 small packets, each containing one gram of brown sugar, to supply across Patna. Besides that, Rs 90,000 in cash, two cellphones, an electronic weighing machine and passbooks of several banks were also seized,” the SHO added.

The SHO further said that the apprehended drug peddler was just a pawn and was acting on the directions of drug lords who are lodged inside Beur central jail since the last few months.

“Sudama was getting directions and contact numbers from Abhimanyu, alias Mannu and Guddu Kumar over the phone from inside the jail for procuring drug from outside state and selling it across Patna. Abhimanyu surrendered after the police had seized a large amount of brown sugar from him last year. Guddu, with his wife Bhabhi Ji alias Radha, the masterminds behind the steadily expanding drug racket in state capital, were also nabbed in October last year.”

“The racket was first exposed when five members were arrested from the Jakkanpur police station area with 300grams brown sugar in their possession in September last year,” he said, adding that further investigation was going on in the same connection.

Title: Normal summer in Bihar this year: IMD
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Bihar is likely to witness nearly normal temperature between March and May (File photo)

PATNA: Bihar is likely to experience normal temperature in the summer season of March to May — contrary to the earlier forecast of above normal temperature in the core heat zone in the country, the Met office has predicted.

An extended weather bulletin issued by the Patna Meteorological Centre on Friday for forecasting weather parameters over the next fortnight said maximum temperature in Bihar was likely to cross 30 degrees C in the second week of March. The current temperature is hovering in the range of 26-27 degrees C.

The daily weather bulletin by Patna Met office on Friday also said that gradual rise in day temperature by 2 to 3 degrees was expected over the next two to four days.

On the expected seasonal temperature from March to May, a senior official at the Patna centre said: “Though there is 43% probability of temperature to remain 1-degree C above corresponding normal in core heatwave region, which covers Bihar, but as per detailed observation of different weather parameters, Bihar is likely to witness nearly normal temperature between March and May.”

The seasonal outlook for temperatures during March and May issued by the Indian Meteorological Department on Thursday stated that there was about 43% probability of maximum temperatures in the core heatwave zone to be above normal.

Core heatwave zone covers Punjab, Himachal Pradesh, Uttarakhand, Delhi, Haryana, Rajasthan, Uttar Pradesh, Gujarat, Madhya Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Bihar, Jharkhand, West Bengal, Orissa and Telangana and metereological subdivisions of Marathawada, Madhya Maharashtra and Coastal Andhra Pradesh. “This in turn suggests that normal to slightly above normal heat wave conditions are likely in the core heatwave zone during the season,” the season outlook bulletin of the IMD said.

Heat apart, weathermen have also predicted light showers along with thunderstorm at isolated places in all 38 districts in Bihar on March 1 and 2 but the intensity of showers is likely to be comparatively higher on March 2.

Title: Oriental Insurance eyes 3k cr capital infusion from Centre
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Kolkata: Public sector general insurer The Oriental Insurance Company is looking for Rs 3,000crore capital infusion from the Centre for growth and solvency in 2020-21. The board of OIC is meeting on March 18 to look into the budget for growth in the next fiscal. This was disclosed by Oriental Insurance chairman & MD A V Girijakumar on the sidelines of an interactive session with the members of Merchant’s Chamber of Commerce and Industry (MCCI) here on Friday.

He also indicated that the current valuation of the company would be in excess of Rs 10,000 crore. It is to be noted that valuation of all the three PSU insurers which would be merged to form a single entity is going on.

Elaborating on capital requirement, the OIC CMD pointed out that the requirement is based on the initial business plan of the insurer but this can be tailored as per the situation and availability of capital.

The Centre has already announced Rs 6,500crore capital infusion in three PSU general insurers — OIC, United India Assurance and National Insurance Company (NIC).

Girijakumar argued that since the inception of OIC it has paid Rs 9,500 crore as tax and dividend to the government, its promoter. After giving the initial capital in 1974, there was no further capital infusion in any of the PSU insurers by the Centre.

“GIC and New India Assurance had raised capital through an IPO. All the other three companies too were supposed to tap the capital market but that has not happened. This is why the Centre is infusing the capital,” he added.

According to him, third-party motor insurance (TP) which was administered till 2013 but the claim was based on actuary valuation and with no time limit was the main reason behind the PSU insurers losing money. “The loss ratio in motor TP at one point of time was 200-220%. Now, we are trying to settle the TP cases first. We have a target of cocealeation of 24,000 cases this fiscal and already did 18,000,” he added.

Elaborating on the growth plan of the company, the CMD added that they will look at different options like economy of business, growth for the insurer. “This year, we are concentrating on economy of business and grown so far by only 6% which is lower than the industry average. Our focus was consolidation. Last year, we grew at 15% which was higher than industry average so we increased out market share,” he added.

This fiscal, he indicated that the company did a lot of repricing to improve the bottomline. The company has a total premium target of Rs 14,250 crore for 2019-20 compared to Rs 13,450 crore in the last fiscal. Now, health constitutes 30% of its portfolio while motor is 34% and crop is 17%.

Title: Tamil Nadu: CISF constable, friends steal hens, arrested
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

DHARMAPURI: A 28-year-old central industrial security force (CISF) constable and three of his friends were arrested for stealing 39 hens here on Thursday night.

The Harur police identified the accused as CISF constable S Ponnumani, P Bharathi, 28, M Poovarasan, 27 and K Janakar, 22, all residents of Vadakarai village.

An investigation officer said the hens were reared by K Dinakaran, 30, of Vadakarai village. “As part of work, Dinakaran and family had left for Madurai on Tuesday after leaving 42 hens and roosters in the coop in his house. The incident took place when they were away.” His brother, meanwhile, found that 39 hens were missing from the coop and alerted Dinakaran, who returned home on Thursday morning and lodged a complaint with the Harur police.

During inquiry, police came to know that the hens were stolen by Ponnumani and his friends, who confessed to the crime. “We arrested all the four based on their confessional statement. Ponnumani, who was on leave, was planning to leave for Chennai on March 1 to rejoin duty,” the officer said.

The four were lodged in the Salem Central Prison under judicial custody the same night.

Title: Indian Oil to release LPG from renewable sources
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Coimbatore: Indian Oil Corporation Limited (IOCL) is targeting to ensure that at least 10% to 20% of LPG produced in the country is from renewable energy sources in the next two to three years, said director of the research and development wing of the company S S V Ramakumar.

He was speaking at the inauguration of the two-day National LPG Conclave 2020 in the city on Friday.

He said their research has so far shown that LPG can be produced from alternate sources like vegetable oil, glycerol and biomass. Indian Oil is now working on technology to scale up that production.

“We already have proof of concept that bio mass can be converted into LPG. Now we are working on the technology for us to do that in large scale,” Ramakumar said.

“The technology to convert glycerol, vegetable oil or even biomass into LPG is present already but yet to mature,” he added.

The conclave acknowledged that LPG’s growth potential as a cooking gas has nearly saturated, with more than 95% of households already being connected. Now, promoting LPG as an auto fuel has potential. In this regard, Ramakumar said Indian Oil had developed a technology to extract “auto LPG” directly from the fossil fuels.

“LPG as an auto fuel needs more olefinic properties, being a mixture of propane and butane, which is slightly different from our cooking gas requirements. However, this technology is also in the laboratory stage. We will install it soon in one of our refineries,” Ramakumar said.

Auto gas in our country is now CNG (compressed natural gas), which is slightly more efficient than LPG, he said. LPG produces less NOX and methane emissions, making it a cleaner form of energy. “CNG may give 1km more mileage than LPG per kg, but it gives more NOX and methane slip emissions, which are polluting. Auto LPG may also become more cost efficient, because our new extraction technology requires lower temperatures than usual,” Ramakumar said.

The conclave also plans to discuss potential for LPG being used in industrial and commercial purposes, including hotel, food and glass industries, among others.

Title: SBI sees corporate credit growth for Q4 at 5-7% YoY
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Kolkata: State Bank of India , the largest bank in the country, is expecting that corporate credit growth for it during the fourth quarter this fiscal could be around 5-7% on year-on-year basis. The bank has witnessed fresh interests in the project finance side in various sectors, particularly in road, city gas distributions and renewable energy, SBI deputy managing director P N Prasad said on Friday.

“There are a lot of interests from renewable side. Our bank has particularly been involved in large renewal proposals and we have been appraising many of the requirement. So, there are fresh shoots coming in that sectors,” he emphasized, adding corporate credit was expected to see good growth in the next fiscal.

“Some of the PSUs, central government and state government indeed do disburse money and consume money in the last quarter. So, normally we expect the credit growth to surge in the months of February and March. At the current trends it could be around 5-7% for the fourth quarter this fiscal, it cannot be more than that,” Prasad told reporters on the sidelines of an event on insolvency and bankcrupcty code organised by CII and NFCG. So far the banking sector has experienced muted credit growth in corporate banking so far, and SBI saw a marginal 0.5-1% y-o-y growth in this segment during the third quarter of the current financial year.

Significantly, growth in bank loans to companies and individuals plunged to 6.3% year-on-year in the fortnight to February 14, the lowest pace seen since May 2017. Non-food credit between April 2019 and mid-February grew at just 2.5%. In a recent report, CRISIL, however, said the prolonged slowdown in bank lending may be bottoming out this fiscal, with gross credit offtake set to rise 8-9% on-year in fiscal 2020-21, a good 200-300 basis points (bps) over the likely growth of ~6% this fiscal.

“A gradual pick-up in economic activity, continuing demand for retail loans, and strong growth in lending by private sector banks should drive the uptick. Recent policy moves announced in the Union Budget, and by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) are also expected to provide spur," it added.

The deputy managing director of SBI said thermal power, NBFCs and commercial real estate sector were currently facing some stress. "We are generally facing some kinds of stress in the power sector. There are some thermal power projects which are facing some challenges in terms of their tariffs and delay from payments from discoms (distribution companies). And, we are seeing some stress in some of the NBFCs, and commercial real estate," Prasad informed. On asset quality in corporate segment, he said sequentially fresh slippages came down. SBI's exposure to NBFC sector is currently around Rs 1.70 lakh crore, including investments.

Speaking on resolution mechanism under Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code (IBC), Prasad said prolonged litigation of some of the cases which are under NCLT has been a cause of “frustration” for bankers.

Title: ‘Odisha to be nerve centre of Purvodaya in steel’
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Bhubaneswar: Minister of petroleum and natural gas and steel Dharmendra Pradhan has said that with Japan as the partner country, he is looking forward to making Odisha , the nerve centre of Purvodaya in steel sector. It has participated in the workshop on “Enabling Procedures for Increase of Steel Usage for the Growth of Economy” in Bhubaneswar. This workshop was organised by ministry of steel in partnership with the ministry of economy, trade and industry, Government of Japan and industry body Confederation of Indian Industries (CII).

Prime Minister Narendra Modi has given a clarion call for Mission Purvodaya, that is Eastern India driving the national growth and propelling India towards becoming a $5 trillion economy.

Speaking about this initiative, he added, “We are organising series of workshops to deliberate on how to increase steel usage in India. We have rightly chosen Japan as our partner country who will guide us for making Indian steel ecosystem bigger both in qualitative and quantitative terms.”

On Japan-Odisha connection, he said, “Japan and Odisha has age old association. The iconic Dhauli Stupa built with Japanese support is a link between the two civilisations. Today after few decades, we have again gathered here to rewrite history and write a new chapter in growth of steel sector in Odisha with Japanese collaboration.”

Speaking about eastern India, he said, “The society of eastern India is aspirational-- people are getting economically sound, their spending capacity is increasing. Eastern India will play a pivotal role in driving national economic growth and achieving PM Modi's vision of making India a $5 trillion economy.”

Speaking about Odisha, he said, “Today, $5 billion infrastructure spending is being done only in Odisha in developing railways, roads, airports, pipelines, bridges etc. We have achieved 100% electrification in Odisha. 8 Cr new LPG connections have been given to the poorest of the poor. We have an ambitious plan to build next generation infra and boost economic growth.”

Speaking about prospects of steel sector in Odisha, he said, “Today Odisha is the highest steel producing state in the country.We are working to strengthen the steel ecosystem in Odisha. By 2030, Odisha's steel production alone is set to cross 100 MTPA.Odisha is going to be the nerve centre of Mission Purvodaya in steel. Kalinganagar will be the hub of the clusterization program involving entire eastern India. Moving beyond just producing primary steel, we will create an ecosystem of ancilliary, value added products, capital goods with industry participation.”

H.E. Ambassador of Japan to India Mr. Satoshi Suzuki speaking on the occasion, said, “I am very pleased to be in Odisha, This is my first visit to this beautiful city of Bhubaneswar. India is moving towards becoming a $5 trillion economy and it is the right time to share our experience with India. Japanese companies are increasingly collaborating with Indian companies. I am pleased to note Japan and India have launched India Japan Steel Dialogue to ensure sustainable growth of steel sector. Demand for steel in India is set to grow.”

Speaking about contribution of Indian iron ore in Japanese economy, he said, “Our iron ore exports from India, particularly Odisha, helped Japan in becoming a leading economic power.”

Shri Prafulla Kumar Mallik, Minister of Steel and Mines, Govt. of Odisha, Ms. Rasika Chaube, Additional Secretary, Ministry of Steel, Govt. of India, Mr. Hemant Kumar, Principal Secretary (Industries), Govt. of Odisha, Mr. Anil Chaudhary, Chairman SAIL, Mr. T.V. Narendran, Managing Director, Tata Steel, Mr. Sanjay Sharma, CEO-India and China, Arcelor Mittal and other officials from Government and industry were present.

Title: Kerala: Buying water from private tankers? You may also get shrimps and fish
Content:
Ever since the government issued guidelines for supplying drinking water through tanker trucks in February 202... Read More

KOCHI: Recently, when residents of an apartment complex in Pettah cleaned their large water tank, they were shocked to see shrimps and freshwater fishes. They said that the tank remained tightly closed, and only water brought by tanker trucks was used to fill it.“Water was stored for drinking purpose and there is no way fishes can enter that tank. We do not grow fish in it. They came with the water pumped from the trucks. This shows, the water supplied by tankers lack quality and there is no mechanism to check the same,” said an officer bearer of the apartment owners’ association on condition of anonymity.Ever since the government issued guidelines for supplying drinking water through tanker trucks in February 2020, residents of apartment complexes alleged they were being denied quality water. They said that the water supplied by trucks weren’t tested.“The trucks generally have all the documents needed for transporting water, but the problem is with the source from where they draw water. Residents don’t get reports of the mandatory tests that are done at government or NABL-accredited labs. Even if we insist on providing water from Kerala Water Authority ’s ( KWA ) filling points, we don’t know whether the same will be given to us by them,” he added.All Kerala Apartment Owners' Apex Association president VK Sankarankutty said if office-bearers insisted on seeing documents regarding trucks and their water source, then there is every possibility that these trucks will refuse to bring water. The trucks come at night. “Except the security personnel, there wouldn’t be anyone to check the documents. There is no assurance on quality and nobody cares,” he said.He also demanded that KWA should say how much water they can supply for domestic purpose in city and how they would meet the shortage during summer.Meanwhile, Ernakulam Residents’ Association Apex Council president Rangadasa Prabhu said that when large apartment complexes start depending on water supplied by KWA, it could result in water scarcity.“People, whether they live in individual houses or apartments, should get pure drinking water. At the same time, there should be no scarcity. Hence, water from other alternative sources should be filtered and treated and then supplied through tanker trucks. Large apartment complexes can install water treatment plants,” he said.

Title: Illegal electric fence claims lives of 2 elephants in Erode
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

ERODE: Two elephants were electrocuted after they came in contact with live wires of an illegal electric fence around a sugarcane field at Karalavadi village near Jeerahalli in Thalavadi forest range here on Friday evening.

Forest officials have arrested farm owner M Karuppasamy in connection with the incident. A forester said Karuppasamy hadn’t obtained permission to erect the electric fence around his sugarcane field that was close to the Sathyamangalam Tiger Reserve (STR).

“He said elephants used to raid standing crops such as sugarcane on his farmland as it was very close to STR. So, he installed the electric fence to save the crops,” the official said.

On Friday around 4pm, a six-year-old tusker and a five-year-old female elephant, attempted to damage the fence and enter the sugarcane field. “They touched the live wires and got electrocuted,” the officer said.

When alerted, Jeerahalli ranger S Kandeepan and other officials rushed to the spot and buried the carcasses in the STR forest area after the autopsy. “We have registered a case against Karuppasamy and arrested him. Further inquiries are on,” the officer said.
