Title: Kotak proposes ‘six-three-three’ formula for public sector banks
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Pune: The chairman and managing director of the Kotak Mahindra Bank, Uday Kotak, on Friday proposed diluting government stake to below 50% in three of the 12 state-owned banks and running the other three under public-private partnership.

“After the merger of various state-owned banks, we are now down to 12 state-owned banks. I still believe that we need to have a six-three-three formula. Six banks should remain in the public sector. In three others, state ownership should go below 50%. And for the others, we should think out of the box and find out a transparent way for public-private partnership, with domestic and non-domestic players,” Kotak said, while speaking at the Asia Economic Dialogue (AED) in Pune.

He said India was at the cusp of making some serious choices in the financial sector and people needed to ask some tough questions. “India nationalized its banking system in 1969. I want some analysis on the amount of taxpayers’ money that has been put into these banks from 1969 to 2020…Then we need to ask that over a period of 70 years, what is the return to the Indian taxpayers on the crores of rupees that have been put into the state-owned banks?” Kotak said.

Kotak said he did not advocate moving away from state-owned banks, but state ownership, in some of them, could be reduced.

He added that he saw a potential battle for the global financial technology order in the future, between Western and Chinese systems, currently exemplified by the debate over 5G wireless technologies that were being aggressively marketed by Chinese companies.

Title: They kept rioters out, preserved amity
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

New Delhi: While communal tension gripped Maujpur, less than a kilometre away, Babarpur village kept hostility at bay, with the Hindu and Muslim residents living as neighbours deciding not to be provoked into senseless violence.

“On Monday, when news of stone pelting emanated from Maujpur, senior citizens immediately called a meeting and asked the residents here not to allow outsiders entry into the village,” disclosed area resident Ajay Sharma. “We also decided to nab any suspicious people and hand them over to the residents’ welfare association or the local police.”

Sharma’s neighbour and childhood friend Waseem Khan joined the conversation to add, “Some people claimed that Muslim houses were being targeted elsewhere in northeast Delhi and that we should join the protests. But we didn’t give heed to such talk, opting instead to say at home.”

While the cops began patrolling the area, the residents took it upon themselves to take the rounds of the village in batches, especially at night. “Our only objective was to keep goons or anti-socials away from our area. We were worried that the harmony shared by the people here would be affected by the presence of such people,” said Desh Raj.

Social life in Babarpur has been marked by communal amity. Mohammad Imran shared how all Muslims keenly wait to partake of the bhandara organised every year at the local temple and how dishes prepared during the Eid celebration are distributed to all Hindu houses. Mangu Singh affirmed that his Muslim landlord was very protective about his family. “I saw a few tenants in my neighbourhood collecting stones to deal with any unforeseen incident, but I convinced them that no violence would take place here,” said Singh.

In Mustafabad, amid the hatred, chaos and violence, this spirit of amity was in evidence at the Mankameshwar Mandir. Muslims sacrificed sleep the whole night to protect the Shiva temple from attacks by rioters. They also assisted Hindus employees of a sweet shop to leave the area when rioting broke out.

The mandir is surrounded by Muslim residences. As soon as reports of vandalism at a mosque in Ashok Vihar started being circulated, the residents became angry, “But we didn’t let anyone attack the temple,” claimed carpenter Mohammad Khalid. “Most of those indulging in violence were people from outside our localities. It was our responsibility to make sure our Hindu brothers and sisters did not face hostility.”

Harikant Sharma, the son of temple priest Indradev Shastri, commended the act of the local Muslims. “It was the Muslims who ensured our safety and protected the temple,” he corroborated. “Policemen were nowhere to be seen during all this, and if not for the locals we don’t know what could have happened.”

Mukesh Kumar, who runs a sweet shop in Mustafabad, expressed gratefulness at how the local Muslims alerted him to the violence in the nearby areas on Monday and helped him reach his home in Nand Nagri. “I have never seen anything like this before. I can’t even imagine how it all began,” said Mukesh, who returned to Mustafabad on Saturday to open his shop and meet with the locals.

Title: Sedition case: After Karnataka high court prod, lawyers seek bail for Jammu and Kashmir students
Content:
Kashmiri students charged with sedition

DHARWAD: A team of advocates from Bengaluru on Friday submitted applications in the district and sessions court here, seeking bail for three Kashmiri engineering students, who were charged with sedition on February 15 for allegedly raising pro-Pakistan and ‘azadi’ (freedom) slogans in their Hubballi hostel . The case was filed after a purported video containing their act went viral.The advocates submitted the bail applications to the court administrative officer. The district judge will decide on the jurisdiction court before considering the applications. To avoid public glare, police let them into the court hall from the backdoor. After filing the bail applications, the advocates walked out from the front gate amid tight security.The development comes a day after the Karnataka high court said that a senior member of the Hubballi Bar Association (HBA) or its Dharwad counterpart (DBA) should argue the case on behalf of the Kashmiri students to uphold the best traditions of the legal profession. However, the lawyers who finally filed the bail petitions are from Bengaluru.DBA, which had opposed the Bengaluru advocates appearing for the accused students on Monday following an HBA resolution, chose not to resist their entry into the court on Friday. HBA had on February 15 passed the resolution barring its members from appearing on behalf of the accused students and requesting members of other bars to follow suit.Police, who had come under the HC scanner after unruly scenes erupted during the Bengaluru advocates’ visit to the court on Monday, had imposed prohibitory orders around the court premises on Friday. More than 500 personnel and half-a-dozen escort vehicles were on the court premises during the visit of the Bengaluru advocates.After the HC rap, police had requested the court administrative officer to enable the advocates of the accused to move their bail applications during lunch hours. The applications were submitted at 2:30pm.Earlier in the day, the advocates were escorted to the Hindalga jail in Belagavi by the Hubballi-Dharwad police to meet the Kashmiri students lodged there. The jail authorities permitted the advocates to take signature of the accused on Vakalathnama.In Video: 3 Kashmiri students sent to judicial custody for raising 'pro-Pakistan' slogans in Karnataka

Title: Ayurvedic medicine dealer among two killed in accidents
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Nagpur: An ayurvedic medicine dealer and a truck driver were killed in separate accidents in the city and rural between Wednesday and Thursday.

In both the cases, police have registered rash driving and death due to negligence cases. Further investigations are on.

In the first incident, a truck driver was killed after his speeding vehicle rammed a stationary truck from behind at Mahalgaon, around 20km from Mauda police station, on Wednesday. The deceased has been identified as Mohnish Bhaisare, while the driver of the stationary truck Sunil Sahare sustained injures.

Mauda police have registered a case against the deceased for rash driving and death due to negligence while Sahare for parking his vehicle on road without following any safety measures.

In another incident, Kailash Gajbhiye, 39, was knocked dead by an unidentified vehicle near Wathoda village on Jabalpur-Hyderabad highway on Thursday. Gajbhiye was returning from Seoni on a bike.

Cops said Gajbhiye, an ayurvedic medicine dealer, was found lying on road by passers-by who informed police control room. Wathoda police rushed to the spot and shifted Gajbhiye to Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH) where he was declared brought dead.

Police suspect that Gajbhiye’s bike must have been dashed by an oncoming vehicle as the two-wheeler’s headlight was found broken. Police also suspect that Gajbhiye may have died due to internal injuries as there were no major external injuries on his body. Gajbhiye’s body was later handed over to his relatives after post mortem on Friday.

Title: Narrow margin victories: EC urged to delay results till count of voter turnout
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Amaravati: The narrow margins of victories in Guntur and Visakhapatam Lok Sabha seats in 2019 have figured prominently in a public interest litigation filed by Association for Democratic Reforms (ADR) and Common Cause, an NGO , in the Supreme Court seeking declaration of results only after completion of voter turnout .

In Guntur TDP’s Galla Jayadev won by 4,205 votes but there was a mismatch of 6,982 votes in the final voter turnout.

In Visakhapatnam, YSRC’s MVV Satyanarayana won by 4,414 votes but the final voter turnout was up by 4,956 votes.

Noted lawyer Prasant Bhushan, appearing for ADR and Common Cause, sought a direction from the SC to the Election Commission not to announce results based on provisional and estimated vote count and wait till the completion of the tally of total votes.

The results in Guntur and Visakhapatnam were taken as basis for filing the case since ADR found serious discrepancies between voter turnout and votes counted.

Modugula Venugopala Reddy, YSRC candidate in Guntur who lost the election, said he would file a petition to implead in the case.

ADR and CC contended that there was no justification in declaring results before the final vote count was released.

“To maintain veracity of elections and uphold voter’s confidence a statutorily valid election result should be given importance over a few days of delay. That results based on estimates and assumptions and without any statutory backing defeats the very purpose of elections,” the petitioners argued. They said the EC too had admitted in its disclaimer of ‘result sheet’ which was available on the EC website that these election figures are provisional, based on estimates which are subject to change and has no statutory validity that “the data is estimated and subject to change”.

They said the EC had introduced My Voter Turnout app during 2019 Lok Sabha elections, a real-time reporting of voter turnout for every constituency.

The reporting was done on the basis of voting at booth level at any given point of time which was consolidated and put up on a mobile app called ‘My Voter Turnout’ app. They said the EC published the voting data on real time basis for the first six phases through the app.

A team of experts with ADR and CC found discrepancies between the number of voters in different constituencies such as voter turnout data collated and provided by the EC and the number of votes counted. The study of discrepancy patterns in all the constituencies based on the data available on the EC website and the ‘My Voters Turnout’ app found discrepancies in 347 out of 542 constituencies. Only 195 seats were without discrepancies.

“The discrepancies range from 1 vote (lowest) to 1,01,323 votes @ 10.49% of the total votes (highest). There are six seats where the discrepancy in votes is higher than the winning margin,” the PIL said.

Title: Chennai Metro rail forms panel to acquire land for phase-2
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: Instead of fighting lengthy legal battles, Chennai Metro Rail Limited (CMRL) has begun acquiring land for phase-2 construction by holding talks with the property owners through a private negotiation committee to quicken the process. According to CMRL officials, the approach helps convince property owners as CMRL is also ready to make changes to station design and location, if possible, to save owners from parting with large parcels of land.

On Friday, Good Shepherd School in Nungambakkam handed over land for building Sterling Road Junction metro station after a delay due to lengthy legal proceedings.

A metro rail official said they have acquired several properties through the private negotiation committee. “Recently we cleared five cases including those for Kellys, Chetpet, Adyar Gate junction stations,” the official said. “Private talk is mutually beneficial instead of long legal battles as we make people understand they can give us the land for more than the market price which they may not get by fighting a case,” the official said. CMRL requires 117.12 hectare land to construct the 118.9km phase-2.

Private negotiations with property owners come after CMRL faced difficulties in acquiring land for the construction of the 45km phase-1. This time, CMRL is also making changes to the design and location of stations, wherever possible, to cut down on the amount of land acquired.

“Since it is a design and building contract, we have the flexibility to change design and minimise the area of land being taken from owners as much as possible. We take our design consultants along with us when we hold talks with owners and make changes,” an official said.

For instance, officials said they have taken over 17,495sqft instead of 0.88 acre, as was initially planned, from Good Shepherd school, a major portion of which is the school’s playground. The school had moved the court against the acquisition.

On Friday, a cheque was handed over to the school authorities for giving the land. “We are not taking the playground. We have taken over a piece of land from a corner of the school campus where there is a school block. We will rent out the building to the school for a year till they get a new block ready,” the official said.

Title: Hospital that admitted to bribing back on govt panel
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Chennai: The state health department has brought back Gleneagles Global Hospitals into the list of empanelled hospitals under the state health insurance scheme, three months after it suspended the hospital citing “moral hazard” and “public interest”. The temporary suspension was following reports that it offered money to ambulance drivers and paramedics for bringing patients to its facility.

Incidentally, an inquiry committee appointed by the state health department in its report said that the hospital admitted to paying money to some drivers and paramedics. The letters to Directorate of Medical Services recommending action under the Clinical Establishments Act and to state transplant authority, Transtan for “suspension of transplant licence” are still pending. But more than two weeks ago, the state revoked the “suspension”. “Action based on the inquiry is still pending action,” senior health department official said.

The officials in the health department refused to comment further, but a Global Hospital spokesman said one of the hospital employees was found paying money to get patients into the hospital.

“We have removed him from the company rolls. We told the government he does not work with us anymore. After the inquiry, we were allowed to treat patients covered by the state health insurance scheme,” he said.

In September, former employees of the hospital complained to the government that the hospital was offering money to ambulance drivers and paramedics to bring patients including road accident victims into their emergency room. They told TOI that cash they gave to drivers soon after the drop ranged between Rs 700 and Rs 5,000 and the hospital transfers a percentage of the total bill as commission after the patient is discharged, they said, showing ‘entries’ of Rs 45,000 shown as being deposited into back accounts of some EMRI staff.

A fortnight later, GVK-Emergency Management and Research Institute, an agency outsourced by the health department to run 108 ambulances, dismissed 10 of its contract employees and placed nine other permanent employees on suspension after an internal inquiry against its drivers and paramedics.

Almost simultaneously, the health department ordered a detailed inquiry by a team of officials and suspended the hospital from empanelled list of hospitals for the chief minister’s comprehensive health insurance scheme of Tamil Nadu (CMCHISTN ).

Title: Ministers told to be at sectt on Wednesdays
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Amaravati: Responding to complaints about the unavailability of ministers in the secretariat, the state government has directed all ministers to be available in their chambers on every Wednesday in the secretariat at Velagapudi.

Many ministers were not going to the secretariat after chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy announced plans to shift the secretariat to the executive capital in Visakhapatnam.

Except for finance minister Buggana Rajendranath Reddy, deputy CM Pilli Subhash Chandrabose, municipal administration minister Botcha Satyanarayana and transport minister Perni Nani other ministers were rarely visiting their offices in the secretariat, said sources.

The ministers were not even taking stock of the matters in the respective departments at regular intervals, said sources. Since the chief minister is holding reviews of all the departments on a regular basis, the ministers were attending the reviews mostly held at the CM’s camp office in Tadepalle.

The CM himself is rarely coming to the office in the secretariat either for cabinet meeting or to interact with district collectors via video-conference, said sources. Recently, the CM’s meetings with foreign delegates have been taking place at his camp office.

Although there would be no big difference for the CM as the entire administration would be at his side at either place, the absence of ministers in the secretariat was said to be adversely affecting the administration.

According to sources, the CM has received reports about the unavailability of ministers for important delegations from industry or foreign countries to hold discussions on different projects.

In recent times, many people could not meet the ministers at the secretariat. Taking the feedback into consideration, the state government directed the ministers should be available in the secretariat on every Wednesday.

Title: CM YS Jaganmohan Reddy sets year-end deadline for completion of Polavaram works
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy inspects the Polavaram project works at the project site on Friday

Chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy has directed irrigation department officials to ensure release of water from Polavaram project by 2021. The CM, who visited the project site and conducted a high level review meeting on the progress of works on Friday, made it clear that the government is committed to complete the project and release waters to coastal and north Andhra districts including Visakhapatnam by the end of this year or early next year.

“The next five months are going to be crucial for the project. Meticulous planning is needed to complete it before deadline, without compromising on quality. The work should continue in the months of June, July, August, September and October,” Jagan said. He also asked officials to ensure that the spillway works are completed by June so that water can be diverted through the spillway.

“Work on the approach channel should also be done with the same pace and gaps in the coffer dam should be filled as soon as possible,” he added. As several villages are likely to get submerged once the coffer dam is completed, the CM directed the authorities to focus on rehabilitation works without further delay.

He further asked the project authorities to have a special officer posted in New Delhi to ensure that there is no delay in getting permissions for drawings and other technical issues. With regard to the left main canal connectivity, the officials told the chief minister that works are going on in two phases. Jagan suggested that the bridge to be built on the spillway should be called ‘YSR gateway’.

The CM also reviewed the relief and rehabilitation measures for the project displaced. Project officials told him that 41.2 metres of water can be stored in Godavari if the gaps in coffer dam are filled and six villages should be vacated immediately. He asked for an officer to be appointed to oversee the relief and rehabilitation works. “Be compassionate towards the displaced people even the expenditure escalates,” he said, while assuring speedy release of funds for setting up of rehabilitation colonies.

Earlier, Jagan conducted an aerial survey of the Polavaram project.

Title: Kolkata: Woman pushed off running train after resisting assailant
Content:
The spot between Park Circus and Sealdah stations where Mita Das was pushed off the running train

KOLKATA: A 24-year-old sales executive employed at a Quest Mall shop was allegedly pushed off a moving train between Park Circus and Sealdah stations last month when she tried to escape from a molester and call for help. The incident, the woman claimed, had happened last month and on Wednesday evening, she took to Facebook to describe her ordeal and shared some images of her bruised face, head and hands.Reasoning for the delay in coming up with the complaint, the Ranaghat resident said she was under treatment till now and was not in the perfect frame of mind to speak about the ordeal. But on Wednesday evening, she gathered courage and wrote about the horror ride back home in detail. Some of her friends tagged Kolkata Police and the Sealdah GRP in the post that was shared 11,000 times over the last two days. Kolkata Police has already replied her on Facebook Messenger saying they had passed on the information to Sealdah GRP, under whose jurisdiction the incident had happened but none from the GRP called her till late on Friday. A senior GRP official told TOI on Friday that they were yet to receive an official complaint about it but will look into the matter.“I live in Ranaghat with my mother and hence, neither my mother nor I could go to Sealdah and lodge a complaint all these days. But now, I am a bit stable and plan to visit the GRP by Saturday and lodge an official complaint,” said Mita Das, who had suffered multiple injuries in her head, hands and legs.According to the woman, on January 29, she had boarded the ladies compartment of a train to Sealdah from Park Circus station around 8pm. She would have got down at Sealdah and take another train to reach Ranaghat. “There was only another girl in the compartment but just as the train chugged out of the platform, a youth in his 20s hopped into our compartment and started making indecent gestures towards us and sat beside us. He started making advances towards me and asked the other girl to go away. I protested and just as I was about to scream for help and pull the emergency chain, the youth grabbed me by my hand, pulled me towards the gate and pushed me out of the running train,” said Das.Das lost consciousness after the fall and when she gained sense, she realised she was lying beside a railway track. She somehow dragged herself towards the Park Circus railgate and pleaded for help. “Two men took me to Kolkata National Medical College and Hospital but asked me not to tell anyone about the accident as it would have meant a police case and more hassles for them and me. So, I stayed mum. The doctors treated me and later called my family. I was under treatment at home all these weeks,” she told TOI over phone.Within hours of her post, people began commenting on the incident and sharing her post. One such user posted about another woman who also met with a similar fate on the same day. “It looks like the work of a same set of men. I want cops to take some action,” Das said.

Title: Health camp for infants on March 5
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Guntur: The authorities of Government General Hospital (GGH), Guntur will organise a special health camp for infants with disabilities on March 5. The camp will be held under the aegis of Guntur Medical College Spastic Society (GMCSS), where an expert orthopedic surgeon would treat the children .

Speaking to the media, GGH superintendent Dr S Babulal said that the success rate would be high in surgeries performed for correction of physical disabilities for the children below six months. He said that they have decided to organise the special camp as GGH has many experts in handling in such complex cases. He said that senior surgeons in the orthopedic department would take a call on the need of surgery after screening the disabilities. Dr Babulal said that they would also screen the infants suffering with cerebral palsy as it affects movement and muscle tone or posture.

Title: Sweeper held for molesting minor at Ytl wedding
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Yavatmal: A 25-year-old sweeper was arrested for allegedly molesting a 10-year-old girl at a wedding in the city on Wednesday night, police said on Thursday.

Lohara police arrested Akshay Chandekar after he was allegedly caught molesting the minor in a lawn of a hotel on Darwha road where the wedding was taking place, an official said.

Chandekar had approached the girl on the pretext of giving her food and took her to the lawn and molested her, he said, adding that the act was caught on the hotel’s CCTV camera.

The accused has been arrested under Section 354 (assault or criminal force to woman with intent to outrage her modesty) and provisions of Prevention of Children from Sexual Offence Act (POCSO), he added. agencies

Title: Milch cows owners demand hike in insurance amount
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Coimbatore: Farmers who own milch cows and supply milk to Aavin in the district have raised their concern with the district administration about the cap imposed by the animal husbandry department on number of cows to be insured and the insurance amount for each cow.

The Tamil Nadu Vivasaigal Sangam petitioned collector K Rajamani in this regard at the collectorate in the city on Friday.

According to the farmers, the animal husbandry department is agreeing to insure only two cows per farmer with the maximum insurance amount of Rs 30,000 per cow. State secretary of the association P Kandasamy said, “The department insures most cows for only around Rs 20,000. Even if a farmer owns 10 cows, he can insure only two. Moreover, if his two insured cows are worth Rs 50,000 each, he can insure them only for Rs 30,000 each.”

The animal husbandry department has reduced the insurance amount because it has only limited funds, the association said.

“As per the scheme, a farmer must pay 1% of the insured amount as premium. 50% of that 1% will be borne by the government. So, for a Rs 30,000 insurance amount, the government pays its share of premium of Rs 150. So, if they insure a cow for Rs 70,000, then the government must pay a premium of Rs 350, and more cows means more premium,” Kandasamy said. tnn

Title: Racing bus rams Metro pillar
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Kolkata: A private bus packed with passengers, mostly returning home from Sector V offices, were injured when the vehicle rammed into a Metro pillar near Unnayan Bhavan in Salt Lake on Friday. According to cops, 12 passengers suffered injuries and nine of them had to be taken to the hospital.

Power connection to the E-W Metro third rail was switched off for nine minutes from 9.13pm for inspection. No pier was damaged, said a Metro official.

Around 7.30pm, the bus of route 215A/1 was speeding towards Howrah from Sector V. “As it crossed Central Park, it tried to overtake another bus of the same route from the right but hit a pothole. The driver lost control. The bus climbed a median divider before ramming into a Metro pillar,” said Ajit Ghosh, who was passing by the area at that time.

As the bus came to a halt, the driver jumped out of the cabin and ran away leaving passengers, many of them lying on the floor, injured. Locals and guards and a medical team from Sabala Mela helped the passengers and treated them initially, before those with serious injuries were rushed to Bidhannagar sub-divisional hospital.

“ The moment it crossed Karunamoyee, the bus picked up speed and began overtaking vehicles from the right. We were finding difficult to stand. Suddenly there was a jerk. The bus rammed into something. I fell on the floor,” said Priyanka Jhawar, a passenger. Though police said 12 were injured, witnesses claimed the number was much more. “We have started a case of rash and negligent driving,” said an officer.

Title: Graveyard sold as plots in BHEL housing society, GHMC begins probe
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

A view of the BHEL MIG Colony

HYDERABAD: In a land scam which has come under GHMC radar, a total of 38 plots have allegedly been sold in the graveyard and open space in BHEL MIG Housing Society Colony in Serilingampally. Complaints have been filed against some housing society members and Chandanagar police have begun looking into the charges of irregularities.

Deputy city planner of GHMC Serilingampally zone R Srinivasa Rao told TOI that they have received a complaint on February 26. “We have sent teams for inspection at the site. We will take suitable action,” he said.

Human Rights and Consumer Protection Cell, in a complaint filed with various authorities on February 24, alleged that the space earmarked for the graveyard in the colony was being sold as plots of 80 square yards each to various persons. “The HUDA-approved layout clearly shows that the area is designated for a graveyard,” it said.

Apart from GHMC town planning, revenue and police officials are also seized of the alleged sale of graveyard and shopping complex areas in the housing society. An encumbrance search of stamps and registration department records has revealed that the plots had been sold between 2017 and 2019.

The BHEL MIG Colony was founded in 1989. As per Hyderabad Urban Development Authority-approved layout, 2,500 houses with space for parks, garbage, dumpyards and a graveyard were planned.

Whistleblower Thakur Raj Kumar Singh, who filed a complaint, said some old houses which sprung up in the graveyard should be demolished. “If they are any BPL families, they should be relocated,” he said.

Meanwhile, the housing society has asked the authorities to protect the graveyard and take suitable action against the members who resorted to irregularities. Repeated attempts to reach housing society president Venkat Reddy went in vain.

Title: Kolkata: Rogue biker thrashes cop, held
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

The bike the accused was riding.

KOLKATA: A youth was arrested near Mukundapur on Thursday evening for allegedly assaulting a traffic sergeant and attempting to flee when the latter stopped him after he had hit two pedestrians. The youth, Dipankar Das , was charged with rash driving and preventing a government employee from discharging his duty. The bike Das, 23, was riding had ‘Police’ written on the number plate.

Around 7.30pm, Suman Kalyan Dhak , the traffic sergeant, was on duty near Mukundapur when Das approached from the Metro Cash & Carry outlet at a high speed and attempted to turn right. There were some pedestrians at the crossing and Das crashed into them.

When a scuffle ensued, Dhak tried to intervene but he was pushed away by Das. The youth then tried to speed away but was stopped by another police personnel and Somnath Sarkar , Survey Park SI.

“We have identified the bike owner. He has nothing to do with police,” an officer said. Das was produced in court on Friday, where he was granted bail on condition that he performs a few hours of community service everyday.

Title: For 2nd time, HC stays Uttarakhand’s ‘forest’ definition
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

NAINITAL: Two months after it stayed the definition of "deemed forests" introduced by the state government in November last year, the Uttarakhand high court (HC) on Friday once again put a stay on the changes made by the administration in February.

As reported by TOI earlier, the HC had on December 10 last year put a stay on the state government’s office order which defined deemed forest as “a patch of land of at least 10 hectares and having at least 60 % canopy cover along with at least 75% native species.”

This, environmentalists said, was "an arbitrary definition". They alleged that it was unclear how the government arrived at the figure of 10 hectare and 75% native species in categorising an area as forest land. They pointed out that in 2017, the Forest Survey of India had defined forest as one hectare or more land with 10% canopy cover. However, this definition was also questioned in the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change that sought to know how this conclusion was reached.

"The dictionary meaning of the word forest ( any large area with trees and undergrowth) is being tampered with simply to make profit out of forest land," environmentalist Reenu Paul had told TOI when the definition was first announced.

Even as the HC was hearing three petitions challenging the original government order — the move had been opposed by several environmentalists who alleged that the decision was meant to primarily benefit the land and mining mafia in taking over forest land — the state government this month further tweaked the definition. As per the revised definition, deemed forest was now “a patch of land of at least five hectares and having 40 % canopy cover.”

Ajay Singh Rawat, a Nainital-based former professor of Kumaun University , who has petitioned against the state government in the matter, told TOI on Friday, “We welcome the HC directive. The new definition was primarily intended to duck the high court stay order, and to make the pending petitions in the case infructuous.”

Rajeev Bisht, the lawyer representing Rawat, added that the bench of Justice Sudhanshu Dhulia and Justice Narayan Singh Dhanik heard the case for three consecutive days before deciding to stay the new government order. “We argued before the court that the new definition was in complete violation of a Supreme Court order and is also against the Forest Conservation Act. However, the government through their counsels and forest officials said that the new definition was justified and that it benefits the forests. After hearing the arguments of both sides, the court decided to stay the revised definition as well,” Bisht said.

Rawat said, “If one went by the revised definition of the state government, around 9,000 square kilometer of forest land will not be considered so in the state. It is therefore clear that the aim of passing such orders is to …benefit the builder mafia.”

Madan Kaushik, urban development minister and spokesperson for the government, told TOI, “We will study the HC order in detail and further course of action will be decided accordingly.”

Title: MVA govt ends Chindam’s civic body membership
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

CLEARED SKHER

Nashik: The state government has terminated the membership of Sripad Chindam, an independent corporator of Ahmednagar Municipal Corporation, for his alleged remarks with regards to Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj.

Top AMC sources confirmed to TOI that the civic body had received a communique from the state urban development department on Friday on the issue.

State urban development minister Eknath Shinde had conducted a hearing on the issue at his office in Mumbai on Thursday and ordered for the termination of the corporator’s membership. Chindam was not present at the hearing although the department had sent him prior notice to appear for the hearing. Chindam could not be contacted despite several attempts.

“The minister has the powers to terminate membership of a corporator as there is a provision under Maharashtra Municipal Act. There will be fresh polls to elect a new member from that ward,” AMC sources added.

In February 2018, Chindam had allegedly passed derogatory remarks after Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj while pulling up a civic employee for not doing his work. At that time, he was elected on a BJP ticket and was the deputy major of Ahmednagar.

His remarks against the Maratha king had created a huge furore in Ahmednagar, although Chindam had later apologised for his remarks.

The AMC’s general body had then passed a resolution asking the state urban development department to terminate his membership as the elected member of the corporation for the alleged insulting remarks against Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj.

Even the local BJP unit had sacked him from the party. Ahmednagar city Shiv Sena chief, Dilip Satpute, had lodged a complaint against Chindam in the local police station. Chindam, however, won the subsequent polls held in December 2018 as an independent candidate.

“The previous BJP-led government did not act on the resolution passed by the AMC general body. A few days back, a delegation of Shiv Sena leaders from Ahmednagar city met Shinde in Mumbai. They urged him to expedite the issue. He ordered his department to immediately conduct a hearing,” said Satpute.

Title: Youth who had sustained burns was murdered
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Ujjain: A fire incident that fatally injured a youth in Nanakheda area of Ujjain turned out to be a murder on Friday. The victim succumbed to his injuries at an Indore hospital.

Preliminary investigation and statements of eyewitnesses had brought up the notion that the victim, Ganesh Gupta, a 22-year-old engineering student, sustained burns after flames from a bonfire spread on the night of February 28.

Two days later, the theory fell apart when CCTV grabs of Ganesh catching fire came to fore. His friends Suraj Yadav and Shubham Yadav, were seen pouring kerosene on him and starting a fire.

Nanakheda police station sub-inspector Vikas Devda said investigation revealed that Ganesh picked up a fight with Shubham and Suraj over money for purchasing chewing tobacco. The fight escalated and Ganesh was set on fire.

He sustained critical injuries and was admitted to a hospital in Indore. However, he was later referred to a hospital in Indore where he died on Friday.

“We have registered a case of murder against Suraj and Shubham,” Devda said.

Title: BJP takes out rally in support of CAA
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

More than 300 police personnel, including Rapid Action Force, provided security for the rally

COIMBATORE: More than 500 cadre of BJP took out a rally from Senchiluvai Sangam to the collectorate in the city on Friday in support of the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA).

More than 300 police personnel, including Rapid Action Force, provided security for the rally.

Addressing the protesters at the end of the rally, state general secretary of BJP Vanathi Srinivasan said DMK and its allies were spreading false information without understanding about CAA.

She said that both the state government and police should take necessary steps to control the ongoing protests against CAA in the state. “If they fail, we would also engage in similar protests,” she said.

Pointing out that BJP national general secretary P Muralidhar Rao had challenged DMK chief MK Stalin for a debate on CAA, she said Stalin is yet to respond to the challenge.

Following the rally, representatives of BJP submitted a petition to district collector K Rajamani.

Meanwhile, nearly 100 advocates staged a protest on the court premises in the city condemning the recent communal violence in northeast Delhi. The protest was organized by the All India Lawyers Union (AILU). They raised slogans and condemned the police for their inability to control the violence that erupted over CAA.

An advocate said the police department was hand in glove with Hindutva outfits in the violence.

“We not only condemn the violence but also insist on communal harmony in the country,” he added.

Title: Police association condemns N Chandrababu Naidu’s remarks
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

N Chandrababu Naidu

VIJAYAWADA: Andhra Pradesh Police Officers’ Association (APPOA), Amaravati, slammed former chief minister N Chandrababu Naidu for describing police ‘shepherds of donkeys’ at the Visakhapatnam airport .

They asked Naidu to detract his statement and not criticise the police personnel.

In a press release, APPOA said police were safeguarding law and order and were not ‘shepherds of donkeys.’ APPOA said the police swing into action spontaneously to deal with unpredicted situations to protect public and private properties and safeguard law and order.

Accusing Naidu and his son Nara Lokesh for trying to threating the police, APPOA said the police played a vital role in guarding Naidu against the agitators. But Naidu blamed the police and threatened to take action if they returned to power, it added.

It has become routine for TDP leaders to criticise the police. We want Naidu and other TDP leaders to stop threatening the police, said APPOA. tnn

Title: People sent Naidu back as they are angry with him for opposing Vizag as executive capital: Min
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Naidu protesting at the Vizag airport after his convoy was blocked, on Thursday

Visakhapatnam: Home minister Mekathoti Sucharitha on Friday said nobody arrested TDP chief N Chandrababu Naidu during his visit to Visakhapatnam on Thursday. Speaking to reporters after visiting the central prison in Kadapa, she said Naidu visited the city only for doing politics and it was the people who resisted his visit. “We had to send him back due to law and order issues and also to ensure his security,” she said.

Tourism minister M Srinivasa Rao also lashed out at Naidu, saying the people of north Andhra and Vizag sent him back. “All those who demonstrated against the former CM were residents of Visakhapatnam and north Andhra. Naidu’s comments belittling Vizag and his stance against it becoming the executive capital angered people. He is trying to play divisive politics and is unnecessarily raking up the issue of land pooling claiming that the land is being grabbed from the public. Now, the people have taught him a lesson,” he said in Vizag.

He also dismissed allegations that people were hired from outside to orchestrate the blockade. “This is absolutely absurd, we have no reason to muster people or stage a dharna,” he said, while adding that people of north Andhra have for long been fighting for their rights, which they have been denied. Giving the examples of Rampa rebellion and steel plant struggle, the minister said people of the region are not the kind to give in without a fight. “Naidu, instead of playing divisive politics, must learn to conduct himself with dignity. He should not blame the police for what happened at the airport, instead he must thank them for protecting him,” the minister added.

Title: Bees attack 25 kids in Mandsaur school
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Indore: At least 25 schoolchildren were sent to district hospital on Friday after a swarm of bees attacked them on premises of their school in Mandsaur on Friday.

“Around 25 children have been stung by bees. Of them, condition of two students is serious. The kids are being treated,” doctor at district hospital Ashif Khan said.

The incident took place at the school run by Jain Shishan Prasar Samiti on Mhow-Neemuch highway when the kids were playing in ground. Unfortunately, one of the kids allegedly pelted stone at hive of the bees on a tree. The next moment, children started running and screamed for help. Two students were seriously injured as they were stung so many times.

As students went haywire to save themselves, passersby came to their rescue. “We saw students running and crying with pain of bees sting. We removed some bees which got stuck on their body,” an eyewitness Salim told media-persons.

Another eyewitness Imran claimed, “It was after we informed City Kotwali police, an ambulance reached the spot to take students to hospital.

Taking stock of the incident, naib tehsildar Kavita Katel said, “We will check whether the school administration reacted in an appropriate manner to the bee attack or not.”

"Bees don't attack until they are disturbed. People should be cautious while visiting places near their hives," Mandsaur SDO (forest) RS Tomar said.

Box

Third big attack in a month

In past one month three incidents of bees attack have been reported in various parts of Mandsaur. Bees had attacked over 100 people participating in last rites of a villager in Barkhedaloya village and Titrod village of Mandsaur.

In the recent past, multiple attacks have been reported in rural areas of the district. An elderly person, who had taken his goats for grazing, had died after being stung by bees at Bholamagra in Garoth.

Title: Toll-free nos to address queries of SSC students
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Hyderabad: Telangana State Council of Educational Research and Training (SCERT) has launched a toll-free number for students of class 10 to clear their doubts ahead of SSC exams. Over five lakh students are set to appear for the Telangana SSC exams , which are scheduled to commence from March 19. All the exams will be held from 9.30am. However, the total duration of examination varies with subjects.

B Seshu Kumari, director, SCERT, issued a circular to all district educational officers, principals among others.

They were informed about interactive sessions with students on tension-free and fearless examinations from March 2 to March 6, 2020, through T-SAT. “Students and teachers can interact and clarify their doubts in various subjects of class 10 and also in general to face the examinations in a fearless manner, through telephone directly on the toll-free numbers 18004254038, 040-23553473,” read the circular.

The interactive sessions through T-SAT will prepare students for the final examination. Students and parents can clear their queries on hall tickets, examination centre, counselling, too, by calling on the toll-free numbers. Measures are being taken by SCERT following intermediate student suicides in the last academic year.

Title: TN: Valparai estate workers demand protection from wild animals
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Movement of wild animals, especially elephants, has increased in the past couple of months

COIMBATORE: Estate workers in Valparai have sought collector K Rajamani’s intervention to keep wild animals off human habitations.

Movement of wild animals, especially elephants, has increased in the past couple of months, V Paramasivam of the Kovai District Estate Workers and Officials’ Association said in a petition to the collector. “An elephant herd has been straying in Mudis, Thekkamudi, Periyakallar and Korangumudi,” he said.

Remembering estate worker P Suresh, who was killed by an elephant at Thonimudi in January, Paramasivam said that the animals destroy crops and buildings. “They raid houses in search of ration rice. The movement of elephants in residential areas has been increasing as the summer season is fast approaching. The situation has become more serious compared to the last year.”

“A separate fund has been allotted to construct water tanks inside forest and fill them on a regular basis. The government has also made provisions to set up salt licks in forest. But we don’t know if the forest department officials are maintaining them. If they at least fill the tanks during the summer season, wild animals will not intrude into human habitats,” he said.

As the streetlights installed by the Valparai municipality are not functioning in some areas, residents often bump into wild elephants, Paramasivam said. “The forest department should station kumki elephants in the region to chase away wild elephants as soon as they enter human habitations,” he added.

Title: 2 held with country-made pistol, 4 live cartridges
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Nashik: The city police on Thursday arrested two people under the Arms Act, 1959, after they were found with a country-made pistol and four live cartridges in the Nashik Road area of the city.

The suspects have been identified as Sagar Kokane (20) of Chehedi Pumping, Nashik Road, and Sandeep alias Huslya Narsing Shinde (20) of Sri Krishna Nagar, Aringle Mala, Nashik Road.

Police said that they received a tip-off about the duo from the crime branch unit 2. Police Naik Sanjay Tajane of the crime branch unit 2 received information about two people were carrying a firearm in the Chehedi Octroi Naka area of Nashik Road.

Accordingly, police laid a trap on the stretch between Chehedi Octroi Naka and Bhagwa Chowk at around 3.50 pm on Thursday. Police found Kokane and Shinde arriving on a motorcycle, following which they stopped the suspects. When frisked, police found that the suspects had kept the firearm in the tool box of the motorcycle.

Police also found four live cartridges with them. The duo was immediately taken into custody and was brought to the Nashik Road police station.

Police said that they are investigating the case in details. They said that during the course of investigation, they plan to find out from where the suspects got the firearm and for what purpose were they carrying it.

Title: 4 teams to investigate custodial death of jeweller
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Nashik: The state Criminal Investigation Department (CID) has formed four teams to probe the custodial death of a city based jeweller on Tuesday.

The Cyberabad police, under whose custody the jeweller allegedly jumped to death, have been asked not to leave the city without the permission of the investigating team.

On Tuesday, 47-year-old Vijay Birari committed suicide by jumping from the fourth floor of the government rest house where he was being interrogated by the Cyberabad police. He was detained for allegedly buying stolen jewellery from a Nashik-based burglar who committed several house break-ins in Telangana.

Sources from the CID said that a probe into the matter has already begun. “Apart from taking statements of the 16-member Cyberabad team, including a driver, we are also taking statements of other people who were at the incident spot when Birari allegedly committed suicide by jumping from the government guest house,” said a source from the CID, Nashik.

Title: Make efforts to reduce pendency of cases: Justice Ganediwala
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Justice Pushpa Ganediwala

Nagpur: Justice Pushpa Ganediwala exhorted the judges and lawyers at family court here to make efforts for reducing huge pendency of cases. Speaking at court’s 24th foundation day on its premises in Suyog Building in Civil Lines, the high court judge also advised them to come out with innovative concepts for resolving the family disputes.

Justice Ganediwala is guardian judge of family court here and had earlier worked as a judge in same court before being elevated to the HC. “It’s a matter of pride to be back here as a guardian judge of the court,” she said while appreciating the judges, lawyers and administrative staff.

Principal judge Mangala Thakre, who presided over the function, explained about the various programmes organized by them at the family court throughout the year, including special one for the kids. On the occasion, various competitions were also organized for parents and children, and the winners were bestowed with prizes by the guests.

Green Rating for Integrated Habitat Assessment (GRIHA) council had awarded four star rating to the court’s new building and PWD engineer Rajendra Bari was felicitated on the occasion for his efforts.

The family court officials including Vishwas Pathak, Manisha Kale, Prashant Agnihotri, and the president of the bar council, Shyam Ambhore, graced the event along with scores of litigants.

Title: Tamil Nadu sanctions Rs 1.25 crore to implement 5 landslide mitigation projects in Nilgiris
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

UDHAGAMANDALAM: Principal secretary to the state government and commissioner of revenue administration J Radhakrishnan said five pilot projects could be developed as part of mitigation measures to curtail landslides in Nilgiri hills.

Inaugurating a two-day national seminar on ‘Landslide Mitigation and Slope Management’ in the town on Friday, Radhakrishnan sanctioned Rs 1.25 crore towards the five mitigation projects on the spot.

The seminar was organized by the Tamil Nadu State Chapter of Soil Conservation Society of India (SCSI) and ICAR. Scientists, research scholars, officials from Indian Institute of Soil and Water Conservation, Geological Survey of India, NGOs and policy makers, besides 125 delegates from across the country participated in the seminar.

Radhakrishnan said, “Whatever mitigation measures are taken to prevent landslides and slope management, the natives of the land should be protected and should not be disturbed.”

Speaking on the occasion , Nilgiris collector J Innocent Divya pointed out that with increase in tourists and mismanagement of natural resources, the Nilgiris is facing high vulnerable situation. She said, “A policy needs to be in place to balance the fragile eco-system of the Nilgiris and proper management of water resources, natural streams and the drainage system.”

An appeal in this connection was put forth before the commissioner of revenue administration by the collector.

To mark the occasion, a book of abstract in landslide management was released. Also, an app namely ‘NeedD’ with all details of vulnerable areas in the Nilgiris and contact details of concern district officials was released.

S K Dube, ICAR-IISCEC, Agra, Amitava Kundu , deputy director general, GSI, K Kannan, head (in charge) ICAR-IISWC, Ooty and S Manivannan, convener and chairman TN state chapter of SCSI spoke on the occasion.

Title: Music fest at Le Café on Beach Road on Feb 29
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Puducherry: Saxophone exponent G Ramanathan and three bands of different music genres will enthral the audience during ‘Freedom Jam’, a music festival from 6pm onwards on February 29 at Puducherry tourism development corporation’s restaurant Le Café on Beach Road. The music festival, which is an annual event during the Republic Day weekend, will be held in February this year for the 17th consecutive year. The tourism department sponsors the festival.

The festival will begin with Ramanathan’s melodies and futuristic funk on the saxophone synthesizer. Ramanathan is the son of Carnatic vocalist T V Gopalakrishnan. Born in a family of musicians of over five generations, he has performed extensively both in India and abroad since 1955. He is an empanelled artist of the Indian Council of Cultural Relations.

He has worked with film music directors like A R Rahman, Harris Jayaraj and Vidyasagar among others. He has adapted an electronic Yamaha WX5, a kind of breath-controlled wind synthesizer, to bring out futuristic sounds for an electronic dance music (EDM) and fusion concerts. His ability to mix both classical, neo-classical and film songs has been appreciated by both the light music audience and connoisseurs.

Rap and reggae music band Too Lions from Bengaluru will follow the saxophone concert. The band will infuse fresh air into Indian Indie music scene with their happy carefree songs. The band comprises guitarist-singer Arjun, rapper Rohit, bassist Avram and lead guitarist Jesh Murjani.

Puducherry-based troupe, ‘Oru Chinna Band’, which includes veteran rock musicians from different old bands in the Union territory, will enthral the audience with their rock music. The band includes guitarist Joe, keyboard player Kenny, multi-instrumentalist player Maries and drummer Shaun. The band has recorded tracks for an album, which will be released soon. The band’s performance in the festival will be a sneak preview of their new album.

Young prodigies from Swarnabhoomi Academy of Music, who formed a band, 'Blahs and Blues' will present alternative rock music. The band includes singers - Malvika from Ambala, Rebecca from Mumbai and Rando, who grew up in Puducherry, drummer Prangana from Guwahati, bassist Rohit from Coimbatore, guitarist Jagjit and keyboard player Parthajit from Manipur. They will present their own compositions as well as a few selected covers in the blues idiom.

Title: Hookah parlour busted in city, 1 detained
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Nashik: The Nashik city police on Thursday busted a hookah parlour operating near the Sainath Nagar junction of the city. The action was conducted by the Central Crime Branch unit of the city police.

Police said that they raided the place and detained a 21-year-old man operating the parlour. They also recovered various flavoured tobacco-products worth Rs 11,850.

Title: Maharashtra: 4-year-high stock in 35 dams before hot days
Content:
File photo of Khadakwasla Dam

PUNE: The collective water stock in 35 major dams of the division was on Friday recorded at 69% ahead of the three summer months of March, April and May.This was the highest collective water stock in the division comprising Pune, Satara, Kolhapur, Sangli and Solapur districts in the past four years, state irrigation department data revealed.In 2018, the 35 dams had 65% collective stock during this period. In 2017 and 2016, the storages were 52% and 28%, respectively.The current water availability in the division appeared much better as compared to what it was in 2019, when the collective storage in the 35 major big dams had slipped below the halfway mark (up to 47%) at the end of February.The irrigation department has categorized the dams as “major”, “medium” and “minor” on the basis of their respective storage capacity. This year, the division has more water stock in dams belonging to all three categories. The Pune division has 50 medium, 641 minor and 35 major dams.An irrigation department official said the extended rainfall during the last monsoon in the catchments and the command areas of many dams has led to the additional water in the reservoirs.“Many dams recorded heavy rain till November last year. The demand for water remained low during the four months of winter. This meant lesser release of water. For instance, water stock in the Ujani dam is 69% now. In contrast, the dam had only 15% live stock at the end of February last year,” the official said.The demand for water might go up because the local (water) sources generally become dry during summer. The official said instructions have been issued for releasing water from the dams in accordance with the requirements.Another irrigation department official said the quantum of water also released from the four dams supplying water to the Pune city was less after last monsoon. “Water was released from Panshet, Varasgaon, Temghar and Khadakwasla in two rotations during winter. This year, the first winter rotation started about two months late. The second rotation is on,” he said.

Title: Jaishankar sees challenge for India in global supply chain
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

External affairs minister S Jaishankar addresses the dialogue in Pune via video-conferencing on Friday

Pune: External affairs minister S Jaishankar has said that undertaking changes to make India an effective player in the global supply chain and dealing with the implications of an unfolding knowledge economy on mobility and migration are challenges.

He was addressing the inaugural session of the 1st Asia Economic Dialogue (AED) in Pune through video-conferencing on Friday.

The three-day event is organized by the Pune International Centre, a think tank of eminent persons that provides inputs to the government for policy making.

Jaishankar said links to non-trade issues like social or security concerns have complicated the emerging trade situation. Narrow economic thinking of most societies is other influencing factor, he added.

“The two striking developments of our times are the rise of China and the nationalism of the US, both inextricably tied to the performance in trade. The sharper dichotomy between the two leading economies of the world pose larger challenges. Economies of low per capita income whose livelihood are affected by policy changes (Asian economies), are vulnerable in this context,” he added.

Jaishankar said the changing trade scenario is reflected in forging new partnerships, dependence on sourcing and mapping of supply chains. The debate on connectivity and technology underlines the complicated era in which we now live. An erosion of globalization will influence trading habits of many societies. Reaching international understanding against this backdrop is a challenge, he added.

The challenge for India is how well it is prepared to engage the global economy more openly. “Competing against those with structural advantages can’t be a casual decision justified by political correctness. Many trade relations have a direct livelihood and social consequences. The choices we make in terms of capability and balance are critical. The task ahead not only involves diplomacy but also good governance,” he said.

Earlier, K V Subramanian, chief economic advisor to Government of India, presented his vision on `Ethical Wealth Creation’ and how the invisible hand of trust will play a big role in global markets and trade.

Maldives minister of economic development Uzman Fayyaz Ismail said the island nation faces a challenge in populist governments and climate change. Integration of economies also brings challenges like the Covid-19 virus which is impacting the tourism-based economy of Maldives, he said.

Sri Lankan state minister of development banking and loan schemes Shehan Semasinghe said his country was revising all its micro-economic policies and trade regimes to adjust with the global scenario. The fruits of people-centric development must be felt in the lowest strata, he added.

Former Indian Ambassador to China Gautam Bambawale, convener of the event, said, “The AED will be the third of the annual events organized by MEA and PIC focusing on geopolitical, technological and geo-economics.”

Title: Telangana: Three peddlers arrested, 120kg ganja seized
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Picture used for representational purpose only

HYDERABAD: Rachakonda police arrested three peddlers and seized 120kg ganja and two cars worth Rs 24 lakh from them on Friday.

Officials of the special operations team of LB Nagar Zone, along with Hayathnagar police, arrested Gandikota Kumar, Nune Vijender and Keshamoni Rajesh Goud at Pedda Amberpet on NH - 65 while they were transporting ganja from Ashvaraopet and Bhadrachalam agency area of Badradri Kothagudem district to Mumbai.

Around November 2019, Kumar and Vijender formed a gang with Goud and started procuring ganja from Rakku at Bhadrachalam. They used to supply it to one Sameer of Mumbai.

“The accused used to buy ganja at Rs 3,000 a kg from Rakku and sell it to Sameer for Rs 8,000 a kilo,” Rachakonda commissioner Mahesh Bhagwat said.

Title: ‘PU turned into a detention centre during Venkaiah visit’
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Puducherry: Pondicherry University turned the South Asian regional cooperative centre within the campus into a detention centre and confined 90-odd students, who are on an indefinite strike against fees hike since February 6, for more than 20 hours during the visit of vice-president M Venkaiah Naidu on Wednesday, alleged the students’ council.

Council president Parichay Yadav said the students were confined at the centre from 4pm on Tuesday to 1pm on Wednesday. The students as soon as they were released marched towards the administration block and resumed their protest reoccupying the corridor of the block demanding the university to revoke the hike in fees for all courses.

He said the university hosted the 28th convocation on Wednesday during which Naidu, who is also the chancellor of the university, awarded degrees to the students when 94 students were under detention within the campus.

The students were kept under custody until the convocation ceremony concluded. "Such an unfortunate incident of converting a university into a detention camp is quite unheard of," said Yadav.

The council regretted that the university continues to propagate 'lies' through its statements. "The attempt to malign the cause of the protest is highly condemnable. The arrogant language in each of these releases is a testimony to their lack of concern for the students," Yadav said.

The council said the university promised to reconvene the fee revision committee on February 28 to redress the concerns raised by the students. "We will continue our indefinite strike until our demands are met," he said.

The university claimed that the fees for all courses were hiked after a gap of 10 years. It said the hike for most of the courses were between 25% and 50%. However, various students' forums termed the university's justification as a set of lies and furnished the old and revised fee structures to prove that the university has steeply hiked the fees. They pointed out that the fees for MCA, MSc/MTech (computer science) and MBA courses were hiked by 132.3%, 124% and 95% respectively.

Meanwhile, Democratic youth federation of India and Students Federation of India and other students' forums staged an agitation in the town on Thursday. The agitators blindfolded themselves and raised slogans demanding the university to revoke the fees' hike.

University public relations' officer R Venkatesakumar denied that the students were detained at the silver jubilee block. "The campus was brought under the control of security agencies on Tuesday, 24 hours ahead of VVIP visit, as a security measure and protocol related procedure. The security personnel took the agitating students, who were indulging in protest and occupying the corridors of the administrative block and kept them at the 100-acre silver jubilee campus within the university as a preventive and safety measure to maintain law and order. The students were not locked in the campus," said Venkatesakumar.

Title: HC slams shoddy probe in Merces case
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: The high court of Bombay at Goa slammed the police for not having showing seriousness in investigating the suicide case of former Merces sarpanch Prakash Naik , because the accused, Wilson Godinho, is “brother of the local minister”. It also spoke about the “clout wielded” by Wilson over the investigating agency.

The court observed that the investigating agency would be better equipped to unearth the crime only when Wilson is in police custody, and rejected his anticipatory bail application. Panchayat minister Mauvin Godinho is his brother.

Justice Nutan Sardessai observed, “The offence by itself is serious and the seriousness required to investigate such a case has unfortunately not been exhibited by the investigating agency obviously for the reasons of the applicant being the brother of the local minister, and it appears from the manner of the investigation conducted thus far, as borne out from the case diary, that there is no seriousness to actually probe the role of the applicant in the crime.”

The court said that the manner in which the police allowed him to go at the inception itself, on the specious premise that no FIR was registered against him, speaks volumes about the clout wielded over the agency by the applicant being the brother of the local minister.

The judge held that Wilson had dealings with Naik relating to the property at Merces and that there were money transactions between them. Besides, the applicant wanted access to the property he had purchased with Naik’s intervention, but this was not possible in view of the objections raised by villagers of Merces, following which construction was stalled.

“It appears from the records that the deceased was under tremendous pressure over the money transactions between the applicant and the deceased himself,” the court said.

Title: Goldsmith who duped 57-year-old businessman booked
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: A goldsmith has been booked for duping a businessman of 211g gold bar.

The Big Bazaar Street (crime) police said they have registered a case against Ravikumar based on a complaint lodged by 57-year-old S Ramasamy, a gold merchant from Kempatti Colony.

“Ramasamy used to give gold bars to goldsmiths for making ornaments. In August 2018, he had given 211g gold bars to Ravikumar. But Ravikumar didn't make gold ornaments. When Ramasamy approached him a few months later to reclaim the gold bars, he feigned ignorance of the same and threatened the gold merchant with dire consequences,” a police officer said.

More than one and half years later, Ramsamy lodged a complaint with the Big Bazaar Street police, who registered a case against Ravikumar under Section 406 (criminal breach of trust), 420 (cheating) and 506(i) (criminal intimidation) of the Indian Penal Code.

Title: MSEDCL takes action against 40 consumers in Malegaon for power theft
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Nashik: The Maharashtra State Electricity Distribution Company Limited ( MSEDCL ) officials have taken action on 40 consumers , including one plastic process unit, for illegally tapping power from open sources in Malegaon .

The MSEDCL has earlier snapped power supply of all the 233 units as per the NGT orders; however, the officials said that there were chances of people tapping power from illegal sources. “On the backdrop of the strict guidelines of National Green Tribunals (NGT) the officers in Malegaon did a surprise visit on February 26 to disconnect the power of over 233 plastic process industries. During the visit, one plastic process unit was caught tapping power from illegal sources,” said BK Janvir, chief engineer of MSEDCL, Nashik Zone.

The MSEDCL officials have been keeping a close watch on the unit holders to see if they were relying on some alternate source of power. “Ankush Nale, the regional director of Konkan Region, of which Nashik Zone is a part, visited Malegaon on February 26 and in the surprise visit caught the unit using power. The team of officials also visited other premises – commercial as well as residential – in which the officials found 37 more consumers who were tapping power illegally,” the officer said.

The accused either drew power from the overhead lines, or tapped the same from the nearby distribution points. The power lines drawn from the overhead were even naked at certain points endangering the lives of the people. The underground power lines were also dangerously laid as they were not deep enough to prevent any untoward incident from happening. The lines ran up to 100 meters drawing power from the sources till the house, shop or even other purposes.

All these premises were raided by the team and the penalty was slapped against the guilty parties. “The teams found out that two connections were drawing excessive power than the contract load. The people had connection for residential purpose but that was being used for some other purposes as well, and hence the power consumption was higher. The assessment of the power theft is being further evaluated,” the officer said.

The team was hopeful that the power could be drawn in the night especially in the backdrop of the fact that it was unlikely for any officials to visit there. “The MSEDCL therefore took help of the police department,” the officer said.

Title: Cybercriminal arrested for uploading fake website, cheating several people
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Nashik: The Nashik cybercrime police on Wednesday arrested a 24-year-old man from Raver in Jalgaon district in connection with the case of a fake website of the tribal department. The suspect has been accused of cheating several people through it by posting a recruitment drive and seeking money in the form of examination fee.

Identified as Jitendra Rama Tayade, the suspect has been remanded in police custody till March 2 for further investigation.

Devraj Borse, senior police inspector of the cybercrime police station, said that on February 22, an official of the Tribal Development Commissionerate approached them with a complaint stating that a fake website of the department was created under the name https://mahatribal.webs.com.

The official told Borse that the person who had created the fake website had put up an advertisement of a recruitment drive stating that 3,199 posts were to be filled in the tribal department, under which 1,031 were to be filled in Mumbai, 866 in Pune, 724 in Nashik and 578 in Jalgaon.

The conman had also put a certain link on the website to fill the examination form and had also created a link for payment.

Police said that the conman’s aim was to dupe people of their money in the form of accepting examination fees.

PI Borse said that soon after the compliant was lodged, they sought help of the technical analysis wing to determine the location from where the conman was opearating. Working on the lead, police reached the suspect in a matter of three days.

“Tayade is unemployed. On checking his bank account, we found that he had collected Rs 34,000 in the form of examination fees in a matter of few days,” Borse said.

Police said that since the examination fee charged by the conman was somewhere between Rs 350 and Rs 500, the victims did not bother to report the fraud and file a complaint with the police.

Title: Dubai passenger’s branded watch stolen from Pune Airport
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Pune: A branded wrist watch of the general manager (44) of a private firm in Dubai was allegedly stolen from the airport in the early hours of Thursday soon after he landed in the city.

The passenger’s Air India Express flight from Dubai (IX 212) reached the Lohegaon airport around 1.30am. He was in the city for meeting his mother.

The Dubai-based manager told TOI over the phone, “I placed my watch, belt and cellphone on a plastic tray of the X-Ray conveyer belt for security check and walked up to the machine for collecting my valuables after I was frisked. I found one of the helpers holding my phone. I took it from him and enquired about my watch because it was not on the tray. He told me he was clueless about it.”

The flyer said, “My phone went missing in just 40 seconds. I reported the incident to the customs officials instantly and appealed them to check other passengers. The officials appealed to passengers to return the phone, but no one responded.”

The manager then asked the officials to show him the CCTV footage and stop the passengers, but they did not consider his request. “After checking the CCTV cameras, the officials told me that they do not cover the conveyer belt. By that time, most of the passengers had left. They told me that the incident could have been averted had I been alert.”

The officials then referred the flyer to the Central Industrial Security Force. “After checking the footage of the CCTV cameras, they expressed doubts about some people and advised me to lodge an FIR,” the flyer said.

Deputy commissioner of customs Motilal Shete said, “The watch got misplaced after the handbag scanning procedure, when the passenger was required to collect it. The customs officers immediately tried to help the passenger to search the watch by seeing CCTV footage. The officers made announcement regarding the misplacement. Even baggage and baggage scanning of passengers present at the location were checked.”

(With inputs from Joy Sengupta)

Title: Hyderabad: Housing society fined Rs 53,000 for chopping trees
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: The forest department has imposed a fine of Rs 53,900 on the executive committee of Indu Fortune Fields Gardenia Apartments for the cutting and translocation of about 36 trees without permission. Some residents, however, contested the move on the grounds that the number of trees cut was much higher.

Sudhakar Reddy, the district forest officer of Medchal, inspected the premises before taking the decision. The department held that while the said trees had been translocated, this was done in an unscientific manner. Stating that the act was in violation of WALTA Act, the department also said that 80 saplings had to be planted for the trees.

Confirming the development to TOI, Satish Duvvuru, general secretary, Indu Fortune Fields Gardenia Apartment Owners Association, said there was no malafide intention behind the move. “Last year, we faced an acute water shortage because of which we decided to make way for an addition water tank. We translocated the trees in the interest of the community,” he said adding all 32 stumps have been translocated. Last week, TOI reported that the trees at apartment complex had been cut in December and translocated a few weeks ago.

K Dasaradhi, a resident and former president of the executive committee of Indu Fortune Fields Gardenia Apartments, contested the fine set by the forest department. He said, “The management cut 55 trees out of which only 32 have been translocated. The forest committee is being very lenient.”

In a complaint to Sreedevi Saraswati, forest range officer, Dulapally, Dasaradhi wrote, “It seems around 30 tree stumps were moved to KBR park, Jubilee Hills and the remaining tree trunks or trees are either moved to an unknown location or may have been sold.”

Another apartment owner, Sreekanth Yenamala said, “This fine is not enough of a deterrent. It will encourage people to continue felling across the city. We will be meeting the forest department officials tomorrow to take this matter more seriously.”

Title: Madurai’s famous jigarthanda flown to Singapore for the first time
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

edited

Madurai: While traditional snack items like murukku, kadalai mittai, karachevu and the Geographical Indication (GI) tagged Srivilliputtur palkova have frequently been exported due to their high demand in other countries, it is the first time that Madurai’s famous drink jigarthanda has been flown to Singapore by an Air India flight on Wednesday.

S Thanga Pandian, customs clearance agent, said that traditional Indian sweets were in high demand in other countries and over the past few months, he had seen the exports of not less than 1,000 kg of traditional sweets and snacks being flown from the Madurai airport to various destinations.

The makers of the famous jigarthanda recently received a request from a local trader in Singapore for their jigarthanda. After completion of all formalities, including the FSSAI certification, the first consignment of 135 kg was flown to Singapore on a trial basis on Wednesday.
