Pandian said that all the ingredients for jigarthanda including the milk, almond gum, sea algae, sugar and the ice cream for the constitution of the drink were being taken from Madurai. “It is the taste of cow’s milk and the handmade ice cream from Madurai that gives the specific taste to the drink, hence all the ingredients have to be taken from here, only the algae is taken in the dry form and will be soaked once it reaches its destination,” he said.

As the fasting season of Ramzan is coming up, jigarthanda is expected to be in demand in Singapore as it is an energizer and also has cooling properties. Pandian said that based on the reception that the drink receives in Singapore, the frequency of export may be enhanced to even daily.

Title: Students injured after scuffle over playing music
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Pune: The Chatushrungi police late on Thursday night booked 12 people, including the owners and bouncers of a restaurant in Pashan, on the charge of thrashing seven college students following a tiff over playing music.

The seven students suffered injuries in the incident. One of them is undergoing treatment at a hospital. A 20-year-old student from Gokhalenagar has lodged an FIR with the Chatushrungi police.

“The suspects have been booked under sections 323, 324 and326 (voluntarily causing grievous hurt by dangerous weapons or means) and 143, 148, 149 (rioting) of the Indian Penal Code,” an officer of the Chatushrungi police said.

The incident occurred around 11.50pm when about 100 students were attending the farewell party of their college at the restaurant. “When the restaurant staffers switched off the music, the students requested them to restart it. When they denied, the students had heated arguments with the staffers,” another officer from the Chatushrungi police said.

He said when the students started leaving the place, the owner and the bouncers reached there and started thrashing them with sticks and iron rods. “While some of the students left the spot, others suffered injuries on their heads, backs and legs during the attack,” the officer said.

Assistant inspector of the Chatushrungi police Vishal Pawar is investigating the case.

Restaurant manager lodged cross-complaint

The manager of the restaurant has also lodged a cross-complaint with the Chatushrungi police, alleging that the group of students beat up five employees of the restaurant.

Senior inspector of the Chatushrungi police Anil Shewale told TOI, “We have registered cross-complaints. We are yet to make any arrests as the victims as well as suspects in both the complaints are undergoing treatment.”

Despite repeated calls, the restaurant owner could not be contacted.

Title: Only 7% RTE quota seats for LKG
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Pune: Parents of the children seeking admission to pre-primary sections under the 25% Right To Education (RTE) quota have a task cut out for them.

The Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) city unit said there are only 7% seats reserved for the pre-primary sections in the city under the RTE while 93% was reserved for admissions to Standard I and beyond.

An AAP member the 972 schools in Pune district have a total of 17,053 seats reserved under the RTE quota. Of these, 15,638 seats are for admissions to Standard I and beyond.

The state education department had announced in 2015 that schools can choose their own entry level. Several schools across the city said that since the state government stopped reimbursements for RTE students in kindergarten, they decided to recognise Standard 1 as the entry and reserved the maximum seats for the same.

"Schools with pre-primary sections as entry level refuse to admit students under the RTE quota. Parents hoping to send their children to kindergarten under the quota are stuck," AAP’s city unit president Mukund Kirdat said.

Parents of beneficiaries said the lack of seats is a cause for concern. “While filling up the forms for admission under RTE in Baner area, I realized that there was no school in my vicinity that offers admissions to pre-primary section," Bhagwan Khandare, father of a four-year-old, said.

"Most schools have set standard I as the official entry level for which they would be reimbursed,” director and honorary secretary of Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan Nandkumar Kakirde said. State education commissioner Vishal Solanki said, "The RTE Act applies from Std. I. We will examine other aspects soon.”

Title: Hyderabad wall collapse: Survivor out of danger, but loses two fingers
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

House in Habeeb Nagar where the wall collapsed on Friday

HYDERABAD: Two-year-old Geetha, who sustained injuries after the old wall collapsed on her at her Afzal Sagar house in Habeebnagar on Thursday night, is out of danger but has lost two fingers on her hand.

Her father K Gabbar said Geetha had a close shave. “My two daughters were inside the house along with Roshini, Pavani and Sarika. My elder daughter Geetha sustained head injuries but is conscious and talking to us. She, however, lost two fingers,” he said. Geetha was shifted to Osmania General Hospital.

The younger daughter, who was sleeping a little away from the wall, escaped without any injuries, said Gabbar, brother of Mithai Lal. Mithai’s three daughters had died when the wall crumbled.

K Ganesh, who runs a kirana shop, said the houses in the locality were old. “Some of them were constructed in 1982 and some in 1993. Most of the dwellings are rickety,” he said.

A resident said roofs in some of the houses often fall off. Recently, a portion of the roof in a house collapsed but luckily, there was nobody present at that time, he recalled.

“In 2001, a similar accident occurred and five persons had died after a wall collapsed on them. Then chief minister Chandrababu Naidu visited our basthi,” recalled Tirath Lal, a resident.

Locals said they were promised double-bedroom houses by the Telangana government but nothing much has happened. “Officials said 2BHK houses will be built in Mangar Basthi and issued notices in 2015 asking us to vacate our dwellings. The foundation stone was laid but nothing has happened since then,” S Laxman, a local said.

He said they met the collector and revenue officials. “But, there has been no word on the houses,” he complained.

Title: Chandigarh: PGs will now be registered yearly, to obtain fire NOC
Content:
Students of colleges and Panjab university gathered outside Deputy commissioners office on Friday as the PG ow... Read More

CHANDIGARH: Punjab governor-cum-UT administrator V P Singh Badnore on Friday finalised a revised policy for paying guest (PG) accommodations in the city following an uproar over the death of three girls in a fire at an illegal PG facility in Sector 32 on February 22.A senior official said certain new provisions such as mandatory fire clearance, annual renewal of registration and indemnity certificate from PG owners were added. It was decided not to exempt the requirement of house owners staying in the PG accommodation. However, shortly a new category will be introduced in which owners can rent out buildings for hostels after meeting the statutory stipulations, he said.UT adviser Manoj Parida said the policy was revised keeping in view the need for accommodation of students in private houses and their safety and security. He clarified that the intention is not to close down the PGs but to get them regularised through registration. The deputy commissioner had opened the registration counters at the UT estate office. They will remain open even on Saturday and Sunday this week, he said.The administration will soon start accepting online applications for the registration. Those premises which do not have occupation certificates will be allowed provisional registration, subject to the condition that they will obtain occupation certificate within three months. The administration has also allowed the PGs to operate on the undertaking that necessary fire clearance will be obtained within a month, an official said.In a bid to reduce the woes of students, the administration has allowed various bhawans located in the city to accommodate them on a payment basis. Similarly, the colleges have been told to accommodate students evicted from illegal PGs temporarily in spaces or dormitories available. The UT engineering department has already started construction of hostels for 6,000 students in colleges located in sectors 42, 46 and 50.The DC has directed that all applications for registrations be cleared within two days, so that the house owners do not have to run around various offices. The administration, however, clarified that those PGs, which are housed in less than 7.5 marlas will continue to be sealed.

Title: Maharashtra: IMD forecasts mild summer temperature in first few days of March
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: March may begin with lower summer day temperatures than normal in Maharashtra, at least till Thursday.The month will start on a milder note than usual for regions like Madhya Maharashtra , Vidarbha and Marathwada .The state may be warming up, but except for Konkan, most regions in Maharashtra have been recording marginally below normal day temperatures of late.A fresh extended range forecast by India Meteorological Department (IMD) recently indicated that while above normal (by 2-3ºC) day maximum temperatures were likely over Jammu-Kashmir, Ladakh, Himachal Pradesh, Punjab, Haryana, Chandigarh, Delhi, southwest Uttar Pradesh, below normal (by 2-3 ºC) day temperatures will be witnessed over most of Maharashtra, south Gujarat, south Madhya Pradesh, Goa, among others till March 5.However, the average maximum day temperature may still be above normal over many locations in India, including Maharashtra from March to May.Anupam Kashyapi, head of weather, IMD Pune told TOI that the extended range forecasts are indicating average day temperature in Konkan to be slightly higher than normal.“Coastal locations are generally milder than plains. The normal day temperature in March in coastal locations is around 33-34 degrees celsius. If the temperature rises around 4 to 5 degrees higher than this, then it could be a heatwave situation for the coastal location as threshold temperature for coastal region is 37°C or more. This is not the case for plain locations like Pune and Nashik where normal March day temperatures are 35-36 degrees C,” he said.However, while the day temperatures are expected to be normal to below normal during the first week of March in most of Maharashtra, night temperatures would once again be high in north and central Madhya Maharashtra till March 5. In Pune district, night temperatures are expected to be on the higher side of normal.

Title: MPs seek reports for delay in road construction in rural areas
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Nashik: Members of parliament Hemant Godse (Nashik) and Bharti Pawar (Dindori) on Friday asked the authorities to present their reports about the road construction , power supply and other issues.

Addressing the District Development Coordination and Monitoring Committee (DISHA) meeting, convened by the district committee, the MPs expressed their displeasure on lack of developmental works in the rural areas by the government agencies – especially the construction of roads and processing of government aide for the destitute under Sanjay Gandhi Niradhar Yojana, etc.

The meeting, which was also attended by district collector Suraj Mandhare, ZP president Balasaheb Kshirsagar and Zilla Parishad CEO Leena Bansod, saw representatives being unhappy with the agencies for failing to construct the roads despite government making all efforts to improve the connectivity. “There are villages with more than 250 people living in there but there are no road connections forcing the people to walk and trek,” one of the members said.

MP Hemant Godse questioned the officers about the construction of the road on which the officers present were unable to give a proper explanation. They were asked to furnish the information about the same at the earliest.

MP Bharti Pawar noted that the numbers of the beneficiaries of various government schemes including the help for the destitute, people with disabilities, etc were far less in Kalwan and Deola taluka. She said that people were forced to make repetitive rounds of the respective offices for getting the necessary help.

The issue of the government grant for the toilet blocks also came up during the meeting. While 7,264 toilet blocks were constructed in Nashik city limits, there were about 13,000 constructed in the rural areas. The members raised the issue of expediting the clearance of dues to the beneficiaries.

The members also demanded that MSEDCL raise the electricity infrastructure in Trimbakeshwar to Dahalewadi but the forest department land is becoming a hurdle in the process. “We are in consultation with the forest officials for the permission,” the MSEDCL officers assured.

Title: SPPU student gets award for animal-free pharma test story
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

School students and science lovers visit the Inter-University Centre for Astronomy and Astrophysics (IUCAA) on... Read More

Pune: Savitribai Phule Pune University’s Joyita Sarkar was one of the 21 people and the only one from an educational institute in the state to be awarded by President Ramnath Kovind for her role in science communication and popularisation on the National Science Day in New Delhi on Friday.

She received 'Augmenting Writing Skills for Articulating Research' (AWSAR) award for her science story, 'Coming soon: Animal model-free system for Pharmaceutical Testing', which she penned as a postdoctoral research fellow of the SPPU's physics department. Since January this year, she has been working as an assistant professor at the Institute of Chemical Technology's Marathwada campus.

“It was a great and motivational experience to receive an award from the President. But I hope this is the beginning of many such achievements, and not just once-in-a-lifetime thing,” said an elated Sarkar.

“I had applied for the award in October but forgot about it,” she said.

“The aim of the AWSAR award, as envisioned by Ashutosh Sharma, secretary, Department of Science and Technology, is to convey what scientists are doing in their labs to the common public,” said Sarkar.

Explaining her work, Sarkar said, “Before coming to the market, pharmaceutical drugs are tested on animals. It is very unethical and results are sometimes erroneous because despite having similar systems, we are different from them.

“In today’s day and age, when we are so aware of animal rights, using them for testing a drug that will be used by humans, is wrong. So, multiple research works are going on to build a system which can effectively test medicines that can then be used by humans.”

Sarkar turned this into a story about an imaginary world where all the animals are free and happy in the wild. “The copyright of the story belongs to DST,” she said.

Title: Rs18.50cr GST default by vehicle dealer
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Nagpur: The directorate general of GST Intelligence (DGGSTI) has registered yet another case of tax collected from the customers, but not passed on to the government. Following a raid on Mascot Motors, a two-wheeler agency, the taxmen have found a default of Rs18.50 crore towards GST. Dues pending since March 2019 were not cleared.

The tax component was recovered from customers during sale of vehicles but was not deposited to the government exchequer. Mascot Motors has paid up Rs16.70 crore after the raid, with rest of the amount expected to be recovered soon.

This is second such action against auto dealers in the last one year. In September 2019, the DGGSTI had pulled up five luxury car dealers for similar reasons. GST dues to the tune of Rs25.04 crore were recovered after a raid at that time.

Title: Bus accident survivors from Nepal stranded in Salem
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Omalur (Salem): More than a week has lapsed since the tragic incident in which nine pilgrims from Nepal were killed after an omnibus rammed the minibus that they were travelling in near Omalur on Salem-Bengaluru National Highway. While the two drivers and tour agent in the minibus escaped unhurt, life hasn’t been any easy for them since the incident, with them spending the days in the damaged bus. On Thursday, two victims, who were discharged from the government hospital in Salem, have also joined the trio in the bus, which is stationary on Omalur police station premises.

Talking to TOI, 51-year-old tour agent Amarnath Chowdri said they had to be on the police station premises to complete the formalities. “The inquiry is going on. We have to submit documents such as vehicle registration certificate and insurance papers to police.”

While he was in the company of drivers Kaluram Chowdri, 38, and Anil Chowdri, 36, so far, they were joined by 65-year-old Baglu Chowdri and his wife Daithin Cowdri, 62, who were discharged from hospital, on Thursday.

All the five occupants of the bus are left with no other option, but to cook and bathe on the police station premises. The Omalur police have, however, allowed them to use bathrooms in the station.

Deputy superintendent of police M Baskaran said they hadn’t forced the trio to stay in the vehicle itself. “We had arranged a marriage hall for them to stay, but they declined our offer. It seems they are afraid to accept any help from us. Language is also a barrier and it has affected the inquiry too.”

Amarnath Chowdri, meanwhile, expressed hope that they would be able to leave for Nepal with fellow passengers in a couple of weeks. “It will take at least a week for us to reach our native place.”

It was on February 20 that the minibus, with 32 people on board, met with the accident. While four people were killed on the spot, two others died in the hospital the same day. The toll rose to 7 on February 21, when another critically injured died in the Salem government hospital. Another injured, meanwhile, breathed his last in a private hospital in Chennai on February 23 and the ninth victim died in a private hospital in Coimbatore on February 25.

Now, five injured are undergoing treatment in the Salem Government Mohan Kumaramangalam Medical College and Hospital, one in a private hospital in Salem and 12 others in private hospitals in Coimbatore and Chennai. Their condition is said to be stable.

Title: Telangana CM K Chandrasekhar Rao worried over revenue dip, harps on income generation
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

K Chandrasekhar Rao

HYDERABAD: With income from various sources drying up and economic slowdown casting a shadow on revenues, chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao on Friday asked senior officials to focus on income-generating measures.

Towards this end, highly-placed sources said the government is certainly going to jack up the stamps and registration duty, power tariff and municipal tax.

Worried with the fact that implementation of various government schemes and programmes could face rough weather, the chief minister urged the officials to rejig their plans to mop up revenues.

The government would focus on sale of land, particularly at Kokapet where decks have been cleared. Officials are expecting to net Rs 2,500 crore this year from the Kokapet land sale.

“Increase in taxes and fees in various forms will help the state generate more income,” officials said. It was also felt that any increase in municipal taxes may not provide direct relief to the government exchequer. “But, the local bodies stand to gain and execute various schemes locally,” an official said.

The chief minister, who also reviewed the state budget proposals with finance officials, asked them to look out for ways and means to get more funding and support for the state schemes from the Centre.

Loan waiver scheme and Rythu Bandhu are set to get a major chunk of funding in the budget. Sources said the discussion on budget would continue for three more days before allocations are finalised.

According to sources, the budget session will begin either on March 6 or March 9. The budget would be introduced on the second day of the session, officials said.

Title: A Revanth Reddy moves Telangana High Court over ‘threat to life’, seeks central security
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Malkajgiri MP A Revanth Reddy

HYDERABAD: Congress working president and Malkajgiri MP A Revanth Reddy on Friday filed a petition in the Telangana High Court seeking increased security with central forces.

He alleged threat to his life from chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao and businessman and managing director of My Home Construction Pvt. Ltd, Jupally Rameshwar Rao, against whom he had filed PILs.

In his petition, Revanth named Union home secretary, Telangana, state principal secretary (Home) and Rameshwar Rao, who is also said to be close to the TRS, as respondents. “Before the bifurcation of the united state of Andhra Pradesh , there were physical attacks on me and due to the threats, I was provided 3+3 security. The chief minister of Telangana, in the assembly, openly proclaimed that an operation like Operation Blue Star would terminate me. I have been implicated in a false case. My security cover was reduced to 2+2 from 3+3 in 2016,” he told the high court.

Revanth said that he had filed several PILs on controversial issues involving TRS leaders. “I had filed a PIL in 2018 against the allotment of prime lands to Rameshwar Rao in and around Hyderabad. I filed another PIL against the ruling party in allotting the land in the prime locality of Hyderabad near IT Hub to IKEA on nomination basis without calling for tenders, causing loss of nearly Rs 400 crore to the public exchequer. I filed another petition seeking CBI enquiry into garnering of huge funds by the TRS leaders in the name of Bangaru Coolie,” he said.

He added that the ruling party leaders who collected the amount in the name of Bangaru Coolie received notices from the Income Tax Department.

Title: Farmers demand better service roads on Samruddhi Expressway
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Nashik: The farmers in the Samruddhi belt on Friday met with the district collector Suraj Mandhare and demanding better service roads for the residents travelling across the Nagpur-Mumbai Super Communication Expressway.

The farmers led by local member of legislative assembly Manik Kokate met the collector to draw his attention towards hardships faced by them. The farmers hailed from Manegaon, Pandhurli, Shivade, Jaypraskash Nagar, Marhal, Gonde, Sonambe and many other districts.

The farmers said that the current condition of the roads is because of the heavy vehicles transporting construction equipment and goods. “The roads have huge pits. The two wheeler and four wheelers find it difficult to negotiate the road resulting into accidents,” the farmers said.

The officials of Maharashtra State Road Development Corporation (MSRDC), who are behind the construction of the Samruddhi Expressway, assured the farmers that they will look into the matter. “The engineers will survey the roads and look for some engineering solution by compacting soil for people to travel safely,” a senior MSRDC officer said.

The farmers also raised the issues of constant water-pipeline bursts. “The contractors repair the pipelines immediately. Introduction of utility ducts after every 500 meter section will be constructed and the pipelines will be connected as long term solution by the corporation,” the MSRDC officer said.

Another major demand was of the underpasses and services roads, to which the officers said that the underpasses were already planned for the sections and as far as the service roads were concerned they would be constructed as per the demands only, the officer added.

Title: Rain in some places, but cloudy sky for Pune with 34 degree Celsius day temperature
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Only partly cloudy sky conditions have been forecast for Pune during the weekend (File photo)

PUNE: Isolated parts of Madhya Maharashtra, Marathwada and Vidarbha may witness lightning and very light to light rain on Saturday and Sunday. But neither will Pune city nor the district get any rain.

Only partly cloudy sky conditions have been forecast for Pune during the weekend, with day temperatures of around 34 degree Celsius.

India Meteorological Department (IMD) on Friday said due to the convergence of lower level easterlies and westerlies, isolated to scattered rainfall with isolated thunderstorm/hailstorm was likely over Madhya Pradesh, Vidarbha and Chhattisgarh on February 29 and March 1.

Anupam Kashyapi, head of weather, IMD, Pune clarified that these would be related to moisture incursion due to the western disturbances over north India as well as the confluence of easterly and westerly winds. The confluence zone of these winds would be over Vidarbha, Madhya Pradesh and Chhatisgarh mainly.

An IMD forecast on Friday said, lightning could occur at isolated places over Marathwada on Saturday, while a thunderstorm accompanied with lightning, hail and gusty wind (speed reaching 30-40 kmph) could occur at isolated places over east Vidarbha on March 1, among some other parts of the country.

No lightning or thunderstorm occurrences have been forecast over Madhya Maharashtra during the weekend, except very light rains possibility at isolated places in the region.

Kashyapi said by Friday evening, this interaction had already started and began to show its effect by partially increasing the cloud cover over parts of Maharashtra.

“Since the westerlies and easterlies will be the two dominating wind flows, which will have interaction over the state, night temperatures (which had fallen significantly of late) will start to rise from Friday once again. The clouding may cause a slight dip in day temperatures, temporarily. Slowly, by March 1-2, the interaction zone will shift eastwards, but some clouding would continue to occur over parts of Maharashtra thereafter too,” Kashyapi said.

Title: Delhi: Pay professional tax if you earn Rs 50,000 a month
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

SDMC is hoping to earn Rs 50 crore from the move

NEW DELHI: After rejecting the commissioner’s proposal for four years, the standing committee of South Delhi Municipal Corporation ( SDMC ) on Friday decided to impose a professional tax on everybody with a monthly gross income of Rs 50,000 and above under its jurisdiction.

As per the move, those with a gross income of up to Rs 50,000 will have to pay Rs 1,800 annually or Rs 150 per month as the professional tax, and those earning above Rs 50,000 will be charged Rs 2,400 annually or Rs 200 monthly. The tax will be charged even if the person doesn’t live in the SDMC areas but works there. Traders will remain outside the ambit of this tax.

The SDMC commissioner had proposed the tax in the four consecutive budgets, including the current one that was passed last December. But the BJP-dominated deliberative wing rejected it every time. On Friday, the standing committee, however, argued that the move had become necessary after Delhi government drastically reduced the corporation’s grants, increasing its financial burden. SDMC is hoping to earn Rs 50 crore from the move.

Refuting any link to BJP’s loss in the recent assembly elections, standing committee chairman Bhupender Gupta said the proposal was in the pipeline for a long time. “We don’t believe in the concept of freebies and the decision is an attempt towards making the civic agency self-dependent. In case of unauthorised colonies, too, we want to collect property taxes at least from 2019,” he claimed.

“Every service-class person, including professionals such as lawyers and chartered accountants, working out of offices in the SDMC areas will have to pay the tax. They may not be living here but still use our services every day,” said Gupta.

The proposal will now be placed before the corporation’s House and if approved, it will be implemented from April 1, 2020. “We are working on arrangements to collect the tax. It will be either added to the property tax bill or collected annually in bulk from offices after its deduction in bulk from salaries,” said a senior official.

“The tax is already levied in 21 cities, including Mumbai. With no funds from Delhi government, we are left with no choice now. Even our recent file submitted to the government for releasing a Rs 500-crore grant due from the last quarter has been kept aside,” he alleged.

Title: Glanders affect four horses in two months, 2 men under scanner too
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Pune: Surveillance has been stepped in three districts — Aurangabad, Hingoli and Parbhani — in Maharashtra since the beginning of this year after four horses tested positive for glanders, a highly infectious and often fatal zoonotic disease.

“Being a zoonotic disease, the persistence of glanders poses a potential threat to occupationally exposed human beings, especially equine handlers and veterinarians. Therefore, targeted surveillance of human population in affected areas of the district is recommended,” surveillance officer Pradip Awate of the state health department said.

The animal husbandry department (AHD)'s Disease Investigation Section (DIS) has identified 13 cases of the glanders infection in horses in six districts — Aurangabad, Hingoli, Parbhani, Buldhana, Akola and Thane — between April 1, 2019 and February 15, 2020.

"Blood samples of two persons in Hingoli, living in proximity to infected horses, have been sent to the National Research Centre on Equines in Hisar (Haryana) to rule out infection after they complained of minor illness,” Vinayak Viithal Limaye, joint commissioner of AHD and head of the DIS, told TOI.

“This is just a part of our surveillance. There is no need to panic as glanders has not been reported in humans in the recent past," he said.

Surveillance has been intensified around stables and animal sheds in the state’s affected districts to prevent the bacterial infection from affecting human beings.

The symptoms of the glanders disease in human beings include fever with chills and sweating, muscle aches, chest pain and muscle tightness, among others.

Limaye said, “Since April last year, we have detected glanders in indigenous horses used for drawing carts and in marriage ceremonies. Thoroughbreds used in horse-racing events showed no symptoms. The disease gets detected when owners of the ailing horses seek help of veterinarians.”

"Blood samples of around 2,500 to 3,000 animals — mainly horses, mules and donkeys — are drawn and tested for glanders, annually, as part of surveillance in the state," Limaye said.

Title: Scientist Raghunath Mashelkar urges people to have trust in new startups
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Pimpri Chinchwad: Eminent scientist Raghunath Mashelkar on Friday stressed the need for people to have trust in new startups and urged industrialists to give the youth a chance.

“India’s problem is not budget deficit but trust deficit,” he said in his keynote address during the inauguration of the two-day Festival of Future held by the Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation at Autocluster in Chinchwad.

Civic chief Shravan Hardikar said, “We want the youth to come up with ideas about automobile and industrial sectors thriving in Pimpri Chinchwad, Chakan, Indapur and Baramati, bio-technology, urban spaces, manufacturing, education, art and food.” tnn

Title: ‘Disturbance of crime scene hampered investigation’
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Panaji: During the hearing of the suicide case of former Merces sarpanch Prakash Naik, additional public prosecutor Pravin Faldessai told the high court of Bombay at Goa that the scene of offence was disturbed when the investigation was initially taken over by Old Goa police as Naik’s body was moved by the family before the police arrived. The weapon of offence as well as Naik’s mobile allegedly found on his chest were also disturbed, and in the absence of these vital clues, a material part of the probe had been hampered, he said.

Evidence of gun residue was also not available as the body was moved to the GMC, Bambolim, before police arrived and was handled by several persons, he submitted, adding that the state is also probing the murder angle based on the doubt expressed by Naik’s sister in her complaint.

Faldessai said the 0.32 bore revolver containing bullets and an empty case were attached under the panchanama. Naik’s family and witnesses stated that he had disclosed that he had been harassed in the property at Voilem Bhat.

The prosecutor also said the forensic surgeon had certified that Naik had died due to ‘cranio-cerebral damage’ as a result of perforating firearm missile injury.

Title: Nagpur: Fine imposed, threat of FIR forces restoration of trenches
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: The Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) has slapped a fine of Rs2.46 lakh for loss of drinking water drom damaged pipeline, and also warned of filing FIR over non-restoration of trenches made by an MSEDCL contractor for laying power cables. The contractor has already started restoration of trenches , though with inferior quality work.

TOI had, on February 20, reported NMC did not levy fine and initiate any action against a MSEDCL contractor for damaging drinking water pipeline and leaving trenches without restoration in Sonegaon , Sahakar Nagar, Trimurti Nagar, Swavlambi Nagar etc.

Taking serious cognisance of TOI report, municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe , known as a no-nonsense IAS officer, directed chief engineer Ulhas Debadwar to take appropriate action. Debadwar directed NMC Laxmi Nagar Zone officials to take appropriate action and ensure restoration of trenches.

The MSEDCL contractor had damaged drinking water pipeline while laying power cables on newly constructed cement road at Sahakar Nagar on January 22. TOI had reported this and also alerted officials from NMC Laxmi Nagar Zone.

NMC Water Works Department on February 21 issued a letter to MSEDCL, asking it to direct its contractor to deposit fine of Rs2.46 lakh in NMC’s account for loss of drinking water.

On February 25, NMC public works department issued a letter to MSEDCL executive engineer warning of FIR if trenches are not restored. The department also warned of fixing responsibility on MSEDCL in case of any incident due to the trenches.

On Friday, MSEDCL contractor started restoration of trenches at Sahakar Nagar and Sonegaon. In HB Estate, Sonegaon, the contractor has restored trenches in residential area.

The contractor had removed tiles and dug up newly constructed footpath along cement concrete road at Sahakar Nagar for laying cables. The footpath was restored on Friday.

Unfortunately, the contractor replaced the tiles removed from the same spot, and some of them were broken. Also, the surface layer of footpath has become undulating due to shoddy quality work. People, especially senior citizens and children, may get injured due to undulating surface and broken tiles.

NMC had concretized the road and constructed footpath a couple of months ago.

Debadwar has also directed engineers of NMC public works department not to give permission for trenching roads before restoration of earlier trenches. He warned of action against engineers if his orders are not followed.

Title: Cutting wastage, feeding people
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

The team serving food at NIMS hospital in Panjagutta

HYDERABAD: By day, they are either accountants, engineers, trainers or photographers. But come 5 pm, they shun this professional avatar and take on the role of ‘food soldiers’ -- delivering a hot plate of dinner to thousands of people across hospitals, orphanages and old-age homes in Hyderabad.

But this isn’t the only noble deed that the ‘No Food Waste’ team does every day. This band of orange t-shirt-clad men and women also ensure that the city wastes as little food as possible.

“The food we distribute is collected from functions, corporate events. Every time we get a call from the organisers, informing us about excess food, our volunteers go there and collect it,” said K Venkata Murali, who started the Hyderabad chapter of the group, which took roots in Coimbatore, three-and-half years ago. In between serving a plate of rice, dal and vegetable curry to an old man outside NIMS, he said they get at least 25 to 30 calls (for food collection) every day. The quantity is enough to feed at least 2,000 to 3,000 people.

Every item on the menu is personally tasted, for quality, by the volunteers before being served. “We check the food while collecting and also at regular intervals as we travel around the city,” said 54-year-old Murali who runs an IT firm. Though there are enough good Samaritans supporting his team of 250 volunteers, the donations, he added, are never in cash. “Some corporate firms sponsored our vans…we have a network of hotels that donate food regularly. A kind-hearted lady gives us 200 rotis every day. That’s how we function,” he said tracing back to that Karthika Masam of 2016 when the idea struck him. He realised people starved during that period and started by encouraging friends and family to donate that saved rice to the poor.

“This food is so much better than the Rs 5 meal served near the hospital. It is tasty and fulfilling. Also, they feed us with a lot of compassion,” said Zeenat Begum of Jeedimetla, living at the free shelter at NIMS for over a week. Also in the crowded dorm was 70-year-old B Dasari who teared up as he hoped more people did such “good deeds” for the poor. “Of course, the food is very tasty as well,” the Mahabubabad resident said.

Title: Mayor express concerns over faulty traffic junctions
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Edited | Aishani

Nashik: Mayor Satish Kulkarni on Friday said that many traffic junctions in the city are faulty and the works done so far on those junctions are not satisfactory.

Kulkarni appealed to the Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) and Nashik Municipal Smart City Development Corporation Ltd (NMSCDCL) to resolve the issue.

The mayor was addressing a gathering during the inaugural session of the Smart City conclave attended by officials of different smart cities of the country.

He said that the traffic chaos is a major problem in the city and it seems to be increasing every day.

“Though the commissioner of police Vishwas Nangare-Patil has been monitoring the city traffic, the problem is still continuing,” said mayor Kulkarni.

Commissioner of police Vishwas Nangare Patil, district collector Suraj Mandhare, municipal commissioner Radhakrishna Game, ZP CEO Leena Bansod, NMSCDCL CEO Prakash Thavil and officials from other smart cities were present at the inaugural session of the Smart City conclave.

“Smart cities and smart policing is the need of the time. Smart policing is the goal given by the government to the police machinery. We are facing a lot of challenges like security, terrorism, law and order, and other problems. Smart cities should work on how these problems can be worked out,” said Nangare-Patil.

Mandahre said that Nashik district will be completing 150 years and the liveability index of the city is better than other cities across the country. The target for smart cities should be to make the cities more liveable, he said.

Apart from the smart cities, Focus should also be on smart villages, he said. The development as a whole will not take place unless the villages are not developed, he said.

He added that people should be put in the centre of development to in order to achieve our goals.

Municipal commissioner Radhakrishna Game and NMSCDCL Prakash Thavil informed about the ongoing smart city projects in the city.

The discussion was held on smart and sustainable cities, the future of smart cities, intelligence solutions for non-revenue water, connected and integrated eco-system for smart cities related to infrastructure, transportation and mobility.

Title: Thorat says Cong to meet CM on NPR
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Pune: Maharashtra Congress president and revenue minister Balasaheb Thorat on Friday said his party would have another joint meeting with chief minister Uddhav Thackeray and alliance partners NCP and Shiv Sena next week against the implementation of CAA and NPR in the state.

After Thackeray declared implementation of the Census and National Population Register (NPR) processes in the state, Thorat had tweeted and shared a video on the social media opposing its implementation in the state and that an all-party meet would be held to take a call on the issue.

“We had one meeting on the issue with our alliance partners. But no decision was taken. We will have another meeting, during which we will raise our concerns about the NPR that will be the base for the National Register of Citizens (NRC),” Thorat told TOI.

“The Congress party is opposed to anything that causes discrimination in society. There seems to be some hidden agenda of the Centre to forcefully go ahead with Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and NPR in the wake of rampant violence in many parts of the country,” he said.

A senior Congress leader said a resolution should be passed in the ongoing assembly session, like what happened in Bihar, where the BJP is in power with the JD(U), on the issue. The Bihar Assembly unanimously passed a resolution favouring caste-based census in 2021 on Thursday, two days after expressing a united resolve that the NPR exercise be done strictly according to its 2010 format.

Thorat said the CAA in its present form was “divisive”, unlike its 2003 format. He said, “Why should ancestral details be sought for the CAA exercise?”

Title: Phase 2 of IIT-JICA collaboration to focus on PhD student exchange, joint post-grad
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Hyderabad: The Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) has proposed increased association with Japanese industries and academia as well as research laboratories as part of its collaboration with the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA).

While various projects were undertaken under Phase 1, which will conclude in March this year, Phase 2 will will place greater emphasis on exchange of PhD students as well as joint post-graduation and PhD programmes.

The collaboration began in August 2007 and JICA initiated a project for ‘future researchers at IIT-H to enhance network development with scholarship from Japan’ (FRIENDSHIP) in July 2010.

Speaking about the collaborations, IIT-H director Prof BS Murty said, “With the current FRIENDSHIP project ending soon, we are enthusiastically looking forward to Phase 2 of the project so that we can continue with our collaboration and take it to greater heights for the benefit of both Japan and India.”

The institute received significant assistance for research in five areas — next generation communication technologies, design and manufacturing, sustainable development, environment and energy and nano technology and nano science.

The JICA also supported the construction of buildings and procurement of equipment necessary for high-end research.

Title: Detailed land acquisition plan for Purandar airport within a week
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Pune: The land acquisition officers are expected to submit a detailed plan to the district collector next week, charting out the area required from seven villages in Purandar for the proposed international airport.

A source in the district administration said the work was on to chart out the detailed plan on the land required from each village with survey numbers. “The detailed plan, as per discussions and the land required, would be submitted to Pune collector. He will take forward the land acquisition process in the coming month after holding talks with the villagers,” an official said.

The land for the proposed airport would be acquired from Pargaon, Kumbharvalan, Ekhatpur, Munjwadi, Khanvadi, Vanpuri and Udachiwadi.

On Thursday, Pune collector Naval Kishore Ram had told TOI that the land acquisition process for the new airport would start from the next month after the Maharashtra Airport Development Company (MADC) — the Special Planning Authority of the project — shared the detailed land acquisition plan. The direct purchase method has been put forth as a quicker system for the land acquisition. The collector also said the process should be completed within six months.

The district administration officials claimed that they would be checking the sales and transactions in the area for the past three years to understand the realty sector there and the ready reckoner rate.

“While deciding the compensation amount for each hectare of land, the ready reckoner would be considered as the base rate. The sales and transactions in the area as well as people’s demands would also be taken into count before finalising the rates,” said another official.

The landowners, who had earlier staged protest against the land acquisition for the greenfield airport project, are still firm on not parting with their land. Pargaon sarpanch Bapu Memane said they had been opposing the project for the past three years.

“The sudden announcement of starting the acquisition from the next month is alarming. We shall not allow any land acquisition and take extreme measures if the government does not heed to our request,” he said.

The landowners have decided to hold a joint meeting of all the seven villages in the coming days to draw up the action plan to protest against the acquisition.

Many plot owners in the villages feel that they might be neglected because government is only discussing land being acquired from farmers. While the government has iterated that no land occupying houses would be acquired, adjacent plot to the land acquired may face an issue, stressed the plot owners. “Do the plot owners of such land stand to get any benefits and can they be likely partners for the airport project,” asked many people. Jobs and other issues too are being raised.

Title: ITI student held on charges of raping 14-year-old in Hyderabad
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A 14-year-old girl was allegedly raped by an ITI student at Chandrayangutta on Friday. “The accused is her neighbour.

On Friday, he took the girl to his house when family members were not there and allegedly raped her. We are trying to confirm the age of the accused, as he could be a juvenile. A case was registered under Section 376 of IPC and Pocso Act,” said Falaknuma ACP Md Majeed.

Title: District administration handles 7.8 lakh RTS applications
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Edited | Aishani

Nashik: The district administration has handled 7.80 lakh Right to Service (RTS) applications since April 1 2019, said Suraj Mandhare, the collector of Nashik.

The administration claims to have resolved 7.20 lakh applications filed in person or through online. Though most of them were online.

“The inflow of the applications through the RTS has been tremendous and every application has been followed closely to ensure that the applicants do not have to worry about the delay or unnecessary visits to the collectorate,” the district collector said.

There were 56,297 applications which were delayed till February 25, the collector said. The delays amounted to less than 8% of the applications

He added that the administration was keen on analysing the causes for the delay.

“Since there have been delays overtly, the RTS has come into the picture. There should be no delays at all, hence we are keen to find out the reasons,” collector said.

The collector pointed out that after the delays, the system would be strengthened and there will be an increase in efficiency.

“Our target is to improve the system and hence after analysing the things, it will be put in to place. Those performing best would be felicitated by the administration in order to encourage others. Those lagging behind shall get an opportunity to improve and they will also be given tools to improve their performance,” the collector added.

The income certificates are the most sought from the revenue department. As many as 4.05 lakh applications were received by the administration.

Similarly, there were 1.44 lakh applications related to age, nationality and domicile certificates.

The third service to top the chart was caste certificates in which 1.37 lakh applications were received.

The revenue department of Nashik district with its office ranging from a talathi of a village, to a circle officer – who overlooks a set of villages, to the office of tahsildar (executive magistrate), the sub-divisional officer, and the district collectorate, have collectively received the 7.80 lakh applications from the citizens in the district.

Title: SDMC may increase electricity tax to generate revenue
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Picture used for representational purpose only

NEW DELHI: Electricity may become costlier for people living in south Delhi from the next financial year. South Delhi Municipal Corporation (SDMC) on Friday passed a proposal to increase the electricity tax , which is added to the final bill.

Standing committee chairman Bhupender Gupta said the proposal to increase the electricity tax from 5% to 6% will soon be forwarded to the House for approval. “We have decided to increase it by 1% to get more funds for development work. SDMC is burdened due to reduced financial assistance from Delhi government,” Gupta added.

As per Delhi Municipal Corporation Act, electricity firms or power discoms have to collect the electricity tax on behalf of the municipality, while other agencies or individuals consuming electricity are supposed to pay this tax directly to the corporation.

An SDMC official said that the proposal specifies the maximum increase, properties to be taxed, exemptions and system of assessment to be adopted.

“The ultimate burden of this tax will be transferred to residents or Delhi government (in case of subsidised bills),” said a senior south corporation official.

Once the proposal is approved in the House meeting, SDMC will forward it to the state government for final approval. “After its approval, we will give direction to the power discoms to increase the tax rates,” said an official.

With the increased electricity tax, SDMC is expecting to generate Rs 30 crore extra annually.

Title: Pay Rs 99 lakh fine: Chandigarh municipal corporation notice to former paid parking firm
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

The company had managed the parking lots from June 2017 to Feb 2019

CHANDIGARH: The municipal corporation (MC) has issued a notice to a private company managing the paid parking lots from June 2017 to February 2019 to pay a penalty of Rs 99.78 lakh for violating the terms and condition of the agreement in operating 25 paid parking lots and the underground multi-level parking lot in Sector 17.

The notice mentioned that the penalty amount is subject to the outcome of the case that Arya Toll Infra Limited has filed against the civic body in the Punjab and Haryana high court.

The civic body has written to the company numerous times on different issues like bounced cheques or non-payment. The MC offices had also called the representatives of the company in the past for a meeting but the financial issue was not resolved.

The penalty notice said, “It is intimated to you that you have not deposited the amount of penalties imposed from time to time on breach of terms and condition of the agreement till date. The amount of notices issued to you (without interest) comes to Rs 88.06 lakh. Further, an amount of Rs 11.72 lakh (without interest) is also liable to be deposited by you on account of inspection,” the notice said.

“You are required to deposit the outstanding amount of Rs 99.78 lakh (without interest) and interest will be charged up to realization of amount as per the terms and condition of agreement subject to the final outcome of the civil writ petition in the Punjab and Haryana high court...” the notice said.

The implementation of smart features in the smart parking had caused friction between the MC and Arya Toll Infra Limited. The general house of the MC had constituted a committee led by the then municipal councillor Rajbala Malik to inspect the parking lots. The committee in its report had pointed out that there were no smart features in the parking lots as committed in the tender document. On the other hand, representatives of Arya Toll Infra Limited had accused the MC of noncooperation, claiming the civic body had failed to stop illegal parking leading to revenue loss.

Title: Chandigarh: Sanjay Tandon aides skip rose festival, MP Kirron Kher livid
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

MP Kirron Kher with mayor Rajbala Malik

CHANDIGARH: Only four out of 20 BJP councillors showed up for the inaugural ceremony of the Rose Festival in Sector 16 on Friday, leaving chief guest MP Kirron Kher furious .

“Where is Arun? Why he has not come here,” Kher asked, referring to the absence of BJP city president Arun Sood, who is close to former party chief Sanjay Tandon . Kher had played a key role in elevating Sood to the new post and was expecting him, sources said. Former mayors and BJP councillors Rajesh Kumar and Davesh Moudgil, deputy mayor Jagtar Singh Jagga and councillor Mahesh Inder Sidhu along with lone SAD councillor Hardeep Singh and a few nominated councilors gave Kher company at the Rose Garden.

Senior deputy mayor Ravi Kant Sharma, former mayor Asha Jaswal, councillors Heera Negi, Sunita Dhawan, Shakti Prakash Devshali, Gurpreet Dhillon, Vinod Aggarwal and others close to Tandon were missing. However, Sharma, Devshali and Negi along with three more councillors landed up at the venue after Kher left.

“We had invited all councillors and cards were sent to them on Friday. We don’t know why they did not attend the ceremony?” said an official of the MC.

Sources in the BJP said it was for the first time that such a huge number of BJP councillors remained absent from the annual Rose Festival.

Title: Two held in drug raid at Ashvem, five foreign nationals detained
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: Police on Thursday searched a cafe and hostel at Ashvem and arrested two persons for running a drug den. Five foreigners who had been staying there without filling up police verification forms were detained.

After the raid, which resulted in the seizure of ganja and charas from the premises, North Goa SP Utkrisht Prasoon said the state’s police force had zero tolerance for drug trafficking.

Anti-narcotic cell SP Shobit Saxena said the raid was conducted soon after police received information that one person had been operating a cafe and hostel that allowed foreigners to stay without police verification.

“When police personnel reached the spot, they noticed that the owner of the cafe and hostel had laid a table where foreigners sat and consumed drugs ,” Saxena said, adding that the two persons arrested in the case were both non-Goan.

“The owner was found to be keeping foreigners without submitting the requisite ‘C Form’. The deputy collector has been requested to lock down and seal the said premises,” Saxena further said.

Title: Big cat in Adilabad: Teams of forest guards on tiger trail
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

A picture of the tiger captured by a motorist in Jainath mandal

HYDER ABAD: Authorities of the forest department on Friday began efforts to monitor the movement of a tiger and ensure that there is no man-animal conflict after the sighting of the animal created a flutter in certain villages of Jainath mandal in Adilabad earlier this week.

Adilabad forest divisional officer V Chandrasekhar Rao told TOI that they have deployed 30 forest guards and divided them into teams in the border areas of the village. “We have deployed our personnel and are conducting awareness drives in the villages. We have warned people against venturing out alone early in the morning or late evenings because that is usually the time when most wild animals are active. Since the tiger has attacked a cow, we are ensuring that cattle grazers don’t venture into the fields,” said Rao.

Forest officials further said that there was nothing to worry about as the forest officials are taking all necessary measures to keep the villagers and the tiger safe. “There is no need to panic because the tiger was just passing by the village towards Sathnala reserve forest. Sathnala project itself is a huge forest area spread across nearly one lakh acres which is directly connected to Kawal Tiger Reserve. So, the tiger may have already crossed the villages and moved into Kawal,” said Rao.

Experts said that the growing tiger population in Tipeshwar in Maharashtra, a tiger reserve just across the Telangana border along NH-7, about 20 km north of Adilabad, is leading to an increase in big cats from neighbouring states crossing over into Telangana. “Tigers migrating to Telangana is a good sign. Villagers in these areas need not panic. Tigers are not going to stay in these forest patches for long or make it their home,” said Mirza Kareem Baig, a member of the Forest and Wildlife Protection Society (FAWPS).

Baig said that the forest patches in Adilabad are just a passage for tigers moving from Tipeshwar to Kawal Tiger Reserve. “There are more than 20 tigers in Tipeshwar, which is very high, according to the area of the reserve which is spread across 140 sq km. This could be a reason why the tigers are entering Telangana,” said Baig, adding that the only thing the state needs to do is make the high tiger movement routes safe for these animals.

Title: Head to Undri today to make most of the fun activities for one and all
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Pune: Happy Streets will bring a one-of-its-kind carnival packed with fun and frolic for season’s last in the area on Saturday evening at Corinthians Resort & Club in Undri.

Exercise, games and activities will keep participants occupied throughout the evening. Children will get an opportunity to play an assortment of games and engage in art, craft and science activities. Participants can also enjoy “Acrylic On Canvas” workshop, curated specially for the event.

Learning Curve will offer obstacle walk, play dough, toss the ring, hula hoops, while aspiring masterchefs’ can show-off their skills by creating pizzas and cookies at a section organized by Serra Preschool. Cross Strength will provide an energetic workout, while Decathlon will give the participants a taste of the outdoor sports.

“Happy Streets is the platform to break misconceptions about Zumba as a form of exercise and give a glimpse into what the workout session actually means,” an instructor from Core Zumba, Neha Shukla, said.

“I have been attending the Zumba sessions of Happy Streets for while now and as the name suggests, it is all about spreading happiness. With over four years of experience in Zumba and nine years of experience in dance, I have never seen crowd enjoying Zumba as much as at Happy Streets,” instructor Pranali Doshi said.

“If the 60 minutes session can bring a smile on the faces of people, I have accomplished my goal. I am glad to be associated with Happy Streets,” Shivani Jain, another instructor, said.

Happy Streets is an initiative of The Times of India, in association with Pune police and Pune Municipal Corporation, powered by Nyati Group.

Title: Congress alleges revenge politics behind Delhi riots
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Picture used for representational purpose only

HYDERABAD: The Congress , referring to Delhi riots , on Friday charged the BJP of taking revenge against the people of Delhi for defeating it in the recently concluded assembly elections.

Telangana Congress spokespersons G Niranjan and Addanki Dayakar among others demanded a probe into the alleged role of the BJP’s ‘private army’ in Delhi violence .

They reiterated the demand made by Congress interim president Sonia Gandhi that Union home minister Amit Shah should resign for failing to keep law and order under control in Delhi. The police in Delhi is under the control of the central government and not the Delhi government. “Cases should be booked against the BJP and MIM leaders for their provocative statements,” Dayakar said.

Dayakar said the BJP has brought the situation to such a state that some of the saffron party leaders are openly praising Nathuram Godse, who killed Mahatma Gandhi.

Title: NMC appoints IT firm to operate ITMS for city bus service
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Nashik: The standing committee of the Nashik Municipal Corporation ( NMC ) on Friday gave its nod to appoint Ahmedabad-based private IT firm for operating the Intelligent Transport Management System (ITMS) for city bus service .

The Amnex Infotechnologies Pvt Ltd will operate the city bus service for five years at a total cost of Rs 22 crore.

Four IT firms had filed bids for operating the city bus service after the municipal corporation had issued a tender for the purpose. After much consideration, the civic administration finalised the Ahmedabad-based IT firm and tabled the proposal in the standing committee meeting.

The ITMS will help the municipal corporation locate its buses through the GPS system and will help to keep a tab on the revenue collected through bus fare as ticket machines will be mapped online.

Moreover, the system will also help to know the exact location of the buses and the routes they take. This new system will also help the NMC to know if the buses are delayed or running behind schedule.

In addition, the buses will be equipped with an LED display and public announcement system through which the passengers in the buses as well as those waiting for the buses at the terminals and bus stops will be able to get information about the vehicle, its routes, etc.

The NMC plans to operate 400 buses through private agencies. Of these 400 buses, 200 will be CNG, 150 electric and 50 will run on diesel.

The municipal corporation has already finalised three agencies to operate these buses in the city. The civic administration has also given a letter of intent to the selected agencies; however, the further process was stopped due to the model code of conduct enforced due to the state assembly elections last year.

Civic officials said that the municipal corporation will soon start the process of deploying the selected agencies for operating buses in the city.

Title: Interview for Haj officers on March 4
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Hyderabad: The Telangana State Haj Committee (TSHC) on Friday said that Haj pilgrims will be provided all possible facilities during the pilgrimage this year. A meeting in this regard was held at the Haj House in Nampally on Friday.

“The last date to pay the second advance of Rs 1.2 lakh is March 15. The interview for Khadimul Hujjaj (Haj officers) will be held on March 4 and selection will be on the next day at 3pm,” said TSHC chairman Mohammed Masiullah Khan.

Title: Delhi riots: Colony with 60 houses opens doors to strangers
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

People from Chand Bagh and Khajuri Khas have taken refuge in the neighbourhood colony of Chandu Nagar

NEW DELHI: Over the last few days, Chandu Nagar , a small neighbourhood in northeast Delhi has become a “temporary” refugee colony. Each one of the 60 houses here has virtually been converted into a bunker, well-stocked with essentials and medicines.

The colony’s entry point has been barricaded with bamboo sticks and young men keep a watchful eye on outsiders. But despite the restrictions on entry, residents of the area are a welcoming lot, having opened their hearts and homes to over 800 strangers from Chand Bagh and Khajuri Khas. These newcomers to the colony are victims of riots that have left behind a trail of destruction in the past few days.

When TOI visited the neighbourhood, Mohammad Ishaq and his wife, Nasreena, had been living there for the last three days. As mobs ran amok, the couple suspected that they would be the next target. They just had a few seconds to decide the next course of action. They used that time to convince their eldest daughter and son to flee to their paternal aunt’s house. They could not escape with their children because of their youngest son, two-year-old Liyan, and the elderly in the family.

“We took our children to the terrace and they climbed on to other people’s rooftops to escape the area,” Nasreen said. The 35-year-old has not had a chance to meet her children since then. “We have spoken to them on phone. But we have not seen them for the last five days because nobody can leave their homes. We feel extremely unsafe,” said Nasreen.

According to the couple, they only managed to escape later in the day when several men from the neighbouring Chandu Nagar came to their colony aided by policemen. “When we heard about the attack, we made several calls to the police. When the cops finally arrived, we accompanied them to aid the rescue operation,” said Ikramul Haque. Haque, a government official with Food Corporation of India, also opened his house to several families, one of them Nasreen’s.

As TOI spoke to Nasreen, her youngest stayed in her lap, clutching her dupatta, even while deep in sleep. Liyaz’s forehead bore a deep cut and a purple bruise, a testimony to the violence that the couple escaped. “As we were escaping, the mob started pelting stones in our direction. When the stone hit him and he started bleeding, I thought I would lose him,” said Nasreen.

The two rooms in Haque’s house are now a safe haven for 21 people. He is not charging any rent. But Haque is not the only one doing this. Several others have opened their houses to complete strangers. Zakir Hussain, 35, a cloth manufacturer has four rooms in his small home. While his family occupies two rooms, he has sublet the other to a family whose house was gutted in the fire. The third room is filled with milk packets, which are crowdsourced through volunteers, NGOs and Khalsa Aid.

A corner in the road has become an open kitchen, with everyone pitching in foodgrain and vegetables.

Even though their houses lie just a kilometre away, most victims have not mustered the courage to go and see the fate of their residences. A group of men went on a march together to assess the damage but could not retrieve anything from the charred remains. Mohammad Salim, a parking contractor, was one of them. He had escaped with just the clothes on his back. The 22-year-old said he was unsure of going back home “as the friends who I played cricket with, came and attacked my home”. “One of them put petrol on my father. It is just luck and the help from the police that he survived,” he said.

But amid the despair, the young are determined to reclaim their lives. Fifteen-year-old Laiba is one of them. The teenager, who is to appear for her Class X boards, has got a duplicate admit card and is determined to take her examination. “It’s my father’s wish that I become an IAS officer. I will work towards that. The country needs honest people in the administration,” she said.

Title: Hyderabad: School forcing my class 2 kid to take TC, says dad
Content:
Representative image

TimesView The Council for the Indian School Certificate Examinations should immediately probe how The Right to Education Act was flouted by the school. The law says no student can be detained up to class VIII. Also, it should be seen whether a councillor was appointed to check the IQ level of the child and if the school, in coordination with parents, worked out a performance improvement plan

HYDERABAD: After allegedly forcing a class 2 student to repeat the same academic year for two consecutive years, St Joseph’s Public School , Malakpet , is now allegedly forcing the child’s parent to take transfer certificate (TC). Father of the boy said that the school management assured to promote his son provided they took a TC and made him join class 3 in another school.“My son was studying in the same school since kindergarten. Why is the school blaming the child and us for his performance. Does the school not have any responsibility,” asked P Janardhan Rao, the boy’s father.He added, “When I questioned the management, they said that he was not performing well. What is the point of paying lakhs of rupees if they can’t even teach a class 2 student,” asked Rao.The school management said that they wanted to issue a TC during the last academic year, but gave the boy another chance as his parents pleaded with them. “This is an ICSE school and the boy is not able to keep up. We asked the parents to shift him to another school last year, but they did not do so. We are issuing TC keeping the child’s future in mind,” said the in-charge of the primary division of the school, who did not want to be named as she was not authorised to talk to the media. She added that she was not aware of any rule prohibiting schools from issuing TCs or detaining primary school students in the same class. The district education officer of Hyderabad said that they did not receive any complaint from the parent on the issue.

Title: Chandigarh: Hospitals to have organ donations’ registry
Content:
Representative image

CHANDIGARH: All hospitals will have a registry of organ donations , allowing states and others to know the waiting list and which organ donor is available at the nearest place.National Organ and Tissue Transplant Organisation (Notto) head Dr Vasanthi Ramesh made this announcement while visiting PGI during the organ transplant games.The Punjab and Haryana high court had directed to have a national registry of voluntary organ donors last year, prompting Notto to begin work.“We are signatory to the world health assembly. The mandate of this assembly is to have a national-level organisation to oversee work of organ donation and transplantation. To achieve this, it is important to establish a national registry, which was structurally done in 2015. We are striving to make it functional,” said Dr Ramesh.To be a part of the registry, the Notto’s website has been created in a manner which has national, state and regional-level components. “Every treating hospital registered with the state authority should also register on the Notto’s website and upload the data. This includes doctors performing surgeries and patients’ waiting list,” said Dr Ramesh.Besides, the government is planning to convert all trauma centres into organ retrieval centres. Also, to facilitate deceased organ donation programme, Notto has started reworking on the organ airlifting project mooted in 2017. “The Indian Society for Heart and Lung Transplant had approached the health ministry more than two years ago. Recently, the health ministry has again shown interest for the airlifting of the deceased organs,” said Dr Ramesh.Clarifying that the Notto is coordinating at all levels and not taking over the functions of the state or regional level organisations, Dr Ramesh said, “We are asking hospitals and other state and regional level organ transplant organisations to upload their database of donors and recipients to make things easier for the transplant coordinators. This is in no way a takeover of the functions of these organisations.”Data on Notto siteThe Punjab and Haryana high court had directed to have a national registry of voluntary organ donors last yearEvery treating hospital registered with the state authority will have to register on Notto’s website and upload dataInformation on doctors performing surgeries and patients’ waiting list will have to be uploadedThe government is planning to convert all trauma centres into organ retrieval centres

Title: Nine trains from Secunderabad to be affected due to MMTS work
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

SECUNDERABAD: Services of 19 trains will be affected due to MMTS Phase-2 works scheduled in March, South Central Railway (SCR) said in a statement. The project includes quadrupling of tracks between Moula Ali and Ghatkesar railway stations.According to the SCR statement, nine trains from Secunderabad will be either cancelled or partially cancelled. “Six MEMU trains from Hyderabad and Falaknuma railway stations and three passenger trains from Secunderabad railway station that were scheduled on March 11 have been cancelled,” the statement reads.“Trains running between Ballarshah and Secunderabad as well as Guntur and Secunderabad will be partially cancelled between Kazipet and Secunderabad stations on the same date,” it added.Meanwhile, train no. 12704 from Secunderabad to Howrah which was scheduled to leave at 3.55 pm on March 11 will now leave at 4.40 pm on the same day. Similarly, train no. 08502 from Secunderabad to Visakhapatnam which was scheduled to leave at 4.30 pm on the same will now leave at 5 pm.

Title: BJP moves HC over stay in appointment of standing panel members
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Nashik: The group leader of BJP in the civic body, Jagdish Patil, has moved Bombay high court challenging state urban development department’s stay over appointment of eight new members of the standing committee and town secretary’s decision to stay elections for the post of the standing panel chairman.

Sena group leader Vilas Shinde had complained to urban development department accusing mayor Satish Kulkarni of appointing more BJP members in the panel although its strength in the civic body had reduced after the state assembly polls.

When contacted, lawyer of the petitioner Jay Bhatiya said the high court has admitted the petition and the hearing is to be held on Monday.

On Monday, Kulkarni had declared the names of eight new members of the standing committee — four from BJP, two from Shiv Sena and one each from Congress and NCP — after the term of eight former standing committee members came to an end.

In the 16-member standing committee, the BJP had nine seats, while Sena had four and Congress, NCP and MNS had one member each. The quota of standing committee members to the political parties is decided on the basis of their strength of corporators.

During the 2017 civic elections, the BJP had won 66 seats and Shiv Sena got 34. Accordingly, the comparative strength of both BJP and Shiv Sena was 8.65 and 4.45, respectively. Hence, BJP had got a quota of nine members, while Sena had got a quota of four members.

The total number of BJP corporators later reduced from 66 to 64 and Sena’s number increased to 35. Owing to this the comparative strength of BJP reduced from previous 8.65 to 8.39, while Sena’s increased from 4.45 to 4.59.

After the drop in comparative strength of the BJP in the civic body, Sena had demanded the mayor to reduce the BJP’s quota to eight members and increase Sena’s quota from four to five members. The proposal, however, was rejected by the mayor.

Following this, Shinde lodged a complaint with the urban development department. Accordingly, the urban development department stayed the appointments of the new members.

After this, the town secretary of the NMC also stayed the elections for the post of standing committee chairman that was to be held on March 3.

Title: Bhujbal to ensure appointment of dy director of education
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Nashik: During a meeting with the youth wing of National Congress Party (NCP) in Mumbai on February 26, guardian minister Chhagan Bhujbal said he would ensure that a full-time deputy director of education for Nashik division is appointed within a few days.

The Nationalist Youth Congress (NYC) delegation also submitted a memorandum of their demands to Bhujbal. The NYC is the youth wing of the NCP.

The NYC members drew Bhujbal’s attention to the problems faced by schools, junior colleges as well as teachers.

“The present incumbent is a zilla parishad (ZP) secondary education officer and has been given additional charge as deputy director of education for over a year,” said Chinmay Gadhe, city president of NYC.

The NCP leaders said that, at times, the students and school authorities return empty handed as the deputy director is unavailable.

“It gets difficult for the students from the division to meet the deputy director as he has to visit both the offices which are located far from each other. The divisional office is at Nashik Road while the ZP office is in the city,” added Gadhe.

Bhujbal has assured the NCP leaders that he will look into the matter and will appoint a person on the post soon.

“We have been assured by the guardian minister that he will appoint an individual in the capacity of the deputy director of education within eight days,” he said.

The deputy director, also known as the regional director, is a governing authority for schools and junior colleges of Dhule, Nandurbar, Nashik and Jalgaon regions.

If a junior college wihes to open an additional branch, sanction new policies, send a team for inspection of schools, junior colleges or implement a government’s scheme, the deputy director has to take the charge for it.

Nitin Bachhav, who is currently handling the charge of deputy director of education, told TOI “It has been difficult handling two departments. I had also asked the guardian minister to relieve me from the position a couple of months back. It would be a great relief if he finds a replacement soon.”

Title: Joblessness grave: Uttam
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Hyderabad: Telangana Congress president N Uttam Kumar Reddy blamed the Centre and the state for the rising unemployment

Referring to a parliamentary committee meeting which he attended recently, Uttam said the gravity of the situation could be understood from the fact that more than 2.8 crore people had applied for 90,000 jobs in railways.

Reports of unemployed youth committing suicide were unfortunate, he said, and urged the government to fill over two lakh vacancies in government sector. Uttam also demanded that CM K Chandrasekhar Rao immediately fulfil the electoral promise of providing Rs 3,016 monthly allowance to unemployed youth. He was speaking after inaugurating a National Skills Development centre in Huzurnagar on Friday. tnn

Title: Riots in Delhi: Delhi riots: BSF jawan’s house among those torched
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Mohammad Anees’ father was at their Khajuri Khas residence with a relative when the mob struck

NEW DELHI: Among the scores whose houses were targeted by mobs over the last few days is BSF jawan Mohammad Anees. Currently stationed in Odisha, Anees told TOI over the phone that it was his father, Mohammad Munees, who was at their home in Khajuri Khas Gali No. 5 with a relative when all hell broke loose.

Chand alias Guddu, the younger of the two brothers, was also out station with the rest of the family. When TOI caught up with him on Friday, Chand said: “Even as tension escalated, my father refused to leave the locality in the belief that police will protect them.” On February 25, as a mob tried to force its way into the house, Munees tried to reason with them, but to no avail.

As things appeared to be getting out of hand, some relatives whisked Munees and his relative away to their place in the nearby Chandu Nagar.
