NEW DELHI: Activist lawyer Prashant Bhushan on Friday claimed Delhi Police officials were complicit with the rioters in northeast Delhi and asked whether they could carry out a fair investigation into the riots which has so far claimed 42 lives and injured hundreds.

Bhushan was requesting a Supreme Court bench headed by CJI S A Bobde for early hearing on a contempt petition filed by former DGP Prakash Singh for non-implementation of the SC’s 2006 judgment directing extensive reforms in police establishments to reduce the political executive’s role in its functioning.

Bhushan said to avoid situations like Delhi riots, the 14-year-old judgment in the PIL filed by Prakash Singh had directed separation of law and order control wing from investigation wing of police. “Law and order is essentially an executive function, whereas investigation into crime is part of the criminal justice system and hence needs to be independent of the wing tasked to control law and order,” he said.

The SC had in September 2006 directed fixed tenure for top cops, separation of law and order wing from investigation wing of police and setting up of police establishment boards and grievance redressal authorities in each state. “Though so many years have passed, none of the states have implemented the directions which are crucial to functioning of police as a professional force,” Bhushan said.

The bench said it would list the matter immediately after it completes hearing in the faith versus fundamental rights case arising from reconsideration of the SC judgment quashing the religious custom banning entry of women in the 10-50 year age group into Sabarimala Ayyappa temple.

Title: Maaz Ahmad Siddiqui murder: Life term to ex-cop, 6 others
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

LUCKNOW: Seven persons, including a former police inspector, were on Friday sentenced to life imprisonment in the murder of 14-year-old boy, Maaz Ahmad Siddiqui , who was shot dead by three men at his home in Fareedinagar area of Lucknow on May 29, 2013. Pronouncing the sentence, additional sessions judge Swapna Singh also imposed a fine of Rs 25,000 on the then inspector at Ghazipur police station Sanjai Rai, Ram Babu alias Chhotu, Ajit Rai alias Sintu, Sandeep Rai and Rakesh Kumar Soni, and Rs 30,000 on Sunil Kumar Saini alias Pahalwan and Rahul Rai.

The court had found inspector Sanjai Rai, Ram Babu alias Chhotu, Ajit Rai alias Sintu, Sandeep Rai and Rakesh Kumar Soni guilty of hatching conspiracy for murder under Section 302 (murder) read with Section 120B (criminal conspiracy) of IPC. One accused, Ajit Kumar Yadav alias Banti, is absconding.

Title: Pune: 16-year-old student bags Australian scholarship
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Leena Thawani

PUNE: Leena Thawani has bagged the Monash University International Merit Scholarship of Australian $40,000, applicable for four years.

Leena, a 16-year-old diploma programme student at Victorious Kidss Educares (VKE), was offered the scholarship by Monash University in recognition of her outstanding academic achievements. She is to take up the bachelor of computer science course at the varsity. Additionally, she received an international study grant amounting to AUD 8,000.

Leena said, “The learning environment at VKE and the encouragement offered through its multiple facilities helped me reach this stage. I am happy that this scholarship shall place me in a university renowned for producing impactful research and also highly skilled graduates.”

Rated by business leaders as the best university in Australia to recruit graduates, Leena would now have the opportunity to utilize her potential and make a difference through her exceptional talent, skills and leadership qualities.

VKS president Robbin Ghosh said Leena had always been a focused and diligent student. “It was through dedication and hard work that she was able to acquire the desired prerequisites for bagging such a prestigious scholarship. In addition to her own effort and merit, she was guided by the VKE counselling team,” he said.

Students at VKE are encouraged to carve a niche and establish themselves as role model entrepreneurs through early career guidance opportunities provided by the school’s counselling department to enhance their future opportunities.

Title: Crohn’s disease cases rise, diagnosis still a challenge
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Hyderabad: One of the rare diseases which is on a definitive rise in the city and many other parts of south India country is the Crohn's disease-a type of Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD).

While Telangana alone has 1,231 identified patients of the disease (as per figures from the Indian Organization of Rare Diseases), the actual numbers are estimated to be much higher. The ambiguity is numbers has been attributed to the fact that identifying the disease is an issue due to lack of awareness about this rare disease.

The numbers have been on a constant rise over the last decade and experts in the city point at an increase in incidence among professionals. “The increase in westernisation and globalization could be a reason for rise in IBD (including ulcerative colitis and Crohn’s disease). In developing countries usually, incidence of ulcerative colitis is higher. But in India we are seeing a rising incidence of Crohn’s disease . In fact, the incidence among Indians migrating to other countries is also very high, possibility due westernisation and environmental changes,” said Dr Rupa Banerjee, head Emerging Nations consortium on IBD.

While living with the disease is a challenge, the first hurdle to cross is getting the right diagnosis. Nidhi Swarup, a patient who is consolidating a patient support group in the city said that she had to visit 20-25 experts before her disease could be diagnosed.

The symptoms of Crohn's disease include abdominal pain, nausea, diarrhoea, bleeding from rectum, weight loss, anaemia and fatigue. While some people may be symptom free most of their lives, other have severe chronic symptoms that never go away.

“Crohn’s disease incidence is rising in India, where the burden is second only to USA. Researchers believe the numbers are actually much higher as cases are often misdiagnosed. Indeed, Crohn’s disease is complicated to diagnose generally, and especially in a country where infectious diseases are still prevalent, and many have symptoms similar to Crohn’s. Misdiagnosis or delayed diagnosis often leads to further health complications, which can include the need for surgery,” as per an official statement from the Helmsley Charitable Trust, which has partnered with the research and training wing of city based, Asian Institute of Gastroenterology (AIG).

Title: Delhi: Good Samaritans offer food, hope to riot-affected
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

A group of youths brought food for at least 100 people, including the cops on duty

Title: Police seize 10kg ganja from uninhabited house
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: In a major catch, the Venjarammoodu police have seized huge quantities of ganja stashed in an uninhabited house at Kottakkunnu near Nellanad.

The ganja weighed 10kg in total and was stored in three briefcases in one of the rooms of the two-bedroom house, which is in a dilapidated state.

According to the police, the ganja was seized around 4pm on Friday following a raid conducted under the leadership of Venjarammoodu station house officer inspector Aji Chandran Nair. The raid was launched following reliable information received by the inspector. However, the police are yet to find those who stored the ganja in the house.

The police said that the house belonged to one Rajappan Achari. But he lived in another house in the neighbourhood and had given the house for rent. The last tenant of the house vacated one and a half year ago and the house had been lying empty ever since. The house did not have any doors.

Venjarammoodu sub-inspector Bineesh Lal, who was part of the team that conducted the raid, said that the ganja was stored in five packets inside three briefcases. Each packet weighed 2kg each.

“We suspect whoever stashed the ganja here was using the old house as a storage place. They might have been selling it in small quantities,” the SI said. The police suspect that a few youths in the neighbourhood, with a history of ganja peddling, are involved in the incident.

Title: National Science Day celebrated at Wadia, Survey of India
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Dehradun: “Preparedness is the only way to avoid deaths during natural calamities like earthquakes and tsunami,” said earth scientist and seismologist Harsh K Gupta while addressing a gathering at the Wadia Institute of Himalyan Geology in an event to mark the National Science Day on Friday.

“Dehradun will have an estimated lead time of 25 seconds if Chamoli district, which witnessed 6.8 magnitude earthquake in 1999 claiming hundreds of lives, is again shaken by such intense tremors. The effect of such a quake will reach Delhi in about 76 seconds. So, we cannot fly or vanish in this small span of time. Also, we cannot avoid earthquakes nor get early forecast. Hence, the only thing we can do is to learn to live with earthquakes. People should identify safe places near their homes, offices, schools, and market places where they can remain safe during an earthquake,” he added.

Survey of India (SOI) also observed National Science Day by opening its museum for students and public. According to SOI officials, over 1,000 students and city residents visited the museum where subject experts showed them the rare surveying equipment which is in the possession of the body.

UCOST holds brainstorming session on ‘Himalayan Knowledge Network’

A workshop on ‘Himalayan Knowledge Network’ was organised by Uttarakhand State Council for Science and Technology (UCOST) as well as GB Pant National Institute of Himalayan Environment at Vigyan Dham, Dehradun on Friday. A communique from UCOST said that the main deliberations during the workshop were on strengthening regional hub of academicians, scholars and knowledge centres, promoting evidence-based policies and practices, sharing of research findings and good practices across Indian Himalayan regions and Niti Aayog recognition of the uniqueness of the Himalayas.

Title: Delhi government gave sanction under ‘popular pressure’: BJP
Content:
Prakash Javadekar

लोगो के दबाव के कारण आखिर दिल्ली सरकार @AamAadmiParty को #JNU मामले में मुकदमा चलाने की अनुमति देनी पड़ी। 3 साल दि… https://t.co/1llmLZJ9pD — Prakash Javadekar (@PrakashJavdekar) 1582901698000

NEW DELHI: BJP on Friday “welcomed” AAP government’s decision to grant sanction for prosecution of Kanhaiya Kumar and Umar Khalid for allegedly shouting seditious slogans, saying that the Delhi chief minister had yielded to “popular pressure”.“Finally, the Delhi government has to sanction prosecution of Kanhaiya Kumar in JNU case. Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal kept postponing a decision but finally he succumbed to public pressure after three years,” Union minister and senior BJP functionary Prakash Javadekar tweeted soon after the Delhi government sanctioned prosecution of for the former JNUSU president.“Bharat tere Tukde honge Inshallaah inshallah, war will continue until India is destroyed, you kill one Afzal, there will be an Afzal in every household, Afzal we are ashamed your killers are alive ... these slogans were seditious ... now justice will prevail,” Javadekar said.BJP Delhi President Manoj Tiwari also reacted similarly, attributing the decision to the “current political situation”. “Probably keeping current political situation in mind, the chief minister has finally given sanction to prosecute former JNUSU leader Kanhaiya Kumar. We welcome the decision. We had been demanding that the Kejriwal government give approval and let the law take its own course,” he said.BJP had turned the shouting of “tukde tukde” slogans at JNU in 2016 as a major issue, calling it an “anti-national” act.

Title: Gujarat HC issues notices over parents’ plea
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Gujarat high court

AHMEDABAD: The Gujarat high court has issued notices to the Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE), the state government and the Delhi Public School, East over a petition filed by parents of four kids studying in the school.

The parents have challenged the CBSE’s decision of November 30, 2019 to cancel school’s affiliation and the state government’s order passed on December 5, 2019 to cancel its recognition. They have argued that the decision to close the school was taken without giving any opportunity of hearing to the school management as well as parents. This is against the provisions of the Right to Education Act (RTE) and the primary education laws. The government could not have derecognized school without issuing notice and hear the stakeholders for any alleged violation of norms.

The HC has sought reply on this by March 5, said petitioners’ advocate Dhaval Barot.

Another such petition, filed last month by parents of 369 students, is pending in the HC objecting to administration’s decision to close the school on March 31, 2020.

Meanwhile, the DPS has withdrawn its petition filed in the Delhi high court challenging the CBSE’s order to de-affiliate the school over the allegations that it was obtained on a forged NOC.

Title: Prodded by HC, time state acted on PoP idol makers
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Nagpur: The Nagpur bench of Bombay High Court has directed the state government to bring in legislation for banning Plaster of Paris (PoP) idols across the state.

The court was hearing a petition filed by chief officer of Khamgaon Municipal Council Dhondiba Namwad against whom a complaint was lodged for disposing Ganesh idols in the waste dump yard.

Accusing Namwad for hurting religious sentiments of people, the complainant Omprakash Gupta had filed a criminal complaint against him in 2016. Refuting all allegations, Namwad had knocked the doors of judiciary seeking quashing of the first information report (FIR).

While hearing his petition on Thursday, HC asked the government to introduce a legislation for banning PoP idols and imposing heavy fine on its manufacturers. It also asked the government to explore the option of a uniform policy for disposing PoP idols in artificial tanks across the state.

The HC further quashed the FIR and imposed a fine of Rs1 lakh on Gupta for filing bogus complaint and misuse of law.

Environment activists have been demanding a blanket ban on manufacturing, sale and use of PoP idols since many years. Welcoming the court’s directives, they demanded urgent action by the state.

“The ban has come at right time as the process of idol making is yet to start. The government needs to first address the idol makers rather than the sellers. Also, religious sentiments are attached and hence public awareness about ill-effects of PoP idols need to be done on a war footing level,” said Kaustav Chatterjee, founder of NGO Green Vigil Foundation.

Stating that a lot myths are associated with the outer looks of idols, Anu Chhabrani from NGO Swachcha Association said, “The government should start by sensitizing the idol makers as well as citizens. Also, policy should be framed to construct small permanent tanks in all areas, periphery of lakes inside cities and big permanent tanks on the outskirts for the convenience of mandals.”

Stressing that the real challenge is immersion of big idols, Chatterjee said, “Number as well as height of big idols need to be reduced. The policymakers should formulate a law to fix the height of community idols. Administration should identify specific water- pit like abandoned mines for immersion of big idols.”

Chhabrani added that importing of idols in the city should be strictly checked for POP content.

Title: 8,508 houses constructed in district under Life Mission
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: City mayor K Sreekumar said that the state capital has the highest number of houses constructed under Life Mission . As many as 8,508 houses were constructed under the scheme in the district.

Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan will formally announce the completion of construction work at a meeting of beneficiaries from the district at Putharikandam Ground at 3pm on Saturday.

City corporation has constructed houses for 3,672 people under the first phase of Life Mission. In the second phase, 9,161 homeless people were included in the list of beneficiaries of Life Mission and PMAY schemes and houses were constructed for 4,836 people.

An amount of Rs 4 lakh allocated for each house under Life Mission comprises of Rs 1.5 lakh from Central government, Rs 50,000 from state government and Rs 2 lakh from the city corporation. In addition to it, an amount of Rs 24,390 is allotted from Ayyankali Employment Guarantee Scheme.

Mentioning the incident of a family found living at railway puramboke land at Kaithamukku, the mayor said that a vacant flat at Kalladimugham will be allotted to them. Due to poverty, the mother of six children, who was residing at the puramboke land, had to handover four of her children to the Kerala state council for child welfare.

“We have promised the family that they will be provided a safe shelter. A temporary job will be given to the mother. The house will be allotted in a meeting to be held on March 2,” said Sreekumar.

Corporation has identified 18,018 beneficiaries in the third phase of the project. For the work, 50 cents in Karimadom Colony will be utilized. Costford will carry out the works.

“People with political motives are trying to sabotage the project, which is being implemented successfully. Steps to fund the construction of houses at available land at Kalladimugham and Poonkulam are in progress. We have set a target to complete the construction work within six months,” said Sreekumar.

The mayor also spoke about the plan to seek opinion from public regarding the proposal for day-night vending zones in the city. A Facebook post by Sreekumar seeking public opinion received good response from people and the post was widely shared.

“The post received over 500 comments. After codifying the opinions, the proposal will be put for approval at the corporation council meeting. The work for the project is proposed to be started by March itself,” added Sreekumar.

Also, the complaint redressal cell started at the corporation office received 276 complaints in a month. Out of this, 148 complaints were resolved and steps were taken to address the remaining issues. People can send the complaints to complaints.tmc@gmail.com or to WhatsApp number 8590036770.

The punching machines and CCTV cameras installed at corporation office will be formally inaugurated by minister for cooperation Kadakampally Surendran on March 2.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: 9 years on, life term for cop, circle officer gets 5-year jail
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

LUCKNOW: A police constable was on Friday awarded life imprisonment while the then circle officer was sentenced to five years in jail in connection with the murder of a minor girl inside Nighasan police station in Lakhimpur Kheri on June 10, 2011.

The court, however, acquitted two other policemen, Shiv Kumar and Uma Shanker, for want of evidence.

The court had convicted two accused, constable Atiq Ahmad and the then circle officer Inayat Ullah Khan, on February 24 and fixed February 28 as the date for pronouncing the quantum of sentence.

CBI judge Pradeep Singh had found constable Atiq Ahmad guilty under sections 302 (murder) and 201 (disappearance of evidence) and circle officer Inayat Ullah Khan under section 201 of IPC. Atiq was posted as the gunner of the circle officer.

The court also imposed a fine of Rs 1 lakh on the constable and Rs 50,000 on Khan.

On June 10, 2011, girl’s mother had lodged an FIR at Nighasan police station claiming that her daughter had gone to graze the buffalo but did not return.

She said while searching for her daughter, she went inside Nighasan police station and found the girl’s body hanging from a dry tree.

She alleged that injuries on the girl’s body suggested that she had been raped and hanged from the tree to make it appear to be suicide case.

The investigation was initially conducted by CBCID which filed charge sheet against Atiq for rape and murder and accusing Shiv Kumar and Umashanker of destruction of evidence. “Later, CBI took up the probe and filed a charge sheet against Atiq for murder and disappearance of evidence and charging the other three, including the CO, with disappearance of evidence,” CBI public prosecutor Deep Narayan said.

Title: Utttarakhand government defines 'forest' twice, high court rejects it both times
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

NAINITAL: Two months after it stayed the definition of " deemed forests " introduced by the state government in November last year, the Uttarakhand high court (HC) on Friday once again put a stay on the changes made by the administration in February.

As reported by TOI earlier, the HC had on December 10 last year put a stay on the state government’s office order which defined deemed forest as “a patch of land of at least 10 hectares and having at least 60 % canopy cover along with at least 75% native species.”

This, environmentalists said, was "an arbitrary definition". They alleged that it was unclear how the government arrived at the figure of 10 hectare and 75% native species in categorising an area as forest land. They pointed out that in 2017, the Forest Survey of India had defined forest as one hectare or more land with 10% canopy cover. However, this definition was also questioned in the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change that sought to know how this conclusion was reached.

“The dictionary meaning of the word forest ( any large area with trees and undergrowth) is being tampered with simply to make profit out of forest land," environmentalist Reenu Paul had told TOI when the definition was first announced.

Even as the HC was hearing three petitions challenging the original government order — the move had been opposed by several environmentalists who alleged that the decision was meant to primarily benefit the land and mining mafia in taking over forest land — the state government this month further tweaked the definition. As per the revised definition, deemed forest was now “a patch of land of at least five hectares and having 40 % canopy cover.”

Ajay Singh Rawat, a Nainital-based former professor of Kumaun University, who has petitioned against the state government in the matter, told TOI on Friday, “We welcome the HC directive. The new definition was primarily intended to duck the high court stay order, and to make the pending petitions in the case infructuous.”

Rajeev Bisht, the lawyer representing Rawat, added that the bench of Justice Sudhanshu Dhulia and Justice Narayan Singh Dhanik heard the case for three consecutive days before deciding to stay the new government order. “We argued before the court that the new definition was in complete violation of a Supreme Court order and is also against the Forest Conservation Act. However, the government through their counsels and forest officials said that the new definition was justified and that it benefits the forests. After hearing the arguments of both sides, the court decided to stay the revised definition as well,” Bisht said.

Rawat said, “If one went by the revised definition of the state government, around 9,000 square kilometer of forest land will not be considered so in the state. It is therefore clear that the aim of passing such orders is to …benefit the builder mafia.”

Madan Kaushik, urban development minister and spokesperson for the government, told TOI, “We will study the HC order in detail and further course of action will be decided accordingly.”

Title: Delhi: Shaheen Bagh women grieve for the riot-hit
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

The chatter centred on the lives lost and grieving families

NEW DELHI: A sharpened need for their own security, a shared grief with “families who lost their sons” in the northeast Delhi violence and some disappointment that the case was deferred to March 23 marked the first reactions at Shaheen Bagh after Supreme Court said it did not find the climate conducive to proceed on the road-closure case.

“Supreme Court took the decision recognising the circumstances. It had already recognised our right to protest. In the current situation, if only SC had also seen it fit to say something about our own protection,” said Ritu Kaushik on the 75th day of the women’s protest on Thursday.

The report from SC on Wednesday had brought the women to their feet. After a cathartic spell of Delhi Police hai hai and Amit Shah hai hai, the men and women collapsed back into position, grieving the “riots and attacks” in northeast Delhi where some have family and friends.

“How many mothers must see sons killed for politicians to gain?” asked Fatima. From the stage, Amna Faheem tried to calm frayed tempers: “This fight is not of religion and it will not be allowed to become one despite all efforts. People of all faiths are here and we grieve for all who are shaheed in the violence.” Notably, the elder men were also out, taking to the stage to share animal parables that talk peace and humanity. “All youth have to be guided.”

Fear in their heart, steel in their eyes and message of peace on their lips, Shaheen Bagh spent Wednesday afternoon in dua, a tentful of people in quiet prayer.

The chatter centred on the lives lost and grieving families. “The instigators, the ones behind it, will all have to answer god — call him allah, call him bhagwan.”

Talking of the massive 2019 victory for Modi-led BJP, Bushaira Parveen said: “Vote dene ka sazaa hai ye? (Is this what we get for voting them?”

The violence came as a body blow. “This is what they will do? They keep talking population. So, kill some, nullify documents of some, chase people out by destroying their homes and documents and those who are left, keep them under their thumb,” said a woman, who had returned from visiting the affected families in Jafrabad. “They should know the public is against riots. That is a fact.”

Kehkeshan Riyaz said: “One Kapil Mishra wreaked havoc. Imagine how many Kapil Mishras would have been born had the Ayodhya verdict been in our favour.”

After every outburst, they returned to talk of their protest and the necessity to secure the “sanctuary of peace”. “What has happened is that their misrule and kala kanoon has brought Hindus and Muslims closer. That they cannot tolerate,” said Bushaira.

“The plan was to fatigue us out. Let this linger, the women will get tired. The idea is to crush the andolan. We held together through very difficult days, we shall continue,” said Zia Bano. They are wary for their own security. “Should we not be given adequate security?” Shaheen Kauser said, “Police in places is playing a role in worsening the social fabric,” but refused to paint all police with the same brush. “Yahan ki police seem more responsible,” is the general sentiment.

“We have no expectation from any government now,” said one, while Kauser added, “Our only hope lies with Supreme Court.” On AAP government, Riyaz said, “In our situation, we cannot trust political parties. But we plan to call Amanatullah Khan, our MLA, here and ask him if (CM) Kejriwal will pass a resolution against CAA and announce there will be no NPR.” Kauser said, “We will not accept the new format.”

Title: After 2 yrs, waste removal begins at old trenching site
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Dehradun: The Dehradun Municipal Corporation (DMC) has started the exercise to clean the Sahastradhara Road dumping site and ensure bio-treatment of the waste that had piled up in the area for over two years when the site was closed.

Recently, mayor Sunil Uniyal Gama had announced that a “Shaheed Smarak” will be built at the site.

Ved Prakash, assistant engineer, DMC who is co-ordinating the cleaning drive at the ground, told TOI onFriday, “The removal of legacy waste is in full swing. We have divided teams for segregating plastic waste with other trash for recycling purposes. We are also leveling the land and making it ready for the construction of Shaheed Smarak.”

Though the removal of garbage has brought some relief to area residents, absence of a proper garbage disposal system and lack of basic amenities like water supply still remain major challenges. Residents allege that though the site hasn’t been used as a trenching ground for two years, people from nearby localities often dump their domestic waste there.

Badal Sajwan, a resident of the locality, told TOI, “I have seen private vehicles coming late in the night to dump trash bags here. On occasions, we have intercepted such people but the practice hasn't stopped.”

Availability of clean drinking water is another major issue, residents add, complaining that they still have to depend on 1.5-inch-long water pipes for supply despite the locality comprising of around 30 houses and multi-storey buildings. “The population of the ward has increased significantly over the years but we still do not get adequate water supply for our households. Even after several complaints to Jal Sansthan and visits by officials, no concrete step was taken,” said Sundar Singh Tomar, another resident of the area. Manjula Tomar, president of the Vedant Puram Residents’ Welfare Association told TOI, “The closure of the dumping ground has given us respite from the constant stench and has paved the way for better property deals here. However, DMC has not yet provided us with the door-to-door garbage collection facility. The residents of the area still have to hire private vehicles for garbage disposal.”

Kamlesh Bhardwaj, who owns a shop in the area, added, “I settled here around a year ago. Since then, the land rates here have shot up from Rs 18,000 to Rs 25,000 per square yard.Many of us are hopeful that once the site is landscaped and a memorial to martyrs comes up on the site, it will give a further boost to the property market here.”

Title: Air quality in Ahmedabad deteriorates to ‘very poor’
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Your morning doesn’t feel fresh? The smog leaving you gloomy and vulnerable to bronchitis and allergies? It isn’t just the onset of spring causing health disturbances, but the city’s deteriorating air quality too. According to the Safar Air Quality monitoring stations, air quality in Ahmedabad ranged from poor to very poor with AQI ( Air Quality Index ) readings from 282 to 345 across the city. Overall, the AQI was 302 for Ahmedabad, which is ‘very poor’.Track the pollution level in your cityAir quality at Pirana was the worst with an AQI reading of 345, which is considered ‘very poor’, whereas the lowest AQI value was in Satellite, at 282, which is ‘poor’.Dr Manoj Singh, consulting chest and critical care specialist, said there are two health issues arising from poor air quality. “If a person is healthy, he/she can have very bad viral infection due to the simultaneous hot and cold weather in the city. If a person is suffering from asthma or lung disease, suspended particles can enter the respiratory tract and can work as irritants, causing acute lung disease or asthma attack,” said Dr Singh.Experts from the India Meteorological Department (IMD) said that this season, there have been colder days and hotter nights than normal. On Thursday, the city saw a change in weather due to the western disturbance.Doctors confirmed that the deteriorating air quality had led to an increase in cases of upper respiratory tract infections. Experts have called for initiating surveillance and regular monitoring of cases of respiratory illness. “The state health department and civic authorities must begin monitoring cases of bronchitis, asthma and other respiratory diseases, map them with the changing air quality and identify the threshold levels for public health. This data can come handy in deciding how and when alerts should be issued,” said Prof Dileep Mavalankar, director, IIPH, Gandhinagar.On measures taken, Dr Chirag Shah, in-charge of air quality in the AMC, said, “Various initiatives are being undertaken. The AMC has bought electric buses to reduce its carbon footprint, and the roads and buildings department has begun wall-to-wall carpeting to eliminate dust.”

Title: Water shortage: Fed up residents gherao officials
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Kerala water authority’s (KWA) decision to divert more water to Technopark has resulted in resentment in other parts of the city. This, along with its attempt to stock water for Attukal Pongala in the Iranimuttam tank, has resulted in water shortage in several parts of the city. Residents in Peroorkada protested by gheraoing the office of KWA assistant engineer on Friday.

Residents of AKG Nagar, Darshan Nagar and Krishna Nagar in Kudapanakkunnu gheraoed assistant engineer and assistant executive engineer of Peroorkada division after they failed to receive water continuously for several days.

“For the past two months, residents in these areas are deprived of drinking water. Most of them are senior citizens, who find it difficult to fetch water from tankers. These areas have never experienced water shortage in the past years. I am 63 years old. Never in my lifetime I witnessed such a shortage. When enquired, we learned that the water was diverted to Pongumoodu through valve control. If they wanted to divert water, it has to be done without bias,” said Hariharan P, president of Darshan Nagar residents’ association.

The residents withdrew the protest only after they received water following a meeting with KWA executive engineer in the presence of police.

Senior officials of KWA said that water was indeed diverted for Technopark as it was experiencing shortage for the past ten days.

“Technopark is located in the tail end of the areas coming under the Peroorkada tank. For the past 10 days, they have been experiencing shortage. We had to divert water to this area, which created shortage in other areas in Peroorkada,” KWA officials said.

Residential areas such as Sastamangalam, Vellayambalam and Nathancode etc. in the city, which are already facing water crisis, had to make calls for tankers again on Friday after the KWA division (South) started stocking water for Pongala in the Iranimuttam tank. KWA has to stock additional water in the tank to meet the requirements for the pongala on March 9 when lakhs of devotees will reach the city.

Due to the additional requirement, water could not be released from the PTP Nagar tank to affectied areas such as Sastamangalam and Kowdiar.

KWA officials said that considering the shortage experienced in several areas, a campaign would be launched soon to curb wastage of water. “Treated water is used for various purposes, including washing cars and watering plants, while people in other areas are not getting water to meet basic needs. We will launch a campaign after Attukal Pongala to make city residents aware of the situation,” said KWA officials.

Title: Ensure security at northeast Delhi board exam centres: Delhi high court
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

A school was burnt in northeast Delhi during communal riots (File photo)

NEW DELHI: Delhi high court on Friday ordered the AAP government and police to make full-proof security arrangement at board exam centres in northeast Delhi , which has been rocked by violence.

Justice Rajiv Shakdher issued the direction while hearing a plea of a school seeking change in its centre, which is located in the area.

The court issued notices to the government and Delhi Police and sought their stand on the petition by March 4. It noted that the government and police “should ensure the (exam) centres are sanitised and there is no breach of security”, adding that the situation in northeast Delhi appears to be “improving.”

During the hearing, CBSE told the court that it has already postponed the exams for classes X and XII scheduled for Friday and Saturday at 86 centres in northeast Delhi. However, it was hopeful to conduct the papers from March 2. The board added that it has no plan to shift the centres to other locations.

Advocate Kamal Gupta, appearing for the school, informed the court that there was no police presence at the centres in northeast Delhi and highlighted news reports that schools and buses had been burnt down in the area. The court on Wednesday took note of the “worsening situation” in the area and directed CBSE to come up with a plan to reschedule the board exams or change the affected centres.

The private school, Bhai Parmanand Vidya Mandir at Surya Niketan in east Delhi, has said in its plea that the centre allotted to them was 16km away from their school and situated in Chandu Nagar-Karawal Nagar road, one of the violence-hit areas. The petitioners, including some students, have said it would be difficult for them to reach the centre due to the clashes. They have urged the court to direct CBSE to change the centre.

Title: Yavatmal first in state to conduct online crime review meeting
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Aurangabad: In a first, Yavatmal district police have successfully conducted an online crime review meeting, thus saving precious man-hours and money spent on travelling of police officers for the meeting.

According to senior police officers, this project has been set up without spending a single rupee of the state exchequer.

“As setting up and running of this unit does not require any approval for spending money, the scope of red-tapism in implementation of the project has automatically been wiped away,” M Raj Kumar, Yavatmal superintendent of police , said to TOI.

The project is the brainchild of Noorul Hasan, an officer of 2015 IPS batch, currently serving as additional superintendent of police (Yavatmal district). Additional SP Noorul told TOI, “We have used the existing resources. All we had to do was get a license from NIC Delhi, followed by NIC Yavatmal for using the secured line and open interface.” It requires a software from NIC Delhi, locally available internet and an android device, he added. Police can also review pendency of cases, law and order situation as well as progress in any given case during such meetings.

In the recently concluded crime review meeting, the district superintendent of police was connected with an additional superintendent of police, six sub divisional police officers and officers heading each of the 31 police stations in the district. This crime review was attended by all the investigation officers till the rank of constabulary.

The officer said that it is mandatory for all the sub divisional police officers, police station in-charge, local crime branch and special branch heads to attend the crime review meeting. “For the crime review meeting, the officers end up leaving their respective jurisdictions to reach the police headquarters. If any untoward incident takes place on the meeting day or any law and order situation arisis in their jurisdiction, the police’s response time becomes poor. Use of this application, which can be used through the cellphone, laptop as well as desktop has addressed several such odd problems,” said Noorul, who along with his officers has implemented the project after successfully carrying out six months’ testing.

Title: Delhi: Uneasy calm on first Friday after riots
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

The protest tent served as the prayer venue

NEW DELHI: At the mosques, roads and even in rubble-riddled compounds in Jafrabad-Maujpur, Friday prayers passed off peacefully. In other areas in northeast Delhi , where 42 people were killed in communal clashes, the Jumma prayers similarly went off without incident. Bhagirathi Vihar in Mustafabad, however, remained on edge when the locals were prevented from praying at the mosque there.

While Section 144 of CrPC had been lifted for 10 hours to allow assembly of people, police used drones to monitor the situation in the sensitive areas. “The drones have a range of one kilometre and we can be forewarned of any suspicious gathering,” a police officer said.

On the main Jafrabad road, hundreds gathered at the Faizan-e-Madina Masjid located adjacent to the anti-citizenship laws protest site. The protest tent served as the prayer venue. Mohammad Faizan, a resident of Welcome Colony, said that whenever situations like these arose, the community gathered for Jumma namaz here to support each other.

In Maujpur, Muslims offered prayers on the rooftop of the Brijpuri masjid, which was burnt down by rioters on Tuesday, the Indian flag fluttering by their side. In Chand Bagh, the worst affected locality, hundreds turned up at the Moonga Nagar Jama Masjid around 1pm, while police filtered the crowd to permit only those going to the mosque to proceed. “There were many more Muslims living in the area,” noted Farhan. “But after what happened, they were scared and have vacated the area.”

At the Ashok Nagar Badi Masjid — the alleged attacks on it had gone viral on social media — there was no namaz on Friday. Instead of the faithful, there was a heavy presence of paramilitary forces and non-Muslim residents. Asked by TOI reporters about prayers at the mosque on normal days, a resident said that “over 300 people gather here for prayers, and they always block the road”.

When asked why none had reached the mosque on Friday, an angry local bristled, “How can they come? We will not let them come here.” He also heckled the TOI reporter and photojournalist.

Normalcy in social relations will take time it seems, with people not being allowed to go to the local mosques in some places here. Mahmood Hassan, a retired AIIMS official, claimed that the lane on which he lived near Meena Masjid had witnessed intense clashes on Monday. “Our neighbours are not allowing us to enter the mosque because they feel outsiders will also gain entry to the locality.”

Rajeev Dixit, another resident on the lane, maintained, “There are only 5-7 Muslim households here. So where is the need to go to a specific place for worship in this tense scenario? There are many places where they offer prayers.”

(With inputs from Pankhuri Yadav and Mohammad Ibrar)

Title: Will consider plea to declare state highway as NH: Nitin Gadkari
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Nitin Gadkari

PUDUCHERRY: Union road transport and highways, micro, small and medium enterprises minister Nitin Gadkari said the ministry will consider the Puducherry government’s request to declare stretches of state highway as national highway in the Union territory.

He was here on Friday to review the national highways projects in the Union territory. Later speaking to reporters, he termed the outcome of the meeting ‘positive’ and assured that the ministry will clear all the issues raised by chief minister V Narayanasamy. He said one of the issues – declaring stretches of state highway into national highway may take some time’.

“First of all, let me complete my commitment and in future, we will think about it (declaring state highways into national highways,” he said.

He revealed that the ministry has changed the alignment of the ring road after the objections raised by the ashram and people. “We have made a new study and based on that we have selected a new alignment and today we finalized it (new alignment),” he said.

On the proposed elevated roads within the town limits, Gadkari assured that the ministry will complete the project with essential components like underpass and adequate lighting arrangements before transferring it to the Puducherry government.

Narayanasamy said he urged the minister to expedite four road projects connecting Mahabalipuram and Puducherry, Villupuram with Nagapattinam , Murungapakkam with Sivaji statue junction on the east coast road and Madagadipet with the Puducherry town. Gadkari earlier visited National institute of technology (NIT) at Karaikal and awarded degrees to the successful students at the 6th convocation ceremony. Speaking on the occasion, he urged the students to imbibe entrepreneurial skills and undertake research to come out with innovate ideas, projects and solutions catering to the needs of their local communities and regions.

“Education, knowledge and technology are important but what is most important is entrepreneurship skills. We have financial management institutions offering masters in business administration and human resources. But we don’t have an institute for development of management of entrepreneurship and enterprises,” he said. He pointed out that when sugar mills in Maharashtra started incurring huge losses, he mooted the idea of extracting ethanol from sugarcane. He said ethanol has a wide range of uses including manufacturing plastic materials that will degrade within 72hours. “You have to undertake research on the strength and weakness of your region and analyse the raw materials available,” he said.

Title: Traffic law enforcement drive from tomorrow
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The accident involving a speeding car at Kowdiar on Wednesday night has prompted the city police commissioner to intensify traffic law enforcement in the city. The decision has been taken after it has been confirmed that the accident was a case of rash and negligent driving.

City police commissioner Balramkumar Upadhyay said that the police will start a special law enforcement drive from March 1 onwards.

The focus will be on young motorists and two-wheeler riders, including pillion riders, who are not wearing helmets.

“It is a fact that death rate has come down ever since helmet was made compulsory for pillion riders. But we have noticed that majority of pillion riders are still reluctant to wear helmet,” the commissioner said.

In the previous year, the city police had booked as many as 22,567 two-wheeler riders for riding without helmet. The goal of the police is to drastically bring down this figure.

In January, the police had booked over 500 motorists for helmetless riding as part of a special drive conducted in connection with Road Safety Awareness Week.

The special drive of the city police will coincide with an awareness campaign being launched by the state police department, in association with a private firm, to encourage use of helmets. The campaign will be inaugurated here on Monday.

The second priority under of the special drive will be checking rash and negligent driving among the youths. It was a 21-year-old youth who was driving the car that crashed into the electric pole on the median on Kowdiar–Vellayambalam stretch on Wednesday night. The police are yet to verify whether he had a driving licence or not. He is still under treatment.

As per the latest available data on road accidents released by national crime records bureau, which is of the year 2018, there were a total of 14,247 cases of accidents owing to rash and negligent driving reported in the state. This is the highest in the country. As many as 1,515 people had died in those accidents.

Title: At Jama Masjid and Jamia Millia Islamia Central Mosque: Prayers for peace, amity
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Hundreds offered prayers for the people killed in the rioting

NEW DELHI: Congregational prayer in the aftermath of riots can be an uneasy affair. But Friday felt like most other days of prayers at old Delhi’s Jama Masjid and its neighbourhood. At the Jamia Millia Islamia Central Mosque , however, the proceedings were tinged with sadness at the loss of lives in the communal frenzy in northeast Delhi .

At the historic Jama Masjid, people came in decent numbers for the Jummah prayers amid strong police security. Farooq Ahmed of Kaumi Ekta Sangathan Trust stood outside the mosque with a placard requesting citizens to maintain communal harmony. “Our trust organised peace marches outside various mosques today. I have already visited two places,” Ahmed said.

Arshad Ali Fehmi, who lives near the masjid, said everyone desired peace and amity and were contributing in their way to maintain calm. Another man, who requested not to be named, added, “Those indulging in violence are misguided by miscreants who don’t want peace or social unity.” Many people at Jama Masjid, however, avoided talking much about the anti-citizenship law protests.

At Jamia Millia Islamia in south Delhi, hundreds offered prayers for the people killed in the rioting, with some breaking down in the middle of the prayers. Khalid Faruqi, 75, a Jamia Nagar resident, was aggrieved at the lack of official action to prevent the violence. “Ask Modi, Ask Amit Shah. They could have stopped the violence in five minutes. It has to end now,” he said. “Humanity is dying, not Hindu or Muslim. Lives, homes and livelihoods, regardless of religion, have been lost.”

Before prayers, the imam pleaded on the loudspeaker for peace and asked people to assist the riot victims. “We should help in every way possible. Try and adopt the orphans. This is our Hindustan. Let us not spread the various rumours going around. We have to keep the peace,” he said. He sobbed at one point while addressing the congregation.

While the prayers finished without incident, some Jamia students sat on an impromptu protest afterwards, raising anti-government slogans targeting both central and Delhi leaders. Mohammad Shabeeb, a 24-year-old international relations student from Kerala, said, “I am not politically active, but today I am standing against what happened in northeast Delhi. Against police, aggressive Hindutva, against brutality.”

On the main road, local residents collected food supplies and money for the families affected by the violence. “We are giving everyone, irrespective of their religion, ration, water and first aid,” a volunteer said.

Title: Delhi high court notice to government, police on pleas over hate speeches
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Delhi high court (File photo)

NEW DELHI: Delhi high court on Friday sought the response of the Centre , Delhi government and police on a batch of plea demanding registration of FIRs against several politicians, including Congress’ Sonia and Rahul Gandhi , and AIMIM’s Akbaruddin Owaisi , for allegedly making hate speeches .

One of the plea by a lawyers’ group has named the Gandhis as well as Delhi’s deputy chief minister Manish Sisodia, MLA Amanatullah Khan, and AIMIM’s Owaisi and Waris Pathan. A bench of Chief Justice D N Patel and Justice C Hari Shankar issued the notice on the Lawyers Voice’s petition, which wants setting up of a special investigation team (SIT) to look into the alleged hate speeches.

The court also acted on three separate applications — by one Sanjjiiv Kkumaar, Hindu Sena’s Vishnu Gupta and Bhim Army chief Chandrashekhar Azad — who have sought to intervene in a petition moved early this week for lodging FIRs against BJP’s Anurag Thakur, Parvesh Verma and Kapil Mishra for alleged hate speeches.

Kkumaar has sought an FIR against activist Harsh Mander, who has demanded an FIR against the BJP leaders. Kkumaar has also sought FIRs against Khan, Bollywood actor Swara Bhasker and RJ Sayema for alleged hate speeches. Gupta has sought prosecution of Pathan, Asaduddin and Akbaruddin Owaisi. Azad argued that an FIR against Mishra must be registered immediately, alleging his speeches were “responsible for inciting” the violence in northeast Delhi. All matters will be heard along with Mander’s PIL on April 13.

Title: Telangana CM K Chandrasekhar Rao approves power tariff hike, likely from April 1
Content:
Telangana CM K Chandrasekhar Rao

HYDERABAD: Come April, Consumers may have to pay higher electricity bill as chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao is believed to have given go-ahead to power distribution companies for increasing the tariff.The tariff hike would be extended to all categories of consumers, including domestic, commercial and industrial. The revised tariff is likely to come into effect from April 1.The tariff hike is likely to be between 8% and 10% for domestic consumers who fall in the category of over 100 units-1,000 units consumption per month. The tariff revision is expected to be higher for commercial and industrial categories of consumers.The discoms are planning to mop up an additional Rs 1,500 crore per annum through the increased tariff rates, sources said.A decision to this effect was taken at a review meeting held by the CM at Pragathi Bhavan with officials from the energy department, discoms, TSTransco and TSGenco on Friday.The southern and northern power distribution companies are likely to submit tariff hike proposals along with aggregate revenue requirement (ARR) to the Telangana State Electricity Regulatory Commission (TSERC) on Saturday.Though a hike in the tariff is being allowed after four years to overcome over Rs 15,000 crore loss incurred by discoms, KCR, it is learnt, has asked the them to not burden the domestic consumers consuming up to 100 units per month.Officials told KCR that while the southern discom was incurring a loss of 39 paise on every unit of power being supplied to the citizens, the northern discom was incurring 17 paise loss on every unit of power being supplied.Both northern and southern discoms owe arrears to the tune of Rs 13,700 crore.The chief minister has assured the distribution companies that the government would allocate Rs 10,000 crore towards power subsidy in the upcoming budget for 2020-21 to reduce the losses incurred by them.

Title: Fill potholes within 10 days or face police action: HC
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Aurangabad: The Aurangabad bench of Bombay high court on Friday directed the civic body, Maharashtra State Road Development Corporation (MSRDC) and the public works department (PWD) to fill potholes within 10 days after a complaint has been filed.

The bench, comprising Justices Z A Haq and S M Gavhane, said: “If the grievance of the citizen/citizens is not addressed within 10 days, the police department shall start an investigation and if the police find that a crime needs to be registered, the same shall be done within 3 days of starting the investigation.’’

The bench added that “on receipt of any complaint by email or on social media, the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) official shall redress the grievance within 10 days from the receipt of the complaint. On receipt of the complaint directly by the police department, the same shall be forwarded immediately to the municipal corporation.”

A lawyer, Rupesh Jaiswal, had filed a PIL in September 2013 seeking directions to the civic body and other agencies to fill potholes and properly maintain the roads in Aurangabad.

“The matter came up before the bench on Friday and the next hearing has been posted for March 3,” Jaiswal said.

A Nagpur-bench — headed by justices Z A Haq — in a suo motu petition had passed similar order on October 16, 2019 to the Nagpur Municipal Corporation.

The respondents in Aurangabad’s PIL admitted that they were aware of the Nagpur bench orders and subsequently, on Friday, the AMC deputy commissioner (revenue) Sumant More, executive engineer of the PWD Sundardas Bhagat and MSRDC’s Vikram Jadhav filed separate affidavits stating that they would comply with the high court order.

They also agreed that if residents wish to lodge complaints regarding potholes with their departments in their respective jurisdictions, they could do so by lodging their grievances on the helpline number, WhatsApp number and other social media platforms. They also said these numbers would be given wide publicity.

Assistant commissioner of police (traffic branch), Dineshkumar Kolhe also filed an affidavit stating that the police department will provide the email ID of Aurangabad police by giving wide publication in local newspapers, appealing citizens to lodge immediate complaints regarding potholes which may become reason for vehicular accidents or hurdle for smooth road traffic.

“The police department will also share WhatsApp number and twitter handle so that the complaints can be lodged by citizens,” he said.

Title: ‘No sedition slap on CAA protesters, no review of Jafar case’
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

UP deputy chief minister Dinesh Sharma

LUCKNOW: For the first time, UP government has said in writing that none of the protestors, arrested for violence which rocked the state during anti-CAA protests in December last year, has been booked for sedition.

Speaking in the Vidhan Parishad on Friday, deputy chief minister Dinesh Sharma said 126 people, arrested for violence, had been charged with damage to public property and under various sections of the Indian Penal Code (IPC).

Samajwadi Party MLC Shatrudra Prakash, in response to whose query the details of cases were shared, said his purpose of asking the question was to make the government admit that none of the arrested persons had been charged under sedition.

“I am glad that the government has finally accepted this. You have been accusing all the protesters of being anti-national but it is clear from your response that they have only been arrested for damage to property and for protest against the Citizenship Amendment Act,” he said.

Prakash added it was the constitutional right of citizens to hold protests.

He also sought to know whether, as per directions issued by the Supreme Court, notices were issued to arrested persons like activists Sadaf Jafar, SR Darapuri and Deepak Kabir, as punishment for sections slapped against them was maximum of seven years.

“Now, that the government has accepted that these people are not anti-national, did it bother serving them notices at all? Has investigation into their cases ended,” he asked.

Responding to a question by SP MLC Shashank Singh who claimed there seemed to be no proof of Jafar, Darapuri and Kabir being involved in violence, the deputy CM said cases against them would not be reviewed as it were already in court and government would not interfere in police investigation.

Title: FDCA mandates use-by dates on sweet packs
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: In a notification on Friday, Gujarat Food and Drug Control Administration ( FDCA ) announced that producers of sweets must carry the production date and best-before date on packaging. The move is aimed at sweets made of milk and milk products.

FDCA commissioner H G Koshia said that they often find that the quality of packaged sweets is not up to standard and can lead to health hazards. “The best before date will be decided based on local factors such as temperature, type of sweet and production method,” he said.

Those failing to comply can be booked under the Food Safety & Standards Act, 2006, FDCA officials said. Those selling unpackaged sweets will have to display the manufacturing and best-before dates on the tray, they added.

Title: Rural power supply up 52% in 3 years: Minister
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Shrikant Sharma

LUCKNOW: By increasing an effective power supply from just 200 million units to 305 million units in the rural areas every year, the state government has not only boosted prosperity, but also succeeded in checking migration from the villages to the cities, claimed energy minister Shrikant Sharma in assembly on Friday.

Replying to a series of questions related to his department in the assembly, he said: “In the previous SP-BSP governments, darkness triggered migration from villages to cities for studies and livelihood. We have enhanced rural power supply by 52% in the past three years."

“In 2015-16, rural areas used to get 201.59 million units which has now increased to 305.84 million units. “The increase has helped the state government to provide 18 hours of power supply to the rural areas,” he said. He also said that the cumulative financial losses of the UP Power Corporation has risen from Rs 77.47 crore in 2000-01 to Rs 82,212.40 crore at present. Sharma revealed it while replying to a question raised by Congress MLA and its state chief Ajay Kumar Lallu, who sought to know what steps the state government had taken to bridge the massive losses which have incurred to the power utility over a period of 20 years.

The minister said that his claims for rural prosperity were not only limited to increasing power supply in the villages, farmers have benefitted a lot as in the previous governments ,the average connections for tube wells were around 18,000 a year which had now risen to 45,000 a year and this has assisted farmers in increasing their farm production.

He also submitted a 16-point schemes aimed to recover the losses. It included setting up of 59 police stations in different district to register crimes related to power theft. He said that the energy department had also put in place 55 enforcement squad to check incidents of power theft. Sharma said the department had come up with an encouragement scheme for the raid squad and associated team. He also mentioned execution of' `Mukhbir Yojana’ (whistle blower scheme) under which people could inform the government about the incident of power theft without revealing their names.

Title: Former professor booked for making obscene remarks
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

PUDUCHERRY: The CB-CID police have booked a retired Pondicherry University professor for posting obscene remarks on a social media site about the chairwoman of the district-level complaints committee (DLCC) probing sexual harassment at workplace.

DLCC chairwoman Vidyaa Ramkumar noticed the obscene remarks on Facebook and lodged a complaint with the cybercrime cell of the CB-CID.

The agency booked Pondicherry University retired Tamil professor S Arokianathan under Section 509 (word, gesture or act intended to insult the modesty of a woman) of the Indian Penal Code and Section 67 (punishment for publishing or transmitting obscene material in electronic form) of the Information Technology Act.

In her complaint, Vidyaa said she was shocked to find derogatory remarks about her posted by the retired professor on Facebook. She said the contents of the post outraged the modesty of a woman. The remarks are sexually coloured, she said urging the CB-CID to initiate appropriate action against him.

Title: Maharashtra: No notices yet to sugar mills for failing to pay FRP in 15 days
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Around 33 lakh tonne of sugar cane has been crushed in the last three months

KOLHAPUR: The state government has failed to take action against most of the private and cooperative sugar factories which have failed to pay farmers as per the fair remunerative price (FRP) for the current crushing season within the stipulated time.

Of the 140 sugar factories in the state, 71 mills have made payments as per the FRP. As many as 69 factories have arrears to the tune of Rs 853 crore.

According to the data released by the office of the sugar commissioner, it has not served notice to a single sugar factory for failing to pay farmers as per FRP for the current crushing season, which began in last week of November, 2019.

The government’s current stand assumes significance as it had served notices to almost 100 private and cooperative sugar factories during the last crushing season. Notices were served for violating the Sugarcane Control Act, under which it is mandatory for sugar mills to pay farmers as per FRP within 15 days after cane is taken for crushing.

Sources in the sugar sector said that the government was going slow on making payments to the farmers in view of the financial crisis before factories because of water scarcity and flood in parts of Maharashtra .

Sugar commissioner Saurabh Rao told TOI that the government would serve notices to sugar factories if they did not make payment as per FRP. “Most of the factories are in the process of making payment as per FRP. We will act if we get any complaint,” he said. As per data, sugar factories in Maharashtra have total arrears to the tune of Rs 390 crore till date.

Cane production in Maharashtra is likely to be affected by 30 % due to water scarcity in Marathwada region and flood and unseasonal rainfall in western Maharashtra.

In the last crushing season, around 952.6 lakh metric tonne of cane was crushed and sugar production had crossed 1,000 lakh quintal. In the current season, Maharashtra has crushed 33 lakh metric tonne of cane in the past three months. Sources in the sugar sector said that the availability of cane for crushing has come down by 30 % this season, because of which sugar production may also be affected.

Title: Police start checking phones for hate content
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Aurangabad: City police commissioner Chiranjeev Prasad has directed his personnel to carry out surprise checks of mobile phones of citizens in the backdrop of videos about the recent Delhi riots going rife on social media.

Prasad told TOI, “After we found that some anti-social elements are trying to peddle hate by using videos showing the riots, violence and desecration of religious places, we ordered our personnel to carry out surprise checks of mobile phones of people they find suspect.”

“We have told our personnel to register offences against such people found sharing or spreading such messages and videos,”he said.

Prasad, however, said that he has cautioned his personnel to check only social media accounts and group messages on mobile phones.

Over the past two days, the police have issued notices to two people after some hate content was found in their mobile phones.

Deputy commissioner of police (zone-II) Rahul Khade, along with a few police sub-inspectors (PSIs), carried out checks in his jurisdiction over the past two days.

A PSI who was part of Khade’s team said, “We are not even concerned about adult content in a mobile phone. We are just checking if any message or video about communal hatred has been shared by the person or has been received in any group he is part of, such as on WhatsApp.”

Civil society members are divided on Prasad’s diktat, with some in support of the police action and others citing rulings of the Supreme Court.

Social activist Faisal Qureshi said, “Social media is more misused than used. The spread of communal hatred as well as false propaganda is done through elements who want to divide the country. We welcome and support the police’s move.”

However, human rights activists, while maintaining that the objective may be good and in the interest of the overall law and order, said the diktat also has to be legal.

Human rights activist and lawyer Asim Sarode said, “First of all, it is the duty of commoners to delete any such hate content or video they receive over social media. At the same time, when the Supreme Court in 2017 had decided that right to privacy is a fundamental right, it would be inappropriate for the police to check someone’s mobile phone without prima facie reason as well as substantial ground.”

Retired police officer and assistant commissioner of police Khushalchand Baheti said civilians have a right to know the identity of the policemen before they hand over their mobile phones to them.

Moreover, social media content shared in groups should be checked in the presence of mobile phone owner.

Title: Two families plan to move in, bring Gulbarg Society back to life
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Firozkhan Pathan (L), Firoz Bandeli Shaikh (R)

Gulbarg Society, which has been desolate since that fateful day of massacre on February 28, 2002, may see some life again as at least two families are preparing to return and start afresh.

Eighteen years ago, during the post-Godhra riots, 69 residents of Gulbarg Society in Meghaninagar were killed. Those who survived were displaced.

Firozkhan Pathan, 45, said he plans to renovate his bungalow and move in within six months. “My Gulbarg Society house covers 220 square yards. I cannot afford to buy a house of that size anywhere else. I have police protection anyway,” said Pathan, who currently stays at a rented house in Juhapura.

Firozkhan lost 10 of his family in the massacre. Among those who were killed were his mother, grandmother, brother, sister-in-law, nephew, nieces and aunt. He was also the complainant against human rights activist Teesta Setalvad , accusing her of misappropriating funds collected in the name of Gulbarg Society victims.

Firoz Bandeli Shaikh, who lived with his family in the Gulbarg Society flats , says he will move into his old house if the others do. “As so many people died there, most are reluctant to return,” said Firoz, who has a music band and currently lives in Juhapura.

The uninhabited Gulbarg Society wears a haunted look with soot still visible on walls of the burnt houses. Weeds and thorny shrubs have covered most part of its premises. The only person who can be seen in the society every day is Qasam Mansuri, who is also the owner of a house. Qasam runs a mattress-making business and can be seen making matresses with a helper from 10 am to 6 pm. If all these people move in, the society will see life after 18 years.
