Title: Ghaziabad: Man strangles wife and two kids, hangs himself
Content:
Dheeraj Tyagi worked at a welding shop in Sahibabad

Kajal

GHAZIABAD: A 29-year-old man allegedly strangled his wife, four-year-old daughter and two-year-old son with his hands before tying a noose with his wife’s dupatta and using it to hang himself.The bodies were discovered on Friday morning at their first-floor apartment at Sanjay Nagar in Arthala, Sahibabad. The man, Dheeraj Tyagi (29), was from Bijnor and worked at a welding shop in Sahibabad. He lived in the single-room apartment with his wife, Kajal (27), and their two children — Ekta and Dhruv. Ekta had just started out as a nursery student at a school in the locality.“Main Dheeraj Kajal se bahut pyaar karta tha, par Kajal ladkon se phone par baat karti thi (I, Dheeraj, loved Kajal a lot, but she would speak to men on the phone),” went the purported suicide note, scribbled with a black marker on a pink wall, right next to photos of Kajal and Ekta. To the left of the note was a heart pierced by an arrow and the letters ‘D’ and ‘K’, and four numbers of the “men Kajal would speak to”. A nearly empty bottle of rum lay toppled on the floor. “It’s possible that he got drunk, killed his family and then himself,” a police officer said.Every morning around 9, Dheeraj and a friend, Bheem, would go to work together. “When Bheem got here on Friday morning and called him outside the house, there was no response. He called Dheeraj on the phone and got no response again. He went upstairs and knocked. When there was no response again, he managed to prise open a window and get in,” said Kaushalya, the landlady. “He found Dheeraj hanging and the bodies of the others on the bed.”Bheem scrambled downstairs, told Kaushalya and they informed police. “They had to break the door open to gain entry … Just yesterday night, I had seen Dheeraj return from work with dinner he had bought for the family,” Kaushalya said. She didn’t hear anything on Thursday. And the single-room apartment right next to Dheeraj’s is occupied by a single man, who was away at the time.And there may have been other problems. Their son, Dhruv, had been sick since birth and undergoing treatment at a Delhi hospital. “Dheeraj had been facing a financial crunch. Dhruv’s treatment was expensive and Dheeraj had borrowed money for that but not been able to repay his creditors … In September last year, Dheeraj had bought a 50 sqm plot in Ghaziabad , registered in Kajal’s name. He had been planning to sell that off to pay for their son’s treatment,” he added.Dheeraj seems to have suspected Kajal’s brothers were trying to get hold of that plot, a family member said. “Is saari kahaani ki wajah Kajal ke bhai hain (At the root of all this are Kajal’s brothers),” a postscript to his ‘note’, scribbled in pencil, said.A neighbour said she had never witnessed any sign of trouble in the household.Police are waiting for the autopsy reports before deciding on the next line of investigation. “The reports will disclose the exact cause of death but it does look like Dheeraj strangled his wife and children with his hands. We will look into everything Dheeraj wrote in his suicide note,” said Ghaziabad SSP Kalanidhi Naithani.

Title: SC: Can Uttarakhand hydel projects be shifted to non-eco fragile zones?
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

NEW DELHI: The Supreme Court on Friday suggested exploring the feasibility of shifting hydro-electric power projects on Bhagirathi and Alaknanda rivers in Uttarakhand to non-eco fragile zones to facilitate resumption of the projects which have been stalled for the last seven years.

“It should be considered for all projects across the country and not only for Uttarakhand. Pure commercial consideration cannot be the sole criterion. We agree there is need for power. But protecting environment and lives of people are more important. Power projects can be relocated. They need not be in ecologically fragile areas,” a bench of Chief Justice S A Bobde and Justices B R Gavai and Surya Kant said.

“Our anxiety, in addition to environment, is to protect the lives of people. For project proponents, it is profit. We are suggesting the government to relocate as we have larger interests to guard. Thermal power plants should be stopped. Have you been to Chandrapur (where a super thermal power plant is located)? You cannot breathe in that city,” CJI Bobde said.

But the suggestion of relocation did not go down well with senior advocate Mukul Rohatgi, who was appearing for GMR Badrinath Hydro Power Generation Pvt Ltd, which is constructing a 300 mw project on Alaknanda river near Badrinath. He said, “We will go away. Seven years after investing huge amount in a project that is stuck because of court orders, relocation would mean constructing the hydro-electric power project from scratch at a new location. What happens to the economy?”

Appearing for a PIL petitioner, advocate Prashant Bhushan said the state was power surplus and did not require more hydro-electric projects. Two committees had concluded that these projects contributed to the unprecedented floods that devastated the state in 2013 and that the SC had directed the ministries of power, water resources and environment to file a consolidated affidavit after taking into account all aspects, he said and complained that no such affidavit had been filed yet.

Rohatgi said one of the committees set up by the government had recommended resumption of work at six hydro-electric projects, including the one being constructed by GMR. But the SC adjourned hearing for four weeks while asking the ministry of environment and forests to file a consolidated affidavit.

After unprecedented floods devastated the hill state in June 2013, the SC on August 14, 2013, ordered fresh environment impact assessment of 24 under-construction hydro-electric projects, which involve an investment of Rs 20,000 crore, on the two rivers to examine whether these projects “contributed to the tragedy”. All projects have been stalled since then as many committees have examined the issue.

The SC had also asked the environment ministry and the state government not to grant environmental or forest clearances to any project till further orders. But it had cleared construction of Srinagar hydro-electric project in Uttarakhand by the Alaknanda Hydro Power Company .

Title: Rules for govt staff on holding posts in sports bodies eased
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

NEW DELHI: Central government employees can now hold an elective office in bodies such as sports associations and federations for a longer period of five years or two terms, whichever is earlier, in their entire career. Prior sanction from the competent authority for contesting election to such bodies would continue to be required.

As per the policy, last updated on August 5, 2019, fixing an upper limit on the number of years for which government servants could occupy an elective office, they could get elected to any body, whether incorporated or not, for two terms of for a period of four years, whichever was earlier. In cases where the government servants have assumed charge of elected posts prior to the issuing of office memorandum dated August 5, 2019, the department of personnel has said they may be allowed to complete the full period of their current tenure, except in cases where there are charges of corruption and adverse audit paras etc.

Title: Govt rebuffs plea on Census caste data
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

File image used for representation.

NEW DELHI: The Centre has rebuffed an attempt to secure an OBC headcount in the population by cold-shouldering a plea to rescue the data of the socio-economic caste census (SECC) that has been lying in disuse for over six years.

It is learnt that the “national commission for sub-categorisation of OBCs” lobbied the Centre to put the SECC data to use. The subject was discussed with the government and the Registrar General of India but there was no positive indication from the government. Since then, the Justice Rohini panel has got another extension but without the assurance that it will be handed the SECC data.

With the government having refused to enumerate the OBCs in the 2021 decennial census starting in April, the reluctance to move on the SECC means blowing an opportunity to collate caste-wise population count. The decennial census only collects the specifics of SCs, STs and religious identity.

On Thursday, the contentious subject got a fresh lease of currency after the Bihar assembly passed a resolution seeking a caste-wise census in 2021. The Maharashtra assembly has already passed a Bihar-like resolution while Biju Janata Dal raised the demand in Lok Sabha this month. Interestingly, then home minister Rajnath Singh in August 2018 announced that 2021 census will enumerate OBCs but the Centre went back on it.

Inserting the caste parameter in the census at this late stage may be difficult and the hope of Mandal advocates may now rest only on the SECC. The SECC, ordered by UPA-2, collected caste details of the households in addition to socio-economic parameters, in what was billed as the first backward caste census since independence. The last caste census, which gave details of OBC headcount too, was done in 1931.

However, Modi government refused to process the caste dimension of the SECC. Owing to the campaign launched by RJD of Lalu Prasad ahead of 2015 Bihar polls, the Centre announced the constitution of an expert panel to analyse the SECC data. But the government never constituted the expert committee.

According to sources, the Rohini panel suggested to the government that caste data will help in better sub-categorising the OBCs, which entails division of Mandal castes into sub-groups and apportioning of 27% reservation quantum among them.

“If there has been such an elaborate exercise, its data should be used. Else, it will go waste. But the problem is that neither Niti Ayog nor social justice ministry nor the home ministry want to take responsibility for classification of castes as received in the survey,” said a senior official.

Title: Small plot key to solving MIDC Hingna transport woes
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Nagpur: Industrialists in MIDC Hingna have demanded handing over of a small patch of land that once had a railway siding to MIDC for easing of traffic congestion on Hingna and Amravati roads. The land, around one km in length and 12-16 metres wide, splits MIDC Hingna into two parts. It belongs to Ordnance Factory Ambajhari (OFAJ).

A delegation of Chamber of Small Industry Associations (COSIA), Vidarbha Chapter, led by Mayank Shukla and Julfesh Shah met divisional commissioner Sanjeev Kumar and joint director of industries Ashok Dharmadhikari and requested to pursue the matter with with Defence Ministry and OFAJ for handing over land to MIDC Hingna.

Shukla told TOI, OFAJ had already handed over 5.5km stretch having the same defence siding to Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) for London Street project. This 1 km stretch within MIDC Hingna is left and is causing serious problems to industries and people.

“Heavy vehicles and people from Wadi side or Hingna side cannot cross over easily. They have to use Hingna road and Amravati road for reaching the other side. or for going towards Outer Ring Road. Three internal roads can be constructed this land become available easing pressure on these roads. Industries can use remaining land for expansion or parking,” he said.

Shah said people using Hingna road and Amravati road will get a huge relief. “Hingna road and Amravati road from MIDC Hingna square to Amravati national highway have become congested due to flow of heavy traffic. Also, Metro Rail corridor on Hingna road has made Hingna road narrow. Large number of students of colleges situated in areas near MIDC Hingna use it daily. Heavy vehicles and huge manpower coming to industries will not need to use Hingna road and Amravati road if abandoned line is handed over to MIDC Hingna,” he said.

Shah added OFAJ will get revenue from land and MIDC Hingna will get some revenue from lease of land to industries. “Otherwise too, OFAJ cannot use this land for any other purpose,” he said.

A railway siding used to link OFAJ with main trunk line near Narendra Nagar via Khamla, Parsodi, Yashoda Nagar until 80s. The line fell into disuse later.

COSIA requested Dharmadhikari to give vacant industrial plots to existing industries for expansion and other usages instead of entertaining new ones. “Urgent need is to establish common effluent treatment plant for ensuring zero discharge of industrial wastewater and sewage water. State transport bus facility for employees, development of parking zones, installation of CCTV cameras at prominent places, 24x7 water supply and collection of garbage on daily basis also needs to be resolved,” memorandum said.

Title: Gadkari close aide Dive on Mafsu’s executive council
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Nagpur: Governor of Maharashtra Bhagat Singh Koshyari, who is also chancellor of all universities in the state, nominated city-based Sudhir Dive as member of executive council of Maharashtra Animal and Fishery Sciences University (Mafsu) on Friday.

Dive is one of the close aides of Union minister Nitin Gadkari. He was officer on special duty (OSD) and public relation officer of Gadkari until recently. During the Lok Sabha elections held last year, BJP had appointed Dive as in-charge of Wardha Lok Sabha constituency.

Dive owns a fairly big gaushala (cowshed) in Dhanoli village of Wardha district and also runs Dive Bandhu Cow Products Pvt Ltd, a company under Late Wamanrao Dive Charitable Trust. He has been nominated as representative of dairy industry as per the provisions in the university laws.

As per Mafsu Act, executive council is one of the four highest authorities of the university and it has power to outline broadly what programmes the university should have in the academic sessions. The council also frames annual financial estimates of the university, establishes and maintains constituent colleges, departments, hostels, research institutes, farms, schools, and also sanctions honorary degrees. It has power to transfer any movable or immovable property on behalf of the university.

With vice-chancellor as its ex officio chairman, the executive council has more than 45 members. Commissioners of agriculture, animal husbandry, fisheries, dairy development, and principal chief conservator of forest, three MLCs, two MLAs nominated by their respective Houses, one representative each nominated by ICAR and ICMR are some of them. Governor-nominated members of this council include one eminent scientist in the field of veterinary and animal science, representatives of dairy, poultry and fisheries industries, and one eminent woman social worker.

Maharashtra’s minister of animal husbandry and dairy development is ex officio pro-chancellor of Mafsu. He can also nominate two progressive livestock breeders or fisheries breeders on this body. Presently, minister Sunil Kedar is pro-chancellor of the university and he is yet to do his nominations. Sources at Mafsu said the chancellor is yet to nominate representatives of poultry and fishery industries.

Dive is known to have introduced latest embryo breeding technique for desi dairy cows in his cowshed. Recently, first calf of Gir breed was born in his gaushala to a desi cow with this technique. Mafsu vice-chancellor Dr Ashish Paturkar said Dive’s experience will be beneficial for the university.

“Dive has been working on breeding and conservation of desi cows for the last several years. He has done some projects in collaboration with Mafsu scientists in the past too,” said Paturkar.

Dive was not available for his comments, but a senior office-bearer of his cow product company said his focus will be on making desi cattle rearing a profitable business.

Title: Chronicler of Karnataka’s cultural and linguistic heritage Sha Settar no more
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Sha Settar (first from right) with lexicographer Venkatasubbaiah and playwright Girish Karnad at a ceremony he... Read More

Dharwad: Shadakshar Settar, popular among his readers as Sha Settar , 85, a man of wide-ranging interests and encylopaedic knowledge on disciplines ranging from history and archaeology to spirituality breathed his last at a Bengaluru hospital on Friday morning. An itinerant academic , Settar’s passion took him far from the place of his birth – a tiny village called Hamapasagar in Ballari district – setting him traipsing across the globe.

His years as a student, when he travelled from Ballari to Mysuru, then Dharwad before setting for Cambridge University in England, anticipated his life as a roving scholar. He returned to India, to Dharwad, more specifically, where he served as a professor of history in Karnatak University.

From treatises on Halegannada (Ancient Kannada) to a work on Hoysala sculptures preserved in a museum in Denmark, his scholarly corpus encompassed and oftentimes, integrated many disparate disciplines.

Keenly interested in Jain rituals, Settar’s study on ‘Sallekhana’, a practice among monks to fast unto death bagged him the prestigious Kundukunda award. Settar worked at the National Museum Institute of History of Art, Conservation and Museology in 1978, and was associated with the Indian Council for Historical Research in 1996, besides which he served as a visiting professor at the National Institute of Advanced Studies in Bengaluru.

Dubbing Settar an unparalleled scholar, historian HS Gopal Rao told TOI, “It is a massive loss. Settar’s contributions were not confined to one branch of history. His research ranged from art history to linguistics, and philosophy to archaeology. In fact, the first volume on a subject he was occupied with is now ready for publishing.”

A longtime resident of Dharwad, Settar owned a sprawling mansion in the city called ‘Malamaddi’. Although he sold his opulent mansion, and left for Bengaluru, his love for Dharwad remained undiminished. Never did he miss an opportunity to visit Dharwad, even making an appearance and participating in the Kannada Sahitya Sammelana that was hosted in the city. His impressions on the city he cherished, Settar chronicled in the column ‘Why I Love Dharwad’ that was published in TOI.

- (With inputs from Chethan Kumar in Bengaluru)

Title: When I won, I wanted to hug everyone on stage: Adline
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Mangaluru: Adline Castelino, who was last week crowned LIVA Miss Diva Universe 2020 had a glorious homecoming on Friday. Hailing from Udyavara in Udupi district, she will now go on to represent Incredible India at the Miss Universe.

“This journey is not only mine. To represent India at Miss Universe is not just the dream of a girl, I am going to represent the hopes and dreams of an entire nation. When I do that I need your support and love. It is everyone’s dream and when we are all united, we can definitely achieve it,” she told reporters.

On winning the LIVA Miss Diva Universe 2020 crown, she said, “From the past two years I have been envisioning the finale and wearing the crown. When it happened, I wanted to hug everyone on stage. I could not believe that my dream had come true,” she gushed.

Daughter of Alphonsus and Meera Castelino working in Kuwait, Adline graduated in business management from Wilson College in Mumbai. Hailing from the coastal belt, she is keen on being involved in agriculture and support farmers. She is associated with Vikas Sahayog Pratishthan and believes that bringing together NGOs with like-minded visionaries who wish to help farmers will increase their revenue and help in a sustainable livelihood.

Adline is keen on empowering women and their leadership qualities by conducting leadership programmes as well as spreading more awareness about the acceptance of the LGBTQ community.

A badminton player during her school and college days, Adline loves sports. Deepa Mallik, the first Indian woman to win a medal at the Para Olympics, is her inspiration. She embodies the belief that “What the mind can conceive, a person can achieve.” Dancing, reading and cycling are hobbies and prawns is her favourite seafood.

QUOTE

I got into modelling because I wanted to be Miss Universe. When I was in class VII, a classmate came up to me and said you are my Miss Universe. I gradually found out about Miss Universe and was in love with what happens on stage. When I came to Mumbai, my roommate encouraged me

Adline | Miss Universe

Title: Karnataka: Lingayat math in Bagalkot anoints Kuruba woman as pontiff
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Neelamma Taayi

BAGALKOT: A Lingayat mutt in Jamakhandi on Friday anointed a 47-year-old woman as its pontiff — the first time it has named a woman and a member of a backward community as its head. The move comes days after another Lingayat mutt in Gadag named a Muslim disciple as its pontiff.

Neelamma Taayi of the Kuruba (shepherd) community was ceremonially anointed at Basava Kendra Mahant Mutt in Mareguddi-Budni PM village in the presence of more than 15,000 devotees and 20 Lingayat seers. Having taken deeksha at the age of 15, she has been teaching at the mutt’s primary school since 2010.

Former minister and MLC Basavaraj Horatti, who attended the ceremony, said while women have been heading mutts of the Jagadguru tradition, this is the first time a mutt of the Virakta (renouncement) school has chosen a woman pontiff. “Gender equality has been spoken of since the 12th century but implementation is rare,” he said. The virakta tradition calls for seers to live within society but renounce all emotions and attachments, and dedicate themselves to public service.

The mutt is involved in social and cultural activities, including weekly discourses on Basava’s teachings. It draws about 1 lakh followers.

Guru Mahant Swamiji of Chittaragi Sansthan Mutt in Ilkal, who administered the ‘Shatsthala Upadesha’ to Neelamma, called it a revolutionary step. “A woman from the Kuruba community heading a Lingayat mutt is a dream of the Sharanas of the 12th century. Lingayats upheld gender equality even 900 years ago but sadly, society continues to discriminate against them,” he said.

Neelamma Taayi will now be known as Vijaya Mahantamma Taayi. “The late mahant swamiji of Ilkal took me under his wing for 35 years and inculcated lessons of equality and reform. He was instrumental in the appointment of Dalits as pontiffs in the 90s. We have fulfilled another ideal of his by appointing Neelamma Taayi,” said outgoing pontiff Gurumahant Mahaswamiji.

Title: Donate blood, get biryani free in Mangaluru
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Abdulla Musba

MANGALURU: A restaurateur’s offer of free biryani for those donating blood has a lot of takers, especially youngsters. Abdulla Musba , who runs ‘Ootada Mane’, a restaurant on Light House Hill Road, floated the idea five years ago after realising how difficult it was to get blood for the needy.

“I came across a person from north Karnataka who was attending to his ailing father at a hospital in Mangaluru,” Musba said, adding: “He had a hard time arranging blood. I knew some students and I asked them to donate, and they obliged happily. The next day, I gave them a biryani treat for volunteering. I continued the initiative at our restaurant to encourage others to donate blood and save lives.” Musba’s restaurant is known for its authentic Bhatkali biryani.

In February every year, Abdulla organises a special campaign at his hotel to spread awareness on blood donation. “Valentine’s Day is celebrated in February, and I believe true love can best be displayed by donating blood,” he said. The initiative is being carried out in association with KMC Blood Bank.

The response has grown over the years. Abdulla said he serves free biryani to around 40 people every year. But it’s not an indication of the popularity of the campaign.

“The aim is not to make people eat biryani or patronise my hotel, but to encourage them to donate blood and save lives. Some donate blood and inform us about the same on call. But they don’t turn up for their plate of complimentary biryani,” Musba said.

He said people who donate blood at KMC Blood Bank receive a coupon which can be redeemed for biryani at the restaurant.

Title: Karnataka: Great Indian gaur slips into open well in Belagavi, dies
Content:
The great Indian gaur was pulled out of an open well with the help of a crane in Belagavi

BELAGAVI: In an unfortunate incident, a great Indian gaur died after slipping into an open well in a place called Hanchinala near Hattaragi in Belagavi district. The animal reportedly tumbled into the well late on Thursday evening.Forest department personnel, working in two teams, struggled for more than 12 hours to get the wild animal out of the well. The officials have learnt that the well was owned by a man named Kulkarni.“We started the operation to rescue the gaur on Thursday night, and succeeded in pulling it out of the well on Friday evening,” said a forester.The forester went on to add that the population the Kakati Forest Range had a healthy population of the great Indian gaur, before pointing out that this was the first instance of the wild animal meeting its death owing to a fall. “There have been incidents of the gaur dying in road accidents on national highways. But they do not generally die by falling into wells. They are very sharp, and know the exact location of such spots. There are signs indicating that the animal must have struggled quite a bit before it died,” he added.On the cause of the animal’s death, he said that the gaur drowned. “We had to empty the well of all water before we could pull the animal out. This was carried on through Thursday night and on Friday morning, forest personnel went into the well and extracted the gaur with the help of a crane,” he said.Another official in the forest department said that a postmortem had been conducted, the details of which would be divulged later.In Video: Great Indian gaur dies after tumbling into open well in Karnataka

Title: ICSE helps students manage time better
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Nagpur: ICSE ’s language exam comes with a valuable time management guidelines by the board which is helping students to pace their exams well. Every question in English exams (there are two papers) comes with an advice to students about how much time they should be spending on it.

The most recent example is the English-1 exam where every question came with a clear mention of the suggested time limit. CISCE board, popularly known as ICSE which is the name of its Std X certificate, clearly mentioned, “Do not spend more than 30 minutes on this question” on top of question number one.

This pattern was followed throughout the paper in all five questions. Students were advised in each question about the maximum minutes they should spend on them.

Kenneth Mendonca, principal of Seventh Day Adventist School, said “This has been a trend for quite some time in language papers. No doubt, it is of immense help to students because this gives them a clear idea on time management during the crucial board exam.”

A few state board academicians say this is something which should be implemented by other boards as well. Ashok Gavhankar, a senior academician, said, “In board exams, it is all about time management. Many times children get nervous and are unable to time themselves leading to anxiety when they enter the last 30 minutes.”

Indira Gandhi National Open University (Ignou) does something similar during its exams where it tells candidates the expected length of answers. P Sivaswaroop, regional director of Ignou, said “We give approximate word limit so that students do not spend too much time on a particular question and struggle with the others.”

This also eliminates the problem of students devouring extra answersheets in the misguided belief that writing long answers will get them more marks.

Title: Ahmedabad: ‘Treated waste water turns bacteria drug-resistant’
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: “What does not kill you, makes you stronger,” said renowned German philosopher Friedrich Nietzsche.This ode to resilience ironically applies to micro-organisms which are apparently not even seen by naked eye.A joint study by researchers from India, Sri Lanka and Japan on three wastewater treatment plants ( WWTPs ) in Ahmedabad in India and three places in Sri Lanka revealed that the multidrug-resistant bacteria are more prevalent in the treated water of these plants.“The study included three plants at Jaspur, Chandkheda and Vasna in Ahmedabad. Maximum E.coli prevalence was found at Vasna, which was highest across the six places studied. The study measured bacteria level in the influent, at the discharge point, 20 meters and 50 meters from the point,” said Prof Manish Kumar of IIT Gandhinagar (IIT-Gn), lead author of the study.Polluted water used for irrigationIt is a cause of worry because treated water from Jaspur andChandkheda isusedfor irrigation in 769 hectares collectively, as recorded in 2018. The Vasna plant's water is released into Sabarmati River.Titled ‘Treatment enhances the prevalence of antibiotic-resistant bacteria and antibiotic resistance genes in the wastewater of Sri Lanka and India’, the study was published recently in ‘Environmental Research’ by Elsevier. Other authors include Bhagwana Ram from IIT Gandhinagar (IIT-Gn), Himaya Sewwandi and Tushara Chaminda from University of Ruhuna in Sri Lanka, Sulfikar and Ryo Honda from Kanazawa University, Japan.Prof Kumar added that while the treatment – done by activated sludge process (ASP) – reduces the overall prevalence of faecal bacteria significantly, the bacteria that survives the process are majorly of drug-resistant ability.‘E.coli prevalence was reduced during treatment, but seemingly the remaining bacteria could adapt in the presence of antibiotics that lead to a further increase in resistance... As far as the gravity of the situation is concerned, the resistance to Fluoroquinolone is worse and thus Sri Lankan condition seems better than India’ mentioned the study.The study also mentioned that E. coli strains of all the locations in both countries exhibited multidrug resistance implying a serious health concern in the near future. Strains showed a varying level of resistance for quinolone and non-quinolone groups of the antibiotics.

Title: Pvt schools firm on boycotting RTE admissions
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Nagpur: Many private unaided English medium schools are upping the ante in their clash with the government over unpaid RTE fees by going on a statewide trip to garner support.

Senior office-bearers of Independent English Schools Association (IESA) will be arriving in Nagpur on Saturday and meet local school trustees in a show of strength. The association says that it cannot carry the financial burden of RTE any more and hence, is resorting to a head-on clash with the education department.

Rajendra Dayma, president of IESA, said “All our members from Nagpur and surrounding districts are standing behind strongly our resolution to boycott RTE admissions . For years, the education department has not paid us our dues and yet expects that we implement their guidelines.”

Schools say that with RTE, the financial strain has become unbearable for majority of schools. “The government has fixed the annual reimbursement at less than Rs 20,000. Almost every school nowadays charges around Rs 40,000 per year as fee. So, we are loosing out on revenue drastically from 25% of the seats,” said a school trustee from Nagpur.

“On top of this, the government is either delaying or not giving us any reimbursement even though bills have been submitted,” he said.

Dayma said that it is incidents like these that have been going on for years which IESA is protesting against. “The irony is that the education department refuses/delays reimbursements citing lack of one or the other document. So, we have to prove that the student actually exists, is enrolled and attends school.”

“But these students were selected and sent our way by the education department only. So, if the student is ‘legal’ enough to be admitted, he should be legal enough for us to claim reimbursement,” said Dayma.

On Saturday, the association will hold a detailed discussion with its members and prepare them for the aggressive stand of boycotting admissions.

Title: Parents wary of new divisional level fee authority
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Nagpur: Even though Maharashtra’s school education minister assured speedy setting up of appellate committee for disputes between parents and schools, many are questioning its practical implementation. Parents from six to seven CBSE schools in Nagpur have been trying to organize themselves under a common banner, to give themselves added leverage in disputes with school managements.

Girish Pande, a member of the group calling itself ‘Jagrut Palak Parishad (Aware Parents Council)’, said there are some basic issues which could lead to failure of good initiatives. “As of now, it is clear that there will be no representation of parents in such committees. If stakeholders are not part of such committees, it will never achieve its goal,” said Pande.

He was part of the group that met district collector Ravindra Thakre on Monday over the issue of fee hikes in school, and inaction by the education department. Pande said, “Another problem is that to take the issue before a committee, you require consent of 25% parents, who can approach as a group of affected parties. I think the same rule will continue in the protocol governing appellate councils.”

Even academicians, who are supporting parents’ cause, feel that the new initiative may become a toothless tiger. Sapan Nehrotra, divisional secretary of Shikshak Bharti, said parents’ rights need to be protected at all costs. “Currently, parents are completely at the mercy of school management because they fear for their children. There is always a fear that their children will be ill-treated at school or failed later in Std IX, which can be detrimental to the child’s future,” said Nehrotra, who had accompanied the parents to meet collector Thakre.

He says the best way out will be to amend the Maharashtra Fee Regulation Act itself. “Either scrap it or amend it heavily to ensure that parents are empowered. Otherwise, we are simply doing ornamental work by announcing initiatives which will never be successful at ground level,” said Nehrotra.

Title: Forest officials arrest 5 for illegal fishing and cooking
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Nagpur: A fire was averted at the Ambazari biodiversity park after forest officials apprehended a group of five people who were illegally fishing and cooking food near the water body on Thursday.

Forest officials have been on high alert for such incidents ever since a PIL regarding forest fires came up before the high court.

On Thursday evening, assistant conservator of forests, Surendra Kale, range forest officer AS Ninave, round officers Praveen Badole, S Bhamkar and forest guard Nilesh Tavle were on their regular rounds when they spotted the group indulging in illegal fishing.

The group of five, residents of nearby Pandhrabodi, had also lit a fire to cook food, thus posing a major threat to the surrounding areas. The forest officials booked all five of them under the Forest Act following which the district court granted one day custody.

S Prabhu Nath Shukla, the deputy conservator of forests, said, “The Ambazari biodiversity park is spread over 750 hectares and hence, forest officials are always on high alert because of threats due to fire. Last year, an incident concerning a forest fire was taken up seriously by the court.

There are strict orders from the court to ensure that safety measures are in place to prevent incidents of forest fires. Hence, it is a regular practice by forest officials to go on rounds and inspect the area.”

The entire proceedings by the forest officials were conducted under the guidance of Shukla and Nagpur chief conservator of forests, P Kalyan Kumar.

Title: Congress netas made false promises to refugees 27 times: Amit Shah
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Union minister Amit Shah addresses a rally in support of CAA, in Bhubaneswar (ANI photo)

BHUBANESHWAR: Union home minister Amit Shah on Friday hit out at the opposition parties over their anti-CAA stance at a rally here on Friday. “The entire opposition — Congress , communists, SP, BSP, Mamata Didi (Bengal chief minister) — are opposing CAA . They are saying minorities will lose their rights. Why are you spreading lies,” Shah said.

His remarks on the West Bengal chief minister came hours after he interacted with her at a meeting of the Eastern Zonal Council here.

Reiterating the government’s commitment to provide citizenship to minorities persecuted in Pakistan, Bangladesh and Afghanistan, Shah said: “After Partition, there were forced conversions, forced marriages and rapes were committed. Many (refugees) came to India to save their self-respect. It has been 70 years, but lakhs of such people don’t have citizenship. They don’t have access to healthcare and education. What about their human rights?”

Shah said in the 1950s, every Congress politician had said that Hindu and Sikh refugees from Pakistan will be given Indian citizenship. “The Congress leaders on 27 different occasions made such promises, but never honoured them,” he said, adding, “While introducing Citizenship (Amendment) Act, we knew attempts will be made to malign us. But we are not afraid of such slander campaigns.”

The home minister also touched upon issues like the construction of Ram temple in Ayodhya and nullification of Article 370 in Jammu & Kashmir. “Tell me whether Article 370 should have been abrogated or not? Be louder so that those Congressmen who are opposing it can hear you. Tell me whether a Ram temple should be built in Ayodhya or not? Whenever the issue of the Ram temple came up in the past, Congress tried to delay it in the Supreme Court. With your blessings, the Modi government has returned to power with a massive mandate. Now, a sky-touching Ram temple will be built at the place where Lord Ram was born.”

Title: Transport dept mulls 200km-long elevated corridor for transit system
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The Andhra Pradesh public transport (APPT) department is planning an advanced Rapid Autonomous Connected Bus Transit System (RACBTS) for Visakhapatnam. The project is likely to be funded by the World Bank.

If this happens, Visakhapatnam will be the first city in the country to have such a unique transport system. The government is planning a 200km-long stretch of an elevated corridor for every nook and corner of the city, with a halting point for every 500 meters.

Some of the prime characteristics of this RACBTS are— no property will have to be acquired, no right of way issues, no need of expensive signalling system, no electrical overhead cables, no rails. The system, at least at the planning stage, boasts of a simple design and is deemed to be cost effective.

Apart from public buses, permissions to use this system might also be given to taxies, cargo vehicles and other private vehicles during lean hours.

Significantly, a dedicated software-based system will be a key component of the system which will not require a driver or a conductor.

The proposal for this project was made following the recent policy decision meeting over public transport system organized by the NITI Aayog association with the World Bank in New Delhi.

Representatives of various states including Andhra Pradesh and Maharashtra attended the NITI Aayog meet, wherein stakeholders are believed to have decided to introduce the RACBTS on an experimental basis in Andhra Pradesh and Maharashtra.

A senior APPT official attended the NITI Aayog meet on behalf of the Andhra Pradesh. Following the meeting, APPT also held discussions with experts in public transport system to further discuss the project at the secretariat level.

Confirming the proposal of RACBTS to TOI, an official of APPT said that while the proposal is true, but it will take lot of time to get an official cognisance.

“We are currently holding discussions with stakeholders. We will have to explain this project and the minutes-to-minutes of the NITI Aayog meet to the chief minister. We have proposed this project in Visakhapatnam. If this system is okayed (sic), there will be no need of metro rails which are expensive,” the APPT official said.

Title: City remembers the Raman effect
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Senior students of Sri Prakash Vidyaniketan show their model to younger counterparts during National Science D... Read More

Visakhapatnam: The Naval Science and Technological Laboratory (NSTL)— the premier naval research laboratory under Defence Research & Development Organisation (DRDO) celebrated National Science Day on Friday at the Mohapatra Manasi Auditorium in Visakhapatnam. National Science Day is celebrated on every February 28, since 1987, to commemorate the CV Raman for the discovery of ‘Raman Effect’ on February 28, 1928.

Dr Beela Satyanarayana, former vice-chancellor of Andhra University was the chief guest. Dr OR Nandagopan, NSTL director and Dr Kishore Kumar Katikani, scientist ‘E’ and chairman of NSDC-2020 also attended the celebrations.

Meanwhile, educational institutions of the city also celebrated the 34th National Science Day. At Andhra University, Prof K Hemachandra Reddy of AP state council of higher education flagged-off a rally. While addressing students, he said that students need to have scientific reasoning skills and develop an attitude for innovation.

In course of the celebrations at Geetam Deemed To Be University, Vice-Chancellor Prof K Sivaramakrishna said that scientific knowledge is more essential for wealth creation than any other source for nations today. “It is very difficult to achieve sustainable scientific development without a proper foundation in basic sciences,” the vice-chancellor went on to add.

The day was also celebrated at Sri Prakash Vidyaniketan. Dr S Paul Douglas, HoD of engineering chemistry at AU was the chief guest. Students exhibited their technological creativity through 150 models like wind-based power chargers, anti-theft alarms and automated pens.

Title: Phone thief drags woman out of moving train near Mumbai's Borivli station
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: A 28-year-old woman, who is employed as a visual effects artist, was dragged out of a moving Vapi passenger train when she caught the man who snatched her phone near Borivli station. The accused, Wasim Shaikh, was later arrested. Cops said he is a history-sheeter who had been externed from railway property.

The incident took place on February 20, when the woman (name withheld on request) was returning from Palghar . "I usually commute by local trains, but when the Vapi passenger arrived at 6.50pm, I boarded it as it was getting late. The train was packed, but I managed to get a seat in the general coach," she told TOI. By 8.11pm, the train reached Borivli's platform 10. "The train halted for nearly 10 minutes at the station. I dialled my mother, but as I was not getting network, I moved to a single seat closer to the door." Just then the train started moving. As she was going through photographs on her phone, a man, who was in the coach, snatched her phone. "I grabbed his arm, confident that he could not escape as the train had left the platform. But to my horror, he jumped out of the moving train and dragged me along. I landed on the tracks and hurt my head and shoulders even as he scaled a wall and fled. I screamed for help and a couple from a building near the tracks came to my rescue," she said. They offered her water and cotton to stop the blood flowing from her head, and helped her reach the platform where a policewoman rushed her to hospital. "I couldn't register a complaint at that time, but did after I got better," she said.

Based on the description given by the woman and going through CCTV footages of various stations, the police tracked down Shaikh, who lives on a pavement in Borivli. "Shaikh led our team to Rahul Kahar (20) who had bought the stolen phone. He too was arrested," said senior inspector Bhaskar Pawar, Borivli GRP.

Title: Police hold self-defence camp for girl students
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image

VISAKHAPATNAM: The Andhra Pradesh police organised a self-defence camp for girl students of two city colleges on Friday. The camp was organised in association with Axis Bank. Karate master Lakshmi Samrajyam spearheaded the camp.

The camp was inaugurated by M Rajani, additional deputy commissioner of police. Rajani advised girls to take precautionary measures while walking on the road. A number of students from Government Women Degree College took part in the camp.

Speaking on the occasion, Prem Kajol, ACP of Women Police Station said that the police are trying to raise awareness about the Disha App that was launched three weeks ago. The officer said that police will conduct awareness camps in two to three educational institutions every week.

During the camp, the participants were given tips about how to protect themselves in case they get attacked. Moreover, officials of the Women Police Station distributed pamphlets about the Disha App.

Title: IIM-V gets approval to continue e-governance course
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Following the roll out of the management programme in digital governance and management (PGPDGM) this January, the Indian Institute of Management, Visakhapatnam ( IIM-V ) has now received approval from the Union ministry of electronics and information technology (MeitY) to continue the course for two more batches.

IM-V became the first IIM in the country to launch the specialised management programme under the aegis of the National e-Governance Division, MeitY. The objective of the programme is to create capable managers who can help bolster the Digital India initiative. Applications for the programme, which will commence on September 14, are already out. While MeitY is sponsoring the course fee of 20 candidates in the first batch, the ministry will extend financial assistance to 15 candidates in the second and third batches.

Explaining the mode of course delivery and experiences with the first batch, Prof M Chandrasekhar, director of IIM-V said that the course is structured in a blended learning model using the Learning Management System (LMS) provided by the National e-Governance Division.

“The programme will equip participants with new knowledge and skill sets in digital governance and management that they are expected to be proficient in,” said the IIM-V Director.

In an earlier communique, Ajay Sawhney, secretary MeitY, explained IIM-V’s programme and structure to chief secretaries of states and secretaries of other line departments.

“The programme is considered suitable for executive officers responsible to design and implement the digital governance initiative. You may consider nominating suitable officials, having prerequisite qualifications from your ministry or departments. The prescribed programme for the selected officers will be sponsored by the National e-Governance Division, MeitY,” wrote Sawhney in the letter.

Title: Integrated landscape mgmt project launched
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The innovative landscape management exercise taken up by the civic body as part of Vizag smart city initiative would bring more laurels to the city, VMRDA chairman D Srinivasa Rao said after launching an integrated nutrition project on Friday.

GVMC commissioner G Srijana said Vizag is the first city in the country to take up such an initiative. “The integrated nutrition project will bring in a paradigm shift in landscape management in the industrial and coastal areas of the city,” said Srijana. Representatives of S&T Associates, the agency which would implement the initiative, said the project would offer a practical solution to landscape management challenges.

Meanwhile, GVMC additional commissioner Thameem Ansariya conducted a review meeting on the progress of tax collections for the 2019-20 financial year. She asked zonal commissioners to intensify the tax collection process. With about 70% of the targeted tax realised so far, Ansariya told officials to also focus on collection of long-pending tax dues. While the collectible property tax demand this year is Rs 324.5 crore, the collectible vacant land tax demand is Rs 25 crore.

Title: Don’t preach what you don’t practise, BJP tells Congress
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Ravi Shankar Prasad (L) and Randeep Surjewala (R)

NEW DELHI: A day after Congress delegation called on President Ram Nath Kovind seeking his intervention over the Delhi riots , Union minister Ravi Shankar Prasad on Friday hit out at Congress president Sonia Gandhi and other party leaders saying they should not try to preach “raj dharma” to the government as they themselves have been inciting people with provocative statements.

At a press conference, Prasad said, “Please don’t preach us raj dharma. Your record is full of violations, twists and turns for plain and simple vote-bank politics. Look at yourself in the mirror of raj dharma.” He accused the main opposition party of politicking when time was to make collective bid towards restoring peace and normalcy in the national capital.

Congress functionaries, led by Sonia Gandhi, met Kovind on Thursday and demanded Union home minister Amit Shah 's resignation for “abdication of duty” during the communal violence in northeast Delhi. Gandhi had reminded the Centre for its 'rajdharma' and protecting people of all faiths.

Prasad referred to Sonia Gandhi's “ aar paar ki ladai (fight to the finish)” remark at an anti-CAA rally at Ramlila Maidan here in December and asked the Congress chief to explain if such remarks do not constitute provocation.

He accused Congress of changing its stand on granting citizenship to persecuted minorities from the neighbouring countries. “Manmohan Singh had demanded citizenship rights for people displaced due to religion. Ashok Gehlot had written letters to Shivraj Patil and even Advaniji, both then home ministers, that citizenship should be given to minorities from other countries,” Prasad said questioning the change in stance.

“Sonia ji tell us what kind of 'rajdharma' is this that everyone has backtracked? What we have done your government could not do in 10 years... If Congress does something, it is good. But if we do the same thing, they provoke the people. What type of 'rajdharma' is this?” Prasad asked.

The minister accused Congress general secretary Priyanka Gandhi of making provocative statements saying the opposition party is so frustrated by its defeat that it could stoop to any level for “vote-bank” politics. “Congress should act responsibly for maintaining peace and harmony in the country,” he said.

He said the Citizenship Amendment Act was implemented through constitutional means. “CAA was passed in both the Houses after extensive deliberations. “You had also supported it in the past ... Why did you provoke people (against the CAA)?” he said.

He also lashed out at Congress for its opposition over the NPR exercise recalling as how the opposition party itself had once initiated the exercise. “Congress brought a notification for NPR on March 15, 2010. Chidambaram was the Home Minister, Manmohan Singh was the Prime Minister and Sonia Gandhi was the UPA chairperson. You started this exercise... When you do something it is fine, but you provoke people when we try to do the same thing,” he said.

Asked about the controversial remarks made by BJP members like Kapil Mishra and Parvesh Verma , Prasad cited statements of Shah that the party doesn't approve such statements.

About concerns expressed by BJP allies, including Shiromani Akali Dal and LJP, over the violence in Delhi, the minister said if they have any doubts, it would be addressed.

Title: Legal troubles: Pachipenta-Araku road works to get further delayed
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Pachipenta-Araku road works, which have been going on for over ten years, may take longer than expected to be completed even as the R&B department locks horns with the contractor of the works.

Sources in the R&B department said the contractor’s contract had been scrapped because of the delay, after which he approached court. We are now in the process of attempting an out-of-court settlement.

The project was first mooted two decades ago, but work began in earnest only after 2010. “As of now, 24 km of the 42-km stretch has been completed. We were faced with two problems: One, we needed the forest department’s permission to construct the road; two, the contractor was delaying the project by years,” said, S V Ganga Raju, DEE, S Kota.

“There has been a two-year delay and the only silver lining, so far, is that the forest department has granted permission for us to go ahead with road construction along an 11-km stretch. However, for this to be taken up, we need the contractor to get on with work,” Ganga Raju said.

Officials involved in the project said the inordinate delay in the construction was mainly due to legal squabbles and that if they were resolved, the project could be completed in no time.

Title: Protest in city opposing CAA
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Visakhapatnam: A section of Muslim women from Visakhapatnam, organised under the banner of ‘ Vizag Shaheen Bagh JAC’ staged a protest against CAA , NRC and NPR on Friday. The demonstration took place at the Gandhi statue near the GVMC office.

The protestors, mostly comprising Muslim women, were supported by Progressive Organisation for Women (POW).

The protestors demanded that the government repeal the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA). he protestors further said that the state government should pass a resolution against CAA like some other states. tnn

Title: Tobacco Board trims crop size for Karnataka, decision on AP later
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Tobacco board chairman Y Raghunatha Babu at the meeting

Guntur: The Tobacco Board has reduced the crop size for Karnataka for the upcoming season at its board meeting held on Friday.

The crop size was brought down to 99 million kg from 100 mkg last year. Board chairman Yadlapati Raghunatha Babu presided over the session held in Bengaluru. Raghunatha Babu said the board discussed the issue of Karnataka crop size at length as it was the main agenda of the meeting.

”After taking the requests of the growers and grower representatives, indents given by manufacturers and exporters through Indian Tobacco Association(ITA), we have decided to fix the size at 99 million kgs for 2020-21 crop season in Karnataka,” Raghunatha Babu said.

He said that they studied the past export and domestic performance, global supply and demand position before taking the call. He said that ensuring fair and remunerative prices to the growers was at the top of their agenda to fix the crop size at 99 million kgs.

The board had put the Karnataka’s crop, which is considered to be a premium variety, at 100 million kgs in the last two years.

The board had fixed AP’s crop size at 136 million kgs in the last two years and is likely to go with the same size for 2020-21 season. The crop size for AP would be decided around June as the cultivation season would commence around September-October.

K Sunitha, executive director, N Ashok Kumar, director of export promotion in Union commerce ministry, BY Srinivas, agriculture director, Karnataka, board members Shafi Ur Rehman, Yarlagadda Ankamma Chowdary, Kodavati Vasudeva Rao, Gundala Konda Reddy, director tobacco board (auctions) TV Ravi and board secretary Addanki Sridhar Babu also attended the meeting.

Title: Mumbai: CBI books GST officer for disproportionate assets
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

The CBI has alleged that two flats at Sweet Home building in JVPD are in the name of his older son, Ashutosh.

MUMBAI: The CBI has registered a case against assistant commissioner, CGST, Deepak Pandit, for possessing assets disproportionate to his known sources of income. Three of Pandit's family members have been booked too.

Searches were conducted at six premises in Mumbai belonging to Pandit on Thursday.

Pandit, who is the brother of filmmaker Ashoke Pandit, had allegedly bought six flats in residential societies at JVPD, Juhu, and Thakur Village, Kandivli East, besides two shops. He had also made investments in gold. The CBI examined the assets he had amassed between 2000 and 2014 when he was posted in Mumbai.

Two flats in Oberoi Gardens, Thakur Village, are in the name of his younger son, Divyansh. He had also purchased a flat and a shop in Divyansh's name in Vasant Sagar Complex in the same area. CBI also found investment in gold worth Rs 95 lakh.

The CBI has alleged that two flats at Sweet Home building in JVPD are in the name of his older son, Ashutosh. Pandit's wife Arushi had purchased some immovable properties in her name, which she subsequently sold. Pandit had a flat in Juhu gifted by his mother, which is not counted among these assets.

Pandit paid Rs 1.49 crore to purchase the six flats and two shops at JVPD and Thakur Village. He had also made other investments and had fixed deposits worth Rs 2.9 crore. Pandit had invested a total Rs 4.4 crore which was far more than his savings from salary, CBI said. The FIR stated Pandit earned a salary of Rs 1.05 crore during the period and saved Rs 43 lakh after deducting household expenses of Rs 62 lakh. His wife and their two sons have no source of income and they had purchased these properties on behalf of Deepak Pandit.

The CBI estimated the value of the properties based on their purchase price between 2000 and 2014. For instance, Pandit had paid the builder a total Rs10.3 lakh in 2000 for the two flats in Thakur Village, though their present market value is over Rs 6 crore.

Last year, Pandit courted controversy after he submitted a report accusing three three Indian Revenue Service officials posted at Customs of indulging in corrupt practices. Pandit was then transferred to Bhubaneshwar. He challenged the transfer, but lost the legal battle in Supreme Court.

Title: Seers and BJP put Ayodhya’s culture on display in Delhi
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Faizabad BJP MP Lallu Singh, the organiser of the event, said this was an effort to showcase the local produce... Read More

NEW DELHI: Ayodhya Parv , a three-day celebration to showcase the cultural heritage of Ayodhya, the birthplace of Lord Ram, started in Delhi on Friday. This is the first such event organised by the BJP and Ayodhya seers after the Supreme Court’s judgment on Ram Janmabhoomi in November last year.

As Ram Dhun (chants of the Lord’s name) played in the background at the Indira Gandhi National Culture of Arts (IGNCA) grounds in the national capital, visitors thronged stalls that displayed ‘made in Ayodhya’ wares.

At one kiosk, Jai Prakash and Nand Kishore, visiting Delhi for the first time, were busy serving lentil dumplings, also known as ‘dal fara’, a popular snack in Ayodhya. Nearby were stalls selling Ram prasad (a mixture of peanuts and jaggery), wooden khadau, sandalwood and puja items such as conches. A ‘Sita rasoi’ has also been set up to specially prepare local delicacies. Poetry recitations by locals as well as classical musical performances will take place.

Faizabad BJP MP Lallu Singh, the organiser of the event, said this was an effort to showcase the local produce of Ayodhya. “Whenever Ayodhya is mentioned, only the Ram temple issue is talked about. This event is a message of peace and a display of Ayodhya’s culture . It’s time we do this at an international platform as well. This event will also see current and former Union ministers like Ravi Shankar Prasad, Manoj Sinha, Dharmendra Pradhan in attendance,” Singh told TOI.

RSS joint general secretary Dattatreya Hosbale was present at the event along with newly-appointed Ram Janmabhoomi Kshetra Tirth Trust chief Nritya Gopal Das. Hosbale said, “People like me or Champat Rai of VHP were part of Ran Janmabhoomi movement but even a socialist ideologue like Ram Manohar Lohia celebrated Ramayan mela for several years in Chitrakoot. It’s his template that we are following to celebrate.”

Title: Karnataka News: Village chief kisses dancer at Davanagere temple fair in Karnataka
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

A photograph of the chief of Maganahalli village kissing the woman went viral

DAVANAGERE: A remote village in Davanagere district organised a fair on Friday in which the village head planted a kiss on a woman soon after she enthralled onlookers with a dance recital.

Hundreds of villagers attended Ooramma Devi Jatre (a festival of the village goddess) at Maganahalli in Davanagere taluk, 270km from Bengaluru.

The once-in-a-decade fair is believed to have started around 100 years ago and it’s said to bring good health and prosperity to all those taking part, besides protecting the village from bad times.

“The fair that was to be held in 2018 was postponed because of floods and drought in the village. We decided to hold it this year to appease the village deity,’’ said a 48-year old villager, Parashuram, who has participated in the fairs since 1982.

Fair organisers had invited an eight-member troupe, including two women, from Magala village in Huvinahadagali taluk of Ballari district to perform on the concluding day of the nine-day event.

Just after the dance performance ended, the village head, Rajashekharappa, 52, spontaneously planted a kiss on the woman to express his gratitude and appreciation. The photograph soon went viral. A villager said Rajashekharappa was affectionate towards the dancer, and nothing more should be read into the incident. The fair ended with villagers, including women and children, dancing to folk beats to appease the village goddess.

Title: Couple caught with charas worth Rs 30 lakh in Ahmedabad
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Shenazbanu and Rashidkhan Pathan in police custody

AHMEDABAD: Acting on a tip-off, a city crime branch team apprehended a family of three - husband, wife and 3-year-old girl - with 5.95gm charas worth Rs 29.75 lakh from near the exit gate of Kalupur railway station on Thursday evening. DCP, crime branch, Deepan Bhadran said the accused, Rashidkhan Pathan, 37, and Shenazbanu, 33, of Vatva were caught with the charas wrapped in Hindi newspapers and stuffed in two bags. "He used to take his wife and daughter along when smuggling charas to appear as an ordinary family and escape the suspicions of security personnel," Bhadran said.

ACP crime branch B V Gohil said inspectore D B Barad received information about the charas consignment. "We sent a team in plain clothes to keep a watch around Kalupur railway station. At about 6.10pm we intercepted Rashidkhan, his wife and child on a bike. Rashidkhan had a bag kept on the petrol tank of the bike. His wife was riding pillion with the child, while holding another bag," Gohil said.

When the bags were checked, charas balls weighing 5.95kg were found. "We called the scientific officer to the spot. He confirmed the stuff was charas," said a crime branch official.

Pathan used to bring charas from Rohtak: Crime branch officials said Rashidkhan was once caught in a case regarding fake indian currency notes (FICN). He had met a Kashmiri youth recently.

"He then got into drug trafficking and began selling charas. The Kashimiri used to send the charas from Kashmir to Rohtak and Pathan used to bring it from Rohtak to Ahmedabad.

Changed transport to avoid being caught: From Rohtak, Pathan and his wife used to board different private vehicles, transport vehicles and trains so that it became tough to catch them. Pathan used to park his bike at the railway station. "This time around they had gone to Rohtak by train and came back by bus. They changed buses from Jajjar, Mount Abu and separated at Mehsana and then decided to meet at Ahmedabad railway station where Rashidkhan parked the bike while leaving for Rohtak," said a crime branch official.

Title: Why no FIR against any BJP neta, asks Congress
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Congress spokesperson Abhishek Singhvi (File Photo)

NEW DELHI: Congress Friday asked why FIRs had not been filed against BJP leaders like Kapil Mishra for alleged hate speeches , adding it will give a strong reply in the court over the plea seeking cases against Sonia Gandhi , Rahul Gandhi and Priyanka Gandhi Vadra.

Responding to a query about a court notice on a plea seeking FIRs against Congress leaders , AICC spokesman Abhishek Singhvi said, “We will give a comprehensive reply to the court but let me tell you that the whole world is receiving FIRs but it does not include Kapil Mishra, Anurag Thakur, Pravesh Verma . There has not been an FIR against Giriraj Singh, Chinmayanand, Sangeet Som after months and years.”

“And when the division bench of the Delhi High Court asks questions, a judge is transferred under a remarkable order,” he lashed out.

“I would with the greatest of respect, but in equal firmness, caution the courts that they have to follow their own rules. Their own rules for PILs are to first and foremost see the threshold before proceeding to notice ... to satisfy themselves that a PIL stands for Public Interest Litigation, not Publicity Interest Litigation, Not Paisa Wasool Litigation, not Private Interest Litigation,” Singhvi said, adding, “Notice is not automatic and should never be automatic in PILs.”

Congress also slammed the ruling BJP for questioning Sonia Gandhi’s “raj dharma” barb over Delhi riots, saying leaders like Indira Gandhi and Manmohan Singh believed in harmony while Modi government possesses a “divisive mindset”.

About Union minister Ravi Shankar Prasad’s allegation that Congress instigation over CAA-NPR-NRC triggered violence in Delhi, Singhvi said, “Arrest all of us because we are speaking peacefully in a democratic country against what we believe is a wrong move. I dare anyone to arrest me for saying that NRC is wrong.”

On Friday, Congress constituted a five-member fact-finding committee on Delhi riots. The panel has been asked to visit affected areas and to assess the situation after violence.

Title: Spectrum 2020: NIFT’s annual fest kicks off with a slew of fun activities
Content: Fashion and fun took centrestage as National Institute of Fashion Technology , Hyderabad’s (NIFT) annual fest, ‘Spectrum’ kicked off this week. Preparations for the two-day extravaganza had been on for a while and the excitement in the campus was palpable right from the start of the new semester.And it all culminated in a very eventful first day that saw a performance from noted stand-up comic Abish Mathew .“All the students have been working really hard to put this fest together. It was very heartening to see all our efforts coming together so well. My favourite part was Abish Mathew’s performance. He went a step ahead and did his homework on NIFT, so all his jokes were centered around our life on campus and we laughed our hearts out,” said Saurabh , a third-year student who was also part of the organising committee.Other than the cultural evening and competitions in which students from various city colleges participated, there were also a plethora of stalls selling delectable treats for the students to enjoy.Bringing out their creative side, NIFTians also set up a stall called ‘Calista’ that sold clothes and accessories handmade by them.Even after the tiring first day, the energy was far from dying out as the students looked forward to the activities ahead. “I am waiting for the fashion show. It is the best part of our college fest,” said Aakriti, an excited NIFT student.

Title: Mamata bargains for Bengal at EZC meeting, also raises Delhi violence
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Bhubaneswar/Kolkata: The riots in Delhi and differences among states over CAA-NPR-NRC didn’t overshadow the Eastern Zonal Council (EZC) meeting presided over by Union home minister Amit Shah at Bhubaneswar on Friday. Instead, the EZC meet turned out to be a cornerstone of cooperative federalism where states jointly pressed for their dues from the Centre.

Bengal chief minister Mamata Banerjee made a passing reference to “what has happened in Delhi” and the consequent death toll at the very outset of the meeting. But her focus was primarily on state issues — from GST compensation to non-availability of central funds for relief and rehabilitation of victims of severe natural calamities, namely cyclones Bulbul and Fani. All of these added up to Rs 50,000 crores, Banerjee pointed out.

The Bengal CM also used the EZC platform to point to the delay in release of central funds to states. She held that this was putting pressure on the state’s finances.

“The Centre is an elected government, so are the state governments. No one should veer into the domain of others or try to play Big Brother. I told that the Centre is mopping up huge money from states in the railway sector and others. How much are the states getting?” she said after the meeting.

Banerjee told the media that EZC was not the platform to discuss issues like CAA, NPR and NRC. “It was not the subject also. Yet, I told about it at the very outset of the meeting when my turn came. I said we are deeply disturbed with what has happened in Delhi. So many people died, including an IB officer and a police constable. I said we want the government to stand by the families of the victims,” she added.

Banerjee had ‘raita’ for lunch along with the Union home minister and the chief ministers of Odisha, Bihar and Jharkhand. Odisha CM Naveen Patnaik played the host.

An adept politician, Banerjee could guess that the opposition in Bengal will try to use the “Shah-Mamata” meet to fan public sentiment against her ahead of the Union home minister’s Kolkata visit on Sunday. Banerjee has announced a rally against CAA-NPR-NRC in Kolkata on March 8 to send out the message that she has not given up on the cause.

Congress leader in Lok Sabha Adhir Chowdhury hit the streets in Kolkata on Friday against the “BJP-led violence” in Delhi while the CM was away in Bhubaneswar.

”There was no reason for the Bengal CM to stay put in Bhubaneswar for the last four days. She didn’t attend the opposition meeting in Delhi when Sonia Gandhi sent her an invite. But she found time to attend the meeting presided over by Amit Shah at a time when normalcy is yet to return in Delhi. I call this adjustment politics,” Chowdhury said.

Left legislature party leader Sujan Chakraborty spoke on similar lines. “The chief minister didn’t flag her dissent over CAA-NPR-NRC in the meeting with the Union home minister. She didn’t utter a word against the administrative failure to contain the communal conflagration in Delhi. After all, the Bengal CM and the Union home minister share mutual trust for each other,” Chakrabarty said.

Title: Calcutta HC eases foreign passport rule for Indian citizenship
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Representative image.

KOLKATA: The Calcutta high court has said production of original foreign passport is not mandatory for applying for Indian citizenship if the applicant has stayed in India for seven years and is married to an Indian citizen and has evidence of both.

The order followed a plea by Bismilla Khan, a Pakhtoon, who claimed to have migrated to India in 1973 as a nine-year-old refugee with his father. Khan now stays in Jadavpur , is married to an Indian and has several documents, like Aadhaar and PAN cards, driving licence and electricity bills, to prove he has been in India for nearly half-a-century.

“It cannot be held that under such circumstances... (that) producing a passport and its particulars is mandatory,” Justice Sabyasachi Bhattacharyya said in his order, adding: “There has to be a relaxation... in case the petitioner is able to satisfy the authorities the reasons for non-availability of (the original) passport.”

Khan told the court he was a “refugee in distress” when he came to India; part of the place where he stayed (Wanna village in tribal Waziristan) merged “partially with Afghanistan and partially with Pakistan”.

Khan also provided a “National Identity Card” issued in 1989 by the All-India Pakhtoon Jigra-E-Hind, an organisation working for Pakhtoons in India. Khan was permitted to stay in India on a “long-term basis” in 2002 and then married Hyderabad-based Indian citizen Gulnar Khanam. They now have a daughter, who studies in a reputable Kolkata school.

Persons with all other documents, indicating they had been living in India for a long time, and who were married to Indians would not be able to apply for citizenship “despite having lived their entire lives and contributing to the economy and diverse culture of this country”, Justice Sabyasachi Bhattacharyya said. This, he added, would be contradictory to the spirit of the Indian Constitution.

“His plea for Indian citizenship is under Section 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act (1955), which stipulates a person should be married to an Indian citizen and should have stayed in India for seven years before s/he can apply for Indian citizenship,” Khan’s advocate, Sharmistha Podder, said. “The state’s role ends with scrutiny of the application and forwarding it to the Centre. It was difficult to ascertain whether he was a foreign national because of the absence of the passport. This ambiguity, however, has ended with the order,” state counsel Srijib Chakraborty said.

The HC in July 2018 allowed Khan to file his application afresh and asked the government to decide on his plea in three months. But Khan said the original passport was a mandatory requirement for the online application (Form III); so he could not even file a fresh application. He then moved Calcutta HC a second time.

Justice Bhattacharya said “the requirement of having a passport has to be read as optional” in online applications and, till necessary changes were done in the software, people should be allowed to submit applications manually. But the application, the order said, would have to detail the reasons for non-availability of passport.

Title: Raima Sen: Bhushan Pradhan is Maharashtra’s Most Desirable Man of 2019
Content: You have already met Maharashtra ’s Most Desirable Women, and the votes for Maharashtra’s Most Desirable Men for 2019, from a select bunch of achievers, all under the age of 40, are in as well.After being in the top-20 list consistently, Bhushan Pradhan has taken the coveted top-spot as Maharashtra’s Most Desirable Man this year. Theactor, a popular name among the Marathi audience, says he’s overwhelmed and happy about winning the title. In a quick chat, he shares his feelings and speaks about his journey in the industry. Excerpts:Honestly, I couldn’t believe I had won. It’s an overwhelming feeling. I remember Vaibhav Tatwawaadi and Pooja Sawant calling me desirable in their interviews. At the same time, over the last couple of years, a lot of friends and well-wishers have been telling me the same and that made me confident that I would win the title one day. It feels good to be on top of the list and I am looking forward to my family reading about this in the papers.I think my desirability comes from my humility and kindness. I feel that these qualities are rare to find in people today. Even when someone is rude to me, I reply with humility and I have seen people transform. I have never allowed fame and success take these qualities away from me.That doesn’t concern me at all. I have reached where I have, being what I am. I used to sell pamphlets on Pune’s MG Road to fund my portfolio shoot. From then to today, I believe I have come a long way. I also feel that if you are dedicated and disciplined, success is guaranteed.It helped me hone my craft. I always wanted to be an actor, not a hero. Even today, I keep myself busy with workshops and theatre to brush up my skills. It is a continuous process and theatre is an integral part of it.Reading, watching new shows and learning languages is what I love. I am interested in learning Indian languages. I know a little bit of Tamil, Gujarati, Bengali and Punjabi. There’s so much beauty in our languages. I would also love to act in other language films as much as I can.Yes, my debut Hindi film Anya , with Raima Sen , will release soon. I want to work in more Hindi films, but, at the same time, do something substantial. Besides Anya, there are Marathi projects like Ajinkya , with Prarthana Behere and Pallavi Patil, Lagna-Kallol with Siddharth Jadhav and Mayuri Deshmukh, and a yet-untitled film with Gauri Nalawade. So, this year’s going to be an exciting one and I am happy with what I am doing.(Laughs) I find Hrithik Roshan the most desirable. He has endearing qualities and is a brilliant actor as well. Among the women, I find Sushmita Sen desirable because she has been setting an example for women through her work and life.I have been working out since the last 10 years and was muscular for most part. For a web series, I had to lose five kgs and after that I have been sporting a leaner body. Yes, people ask me why I ditched my muscular look, but I tell them that I am at my fittest form right now. I feel lighter and younger.

Title: HC bars Manirul from Labhpur, stays arrest
Content:
This story is from February 29, 2020

Kolkata: The Calcutta High Court has debarred Trinamool Congress-turned-BJP MLA Manirul Islam from entering Labhpur , his home turf in Birbhum, following bribery complaints from villagers. However, the court refused to issue an arrest warrant against the accused for at least six weeks.

A host of Labhpur residents had complained to police in 2018, saying Manirul had minted money by luring poor villagers with permanent jobs in local schools. He had even entered into a contract in 2016 with two complainants (Kajal Roy and Biswajit Mandal). Police lodged an FIR based on these complaints in 2016.

“We can make out who is the culprit. But it is quite unfortunate that steps are taken only after the accused has changed his political loyalties,” Justice Joymalya Bagchi said.
